id: How does a company like L'Oreal work ? They own many different brands such as Urban Decay and La Roche Posay . Do they compete with themselves for profits ? How does this work ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Same way GM works - they make many products aimed at several target audiences . It may seem like they are competing with themselves , but having several tailored products instead of a single " one size fits all " increases sales .', 'Essentially yes . They can make one product to compete in the market , or make many to try and own the biggest share . They may in some cases cannibalize their business with a new product , but they still get the sale so its not a loss , and with a variety of products they branch out to further consumers .', 'Its called the Illusion of Choice - there are maybe 10 companies that are responsible for everything you buy ( from food to health and beauty products to household cleaning products )']

id: How do members of the clergy get promoted ? What consititutes good performace , which qualifies someone to be considered for promotion ? Or does it not work that way ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Pretty much like any other career . You try to show you can do your job well , especially the parts that are applicable to the next position . You do n't make your boss come in and solve your problems for you , but at the same time you do n't let them get out of control by bringing them in too late . You make it well known you are interested in the next position . You put in your time and pay your dues , and you play a lot of politics . In the case of the clergy , you might start out as a youth pastor at a small church . You run the Sunday school program well , you design interesting youth activities , keep attendance high and get more compliments than complaints , and you get promoted to associate pastor . There you might be in charge of things like adult Sunday school , senior outreach , church maintenance , and you would conduct some services as well . Do well at that , and you become a head pastor and run a whole church . Do well at that , and you might become a bishop or some other kind of regional leader . And so on , until you are pope or grand patriarch or whatever . This assumes you are in a religion with a lot of hierarchy . Many are more grassroots , and there is nothing beyond running a church , and a promotion means leaving to start your own .", "I come from a non\\-denominational background , so I ca n't speak to large denominations , but I 'd say it 's a two\\-parts : 1\\ ) they need to handle tasks and roles \\(teaching , organizing events , offering counseling , administering funds , etc\\ ) assigned to them by the senior pastor and other leadership well , and 2\\ ) they need to have a good rapport with the congregation , as much as their role allows \\(obviously some roles do n't interface as much with people as others\\ ) . Also , in some cases it does n't matter . In strict business terms , if you do n't like how things are run , you can always go start your own . That said , to be affiliated with some organizations , you must serve in their organization first and be ordained , etc .", 'Those denominations that have a central hierarchy and thus have ranks in their clergy members have methods of observing how well they perform . Church attendance , donation rate , conversion rate , amount of charity work done , skill as an orator , etc are all things taken into consideration for advancement . The specifics will vary based on the position being filled and the skill and goals of the specific denomination .']

id: How do websites know when I have AdBlock running ? How do websites know when I have AdBlock running ? Is there a difference in detecting it between ads before YouTube videos and banner ads ect ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['To add onto /u / thinksmooth \'s [ explanation ] ( URL_0 ) , another way they can " detect " if Adblock is running is by hiding an image / some text behind the advertisement . That way , if the ad is removed , the hidden content is displayed . If the ad is n\'t removed , the content is hiding behind the ad , so you ca n\'t see the message anyways .', 'HownAdblock Plus works is it hides the div ( basically a " part " or " container ) of the advertisements . Websites then use javascript to get the height of the div , and if it is 0 ( because it \'s hidden ) then they know you \'re probably blocking the ads . ( This is just one example I \'ve come across , there may be others . )', "Most advertisements are hosted on different websites than the main website . For example , Reddit 's advertisements are hosted on URL_0 . AdBlock stops your browser from connecting to the websites that host the ads . Since ad networks tend not to go down very often , websites assume that if they can access the main website but ca n't access the ad domain , you 're probably running ad block ."]

id: How do we know countries are reporting their emissions accurately in the Paris Agreement ? All countries are responsible for reporting their own emissions . Are any mechanisms in place to make sure they do n't lie about it ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["There is no process for verifying the emissions reporting of signatory nations . This is one of the critiques of the treaty . In fact , a strong case could be made that the treaty itself is largely symbolic as many of the signatory nations would be reducing their emissions whether or not they 'd signed the treaty . It is also worth mentioning that there is no enforcement mechanism for signatory nations who violate their pledges . The entire arrangement is basically an honor system based around policies that most of the important signers were in the process of implementing anyway . Edit : spelling", 'The Paris Agreement contains provisions relating to an " enhanced transparency framework " . It was one of the more contentious elements of the agreement , as the majority of nations wanted and independent body doing the assessment , while some developed nations were against a third - party assessment . The compromise is that each member will provide great transparency on the methodology for assessment they will apply , and the corresponding current input factors . This will be reviewed by a body of experts ( there are quite a few firms specialized in doing carbon audits ) , and it will subsequently be peer reviewed . That \'s an ELI5 . For more info : URL_0', "We do n't . Its not a legally binding thing . Its used by countries as a statement , that they want to work to reduce these problems . Itsan acknowledgement of a problem , and that something must be done about it , and that no one can do it alone . Its one of the many little things that result in international cooperation and trust ."]

id: How do dollar stores even make money ? Do n't the products they buy generally cost more than a dollar to manufacture ? Sorry if it 's worded poorly , I 'm not really sure how to properly explain what I 'm confused about . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["If it costs a dollar , it actually DOESN'T cost more than a dollar to manufacture . You 'd be surprised about how cheap stuff can be bought in bulk and from the manufacturer .", "The ~~crap~~ products that are sold at dollar stores cost pennies to manufacture . The mark up at a dollar store is certainly 200 - 300 % over the dollar store 's cost from the manufacturer , if not 500%+ So , the dollar store sells you something for $ 1 . The dollar store paid between 5 and 50 cents to the manufacturer . The manufacturer made 100 of them for a nickel or something equally ridiculous . edit : formatting", "I know someone who is a buyer for a chain of dollar stores . There are basically three groups of items in dollar stores : 1 . Items that cost less than a dollar wholesale . These are items you might find in other stores for around a dollar as well . Generic branded food items , small trinkets , etc . 2 . Items that have a minor defect that are auctioned off for less than the cost to manufacture . Companies that produce items with a small defect opt to sell for less than the cost to produce rather than trash it . It 's better to recoup some of your money than none at all . 3 . Items that were overproduced . These are items that are in storage because they made more than could be sold . This is a huge source of inventory for dollar stores . The companies do n't want to keep paying storage costs for product that will never sell , so they sell at a loss ."]

id: How do professional and collegiate sports teams determine their playing schedule ? Is there a lot of communication between the teams , or is there some kind of computer program that determines the schedule ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["I 'm not sure about other major league sports , but the NFL 's formula for creating a schedule is [ surprisingly simple ] ( URL_1 ) . EDIT : The MLB is [ way more complicated ] ( URL_2 ) , as is [ the NBA 's ] ( URL_0 ) .", "I can explain college football . At the top of Division 1 ( that I follow ) , there is FBS ( Football Bowl Subdivision ) and below that is FCS ( Football Championship Subdivision ) . In FBS , starting this season , the teams are divided into two sections : P5 , which stands for Power 5 and includes the five major conferences : Southeastern ( SEC ) , Atlantic Coast ( ACC ) , Big Ten ( B1 G ) , Big 12 ( BXII ) and Pacific Coast ( PAC 12 ) . The other conferences are referred to the G5 ( Group of 5 ) . Many of these conferences have 12 or more teams , and are thus divided into two divisions . For example , the B1 G is comprised of the B1 G East ( 7 teams ) and B1 G West ( 7 teams ) . Each team plays the other 6 teams in their division plus 2 teams from the opposite division on a rotating basis ( which will increase to 3 starting in 2016 ) . So that 's 8 ( 9 ) in - conference games . Each college is responsible for scheduling 4 ( 3 ) OOC ( out of conference ) games which are often scheduled up to a decade in advance . If you have the best record in your division , you play the winner of the opposite division in the conference championship game in a neutral field . After that , you either A ) play your bowl game , B ) play in the playoff , assuming you 're selected to do so or C ) stay at home and watch bowl season if you have n't won the minimum 6 games .", "In college football the teams always play the teams on their side of the conference ( if it 's split ) and then they use some of their open slots to rotate the other side of the conference in and they usually have a rotating system for this . As for the bigger non - conference games , these are usually scheduled a couple of years in advance for a home & home or neutral site game . The bigger teams also will pay the smaller teams to come fill up spots on their schedule ."]

Breast milk has a lot of protein , as well as fats , carbohydrates , vitamins and minerals , which you also need to make killer gainz bro . You could argue it \'s the most " well - balanced " diet out there . I \'m slightly disappointed that you , /u / bigbouncytitties , did not know this . The only thing a baby would gain(z ) from drinking protein shakes is the foulest diarrhea ever .', "Mother 's milk has a fairly large amount of protein , and with them being small it takes less to have a noticeable affect .", 'Nature , dude . Milk is made for making babies grow .']

id: How do herbivores like wild horses acquire so much muscle mass just by feeding on grass ? Can a vegan human maintain high muscle mass just by feeding on herbs ? and if no why not ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Horses are naturally herbivores . There is protein in what they eat , although the protein density is low , so they have to eat a lot of it . The digestive tract of an herbivore is different from a human 's , allowing them to process that volume of plant matter quickly and without using much energy , and also getting nutrients from it that human 's ca n't . For a vegan human to have a lot of muscle mass is possible , but more difficult . Mainly , they have to focus on eating high protein plants like nuts and beans .", 'Different species are able to synthesize different nutrients themselves through cellular processes . Nutrients include carbohydrates , fats , proteins ( or their building blocks , amino acids ) , and vitamins . This means instead of the body having to " eat " the protein containing a particular amino acid , the cell itself can make that amnio acid . This of course requires energy and work by the cell . Conversely , " a nutrient is said to be " essential " if it must be obtained from an external source , either because the organism can not synthesize it or produces insufficient quantities " . So there are two kinds of nutrients , those that we can make through our own cellular processes , and those we must obtain through our diet . [ Proteins ] ( URL_2 ) are made up of different [ amnio acids ] ( URL_3 ) . A good analogy is that a protein is like a train , and the individual cars are amnio - acids . Different combinations of railcars , in different orders give different kinds of trains . In the same way , different amnio - acids , in different combinations give different kinds of proteins . Digestion , be it in animals or humans , results in the breakdown proteins into their amnio acid components . The intestine absorbs the individual amnio acids and the body ships these amnio acids to the cells . Cellular processes rearrange the amnio acids in new ways to make new proteins that are used by the animal or human for various bodily functions . So think of the cell as the railyard where new trains ( proteins ) are made but reassembling the cars ( amnio - acids ) into new and different combinations . " Proteins perform a vast array of functions within living organisms , including catalyzing metabolic reactions , replicating DNA , responding to stimuli , and transporting molecules from one location to another . " There are [ nine essential amino acids ] ( URL_1 ) that humans must consume in their diet because our cells can not make them through cellular processes . The rest we can make ourselves in our cells . This means that our diet must meet these minimum essential amnio acids requirements in order for us to survive . We can not make the nine , we must consume the nine . The nine are found in all kinds of foods , from plants to meat which is why humans can have such a wide variety of diets ( e.g. vegetarian , vegan , allergen - accomidating ) and still function normally . However , other animals have different essential nutritional requirements . For example , [ cats , unlike humans , can not synthesize the amino acid taurine so it must be added to their diet ] ( URL_0 ) . Some species are able to synthesize Vitamin C and do not need to consume it in their diet ( e.g. mice ) , whereas humans can not synthesize Vitamin C and thus are required to consume it in our diet . These differences in essential nutrient intake creates different dietary requirements for different species and results in different types of foods being consumed preferentially by different species . This is why a horse is able to survive and thrive just on plant material , whereas we are required to consume a more varied diet . They obtain all their unique essential nutrients from their herbivore diet . So other species have different combinations of essential nutrients in order to sustain a balanced and healthy diet . This makes perfect sense , if all species had the exact same requirements there would be a lot of competition for the same food resources . By diversifying what is essential to consume , there is less competition . Remember that it is costly for the body to produce its own nutrients through cellular processes . It is much easier to just consume an amnio acid than produce it . Thus , if a particular amino acid or nutrient is abundant and easily available in a species environment it makes more sense for natural selection to select against the cell \'s producing that nutrient , and for the individual to simply consume it . For example , most primates - including humans - do not synthesize vitamin C. This makes perfect sense since vitamin C is easily acquired through our collective diets by consuming fruit . Fruit is abundant resource in most primate \'s environments thus vitamin C would not be hard to acquire . So each species is balancing what they need to eat , and what they can produce themselves , along with what is available to them in their environment .', "Herbivores have multiple stomachs with different enzymes that allow them to extract nutrition from fiber . Humans do not . Plus herbivores eat for up to half their lives , chomping on uncooked grasses and such . They did a test where some humans were given a diet equivalent to a gorilla , for a week . They spent ~8 hours chomping on raw vegetables , and by the end they were lethargic and malnourished . The human body simply ca n't sustain itself on raw vegetables . We evolved through cooking an omnivorous diet ."]

id: How does a portfolio of long stocks and short futures generate profits
text: ['I know some derivative markets work like this, so maybe similar with futures.  A futures contract commits two parties to a buy/sell of the underlying securities, but with a futures contract you also create leverage because generally the margin you post on your futures contract is not sufficient to pay for the collateral in the underlying contract. The person buying the future is essentially "borrowing" money while the person selling the future is essentially "lending" money. The future you enter into is generally a short term contract, so a perfectly hedged lender of funds should expect to receive something that approaches the fed funds rate in the US. Today that would be essentially nothing.']

id: How do people die from a broken heart ? What is the condition exactly , or is it solely emotional ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['" Broken Heart syndrome " is often a poetic description of a number of different clinical ailments that can result from emotional stress . You \'re heart does not literally " break " due to physical or emotional trauma . That said , over the course of time your heart can undergo much traumatic damage from emotional sources like PTSD , Clinical Depression , Or Psychological trauma to some degree . These diseases can put stress on your cardiovascular system over time , that can contribute to heart health degradation , and eventual failure .', "There 's also a more acute version of ' broken heart syndrome ' . It 's called Takotsubo . This is a cardiomyopathy ( disease of the muscle of the heart ) induced by stress ( release of several hormones and other factors ) . The muscle of the heart is weakened / destroyed and your pump function decreases . I 've once seen it with a mother who lost her daughter ( who commited suicide ) .", "If I may - why do our hearts physically hurt when we 've had our hearts ' broken ' ? It 's only really happened to me once ( no stud - just not very romantically prolific ) and I was old enough to be almost amused by how the cliche was accurate ."]

id: How do clouds stay up in the sky ? I just read from an article that clouds can weigh over 1 million pounds . If this is true , how do they stay up in the sky ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Air also has weight . Remember that clouds are totally gigantic . The amount of air that would take up that space actually weighs more than that . Since the cloud is lighter , it floats on top of the air . As the cloud gets denser , it can sink down . As it gets less dense , it can rise up . That 's why fog , stratus clouds , cumulous clouds , and cirrus clouds hang out at different heights .", "1 . Humidity is already a component of air , giving it the properties required to keep a cloud suspended . 2 . Air has currents , because it 's a fluid . It keeps things in the air for the same reasons we eventually figured out how to make airplanes . 3 . You 're imagining it wrong , so try this : Put a drop of paint in an aquarium . Notice how the particulates of the paint spread out as they dilute . Eventually , that paint will settle to the bottom . But if ya add a current to that water .... things change . Point being : Clouds are n't being held up in the sky . We 're all stuck on the bottom of that aquarium .", 'yes they can be quite heavy by our standards , however not all of their weight is concentrated in one spot ( high density ) , but is instead scattered and spread apart ( low density ) . a 1 ton block of metal ( higher density than water ) will sink in water , while 1 ton of hollow plastic balls ( lower density than water ) will float , and either spread out or stack up ( depending on the size of the water container ) . in this same way , water droplets can be suspended in the air without much force keeping them aloof . clouds are comprised of condensed water droplets which are formed and held suspended by a number of complicated forces . as air has moisture added to it ( evaporation from the surface , etc . ) , it actually becomes less dense than dry air . this is counter - intuitive , but it has to do with how water molecules orient with nitrogen / oxygen forcing more space between nuclei . for the same reason hot air rises , so do other less dense components ( think helium balloons ) . as the moist air rises to regions where the atmosphere is even less dense and cooler than at the surface , the moisture in the air begins to condense . this causes droplets which are , in fact , more dense than the air around them and given only density and gravity considerations , should fall from the sky . however , the upward force of the rising moist air ( and cross winds or other currents ) prevent the droplets from falling and keep them suspended ( kind of like blowing a feather up into the air continuously ) . as more moisture is added or the temperature drops further ( or many other complex factors ) , the water droplets collide and fuse larger and larger until the updraft and currents are no longer forceful enough to keep them mid - air . based on differing pressures , winds , and temperatures , the size of the droplet needed to escape the cloud varies , which is why rain can be witnessed between fine and very large drops , and why large hail can form before ejecting from the clouds . ice is even less dense than water , and given the subzero temperatures in the upper atmosphere , it is very common for ice ( including snow ) particles to form from the condensed moisture and grow in their shape based on their journey within the clouds . this information is fairly widely available , the Wikipedia entry on cloud physics is a good reading point for more information , as is the howstuffworks article on clouds .']

id: How do people make aimbots ? Something I 've always been curious about . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["When you play an online video game , the server produces and sends you information about the virtual world you are playing in , including the position of other players , so that your computer can generate it graphically . You route some of that information through to an external program , who 's function is to identify where the other players are ( on your screen ) and move your cursor to them so that you do n't have to manually aim at them .", 'Saw the term " aimbot" ..... thought of something completely different . I \'m getting way too old in internet years .', "In addition to the techniques others have posted about digging around in memory , there 's also a cruder one based on image processing . You change the skins for enemy models to a single color . The aimbot then scans the frames for splotches of this color , and then moves the mouse to that location . While clunky , it has the advantage that it has only indirect hooks into the game , so it 's harder for anti - cheat programs to detect ."]

id: How do regulators really know if my system stores sensitive data ? Is it going to be okay if my system did n't provide a mean to read them ? Would anyone know ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["The idea is that , if an organization is handling sensitive data , it should know who has it & where it 's put and they need to have policies in place to ensure the safety of that data . Maybe you 'll get audited but it 's unlikely but * if you do end up losing data * , you 're going to get double - fucked if it turns out you were n't taking proper steps to protect the data . Turns out that lots of people get away with breaking a lot of laws .", "In addition to knowing where sensitive data should be stored , corporations also scan data traveling over their network and data stored on their systems , including the employees laptops , and look for sensitive data , where it 's coming from and where it 's going . They do this by pattern matching . For example , a social security number is 9 digits long and may or may not have dashes after the first three , next two and last four digits , so the system flags all 9 digit numbers . Since there are 9 digit numbers that are n't social security numbers , you can get a lot of data flagged that is n't sensitive and it requires a spot check by a human to determine if the data being flagged is actually sensitive data . Credit card numbers are a bit easier to flag because different credit cards start with specific numbers and are a certain length . For example , Visa credit cards start with a 4 and are 13 , 16 or 19 digits long . As for your question about your system not providing a means to read the data , you would have to encrypt it to prevent an auditing software from being able to read it . Even then , the auditing software could flag the data as being encrypted and it could be flagged as suspicious .", 'They classify the information based on certain criteria . If the information is classified as sensitive data , there are some designated people who have the rights to access . Based on that condition , the regulators know your system stores sensitive data .']

id: How do sound engineers create high quality sounds for use in games ? I mean , like you do n't record yourself shooting a gun and call it a day , right ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["You do record real sounds . Or you pay to use a library of recorded sounds . There 's a lot of money in constructing those libraries , because naturally not everyone can afford to go out and shoot a bunch of guns . Where sound design comes into play is when you design menu and interface sounds , or create things for which there 's no real world equivalent like in a Sci fi game . In that case , sound designers use combinations of samples , synthesizers , and effects to get weird noises they think sound good . It 's an art , just like creating the graphics . The real crazy part comes in when you put the sound in the game to react with the fake world . Walking in and out of rooms or areas changes how the sound will react , as will where the player is in the space . In those cases engineers spend a lot of time doing math to construct models of those spaces and how the player moves to replicate it . It 's a bigger deal in VR right now because it 's actually more taxing to compute than the graphics .", 'It depends heavily on the type of game being made , and the preferences of the lead design team . Games like Battlefield , ARMA etc which strive for " close - realism " in a lot of aspects actually exaggerate almost all of the sounds they use . All of the gun shots , explosions and tank rounds have a low - frequency \' boom \' added about 25ms after the initial attack , and a very high frequency noise ( in the regions of 10 - 15kHz ; usually something like a snapshot of a balloon popping or a speaker clicking ) around 5ms prior to the initial attack , which add a grandiose Hollywood - esque quality to the overall sound . Much more engaging and exciting than the dull \' pops \' and \' crackles \' of actual gunfire . The sound effects ( specifially gore - related ) used in the Dead Space games were often layers upon layers of things like carrots and celery sticks snapping to mimic bone breaks , and watermelons or tomatoes being thrown at walls or stomped on to mimic flesh being torn / squished . Much more dramatic and " atmosphere faithful " than what actual bone breaks sound like . After all of that comes weeks of post - processing and layering . Copious amounts of EQ to enhance characteristic frequencies or remove anything undesirable . If you compare most modern AAA titles for their sounds the overarching quality in each sound is " bass - heavy and bright " , which gives both impact and clarity without " dullness " . EDIT : Everyone else posted links , so here \'s another interesting watch for big budget sound design . URL_0', "A lot of professionally used sounds ( though very far from all ) are just recordings of exactly what they sound like . Other sounds are recordings of other things , that kind of sound like the thing you want . People who do this are generally referred to as foley artists , after Jack Donovan Foley , who was one of the pioneers in the field . The third common way to work is layering sounds . You can often create great sounds by combining several sounds . The following video shows Gary Hecker , one of the great modern foley artists , doing sounds for Robin Hood ( 2012 ) . URL_0 Surprisingly little of modern sound effects are digitally created , though digital audio workstations are very useful in many ways , because digital audio manipulation is usually quite easy to detect . Good sound design is in many ways like good table service . If you do it right , the end user should n't even notice it ."]

id: How do child actors get around child labor laws ? As the title says , I am curious as to how exactly young children are allowed to work . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["They are allowed to work , but under very strict limitations . They can only work something like 4 hours a day ( or 6 for older children ) , and the work is not allowed to interfere with their education . Many child actors have a teacher or tutor on set with them that teaches them between shots and after their day 's work is done . Also , some states / countries have special exceptions in the child labor laws for actors . URL_0", 'The law does not say " children may not work for pay . " Instead , the law puts * limits * on what children can be asked to do for pay . These limits are really pretty convoluted , which is why film and television productions have to jump through a lot of hoops to ensure they \'re in compliance with them .', "Typical child labour is wrong because it interferes with other parts of the kids life like education . However if they are still going to school and doing other normal kid stuff its not damaging . So they have strong laws like limiting the number of hours worked per day , what times they can work ( in my country you ca n't have a schooolkid working at 2AM on a wedsday morning for example ) ."]

id: How do the Reddit bots work ? Are they people ... Are they run by Skynet ... The NSA ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Reddit actually [ provides a nice way for bots to do stuff on the website ] ( URL_0 ) ( this is called an [ API ] ( URL_3 ) ) . A bot is basically a computer program that acts a bit like a regular user . It can do things normal users do ( comment , vote etc . ) but follows whatever rules its programmer sets . Take the unit converter bot . It would use the Reddit API to get a list of all the posts like this - GET URL_2 The bot would download that data and work out where the posts are . Then it would get all the comments in a post like this GET URL_1 Then it would look through all the comments and find anywhere someone had said " inch " , " foot " or " meter " etc . , if there was a number before that it would take the number and work it out in different units . Finally it would post a comment like this GET URL_4 That way a bot can do lots of things that a user can do , but from a computer program instead of a browser . Now , it is possible for a bot to also do actions exactly like a browser , but it \'s more difficult to make bots like that . Because Reddit gives bots a nice API to use it \'s easy to write a bot and so there are lots of bots around .', "They are programs , written by people obviously , that search threads for specific combinations of words . They then place a reaction , which is , depending on the quality of the criteria of the bot , relevant to the subject . No people are needed once the programs is set to run . They can be used to harvest karma , or to help people out ( for instance by supplying the source of an image when someone asked for it ) . For as far as my imagination goes , the NSA would have no interest in replying to posts or comments . I do n't think they would have a reason to build a reddit bot : p.", "They are written by people using the [ reddit API ] ( URL_0 ) . Here 's one written in Python : URL_1"]

id: How do radioactive metals , such as radium , cause illness ? What can a rock to do my body by being near it ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Heavy particles are unstable , so they tend to break . Radium is very heavy , so it breaks into smaller parts and as it breaks it releases pieces of shrapnel , kind of like tiny needles that pierce your body and knocking molecules along the way . It 's all fun and games when it manages to only hit some water in your blood or disturbs a flake of your epidermis , but once DNA of your brain cells keeps getting displaced , you have a problem . Thankfully , hitting a molecule is damn near impossible . Unless you try billions times a second . Like radioactive rocks do .", 'Think of a radioactive rock like a time - released bomb . Or a damage - over - time bomb sorta thing . It is constantly " exploding " and sending out " explosions " of Helium atoms , electrons , or pure energy . If you were standing near a bomb when it blows up , the bomb will destroy your cells . The same thing is happening with a radioactive rock , except the explosions are much smaller and keep occurring , and the stuff that comes out of the explosions slowly destroy you by damaging your DNA , liquifying your organs , etc ...', 'Radioactive things are sending out high - energy particles . Those particles enter your cells and do things at the atomic level , usually screwing up your DNA . This can do things like kill cells or cause you to produce cancerous cells .']

id: How does a " one - way " encryption become one way ? I know that encryption such as MD5 / MD6 are supposed to be irreversible , but since they are calculated by some equations , why ca n't they be reversed ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Lots of functions are easy to calculate but hard to invert\\ * . For instance , given some collection of prime numbers , a computer can multiply them together very quickly . However , given one number , it takes a very long time for a computer to find the collection of primes which multiply together to give that number . This is an example of what is\\ * called a " one - way function " . Cryptographic hash functions like MD5 are similar in that respect : it is fast for a computer to compute the cryptographic hash of a function in one direction , but slow to go in the other direction . \\ * This is only conjectured to be true . I am essentially stating that Pâ NP which is largely believed to be true .', 'MD5 is not encryption per se , it is a hash function . It has a fixed length regardless of the length of the input message . This means that more than one source message will yield the same output hash . There is no way to tell from the hash alone what the input was .', "I 'm thinking of a four digit number whose digits add up to 21 . Do you know what it is ? Clearly , not all operations are two ways ."]

id: How do you crack a password ? Do you just keep guessing ? How relevant is password strength if it 's just a random word ? If ' cheese ' were my password , who would guess it , even without the numbers and dollar signs etc . ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["yep , cracking a password is nothing else than just guessing a lot of times , although people do use lists of dictionary words ( and common password phrases ) for guessing , so passwords like ' cheese ' , ' 123456 ' , ' John ' will get cracked almost instantly , the dirctionary lists also get combined with prefix and suffix lists , so that all the common variations of a word that could be a password will get guessed ( ' 01cheese ' , ' cheese21 ' , ' $ cheese ' etc ) . And of course all the guessing is done by computers who guess millions of possibilities per second", 'Four things , mostly slight corrections ( IMO ) of what other people have said : First method is [ social engineering ] ( URL_0 ): tricking people into telling you their passwords ( or doing other things they \'re not supposed to ) . You want to crack into the computers of Acme Inc. So figure out the name and phone number of somebody non - technical in the company , and give them a call : " Hi , I \'m your company \'s new IT support guy , and I need you to tell me your password so I can install an emergency antivirus update update . " In modern days , the predominant forms of social engineering attacks are [ phishing ] ( URL_2 ) and [ trojans ] ( URL_1 more effective to try to trick 1,000 people at a time than one at a time . The second general method is guessing . The trick to effective guessing , however , is to try likely passwords before you try unlikely ones . This has a few variants : * Use knowledge about the intended victim to guess likely passwords . E.g. , " Joe \'s birthday is May 27 , 1988 , so I \'ll try variations of that . " This sort of guessing is usually done by hand . * Use general assumptions of which passwords are more likely . This goes from ( a ) using dictionary words , ( b ) simple variants of dictionary words ( changing letters to numbers ) , ( c ) letter combination frequencies ( " batedima " is a more likely combination of letters than " gajhhhhha " ) , etc . This sort of guessing is usually automated as a computer program , and works best when combined with the third technique ( just below ) . Third technique : steal a password database . This one \'s easy to misunderstand , because while it sounds like this would give you everybody \'s password , any well designed password database uses a nearly unbreakable secret code for the passwords . But the really neat thing you can do if you steal the password database is that you can guess passwords for * all * of the users at the same time . The way this works is you make a guess , then you encode the guess the same way as the database does , and check if any users match . How do you steal the password database ? Well , you can use social engineering for that , but another way is the fourth technique : exploits . Discover bugs in server software that will allow you to get in without a password .', "Well there 're different ways of cracking a password : * Social engineering . This way requires almost no IT skills compared to other methods , but at the same time requires good communication skills or at least some common knowledge about security . For instance , most people use their birthday dates , pet names etc as passwords . Most of this stuff can be easily googled as in case with [ celebrity emails guy ] ( URL_1 ) , or you can be sly enough to persuade victim to give you credentials . There 's also a famous case [ when hacker used publicly accessible info to persuade apple 's customer support and wiped out all the data from client 's iDevices . ] ( URL_0 ) * Bruteforce . To put it simply , you 're just guessing the password . There 're many applications and scripts to do so , most of them use dictionaries and optimised algorithms for easier word search . The time required for cracking the password highly depends on its complexity and how powerful the system running bruteforce script is . That 's why some sites ask you to put different case letters , digits and symbols for better protection . So it 's a good choice to check your passwords with something like [ this ] ( URL_2 ) . * Exploits . This requires some experience in IT and hacking . The idea is in using vulnerabilities to access user 's credentials . So far that 's the ways of cracking I know . I believe there 's more information available on the internets , but I guess that 's something you can search on your own :)"]

id: How do charities get away with not spending donated money on the designated purpose ? Who / what regulates what % of the money goes where ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Charities are largely unregulated . So long as they do n't make fraudulent claims , they can spend their money pretty much however they like . Also , designated purpose is pretty fuzzy . A charity set out to feed the homeless , but they need to do a lot of other things to make that happen . They need staff , they need management , they need fundraising , and other overhead to meet their goals . It is hard to draw a line where there designated purpose ends and fraud begins .", 'operating costs . Some charities need people to actually manage where the money goes , how it gets spent , it ca nt all be 100 % volunteer hours for everything so there will need to be some employees . Without these kinds of people and employees , the money donated may never reach its intended destination .', 'Depends what you mean by " designated purpose . " There are many donations that come with all sorts of restrictive in terms of when , where , and for what items it can be used for . Often these have to be accounted for both in reporting back to the fonating agency as well as accounted for in annual audits . If you are asking why part of the money you donate online to feeding the homeless goes to pay the salary of the people who work there , it is because that \'s what it takes to feed the homeless . The money does n\'t turn from annonline credit card payment to a calorie in someone \'s diet . It turns into an agency that provides the service , adheres to local regulations , builds partnerships with local agencies to reach the most people possible , hosts events so that it can keep feeding people next year , trains volunteers , manages payroll , negotiates deals with food providers , maintains a kitchen , manages annual audits , etc . As for deciding what percentage is appropriate to go where , typically : An unpaid board of directors ( who often are bug donors themselves and therefore invested in a well run company ) choose an executive director / ceo , who is responsible for deciding the most appropriate use of resources . That is then reported out on publically accessible tax filings ( URL_0 you can see them all for free ) . It is then up to the public , major donors , institutional funders etc to decide whether they agree that the impact is appropriate to their contribution . There is still the rare case of fraud like in any business , but given the required public transparency , audits , and the fact that unpaid people are the ones legally on the hook ( generally diminishing as much as possible conflicts of interest ) , these cases are pretty rare . Unfortunately because they sre rare , they get a lot of press when they happen . Tldr : in most case a ceo / ed decides how the money is best used , who in turn is held accountable by a board of directors , an auditor , major donors , and the general public .']

id: How does Vanguard determine the optimal asset allocation for their Target Retirement Funds?
text: ["While the Vanguard paper is good, it doesn't do a very good job of explaining precisely why each level of stocks or bonds was optimal. If you'd like to read a transparent and quantitative explanation of when and why a a glide path is optimal, I'd suggest the following paper:  https://www.betterment.com/resources/how-we-construct-portfolio-allocation-advice/ (Full disclosure - I'm the author).  The answer is that the optimal risk level for any given holding period depends upon a combination of:  Using these two factors, you construct a risk-averse decision model which chooses the risk level with the best expected average outcome, where it looks only at the median and lower percentile outcomes. This produces an average which is specifically robust to downside risk. The result will look something like this:   The exact results will depend on the expected risk and return of the portfolio, and the degree of risk aversion specified.  The result is specifically valid for the case where you liquidate all of the portfolio at a specific point in time. For retirement, the glide path needs to be extended to take into account the fact that the portfolio will be liquidated gradually over time, and dynamically take into account the longevity risk of the individual.  I can't say precisely why Vanguard's path is how it is."]

id: How does ROUND - UP work and why is it bad ? I know it 's an herbicide , but I 'd like to know how it works to kill plants . Also , what does it do to humans ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['The ELI5 version of this is that it interferes with a plant \'s ability to build amino acids . Amino acids are simple ( well , for organic chemistry ) molecules that are combined to form proteins , which are all of the building materials for life . What makes glyphosate , the active ingredient in Roundup , a clever herbicide is that it only acts on what \'s called the " shikimic acid pathway " , which is a particular method of synthesizing these amino acids . It turns out that all animals get these particular amino acids from plants in our diet , so glyphosate has no known ill effects in humans - we do n\'t rely on this particular method for our needs . Why is it considered bad : this is complicated . The easiest criticism to understand is that it \'s way , way overused . Essentially , we \'re raining death on the plant world increasingly more in production agriculture , simply because it \'s so effective . Too much of a good thing . It has a tendency to run off of fields when overused , to the point where we \'ve been able to see it in aquifers and streams far from fields , where , presumably , it could still kill plants in a high - enough concentration . It \'s also greatly linked with Roundup Ready plants , plants which have had their genes modified to be resistant to roundup ( the shikimic acid pathway is modified in such a way as for the glyphosate molecules to no longer be as sticky as they are in non - modified plants , so they ca n\'t gum up the works and prevent the amino acids from forming ) . For those who oppose GMO plants , Roundup is sort of an enabler for the technology . Monsanto , the company which produces Roundup and Roundup Ready plants , has a long history of not being very responsible in a " big picture " sort of way ( e.g. Agent Orange , DDT , and PCBs were products of theirs as one of a number of chemical companies providing these goods ) , and they \'ve been known to use monopolistic practices in businesses that harm farmers by squeezing their finances from all sides - providing the seeds , providing the Roundup , and ~~owning the grain elevators that take the grain after its grown~~ * * Edit : it was pointed out to me that Monsanto does n\'t actually own the grain elevators . * * _ Hard to keep track of these sort of things : the agriculture business , like all of corporate America , is full of lots of corporation games . For instance , just parcel out what happened when [ Monsanto merged with Pfizer ] ( URL_0 ) - so far as I can tell , that move spawned 2 new companies as subsidiaries of Pfizer , then a decade later Pfizer sold its controlling interest when things got hairy . Maybe ? Who owns what is hard to track . Mea culpa . _ . Finally , there have been some rumblings that Roundup , or glyphosate more specifically , _ may _ act as a carcinogen in very large enough doses ; the mechanism , as far as I know , is still unknown , but it \'s this last that \'s put it in the news recently . Still , as a herbicide , you ca n\'t get much better than Roundup : it kills plants with no known serious harmful effects on the farmers and field workers who use it . It all has to be taken in context - is it better or worse than backbreaking hand - weeding ? Hard to say definitively . tl;dr : much of what is " wrong " with Roundup is due to the political and technological environment in which it \'s being used - sort of how , say , gasoline is not a villainous liquid , but it _ has been _ a big part of global warming due to how we use it . And , I hate to have to do this , but a disclaimer : I \'ve been totally burned in any post where I string the letters G , M , and O back to back : people loooove to draw a line in the sand on them for some reason . This answer is not meant to speak for or against them . Whether or not you agree with genetically modified organisms , I hope that nobody turns this into a huge flame war , as GMOs are not inherently part of the question asked . I tried to address the issues as neutrally as possible , with fairly balanced coverage , but there \'s always someone who loves to hop in and pick apart any aspect of this that does n\'t sit well with them while ignoring those parts that are in favor of their viewpoint . Not trying to be super paranoid , but let \'s just all agree to play nice , shall we ? OK , back to your regularly scheduled Reddit experience :) EDIT : Correction about Monsanto owning grain elevators and extent of Monsanto \'s involvement in chemical manufacturing . Credits to u / CricketPinata and u / dtiftw EDIT2 : I guess there \'s no proactive way to ask people not to troll off of your post :/ These are not my opinions , people , but rather an attempt to provide a balanced digest of these topics . When someone asks " what \'s the big deal with something " , if I hear people say that they do n\'t like that thing , I \'ll put it in , whether or not I agree . It \'s intent is journalism , not editorializing . Not even yellow journalism : I strive to be as balanced as possible , as evidenced by " tentatively may cause cancer ; method unknown " followed immediately " ca n\'t get much better than Roundup " . Feel free to ( politely ! ) correct any facts I got wrong , but any opinions in here are not necessarily my own , so flaming me is pointless . Being the shot messenger gets old real fast .', 'It \'s worth noting that glyphosate ( Roundup ) is less toxic than many / most others ( including " natural " herbicides ) , and you can use less of it than many / most others . So it \'s actually better than a lot of the alternatives . ( I do n\'t have a source for this . It \'s 11:00 at night and I \'m about to log off . But I \'ve seen this claim repeated by many credible sources over the past few years . )', "It 's not * bad * in any way . I spray the 50x power stuff directly on weeds and other crap and they are GONE ."]

id: How do animals that live underwater heal from cuts ? Does the water prevent their blood from clotting ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["No , it does n't prevent their blood from clotting . Many fish also constantly secrete a slime coating that resists infection .", 'Nope blood clotting would more accurately be described as a chemical reaction rather than drying out . At the site of a wound the damaged cells will release a chemical called von willebrand factor which causes the platelets in your bloodstream to stick to the damaged fibers around the cut site and too each other until the cut is sealed . It may take a little longer underwater but the presence of water will not stop the reaction occurring .', "I 'm not a marine life expert but I 'm training to be a wound care expert . The ideal environment for healing is actually a moist environment . You 'll notice that cuts that occur in your mouth heal a lot quicker than cuts you get on your skin . Moisture allows the cells that deal with wound healing to move more efficiently and quickly , thereby speeding up the repair process . For humans , too much moisture can be detrimental to wound healing of the skin ( if there 's a lot of drainage in the wound bed , infectious bacteria can thrive ) . For marine life , whose physiological processes centralize around constantly being in water , healing processes have adapted to suit that environment ."]

id: How do so many people who post obviously copyrighted video on YouTube have YouTube partnerships ( and therefore ads on their videos ) ? Is n't YouTube obligated to delete copyrighted video ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["It 's possible it 's not the video poster 's ad . I 've put up a video on YouTube with a copyrighted song during part of it , and a banner ad got put on it , with the money going to the song 's copyright holder , not me .", "Fair use . You can use copyrighted material in your own material , even for commercial use , if it falls under fair use . Fair use is things like review . That 's how game reviewers , movie reviewers , TV show reviewers , etc all show copyrighted material and then sell their review .", "Because their content counts as transformative work under fair use . They do n't just show the content , they review it our otherwise work with it . ( referring mostly to users with video game content )"]

id: How do game shows continuously give away cash and prizes ? Game shows like The Price is Right and Deal or No Deal always gives away a high number of prizes . How do they afford to do this ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Game shows are really cheap to produce . They only have a couple of high salary hosts , a constant set , no special effects , no script , they can shoot several episodes worth of footage in a day , etc . Also , the prizes are usually given by sponsors ( i.e. advertisers ) , not by the show 's producers .", "They make money from sponsorship and advertising . The products they give away are provided by companies that sponsor the show , and they even pay money- because it 's advertising . There is also money from the network who owns or buys the show , which is no different than the money for non - gameshows that need to pay for cast , crew , and production . For a gameshow there are few * cast members * ( host and assistants instead of actors ) so the money you would otherwise spend to hire actors you can spend on prizes .", 'It \'s interesting that this is such a common question here , yet I \'ve never seen anyone ask , " How do sitcoms afford to pay the actors , " even though it \'s essentially the same question . And the answer is the same , to : advertisers . Companies pay the show to be allowed to air commercials for their product in its time slot . The more popular the show , the more it can charge advertisers .']

id: How do translators capture the writing style of a writer when translating books ? How do they mimic it without making the book loosing the writer 's identity ? Can they actually do it properly ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["We do it in the same way that you capture the writing style of a writer when reading a book in your own language . How easy this is depends on the nature of the source text . I 'm a professional translator , but I avoid reading translated literature for pleasure , maybe that tells you something .", "With great difficulty , is the answer to that question ; and many a book has been ruined for some audiences by terrible translating . The gold standard of literary translation is sometimes considered to be Anthea Bell and David Hockridge 's translations of the popular French * Asterix * comics -- yes , not even an actual book : comics , aimed mostly at children . The original French versions ( at least the early ones , before the writer Goscinny died ) were known for their sophisticated parody , satire , wit and -- a particular nightmare for translators -- an endless stream of puns . Puns can almost never be translated , and so Bell and Hockridge had to write their own puns of the same quality of the French originals * and * ( because these were comics ) which also fitted in with the pictures and the speech bubbles . It takes a translator who is not only proficient in both the source language and the target language , but also understands what the author is trying to do and has a similar level of literary skill . An example of where , in my opinion , this failed catastrophically might be the German translations of Terry Pratchett 's Discworld novels : in some cases , the translator ( or translators ) appears not to have understood some of the aspects of culture Pratchett was satirizing , and so many of the gags fall completely flat .", '" Traduttore tradditore " . Translator , traitor . They try to , but it \'s never perfect . They need perfect command of both languages . It \'s not uncommon for living accomplished authors have one specific translator in one language , that knows them inside and out . Sometimes they even work together . But translations are never perfect . That \'s why classic works keep being translated over and over again .']

id: How do we know how ' old ' light is ? How can we know that there is light that is 13 billion + years old ? If we are still receiving it and sensing it , how can we date something that does n't have tangible mass ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["We look at where it 's coming from . Say , we 're trying to get a snapshot of shortly after the big bang , our theory predicts roughly what it should look like , and roughly where we should see it , so if we something resembling what we 're looking for in the place we 're looking for it , then we can assume the light is that old . But if you were given an individual photon and asked to identify its age without any further information , you would n't be able to .", "You do n't measure the age of the light . You measure how far away the emitter is and the speed of light . You then deduce the age of the light .", 'I think what you mean is the Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation . It is the oldest form of light that we can see . When the universe was young , before the formation of stars and planets , it was denser , much hotter , and filled with a uniform glow from a white - hot fog of hydrogen plasma . As the universe expanded , both the plasma and the radiation filling it grew cooler . When the universe cooled enough , protons and electrons combined to form neutral hydrogen atoms . These atoms could no longer absorb the thermal radiation , and so the universe became transparent instead of being an opaque fog . The universe became transparent after 380000 years after big bang because the cooling caused by its expansion allowed ionized gas to recombine into neutral hydrogen and helium , which is transparent to visible light . So anything before that is just the CMB radiation , which is what they mean when they say the light is 13 billion years old . It is actually microwave radiation from that time , It is like the after glow of the big bang , it is still there , it just decreases in intensity over time .']

id: How do so many mattress stores stay in business ? I feel like I see so many in such a small area . Explain like I'm five.

A mattress that no one has bought for a few years can still be sold at the same price . And eventually everyone will buy a mattress or two .", 'I always wonder this about piano stores .', "Giant Markups . My parents bought a mattress during boxing week . they were looking a mattress at one store on sale and decided to go to another store to compare . they found a mattress that was comparable but was $ 1000 more since it was n't on sale . They asked about a price match without even double checking said no problem he would beat it . ( took an extra 150 off the price ) They saved over 50 percent on the regular price of the matress"]

id: How do balding people still manage to have a full beard ? Cause I 'm balding and still have a full beard Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['The first law of hairodynamics states that male adult hair can never really be created nor destroyed , only transferred . This is what happens to balding men - they lose hair atop their head , but the hair accumulates in other regions . It could manifest as beard hair , an unruly chest forest , a few curly nostril follicles , or a luscious mane for your elephant trunk . The key thing to remember is that the hair is never really going anywhere !', "[ Has to do with testosterone ] ( URL_0 ) Here 's the reddit link , and it includes the link to an article on the subject of why it happens . TLDR : If you get a manly beard early in life , you 're more likely to go bald sooner .", 'Male pattern baldness affects head hair , not beard hair . The two types of hair are very different .']

id: How do companies and stores make money from gift cards ? I do n't understand if I buy a 10 dollar gift card , does company A lose money because store A gets a portion of the profit ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['When you buy a gift card , you are giving the company an interest free loan . That in itself is good enough for them .', 'Ever had a gift card expire ? Free money for the store .', "Gift cards expire , get lost , have money left on them , are exclusive to that store / brand / website . These all lead to high profit margins on them . Gift cards do have costs associated with using them though . Most places get charged some kind of fee for every time they are swiped for a transaction . So if people actually used 100 % of the money on them they would n't be worth it . This is more relevant for smaller businesses though ."]

id: How do actors memorize all their lines ? I have trouble remembering a short grocery list . How do actors do it ? What is the most common technique used ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Practice , practice , practice . It helps that you often have other actors helping you along , providing prompts and jogging your memory with their own lines . Plus , any good actor knows how to improv / stay in character in the event of a slip - up , making the act of forgetting seem seamless to an unsuspecting audience . It 's easy in movies because you have a lot of room to play around with different takes and readings and fix things in post . On the other hand , people in plays have to read the same lines again and again every night , which reinforces it .", "Through repetition over time , And practice and internal rhyme , It 's the same with waiters , And high school debaters , And plenty of time to refine .", 'Memorizing a grocery list is hard when the items have nothing to do with each other . But it \'s easier if they do . If you \'re a baker , and you need to go get flour , sugar , butter , and eggs , it \'s pretty easy to remember that list because they \'re the 4 basic baking ingredients . But if the list is 3 yellow onions , a quart of half - and - half , toothpaste , and dog food , it \'s going to be really easy to forget something . That \'s the key to memorization . Your brain can really only hold on to so many things at once ( I \'ve heard 7 as an upper limit ) , so to memorize more you have to chunk things together into one thing . If I could only remember one thing , I could memorize the first list as " the 4 basic baking ingredients " and the second with some kind of memory device : " I need to brush the dog \'s teeth with onions cooked in half - and - half " . Lines in a movie or play are memorized by becoming so familiar with the scene that it \'s just one thing . Rather than " I have to say this sentence , then wait for her to say hers , then say this next sentence ... " it just becomes " do the scene " . Amateur actors take a lot of repetitions to get there , while veteran actors can get there quicker by visualizing the whole thing in their head and " mentally rehearsing " it before the actual rehearsal .']

id: How does DRM work ? Digital Rights Management . The wikipedia page goes off in many directions . First hit my radar with the Xbox One stuff . How does DRM work and why is it so controversial ? Thank you ! Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["The reason wikipedia goes off in many directions is because it 's a generic term , it does n't describe any single technique . It 's just attempting to get people to pay you for their thing , preventing them from pirating it . It 's controversial because a lot of DRM implementations tend to be very inconvenient for the legit customers , whereas the people that would pirate your product will likely be able to do it anyway , and because their copy is cracked , they do n't see the downside of the restrictive DRM . It literally only hurts the paying customers , which in turn forces more people to pirate . Nobody wins .", "DRM is restricting the ways you can use the product you purchased to make it harder for pirates to use . Some examples are having a CD key before you can use your software , or putting an empty ring on the edge of a CD so that a computer thinks it 's empty , while a CD player is too dumb to care and keeps reading it anyway , or having a code on MP3 files that prevents them from being played unless another hidden authorization file is on the computer , or requiring you to sign into a remote server before you can play your game ( most EA titles , Diablo III )", "sadly , were i to give you the details on how specific types of DRM function , i 'd actually be guilty of violating the DMCA ."]
