id: How do traffic jams in big cities start ? I was driving recently , and realized I have never understood how a traffic jam begins , and how it is possible to have them at the same time every day . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["It 's generally caused by bottle necks in the road , merging , and visual distractions . High traffic volume mixed with those 3 things create traffic jams . A bottle neck is exactly what it sounds like , think of a bottle . Several lanes converging into 1 or 2 , it creates a slow down . Cars merging onto a highway can really slow down traffic because a lot of people do n't know how to merge correctly . Zipper merging is one of the best methods , think of a zipper closing as a visual .", "I 'll give you the short version . When cars are backed up at an intersection or highway ramp eventually the first car has to move . All the cars behind it do n't move at the same time like a train does . The first car moves , then the second car waits a second and moves , then the third car can only move after the second car moves , and so on . The traffic jam is basically all of these cars not moving while additional cars continue to pile up behind it .", 'Too many cars on the road at the same time . Once traffic has hit a saturation point where there are no gaps in which cars can merge , the existing traffic must slow down to provide space for the oncoming traffic . This causes all cars behind to slow down as well . After it repeats a number of times , traffic can slow to a crawl . It happens near the same time because it usually coincides with the time most people are driving to or from work ( many workplaces start at 8 - 9 and end at 5 - 6 ) .']

id: How does Nintendo 's labo work ? I just do n't get it ? Is it just cardboard and you have to pretend that your doing something or is there more too it ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['In conjunction with the software , the IR sensors in the right joy con allows pieces of reflective plastic inside the cardboard to sense different movements and then the software reacts accordingly .', "The piano works by pointing the right joycon into the body of the box and pushing a key changes what the IR camera views ( I 'm guessing it lifts small paddles on the inside via lever motion ) . The camera can detect basic shapes easily and determine distance of objects so that must play into how it works too . The software the kit comes with interprets what the camera sees and outputs the corresponding notes . The robot vr backpack looks like it uses the gyrometers ( things that can sense motion ) of the left joycon headset piece to determine view while it uses the other gyrometers on the right joycon to detect when your ducking . It then uses the ir camera again , to look at the position of markers inside the backpack controlled by pulleys , rubber bands and string . When you pull the strings it pulls on the tab with the marker on the inside up , and the camera can see that info to tell which arm your moving . The rc car works like a hexbug nano but has dual drive lol the way the legs are shaped , the vibration makes it move forward incrementally . If only one side rumbles , it turns to ~~that~~ * the other * side . * * TLDR * * : This is really a kit for creating non electric peripherals that mechanically give info to the gyros and IR camera . It is n't pretending to play with that stuff you make , they interact with the joycon to become actual controllers of what your doing", 'The right side Joy - Con has a little infrared camera and illumination LED . You can see how it all works in [ this ] ( URL_1 ) segment of the video ( pause and look closely a the scenes from that point on ) . The moving cardboard bits have white markers attached . The camera captures an image , and the software looks for the motion of these markers to determine which pieces of cardboard have moved . It seems you can probably customize the layout of the detection ( by defining rectangular regions of interest that detect when a particular white marker enters or leaves them ) to build your own contraptions . Edit : Here \'s an [ annotated diagram ] ( URL_0 ) . For the moving " robot " , the cardboard body is designed so that when the joy - cons vibrate , the robot moves preferentially in one direction ( thanks to the angled comb - shaped " legs " ) . By choosing which side is vibrating ( or both ) , you can steer the robot around .']

id: How do we get pictures back from space probes like Rosetta ? I get that there are big dish antennas but how does it work ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['It encodes the pictures and sends them via radio . Think long distance wifi transmissions', "First , the pictures are encoded into a format that NASA can use . This is n't necessarily a standard image format like GIF or JPEG ; it will most likely be a high - quality , lossless format so that reserachers can get as much information as possible . Next , this image will be compressed . Again , this will probably be a lossless compression so as much data as possible gets through . The compressed image will then be supplemented with Error Detection and Correction codes , such as a [ Hamming code ] ( URL_0 ) . This allows NASA 's computers to receive somewhat corrupted data and reconstruct it . The file that is created through all these procedures is then sent towards Earth with a strong transmitter and antenna . This may be a directional antenna , meaning that it has to point directly at Earth to work . This would have the advantage of needing less power , but the disadvantage of always needint to know where Earth is and being able to manouevre to see it . The signal would then be captured by large antennae around the world . Whichever antenna is facing the right direction at the right time would receive the signal . From the antenna , the file would be sent to a processing facility via fiber optic cable . The processing facility would run the error correction codes , then decompress the original file .", 'I will simplify it down to the very basics . The picture is digital , so every little pixel is determined by a number which tells computers what color the specific pixel is and that number is represented by binary , a bunch of 0s and 1s . That is all sent through the antenna . The antenna transmits the information with bursts of radio waves . The big dishes on the ground receive that information and turns it back into a picture . Hope I was helpful ! Edit : This is a really simplified version , it gets much more complicated']

id: How do people think the holocaust was made up and never happened ? Title . How ? There is plenty of evidence ... Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Most " holocaust deniers " do n\'t believe it was made up . They believe it was n\'t as extensive as claimed . There are a variety of reasons .. some more reasonable than others . I \'d recomend a google search , it would take pages to type .', 'Just like with any conspiracy theory the thinking goes like this : " We found one tiny single insignificant inconsistency or unanswered question in the historical record of ( XYZ ) . Therefore , there may be other inconsistencies or unanswered questions about ( XYZ ) . Therefore , we should treat ( XYZ ) like it \'s a complete fabrication from start to finish ! " The fact is we do n\'t have perfect knowledge of every single thing that ever happened . If a hundred people witness a car crash then 90 of them will say that a red car hit a white car , seven of them will say a blue car hit a silver car , three will say a red car hit a gray car . If you are motivated to believe that the car crash never happened then you \'ll declare this to be evidence of a cover - up . Likewise , one Nazi writes in his diary that he arrived at Buchenwald on May 10 but the camp records show that he arrived on May 12th . One report says that 4,354 Jews lived in a particular ghetto and another report says that over 20,000 Jews lived in that ghetto . If you want to believe that the Holocaust never happened , you will seize on this as proof . And , since nobody can resolve the contradiction perfectly ( because time machines do n\'t exist ) you can keep the debate alive forever .', "As is the case with quite a few conspiracy theories I 've read , people seem to have a personal reason that makes them want to believe it and ignore the contrary evidence . It 's a bit like religion and astrology . ( I know I 'll probably get a lot for crap for saying that but screw it . )"]

id: How do we come to a consensus on what to call countries ? i.e. Why is it Germany called Germany ? Furthermore , why do we sometimes use the native language as a basis for the name and other times we do n't ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Because it 's full of germs ! Kidding of course ( being German myself ) , this is an excellent question . I 'd love an answer .", 'Because a lot of people choose to call it that before formal texts and countries are formed . America - named after the first guy to explore the " New World " who was n\'t convinced it was India . Germany - Based on the Germanic people , which were named as such by the Romans . Romans / Rome - Founded by twin brothers Romulus and Remus ( I believe these two are a myth , but they named the city after the myth ) Italy - Taken from the greek word for a young bull ( Vitalae I think ? ) , glorified during the Social War as opposition to the Roman Wolf URL_0 . Italia means Land of the Young Bulls England - Originally named " Land of the Angles " for disputed origins : either because the Angeln Peninsula was angled ( Land of the Angeln People ) or because the Germanic word for " Narrow " , as in Narrow Water ( Land of the Narrow Water , as in across the english channel )', "Custom . Germany as a unified country is only about 140 years old , so a lot of names exist for the area . English happens to use the old Roman name , from the Latin ' Germania ' . The French use the name of one particular tribe , which the Romans called the Allemanii ( l'Allemagne ) . They themselves are named after another Germanic tribe , the Franks ( which is why the German name for France is ' Frankreich ' , the Frankish Empire ) . It 's a common process . People often develop different names for their neighbours than they use for themselves . Sometimes it 's because the political situation changes - if Burma remains Myanmar for another few centuries , people are going to wonder why the English term is Burmese . For that matter , someone unfamiliar with the history might wonder why we call this language English instead of UKese :)"]

id: How do computers work on the * most * basic level Emphasis on most . Not programming but at the physical level . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["1 = on 0 = off each refers to the state of an electronic switch called a transistor . these are arranged as ' logic gates ' gates with names such as AND , OR , NOT URL_0 These are set out in paths which the signls go down eventually leading to an output connect lots of these togeher in the right order and you get a basic circuit based computer like Pong or a Calculator . In a more complex system the paths of the electronic signals can be programmed and you get more complex results such as Grand Theft Auto .", 'Electricity flows . By turning switches on and off it can be made to flow to different places . Those places do stuff when they get electricity . Maybe make a noise or make a pixel turn on or off . Put together millions of switches and you can do some complex things . Programming basically tells the electricity where to go and when it gets there , stuff happens .', 'From a circuitry perspective , here \'s what s happening : Imagine you have switches , which you can turn on and off . ( You typically see on represented as a " 1 " and off represented as a " 0 " - this is known as the binary representation , where the prefix " bi " means two , since a switch can only be on or off ) . You , as the user , set the value of these switches . That is , you turn them on and off in different orders to represent different inputs ( You can use the order of on vs off switches to represent numbers . For instance , 101 represents 5 . For more , you can view a simple explanation of binary number representation [ here ] ( URL_5 ) . ) Each of these switches you have has a wire , and this wire connects your switches to " logic gates " . Simple logic gates take in typically one or two inputs and make a decision ( output ) based on those inputs . The 3 most basic logic gates are " and " , " or " , and " not " . The " and " gate produces an " on " message if /both/ of its inputs are on . The " or " gate produces an " on " message if /either/ of its inputs are on . The " not " gate takes in only one input , and produces an " on " message if its input is off , and vice versa . Here are visualizations of those gates in action , where bright green is " on " and dark green is " off " . The And gate , where one input is on and the other is off , produces an " off " message : [ X ] ( URL_9 ) The And gate , where both inputs are on , produces an " on " message : [ X ] ( URL_3 ) The Or gate , where either input is on , produces an " on " message : [ X ] ( URL_4 ) [ X ] ( URL_2 ) When both inputs are on , the Or gate still produces an " on " message : [ X ] ( URL_6 ) The " not " gate flips the message it receives : [ X ] ( URL_1 ) [ X ] ( URL_7 ) If you want to download this program to play around with gates and learn more , its called [ Logisim ] ( URL_8 ) and is totally free ! Long story short , you can combine many of these inputs and gates to do increasingly complex things . For instance , here is an example of a [ full adder ] ( URL_0 ) in Logisim whose job is to add two single inputs ( 1 or 0 ) and determine their sum . From the full adder you can build a 4 - bit adder ( which can add two numbers as big as 15 ) , etc . The possibilities are huge !']

id: How do gamers mod their video games Seen tons of photos of video games with mods and I 've wondered how it 's done . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['SDK ( source development kits ) , modding tools , 3D design tools , audio production software and many other means . To explain it in detail would overwhelm you .', 'Developers will make their own tools or at least have their files in a format that can be edited without special software . Modders will do mclitch said and either use tools given by the devs or use third party software to make assets for their mod . Then they import the assets into the game or they replace the files with custom files .', 'These are all good answers . As for how mods are applied and used : if you \'re a total newbie in this regard , here \'s the shortish answer : For years , applying mods had to be done by copying modified files into the game \'s directories , on your hard disk . Usually , some files would be overwritten with altered versions , to implement the mod . As long as you had instructions , it is n\'t difficult . Now , many Steam games use the unified " Steam Workshop " system , which lets you " subscribe " to mods , with a single click .']

id: How do people solve rubix cubes in < 10 seconds ? Edit : Rubik 's , my bad . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Rubik 's cubes are actually solved with a formula , or simple set of rules . Once you know those rules by heart , it just becomes a matter of applying them in the most efficient way ( to minimize the number of moves required ) and then moving your hands very , very quickly . Those with good memories for images can actually look at the cube once then put on a blindfold and solve it from memory . EDIT : Rubix - > Rubik 's , got it .", '20 second solver here . We solve the first two layers by intuition , and then orient and permute the last layer by recognizing the patterns and performing memorized algorithms . This method is called CFOP ( * * C**ross , * * F**2L ( first two layers ) , * * O**LL ( orientation of last layer ) , * * P**LL ( permutation of last layers ) ) . There are other methods too , but to the largest degree , CFOP is the most widely used among speedcubers . Come check out /r / cubers if you have more questions .', "The less than 10 seconds part is just executing the plan to get the cube finished . They look at the cube for much longer than 10 seconds before they pick it up . There 's where they actually solve it . They figure out all the moves ahead of time , then it 's just a matter of executing those moves really quickly ."]

id: How does a key fob authenticator work ? How does this offline device generating random numbers grant access to bank accounts etc ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["They 're not entirely random numbers . The way it works , to simplify it a lot , is that each token starts with a unique seed number , and then that number is run though a complicated encryption algorithm which generates the next number , and run through it again which generates the next , and again for the next and so on . This is done every thirty seconds or one minute . The token has an internal timer that increments the number . Basically what that means is , if the central database knows your token 's seed , and it knows the encryption algorithm , and most importantly , it has an accurate time source , it knows what number your token should be displaying right now . There 's no actual link between your token and anything , it 's a totally self - contained device . It 's just something you have to physically have in order to have access to your accounts . So it adds an extra layer of security . Someone might have your computer , and have your password , but without the key fob too , they ca n't get in . The classic three level security mantra is something you know , something you have , something you are . Something you know is a password , something you have might be this key - fob authenticator just for an example , and something you are is a bit less common ; biometric stuff like iris scans or fingerprint recognition , or voice recognition . Three is ideal , but two is better than one .", 'Basically the device has a secret password inside of it that the server also knows . Rather than ever show that actual password , the device runs some math on it , using the current time as a variable , that produces an output . The server does the same math to check if you gave the right password for that time . This way , you never have to memorise anything , and you have to have that piece of hardware to be able to properly authenticate . It can not be scraped with a keylogger , because it quickly changes .', 'Math ... It does a calculation based on the code you entered on the service you are using it for and also does something with that number and the current time . The code changes about every 90 seconds depending on the interval set . Example : your code 123456 X 91700(9:17am ) that code will work during that whole minute . After that minute the code will change . It can be more complicated than that but as long as both sides know the algorithm and the secret code the codes will be the same at the same time .']

id: How do browsers make money ? I 'm talking about the browsers themselves , not the sites ( like Google or YouTube , which get their profits from ads ) . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["A lot of people search using the browser 's default search provider . Almost all of Firefox 's revenue came from Google paying them for searches done from Firefox ( they recently switched to Yahoo as the default search provider ) .", "Chrome , by itself , does n't make money , being funded by the rest of Google . What it does is tie people into Google 's infrastructure ( by making it easy ) which improves Google 's overall profits .", 'Browsers are not necessarily supposed to make money . They can serve the company \'s goals in more strategic ways . Google wants the internet to be faster , because if ads load faster , people click on them more . Google \'s browser , Chrome , is one of the things that Google does to try and make the Internet faster . Originally , their goal was just to give other browser vendors a kick in the ass to make their own browsers faster , which they have . Since Chrome has become so popular , they use it to promote other technologies that make the Internet faster or cheaper , like SPDY ( HTTP2 ) and WebM. Microsoft and Apple make Internet Explorer and Safari , respectively . These browsers are basically extensions of their respective operating systems , and their primary purpose is to make their operating systems more fully - featured . Windows has a browser just so that you ca n\'t say " Windows does n\'t even have a browser ! " Microsoft used to use IE to push its own technologies as development platforms for internet and intranet applications ( VBScript , ActiveX , XmlHttpRequest , etc ) but they \'ve backed off from that , and right now just want to be able to say that out - of - the - box Windows is the only software you need . I \'m less familiar with Safari , but I assume it \'s basically the same : OS X has a browser so that you can say it has a browser . Mozilla is a non - profit organization that wants to make the web open and accessible ( something about democratization of information ) . Firefox makes money by renting out its search box to search providers . This money is used to fund development of the browser to be open and extensible , and other web - related technologies that are not necessarily browser - based ( like Persona ) . Opera is the biggest company that \'s a traditional company , and actually makes money off of its web browser . It used to be ad - supported with a subscription model to remove ads , but it went free several years ago . After that , they made money by licensing their web browser for embedded use ( e.g. the Wii browser was based on Opera ) . The consumer - usable web browser also made money by renting out its search box like Firefox did , but was also a showcase for the engine that the company licensed out .']

id: How do currency markets work? What factors are behind why currencies go up or down?
text: ['According to Soros in "The Alchemy of Finance", exchange rates fluctuations are mostly influenced by: (sorry I do not have the quote here, and I am paraphrasing from the top of my head what I read about a week ago). I mention his point of view as he is one of the most successful hedge fund manager ever, proved his skills, and dealt a lot with currencies. This is not just theory as he actively used the above points when managing his fund (as explained in the book). What I find interesting is that, according to him, the fundamental reason (the balance of trade) is not the most influential. Speculation on future value of currencies is the most influential, and these can set trends that can last years. Also it is key to notice that Soros thought foreign exchange markets are "wrong" most of the time, just like he thought stock markets are "wrong" most of the time (a point on which Warren Buffet and Jim Rogers also agree from my understanding).']

id: How does / do welfare , unemployment and social services negatively effect the US economy ? And ... How does / do welfare , unemployment and social services positively effect the US economy ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Textbook economics can answer both sides : It would effect the economy positively because it puts money into the hands of people who will spend it . ( If you 're on welfare , you 're probably going to spend most of the money you get . If you 're wealthier , you 'll save more of it and your savings will not be spent ) . Spending puts money back into businesses , pays the wages of workers , suppliers , corporate = > growing businesses = > better economy . This is basic macroeconomic Keynesian theory . Main arguments for negative effect : Benefits of receiving welfare / unemployment is better than benefit of working , thus people decide not to work = > lose labor , costs more to maintain welfare Money could be better spent elsewhere ( investment into infrastructure ) Taxes for welfare damages businesses Not trying to lean the issue one way or the other , these are the main arguments I 've heard for both sides .", "It 's impossible to answer this question objectively .", '\' bikes \' did a great job breaking it down , so I wo n\'t duplicate . Both views have applicability , but neither are universally and unconditionally correct . There are conditions in which either view may be more or less valid . The problem is , these views have been codified into ideology ; a secular religion . No assimilation and analysis of new data is possible . The conditions we live under today are heavily skewed to the supply side . We are in the late stages of " The crisis of capital accumulation " , just prior to system collapse . Moving more money to capital will only hasten the collapse .']

id: How do seeds work in games ? I mean , how can a few numbers decide billions of things in a generated world ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['> I mean , how can a few numbers decide billions of things in a generated world ? I \'m going to give you not " a few " numbers , and not " billions " of things , but one number that can generate infinite things : 1 . Start at 0 . Add 1 . Get 1 . Add 1 . Get 2 . Add 1 . Get 3 . Add 1 . Get 4 . Keep going . Let \'s take a more complicated example , and limit it to a certain range of numbers ( 0 through 9 ) , like the random numbers on a computer would be ( 0 through 2 ^ 64 - 1 or some such ): Add 3 and then take the modulus 10 . Start at 0 . Plus 3 mod 10 , get 3 . Plus 3 mod 10 , get 6 . Plus 3 mod 10 , get 9 . Plus 3 mod 10 , get 2 . Then 5 , then 8 , then 1 , then 4 , then 7 , then 0 again . Obviously those examples ( even the " more complicated " one ) are * much * less complicated than the algorithm that a random number generator is using . But I hope they suffice to show that there \'s no reason a small set of rules ca n\'t provide a large number of results .', 'Randomness in a computer is really a lot of math . With anything math , if you start with the same numbers and do the same equasions , you get the same results . A seed is just a starting number . From there you do all the math to generate your variables for your world . If anyone else uses that same seed , the computer is doing all the same equasions so you get the same world . So say I need the height of a mountain . It has a max of 64 . So I could take your seed " Pidii " and convert that to binary . 01010000 01101001 01100100 01101001 01101001 I can then convert this to a number . 345,365,571,945 I could do a bunch of stuff now . Like take only the last three numbers 945 and use a fancy bit of math like modulo 64 . So count to 64 and if I hit 64 , start again at 1 until I do this 945 times . This gives me a number between 1 and 64 . In this case 53 . So my mountain will be 53 units high from the ground . If I did this with another word or number , I get a whole different result . So it looks all very random and different . But if anyone puts in Pidii . They do all the same math and get a mountain 53 units high .', "I believe you 're asking about setting a ' seed ' correct ? To start with there is no such thing as a ' random number generator ' in computing . All it really is , is a long list of numbers that get stored somewhere . If it looks something like 5 8 3 7 9 2 4 3 .... Now when you generate a world it 'll start at 5 for it 's first chunk of map , maybe 5 means a rock . Then it reads 8 for a tree etc ... Now let 's say you only need 2 items ( your rock and tree ) the next time you generate a map it 'll pick up where it left off so now it 's 3 ( a river ) and 7 a bug . ' Setting a seed ' lets you pick a specific spot to start reading from , it allows you to basically regenerate the same ' random ' map over and over instead of picking up where you left off . I 'll let someone else describe what a procedurally generated map is which is the next step of your question ."]

id: How do competitive eaters fit all the food they eat in their stomach ? Just watched Matt Stonie down 61 hotdogs in 10 minutes . The dude is 5'8 and has a normal frame where does it all go ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['You eat massive amounts in training and it stretches out your stomach . The stomachs of competitive eaters are much more elastic than normal people .', 'Competitive eaters eat mass quantities of lettuce to expand their stomachs and take in minimal calories .', "I 'm pretty sure iv seen interviews where eaters say they do n't always digest the food , so it 's not just their stomach they 're filling up , it 's being pushed straight into their intestines , meaning they get whole bits of food come out the other end"]

id: How do we all not have cancer ? With the rate of genetic mutations , and the rate the body produces new cells , how do we not all develop cancer early on in life ? How does the body defend against new cancer cells ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['I was under the assumption that we have potential cancerous cells produced every day but our immune system combined with cell duplication checks usually destroy them before they replicate .', 'Our bodies have 3 " check points " during our cellular reproduction . These checkpoints must either be met or the cell \'s reproduction process is shut down or the cell will be destroyed by a white blood cell . Our DNA also contains repair enzymes that go through and fix a lot of the mistakes in our genetic coding which fixes most mutations although some always get through .', 'If we all lived long enough then everyone would get cancer eventually . On a long enough timeline it is a statistical guarantee because our cells are constantly dividing . Like a computer program running long enough , eventually a glitch of some sort manifests itself .']

id: How do ships navigate ? Do they use radio Navaids like aircraft ? Also , is traffic controlled like aircraft , or is it just " see and avoid " ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["These days , GPS has largely replaced the older systems like LORAN and manual plots . Radio beacons are still in use for some special purposes but with GPS being so cheap and accurate now they 're pretty much obsolete . Aircraft , in general , also use GPS these days . Busy commercial ports generally have a harbormaster to direct traffic and buoys are , of course , still used .", "See and avoid . There is no equivalent of IFR that would allow you to operate at full speed in fog , basically because surface radar is n't good enough to avoid small boats . Many ports have pilots - people who will boat out and navigate your ship for you . This service is usually required for large commercial ships .", 'They have GPS now , so it tells them where they are supposed to go and which areas are too shallow and they should avoid . Once you get in a harbor they have tugboats to help navigate the turns which might be too tight .']

id: How do people smell whiskey / scotch ? All I can really smell when i drink a glass of scotch / whiskey / bourbon is pure alcohol . How do these connoisseurs distinguish the specific smells ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["As an exercise , go and buy yourself a bottle of 100 % grain alcohol , and then buy the cheapest whiskey / scotch you can find , and taste them side - by - side . I 'm pretty sure you 'll taste a difference . Note : Alcohol consumption may lead to alcoholism , pregnancy , or a good time .", 'It \'s something that develops over time . I \'d use wine for an example but I do n\'t drink wine so I \'ll use soda instead . I can blindly open up a can of Coke and a can of Dr Pepper and immidiatly tell the difference between the two . Going even further , as far as cola is concerned , I easily tell the difference between Coke , Pepsi , RC or store brand . Some people can do that with whiskey . My sister , who does n\'t drink much soda , would open the cans and only smell " soda " in the same way you just smell alcohol .', "It depends on the type and quality of the whisky . If you are drinking cheap - ish stuff then it probably does n't smell like much more than ethanol , even to experienced drinkers . Blended whiskys can also suffer from this , as the subtleties in each whiskey can mask each other unless it is very well blended . But some whiskys smell very noticeable . A nice single malt from Islay , for instance , smells unmistakably peaty , and bourbons can smell quite strongly of the wooden barrel , be it oak or hickory or whatever . Like all these things , the more whisky you drink , and the more types you experience , the more you 'll be able to tell the difference . [ Relevant xkcd . ] ( URL_0 )"]

id: How do sail boats go faster than the wind ? The Americas Cup sailboats can go nearly 2 times windspeed . How do they go faster than the wind is blowing them ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["They are actually sailing parallel to the wind and/or upwind , which is not with the flow of the wind . The sails act like a wing , creating lift which is counteracted by the keel to result in forward motion . Since they are sailing into the wind , they never outrun the wind , instead as they go faster , the apparent wind speed increases . Sailing straight downwind ( with the wind ) , you ca n't go faster than the wind .", 'The common way that a lot of people think of a sail is as if it were a big parachute . With this conceptualization you have a big sheet of cloth and the wind pushes it from behind . This kind of sailboat can only go as fast as the wind pushes it . However , that \'s the wrong mental picture . The goal of a sail is actually to get the wind to move along the sail , like the air moves over the wing of an aircraft . Just as an aircraft gets lift from its wings a sailboat gets " lift " from its sail , but that " lift " is directed forward instead of up . This approach does not limit the speed of the boat to the speed of the wind . It even allows the boat to sail nearly directly upwind .', 'There are two basic ways a sail can drive a boat onward . 1 . If the wind is coming from behind , or at not too big an angle behind , the boat , then the sail is trimmed ( basically , aimed ) so that the wind fills the sail from behind . The wind pushes the boat along , as you \'d expect . If the boat were to reach the speed of the wind , any further increase in the boat \'s speed would cause the wind to start pushing it * back * . So , in that configuration , the boat ca n\'t go faster than the wind . 2 . Once the wind is more than about 45 degrees off from the stern ( rear ) of the boat , though , the sail is trimmed such that the * front edge * of the sail is pointing into the wind . The wind is now flowing * along * the sail on both sides of it . As the boat turns further and further towards the wind , the sail gets pulled in further and further , so that its front edge is aimed into the wind and the wind is flowing along both sides . This works until the boat is heading about 45 degrees upwind - that is , the wind is coming in at a 45 degree angle off the bow ( front ) of the boat . How the sail works in this case , I \'ll explain a bit further down . 3 . When the boat is pointing closer than 45 degrees into the wind , that will stop working . You can no longer get the right sail shape , and the wind will just push against the boat and slow it down and eventually stop it . So the people in other comments saying you can sail almost directly upwind are mistaken . You ca n\'t practically sail very close to directly upwind , you have to be a significant angle off . This is why , when boats are trying to get directly upwind , you \'ll see the zigzag , and you \'ll notice each zig and zag is approximately a 90 degree turn - because they \'re close to 45 degrees off the wind in one direction , and then the other , as they work their way upwind . So , how does the sail work when the boat is pointing somewhere between about 45 degrees upwind and 45 degrees downwind ? It \'s all about the shape of the sail . Imagine yourself looking down on the boat from directly above the mast . The wind is blowing the sail into a sort of billow form . If it could , the wind would blow the sail all the way straight in whatever direction the wind is going , like a flag , but it ca n\'t . A sail is not like a flag in a very important way - the bottom of it is attached to a big straight bar , called the boom . So the sail must stay straight at the bottom , all the way to the rear corner . But , and this is just as important , the sail is n\'t a plain flat triangle either . It has a bunch of extra fabric ; it \'s bigger in the middle than is needed to fill the space between the lines if it were just flat . So there \'s extra material to billow out , and the wind , trying to blow the sail off to the side , turns it into a curve . Because of the shape of the sail and how much extra material is in which parts , the sail forms a shape with a sharper ballooning out right at the front , and a shallower curve towards the rear . If you \'re looking at this from above , this shape looks very much like what the cross - section of an airplane wing looks like from the side . It works in the same way . I \'m not going to fully ELI5 how that works right here , but the simplest way to imagine it is that the wind creates * suction * on the rear side of the sail . Think of it like this , sort of : Along the inside of the sail \'s curve , the side in the direction the wind is coming from , the wind is directly hitting the sail and being curved by it . So here , the wind is partly pushing against the sail . But on the outside of the sail \'s curve , the side away from the direction the wind is coming from , the wind going past the mast would just keep on moving past where the sail is , except that direction of motion of the air would pull some air away from the sail . It causes the wind to curve in towards the sail after it has passed it , but it \'s not actually blowing against the sail , it \'s still blowing kind of away from the sail . It \'s pulling air away from the sail . It \'s creating a kind of suction , sucking the sail in that direction . It \'s pulling the sail towards the direction in which it \'s billowing . Now , you might \'ve noticing , looking down at the boat from above , that this direction the wind is sucking the sail towards is n\'t actually directly towards the front of the boat . And you \'re right - if the boat were flat on the bottom , it would start sliding partly sideways , partly forward . But sailboats have something called a keel ( if it \'s permanently fixed ) or centerboard ( if it \'s made to slide into and out of the water ) , which sticks out from the bottom of the boat deep into the water . This keel is a thing but wide blade shape that allows the boat to easily slide forward or backward , but presents a lot of resistance against sliding sideways . So all of the sideways component of the force coming from the sail gets wasted pushing water against the side of the keel / centerboard , but the forward component of the force from the sail moves the boat forward . Even though the boat is actually being pushed at an angle sideways - forward , it only moves forward . Now here \'s the most important part for answering your question : This motion of the wind along the sail on both sides , creating a force that sucks the sail towards where it \'s billowing ... this force is going to keep on being there as long as the wind is flowing along the sail . It does n\'t matter how fast the boat is moving . This force is stronger when the wind is faster , and this force weakens when the wind is slower , but this force is not affected at all by how fast the boat is moving ! It \'s the same amount of suction - force on a boat standing still , or on a boat slowly , or a boat moving fast . If the boat happens to be moving at a speed that happens to be higher than the speed of the wind ? So what ? There \'s no relationship , per se , between the speed of the wind and the speed of the boat in that sense . The only relationship is that the speed of the wind determines how much suction - force acceleration is being applied to the boat . In theory , this could eventually accelerate the boat to " infinite " speed ( well , eventually relativity and speed of light limitations start to matter :) , as long as the wind kept flowing along the sides of the sail like that . It does n\'t , of course , because there \'s drag on the boat . That is , resistance to its forward motion , mainly from the water , though somewhat from air too . For any specific amount of forward suction - force , there \'s a maximum speed it can get the boat to , where the amount of force from water and air resistance is equal to amount of forward force from the sail \'s suction , and the boat stops getting any faster . Obviously , the stronger the wind , the faster the boat can go before reaching that point , because the stronger the wind , the stronger the suction - force from the sail . But the point is , that maximum speed is * not * determined by a comparison of the boat \'s speed and the wind \'s speed . Rather , it \'s determined by the relationship between the amount of suction - force you can get from that particular size & shape of sail at whatever the current speed of the wind is , vs. the amount of resistance on the boat ( determined by its mass and design ) . Of course skill matters too , because the boat wo n\'t actually get the true maximum force from the sail . How close it is to the maximum possible , depends on how well the sailors trim the sail to just the right point , and keep up with changes in wind direction , with a combination of subtly steering the boat and moving the sail in or out .']

id: How do languages whose word meanings rely on rising and falling pitches , such as Chinese , deal with singing ? Does the pitch of the melody of the song affect the meanings of the words , or at least make it more difficult to understand ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["the same way . when someone sings , you just shift everything appropriately . and also , even if you use the wrong tone people still know what you 're talking about .", 'ìëíì¸ì ! In Korean , many words sound the same . Actually , most verbs have very similar sounds due to the conjunctions having similar endings ; however , in lyrical form , Korean is not as challenging as you may think . The Korean language is very reliant on particles and conjugated words creating context . So if a few words sound similar , you intuitively connect the particles and conjunction and it makes sense . Also , popular culture has created words in Korean to help distinguish context . For instance , a word to say " you " is " ë¤ " which sounds like " neh " while the word to say " My " can be " ë´ " which sounds like " Neh " so to avoid confusion , " You " becomes " ë " or " Nee " and My is stressed more as " Nay " or " ë´ " Thus when singing " I love you , " you sing ëê° ì¬ëí´ ( ì¬ëí´ = love ) and no one thinks you love something you own . They know that you are referring to the person you are speaking to .', 'Chinese traditional vocal music is sung in falsetto , and is in harmony , not melody . Tones do not affect the nature of the music overmuch . Modern C - pop is a different matter of course . Context is key ; missing a word or two could cause you to lose the meaning . I know it does with me from time to time ; sometimes I just guess at it whilst I listen .']

id: How does a citizens arrest work ? I keep hearing about it , but I 'm not sure what gives someone the legal right to do this , or or under what circumstance . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Essentially it 's the citizen 's right to detain someone that has obviously broken the law until the authorities arrive . It can range from a security guard detaining a trespasser until the cops show up , to a homeowner locking a burglar in the pantry , to my personal favourite of a concerned citizen using a zip - tie to essentially handcuff a guy who left a kid and dog in his truck on a hot day . For the most part , if you stop a criminal that you know is committing a crime , without using excessive force , then it 's unlikely that there are going to be any charges pressed .", "* * In Canada * * , you may only make a citizen 's arrest if you find someone who is / has ( i ) escaping from police ( ii ) committed an indictable offence ( more serious offence , like a felony in the US ) or ( iii ) having committed any crime against your property , property you are in possession of , or property in which the owner has given you the authority to protect ( think mall security ) . From the URL_0 site : In most cases , you must find a person either in the act of committing a crime , or escaping from and freshly pursued by persons who have lawful authority to arrest that person , in order to lawfully make a citizen 's arrest . In particular , if you are arresting a person for an indictable offence , which is the most serious type of offence and includes violent offences , you can only make the arrest at the time you witness the person committing the offence . It is against the law to arrest a person after any lapse in time for having committed an indictable offence , unless it is relation to your property . Extreme care should be taken while making a citizen 's arrest .", 'How Stuff Works . Com has a great podcast on it and they make it really easy to understand :)']

id: How do golf rangefinders with " slope " work ? I am looking into purchasing a golf rangefinder . How does this piece of equipment determine the slope and change the distance based on that ? How does the thing know that there is slope ? Thanks . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["You can actually make a primitive slope measuring tool for very cheap , and by doing so it might help you understand the principles behind why a golf rangefinder can measure slope and use it to change distance . First , you could use a plastic protractor , or [ print one online ] ( URL_0 ) . Next , tie a piece of string with a weight on the end to the center of the long , straight part . If you put the long edge right at eye level , then look at an object above or below your eye level , you 'll notice that the string will hang and align with a number . That number is a measure of the angle from level of the object you 're looking at . So if you 're looking at a flag pin that 's 10 degrees lower than you , the string will align with the number 10 on the protractor . The angle is essentially the slope of the hole . Now imagine that there 's a triangle formed . When you 're looking out from the protractor ( or the rangefinder ) , your gaze essentially forms the hypotenuse of a right triangle . By knowing the angle of that hypotenuse and knowing the distance of the hypotenuse , it 's very easy to calculate what the length of the hole is . While rangefinders do n't use string and a protractor , they have other ways of measuring the same exact thing . They have built in computers that do the same calculations that you could do in our example .", 'It has a gravity sensor in it , much like the one in your phone that works the " level " function . It measures the angle up that you are pointing it , and with its distance measurement it can calculate other parameters , like hot far above you the pin is .', 'Some of the older range finders assumed certain pin heights . It made the analog math / legend easy to just print directly onto the device :) With new ones ? Lasers I assume .']

id: How does a stalker change from " loving " someone to wanting to kill him / her ? Do n't understand how these people say that they are in love and suddenly they change and begin sending bombs or even murdering their " loved one " . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Stalking is n\'t actually about " love " . It \'s about having a connection to a person , and in many cases , having influence or control over that person . The stalker places a lot of personal value on that interpersonal connection . ( " I need them in my life " ) If a friendly or romantic connection is refused or ends , then the connection is threatened . Any connection , any contact , even hostile or threatening contact , keeps the object of a stalker \'s attention in their life . To a stalker , being hated is n\'t as good as being loved , but it \'s far far better than being ignored . Many stalking tactics are about forcing the victim to interact with the stalker . ( call over & over again , showing up at their workplace , sending packages without a return address ) Being able to control their victim , in any way at all , gives a feeling of power . The stalker would prefer to be loved , but if they can make their victims feel afraid , that \'s still a form of influence and power .', "I think their thought process is : If I ca n't have them ( and I know I ca n't have them , since I 've tried multiple , multiple times ) then no one can . And then they try to kill them so that no one else can have them either .", 'Stalking is about control . Despite the terminology being incredibly overused in the current social state ( like alcoholism , addiction , insanity , OCD , etc ) , there are very specific factors that categorize someone as a legitimate stalker . This is not to say if someone \'s being a weird asshole , you should n\'t seek legal help - let us be clear on that . But Stalking is specifically about control . Typically speaking , if you \'re stalking someone , chances are , you have tendencies toward a personality disorder ( anti - social , disassociative , etc ) In your specific example , of a stalker , " loving , " someone and then eventually wanting to kill them is typically a control thing . Stalking usually starts small , with frequent phone calls throughout the day , then multiple calls at once multiple times a day , to showing up at the victims \' work place , cornering them in public to cause social anxiety to force them in to contact , etc . The key factor here is fear . The , " love , " portion of this comes from an obsession of bond - there \'s a thing about this victim that causes the stalker to become obsessed . Sometimes , it \'s her career . Her hair color . Etc . There \'s really no end to the potential triggers - it depends on the stalker . The reason it switches from merely trying to make contact to outright violence is manipulation . Once a stalker can find something to exploit , he will use it to force his victim in to a relationship , contact , etc . Often when it escalates this far , they will use physical violence to control their victim , without intent to kill , but to scare them . If we \'re moving to the stalker killing someone , it \'s usually a psychotic break . Ricardo Lopez , the man who stalked and tried to kill Icelandic musician Bjork , is a great example of this . Ricardo Lopez sent Bjork a letter bomb in the mail that never got to her , and once he found out she started dating someone , things went real south . There \'s a lot online about him , including his VHS journal that \'s straight out of a nightmare , including his suicide . He \'s an extreme example , but he \'s a case often looked to for information and understanding of obsessive stalking . Hoping my ranting helps .']

id: How does Velcro retain its strength through continuous use ? Given the basic hook - loop mechanics , I would think it would become significantly less effective extremely quickly . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["There are a couple factors that explain this . First , most loops do n't find a hook each time the Velcro is sealed . Only a minority of the loops need to find a hook for the Velcro to hold . Second , not every loop tears when you rip apart the Velcro . There are many times more loops on the one side than there are hooks on the other , so this combination of factors gives Velcro an appreciable use\\-life . If you notice your Velcro is getting less sticky , you 'll get more bang for your buck by trying to clean lint out of the hook side first .", 'There are multiple components of Velcro . The expensive type almost virtually designed to never wear off . It uses sides of some plastic polymer that is designed to fuse together like a Zipper but forced with pressure . The other common type is the one side velcro and other part fabric . The more its used the more he fabric starts to wear out overtime . Of course this is the most common and widely used commercially and its fairly durable but surly has a lifetime depending on the frequency of usage . Cheers ,', 'Velcro eventually wears out and stops sticking to itself over time from the small loops breaking or dirt and other things getting inside then loops .']

id: How do calculators figure out the square roots of numbers ? I understand how you can find exponents of numbers by multiplying it by itself that many times , but how do they determine roots of numbers ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['ugh , surprisingly no one anwsered this yet : They do that by fixed point algorithms , which basically means a algorithm that keeps repeating itself and getting closer and closer to the value you want : for example : you give me a number a that you want to know the sqrt . I create a function f(x ) = 1/2*(x+a / x ) . Now if we find a point such as f(x ) = x , we will have x = 1/2*(x+a / x ) - > 2x^2 = x^2 + a - > x = sqrt(a ) . Now if we start on a point ( for example , 1 ) and keep applying f(1)- > f(f(1 ) ) ... and so on . We hope that we find a fixed point ( in that case , we will ) . There are other methods for sqrt and for every sort of mathematical operation , but many of them rely on this concept of findind an f(x ) that when f(x)=x you will find your value .', "Essentially a calculator does the same thing that a human does by hand , but much faster . In order to calculate the square of n , you know that n*n = n^2 . From the opposite perspective , if you want to find the square root of n , you need to find a number , m , such that m^2 = n. The calculator then brute - forces the answer . Example , if you want to find out what sqrt(60 ) is , you know that it has to be between 7 and 8 ( 7 ^ 2 = 49 , and 8 ^ 2 = 64 ) , but much closer to 8 . Thus we go with 7.5 ^ 2 , and see if that = 60 , and then seeing how much close 7.6 ^ 2 is to that . Let 's say that we find that 7.5 ^ 2 < 60 < 7.6 ^ 2 . Then we test for 7.55 ^ 2 and so on and so forth until we come up with the answer .", 'Probably using logarithms . For instance , to do 3^(0.5 ) the calculator will divide the log(3 ) by 2 and then use that as an exponent on the log base to give 3^(0.5 ) .']

id: How does a vending machine differentiate between different types of bills and coins ? For example , how would it know the difference between $ 1 and a $ 5 bill ? Popped up into my head at a self checkout line . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Each of the bills have slightly different details the machine can read . As far as coins , it \'s done by weight and , if you can get a slug the same size / weight as a quarter , you can probably " fool " the machine .', 'Look at the back of bills in IR light . There are bands of ink missing in that light spectrum . The device measures the brightness of reflected IR light as the bill moves through it and can decode the denomination from that info of it getting brighter or darker . Coins are easier to understand . They pass down the slot you put them in , and the slot becomes tilted and has holes just bigger than the ones they want to accept , starting with the smallest , the dime , and moving up to the quarter or dollar coin . There is a switch , either mechanical , or light based that counts each coin . There will be more sophisticated ways to detect counterfeits but that is the original way they differentiate the amounts .', "I do n't know about the dollars , but the change gets funneled into a sorter . The coins are rolled on their edge at a slight angle down a ramp with four holes . Dimes come first , then pennies , then nickels , then quarters . A quarter will roll past the first three holes whereas a dime will immediately fall into the first one . Source : I stock and maintain the vending machines at my work"]

id: How do bookies make money from taking bets ? Maybe I 'm just an idiot , but none of my friends knew why either . Edit : Thanks , that cleared it up ! Good luck in March Madness . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Two ways : the spread , which changes because of the number of people voting one way or the other changes , and the bookies slide the spread one way or the other to encourage the bets one way or another . If you place a bet with a spread , your bet remains the same , but future bets will have a different spread . Let 's say for example you bet $ x that team a will win and they are favored to win by 2 , which means the spread is -2 against you . If the majority of people start betting on the same team as you , the spread may increase and those new betters will see -3 , -4 or more , making it harder for them to win of course . On the contrary , if many begin to vote on the underdog , you will see the spread decrease , or even switch over . The entire system is designed to ensure that more betters end up on the losing side than on the winning . If successful , any betters that win are actually just sharing the money with the house that was lost by the majority , the losing bets . Of course this does n't always work , but so long as it usually works , the house makes a bundle . The other system is odds betting , which is pretty self explanatory as to how the house ends up on top . Tweaked a little from URL_0", 'For the layman , odds betting is paying people according to their bet . Baseball usually uses odds betting . So a bet for team A pays 2/1 and a bet for team B pays 1.5/1 , for example . If you bet $ 5 on team A and they win , you get paid $ 10 , or you make 5 bucks , if you bet 5 bucks on team B and they win , you get paid $ 7.50 . The odds change on based on how much money is bet for each side . Lets keep the odds where they are . Lets say $ 100 is bet on team A and $ 150 is bet on team B. That means that the bookie is collection 250 in payments . If team B wins , the bookie will pay out 225 dollars in prize money ( 150 x 1.5 ) . He keeps the 25 $ for himself . If team A wins , he pays out $ 200 ( 100 x 2 ) meaning he keeps $ 50 for himself . Now , the margins will be smaller , ( no where near 10 % ) and much more symmetrical , the point is that the bookie has put himself into a position where he pays out less than he takes in , regardless of the outcome .', "These other explanations are kind of complex . The essential way , apart from any particular implementation , is that the bookie ( like a casino ) , does not give absolutely fair odds . Every bettor who wins is paid out less money than the true odds would dictate . The rest is kept by the bookie . For example , if you bet $ 50 on a coin toss , you would not get $ 100 if you win . You would get , let 's say , $ 95 . The man running the game gets $ 50 if you lose and pays $ 45 if you win , so he 's guaranteed to win over time . A sports bookie does not run the game himself , but the principle is the same ."]

id: How do captcha systems prevent spam ? Why has no one created a system of spamming around them ? What makes them so much harder to break then normal spam filters ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["They do n't prevent it entirely , but they do cut way down on it by requiring human intervention to interpret the pictures . What makes them harder to break is that there are so many different pictures and formats used that it 's not simple , practical , or profitable to code something that automates the process .", 'The basic idea of a CAPTCHA is being able to tell computers and humans apart ( which , coincidentally , is roughly what the abbreviation means ) . As spam is usually sent by bots and not humans that makes them ( if they work ) very effective in preventing the bulk of spam messages . Tech : Image - captchas rely on the ( until recently ) superior pattern recognition of humans over computers . However recent advances there have greatly diminished that gap and even surpassed humans in some cases . There are also other kinds of patterns , like associating two images with each other ( " drag the umbrella and the bucket in the circle " , " click the two icons that belong together " , and similar stuff ) , where afaik humans are still way superior .', "They 're so messed up , that there is n't a computer program around that can use OCR to understand it . Humans , having much more flexible minds are able to decipher it . The primary way people use to crack these is to put a captcha generator on their site , and have humans decipher it , where the image is stored alongside the correct answer in a database . When spammers want to get into a site , they then run the captacha received against their database until they find a match , then put in the correct answer and away they go . In short , it 's because it 's too abstract for anyone to program ( as humans we can barely read it ) ."]

id: How do restaurants play music ? What do restaurants use to play their never - stopping , commercial - free music ? Pandora ? A CD some employee brought in ? A special frequency radio station ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Pandora has a business version , DMX , that takes care of licensing .', 'They pay a performance rights group , namely ASCAP , BMI , or SESAC , royalties to use that music .', "A lot of them disregard licenses and just use someone 's iPod or laptop . Generally only large corporate chains or very successful independent businesses will bother ."]

id: How does a jet engine work ? Is this different than a rocket engine ? Jet engine as in an airplane , rocket engine as in spacecraft . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Simply , jet engines compress incoming air to create thrust . Rocket engines ca n't depend on oxygen , so they have to have all of the fuels needed to create combustion on board . [ Here 's ] ( URL_0 ) a more in - depth explaination , but what I typed above is the main difference . I 'm an aerospace engineer , so I can answer more questions if you have any .", 'To provide a little more to this discussion , a jet engine is a type of gas turbine . A gas turbine is an engine that works by sucking in air with a fan , compressing it along the way , igniting it , and extracting energy from the exploding gasses . Q : what powers the compression fan ? A : At the exhaust , there is another fan . The fans are connected by a shaft , so the expanding gas at the back of the engine twists the shaft , which turns the compression fan in the front of the engine . Q : So the rest of the gas flies out of the back of the engine , pushing the engine ( and whatever it \'s attached to ) forward . A : Not so fast . Some jet engines , like the ones on passenger airliners and jet fighters , do exactly that . But , you can extract the energy from the combustion in another way ! Q : How ? A : By attaching something else you want to power to that fan shaft ! For example , many helicopters and commercial propeller planes have a linkage to that fan shaft that powers a propeller . Yes , some of the energy goes out the exhaust , but the energy used for propulsion is actually sent to the propeller . Q : Wow , these things sound pretty big ! A : They are ! But you might actually have a very simliar device in your car . A turbocharger is like a jet engine without the combusting gas part- it \'s used to compress air coming into your engine so it can burn more fuel . In fact , some people have even taken old turbochargers out of cars , and turned them into [ jet engines to power go - karts ] ( URL_0 ) ! There \'s another , related engine type called a " ramjet " , used on very high speed military and research aircraft , that move so fast that they do n\'t even need the fan part ( and therefore the exhaust fan ) to operate . A rocket needs to carry oxygen so it can burn its fuel . A ramjet is like a rocket that gets its fuel from the very fast air moving through it . I am not an aerospace engineer .', "* Like you 're five :* * * Me :* * Jetplanes go in the air , and use the wings to fly and keep up . Their engines are only there to make them go fast enough for the wings to work . * * You :* * So why do n't rockets have wings ? * * Me :* * Rockets have to go REALLY fast , to get all the way to outter space . Instead of wings they have shoot flames out their butt to push themselves up . The exploding flames are super powerful and move them WAY fast . * * You :* * So why do n't Jetplanes have rockets instead ? * * Me :* * Rocket fuel is heavy , when you see a big rocket 90 % of it is FUEL ! A Jetplane uses AIR as most of it 's fuel . It gets that air as it flies through the sky . There 's no air in space so rockets ca n't use jets . * * You :* * Okay , so Rockets go in space and they needs heaps of power and ca n't use jets cause there 's no air - and that 's why they 're so big ? * * Me :* * Yup , exactly ! * * You :* * And Jet 's fly in the air , so they suck it in and burn it with a little bit of fuel and then blow out the hot air to push the plane forward and make the wings work ? * * Me :* * You got it buddy - sure you 're only five ?"]

id: How do people with minimum wage jobs get by in cities like NY and LA where the cost of living is so high ? ) ( Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['You work two of them , you live in the cheapest areas , and you live with other people to split the rent .', 'They work 2 or 3 of them , and often live with their parents or with several roommates .', "Hi ! I 'm from New York . You 've gotten some good answers , but maybe I can help go more in - depth . The very first thing to remember is that in more expensive cities , wages rise with cost inflation . Now , it 's not a perfect scale-- most of the cost inflation comes because many people are * very * rich , not necessarily because the poor are less poor . However , it 's still a factor-- there are fewer minimum wage jobs , and/or you 're more likely to get a job whose wages are above the federal minimum . In other words , chances are the same job netting you $ 7.25 in Nebraska will get you around $ 10 in NYC . Now that 's not 100 % true . There are still * some * minimum wage jobs here . How do people get by ? Well , about like anywhere else , I suppose . They do n't get to enjoy many aspects of the city where inflation has taken hold . They do n't get to go out to dinner at the nice restaurants or go drinking in NYC bars . They ca n't go to Whole Foods , they have to go to cheaper grocery stores . They have to curb themselves more , and * * they get government assistance * * like anywhere else . Remember , the farther you go from NYC the cheaper things get , so many times people will live far away from the city if they do n't make a lot . And if they 're living far away from the city , and working a minimum wage job ... they can just as easily find one near where they live . Hence , like I said , there being less minimum wage jobs in the city . It all ... * kinda * evens out . You 're not likely to live in NYC and have a minimum wage job as an adult . Matter of fact I ca n't think of a single minimum wage job I 've had , and I 've made the rounds as a student . Office worker , busboy , waiter , receptionist ... they all paid around $ 10 . And one last thing to remember : The cost of living does n't * have * to be high in this city . It 's totally doable on less money . The reason it seems higher is that it * can * be higher . And most people making very little tend to have a social circle where people make standard ( remember how I said there are n't many minimum wage jobs here ? It 's rare ) So what happens is most of your friends can go do things and spend money where you can't-- so it * seems * like everything has to be so expensive here . But it does n't , really . Like I said earlier , there are cheap places to live , there are cheap restaurants , cheap grocery stores . There are plenty of free activities for entertainment . This city actually caters very well to the poor , it 's just difficult if your social circle is n't as poor as you ."]

id: How do electronic countermeasures work ? And how do they for example jamm guided missiles ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Guided missiles are mostly self guided missiles . A lot of military equipment depends on radio signals . A tank , a jeep , a soldier with a radio pack , are mobile with small radio sets . The enemy can have a very powerful radio transmitter with a directed antenna . It can overpower small portable devices overwhelming the signals they want to receive . The Iranians claim they took over a US drone . They could have transmitted signals on the drones frequency disruptiing US control . Or they could have just shot it down and claimed that . Aircraft will carry countermeasures . aluminum chaff to confuse enemy radar , very hot packages to attract heat seeking missiles and anything else to confuse a missile targeted for them . Submarines will deploy beacons to confuse other craft . Aircraft will trick air to air missile systems to turn on their radars . Other aircraft will target the radars . The US army adopted FM transmission early when it was difficult to receive . Now they use frequency hopping to keep communication secret and the radio stations unlocatable . If a missile were actually being directed with a radio beam the enemy would definitely try to jam the signal . Most cruise missiles guide themselves and do not transmit radio signals .', 'A guided missile is often guided by radar . Radar is like a flashlight made of radio waves : the emitter shoots out a beam of radio waves , and the detector looks for anything " shiny " reflecting those radio waves back . The missile then guides itself toward the shiny object . Electronic jamming of radar is basically blasting a spotlight of radio waves back at the missile . This drowns out the " shiny " signal , so the missile ca n\'t see where it \'s going anymore .', 'The ultimate goal is to throw off the radar of whatever is tracking you . Your antennae receives the pulses from the tracking radar , then the countermeasure algorithm records those pulses and repeats them back at a different rate to mimic as if you were going faster , slower , or in a different direction than you really are . If it works the tracking radar will adjust to where it thinks you are , directing the missile off course .']

id: How do telvision producers " create drama " on reality tv shows . What are the processes involved with generating footage with people who are n't actors ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["As others have said , they find melodramatic , attention - seeking and narcissistic people and then ply them with combinations of alcohol , competition , sexual frustration , personality clashes etc etc . They watch as the dynamics develop and then push the ' storyline ' in certain directions by combining people , choosing activities that they think will generate certain reactions , etc etc . Finally ( but by no means least importantly ) they scour the many hours of footage for clips , reactions , moments etc that they can then edit to present certain characters in certain ways to fit the ' storyline ' . Pretty easy to take a shot of someone looking aggrieved because they , eg , have a headache , and paste that after a shot of someone they ' dislike ' saying something .", 'Most of it has to do with casting . The casting producers have files and files of people who they \'ve seen in the past . They look for character types when they are interviewing ( i.e. " The Redneck , " " The Hot Cheerleader , " etc . ) They pair up character types that will likely have conflict -- for example , the naive , deeply religious Catholic Schoolgirl with the flamboyantly gay San Francisco fashion designer . This takes care of a LOT of the drama right off of the bat . Also , the " not actors " is usually a misnomer -- casting notices are posted on almost all of the actor websites , but actors who have secondary professions ( bartender , office manager , etc . ) are encouraged to use those as their professions . For some things , they will actually do takes -- if they wanted a certain reaction that they did n\'t get , the producers will sometimes step in and reshoot the " scene " . And also , never underestimate the power of a good editor . They can dramatically change the story that is being told by inserting a reaction shot of someone from a different time , etc . It \'s pretty incredible .', 'They select dramatic people , and then have plenty of alcohol available . No joke . On Top Chef , for instance , they usually have contestants " on ice " in a closet for hours with nothing to do but drink , before the big judge \'s table scenes .']

id: How do we know water is made of two hydrogen and one oxygen atom ? Curious about how scientists came to discover this , google did nt help much . EDIT : thank you so much for the help ! Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['You can separate the two elements with an electric current , a 9 volt battery is plenty . It is called electrolysis . Look it up and you can see how to make or buy a small apparatus to do it . Fill two test tubes with the resulting gasses and you can measure the volume of gas , showing that the hydrogen tube has twice the volume of the oxygen tube . You can test the properties of the gasses ( explode the Hydrogen , use the Oxygen to make something burn brighter , etc . )', 'As to how it was discovered - Henry Cavendish first discovered Hydrogen as a byproduct of dropping some zinc in an acid . Then later he found that when you have hydrogen + oxygen + a spark you get water . Then scientists played with the ratios to find 2:1', 'You can prove it with electrolysis . URL_0 Or , combine two parts hydrogen to one part oxygen and you get water with no hydrogen or oxygen left over .']
