id: How do holocaust deniers justify their side of the argument ? I 'm not one of course I 'm just completely baffled as to how it is even a belief , what with all the evidence and the likes . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Surprised this has n't been answered in detail yet , but basically there are two camps . 1 . It never happened at all . It was entirely made up out of whole cloth . 2 . Something happened , but there were not millions killed like the history books say . The numbers are in the thousands . The first camp is much like those who say 9/11 was an inside job or deny the moon landing happened . Any evidence you present them is dismissed because it was clearly falsified . Pictures ? Faked . People 's testimonies ? People lie for all kinds of reasons . The millions of people who are n't here any more ? Migrated other places or the records were doctored . Here is where they tend to blend with the second camp . The second camp says the Holocaust was overblown . I 'm at work so I ca n't look up the actual numbers , but I believe it 's in the tens of millions . That may be low . The second camp says that really that number is in the thousands . These thousands were systematically executed either , but they were POWs and political prisoners . Right or wrong , countries take political prisoners during war and some of those prisoners die . This is basically what happened . The millions who disappeared from the record books ? They migrated elsewhere and are lost to history due to jumbled record keeping during and after the war . Some of them moved to other parts of Europe and Russia and some moved to the US . They were n't killed . They simply moved elsewhere .", 'I ca n\'t believe the responses OP is getting here . It \'s plainly obvious that almost nobody commenting has actually looked at what " Holocaust deniers " actually claim . I \'m not a " holocaust denier " , but If nobody else is going to seriously answer OP \'s question , I will try . To understand why people " deny the holocaust " , you have to actually look at their arguments and evidence rather than instantly dismissing them as crazy or stupid as most of the comments here would have you believe . The term " Holocaust deniers " is also a very misleading term , as the vast majority of these people do not actually deny that the holocaust happened - in the sense that they do not deny that Jews were put in camps , and that many died . Rather , they instead dispute the circumstances and details of this incredibly politicized historical event and come to a different interpretation . From what I understand , Holocaust revisionists generally deny that the Nazi Concentration camps were designed to systematically exterminate people , and claim the " death camps " were actually initially designed as political internment camps , similar to [ camps in the USA for Japanese citizens in WW2 ] ( URL_0 ) . They often mention the Auschwitz swimming pool , Orchestra , theater , sports - field and art activities and ask why they were built for , and used by people who the Nazi \'s intended to simply exterminate . They reference eyewitness quotes and testimony to support their claims(For example , from [ videos like this ] ( URL_1 ) ) . Revisionists also point to the design of the camps , using the blueprints as being clearly ( in their opinion ) , inefficient for mass murder . They claim that the " gas chambers " were used for delousing clothing and bedding and go into great detail on that subject . They also explain away much of the holocaust evidence as having been faked after the fact , [ for example this fake photo ] ( URL_2 ) , which has been in newspapers , magazines , documentaries , and even hit front - page on Reddit several times . ( I did some research , in this specific case it turns out the photo really was faked and even mainstream historians admit it . ) When asked to explain why so many died in the camps , they often talk about the mass bombing of farms , railways and roads by allied forces nearing the end of the war - meaning that almost no supplies reached the German people , let alone the camps - resulting in many camp inhabitants dying of starvation and disease . WW2 is an incredibly complex topic , made even more difficult to analyze because of the propaganda used by both sides at the time . Again - To understand why people question the holocaust , you have to actually ask those people ( or watch their videos on Youtube ) . You wo n\'t get a truthful , or even interesting answer here on Reddit . I fully expect to be down - voted for this , because people here are more interested in circle - jerking and making holocaust / nazi puns than learning or understanding . Hope this answers your question though OP .', "It is funny when people post stuff like this . When Holocaust revisionists actually come and try and give a detailed answer for their views and explain why they believe a different narrative , their comment is deleted and they are banned . And than the only thing left is comments of people who do n't understand revisionism at all and try to explain what it is . The top comment especially . OP wo n't get any answers here ."]

id: How do people justify not making police have cameras ? If both police AND criminals act less aggressive when they know they 're being filmed , why is it not law yet ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Expense and privacy concerns . If a police officer has a camera on him at all times he 's basically a walking CCTV camera and so that brings up all sorts of privacy issues . People walking by that he does n't have reasonable suspicion to stop and ask for ID could still be IDed by a facial recognition system looking at that video feed . I still lean towards requiring them , but the privacy issues should be hashed out first . Is this footage going to be public ? Available to the police ? Only available to internal affairs ? Totally secret and only opened at a judge 's order ?", "In many places they are already required . As for the places that do n't require it I think they 're going to find it harder to hide behind things like cost . It prevents lawsuits and helps protect officers from false accusations while also meeting a growing demand for accountability regarding officer behavior .", "It 's expensive and not as necessary as TV seem to imply ."]

id: How do superchargers make cars go faster ? Or why ? Wondering how and why they work . Mostly why . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Put simplistically , the power from an engine is made from the combustion of fuel and air . A supercharger compresses the incoming air , allowing more to enter the engine . More fuel is added to the engine via the fuel injectors , and the two combined combust to create more power than would have otherwise been made .', 'Supercharger sucks more air + more gas = more power', 'A supercharger is driven by a belt on the connected to the engine . A car without a supercharger or turbocharger has to suck air in , this is called naturally aspirated . With a super charger the air is being compressed and fed into the engine . This is why turbo and superchargers are called " Forced Induction " .']

id: How does Greek Fire burn underwater when normal fire does n't ? It just seems magical that this type of fire has distinctively different properties than that of normal fire , what 's the reason behind that ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Greek fire was probably a mixture of crude oil and some other substances . It was basically like early napalm . However there are substances that can ' burn ' * because * of water . Quicklime , which was available at the time , quickly achieves temperatures above 150^o C ( 302^o F ) when it gets wet .", 'Some materials , such as sodium metal , react strongly with water . They must have mixed one such material into the naphtha ( which is just light crude oil ) .', "It 's made of KNO3 , ( an oxidizer- 2KNO3 -- > K2O + N2 + 2O2 ) , and an and an organic fuel . It has it 's own oxygen in the compound ."]

id: How do people make money with websites ? I 'm particularly interested in blog - type websites to narrow it down a bit . Please exclude websites that sell goods or services . Thanks :) Explain like I'm five.
text: ["My web site has provided virtually all my own income for over ten years now . This income has come overwhelmingly from ad revenue and contributions / donations from visitors . However , I 've recently begun spinning off some ebook editions of my content as well , both as an additional revenue channel , and as a convenience option for my visitors . For quite a few years I maintained an array of special purpose blogs , many devoted the the problems and upkeep of particular computer models I used , one to my own health maintenance , and more . However , I have n't updated most of those for a long time now ; but they still bring in ad revenue none the less , as they contain problems and solutions for specific things someone somewhere still needs . I also have how to guides , like for troubleshooting Mac OS X , or creating your own Kindle ebooks , etc . I offer my own personal research compilations too , such as what the next 4000 years of human history might be like , and what the true state of alien civilizations in our galaxy probably is .", "Truth is , a lot of people do n't make any money . You 've got to have something people want to see , and way to get eyeballs on your content . It 's very possible to spend money trying to get eyeballs on your content and never make any of the money back .", "Giigu explained it perfectly , but a little FYI about ad revenue . Do n't expect to become rich by having a few hundred or even a few thousand people visiting your site . You need hundreds of thousands of unique daily page views before you will generate any significant ad revenue . But , once you 're at those levels , the pay - off is fairly well . The best way to profit from a website is to take money from users through either donations , merchandise or premium features . This is why I suspect reddit does n't deploy ads but offers reddit gold . Though , if the owners of reddit were really smart , they 'd allow users to choose to activate google or project wonder ads on that nice 200x200 pixel banner off on the right as a way to bring in additional financially support the site ."]

id: How does a company benefit from offering tuition reimbursement ? There has to be something in it for them . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["In theory , it provides them with more educated , qualified employees . In practice , it 's a benefit that has more value to employees than the cost to the company . Educational benefits tend to be highly valued by potential ( or current ) employees because they imagine themselves using them to further their education . However , very few employees actually end up using them , so the company rarely has to shell out much .", 'There are a number of benefits : 1 ) Better educated / trained employees are more productive 2 ) Offing such a program draws more / better quality candidates to openings 3 ) It gives them captive access to high demand skills , often below market rate -- companies almost always have requirements that workers stay with company for a certain amount of time after getting a degree . So the company basically knows that they have you locked up for 2 - 3 years , and any pay bump they may give for your new skills / degree are often less than if you were to search for a job on the open market . Say you spend 3 years getting an MBA . Maybe average pay is $ 125k for your classmates , but your company only bumps you up from $ 80k to $ 100k . And they know you have to stay for 3 years at that lower pay .', "Most directly , it 's a benefit they can offer to potential employees , possibly attracting a better quality of employee than they might otherwise offer . There 's also the possibility that employees with further education will be better employees for the company , without the company needing to offer that training . How strong a benefit that is for the company may vary , but the rule of thumb is that all education is a benefit ."]

id: How do speakers virtually produce any sound ? From my understanding speakers are made up of some vibrating cone of a fixed shape . It just seems to me that such a thing could only produce one sound like a drum . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['It \'s the * way in which it vibrates * that counts . Different sounds are made from different pitches and amplitudes . Pitch is determined by how fast the speaker vibrates , and amplitude is determined by how " hard " it vibrates . When your computer pumps music to your speakers , it is really pumping a voltage waveform . This waveform represents the sound of the music ( it \'s what the music looks like on the computer , with the wavy lines ) . The waveform represents different sounds with changes in frequency ( pitch ) and amplitude ( loudness ) . Now , inside the speaker is the cone , a solenoid ( solenoids turn into magnets when current runs through them ) and a permanent magnet . When a voltage is applied to the solenoid , it becomes a magnet , the solenoid and permanent magnet move each other , and the cone ( attached to the solenoid ) moves . In fact , if you wanted , the computer could send a signal to the speaker that would make it move the cone once , then hold this position . Whatever voltage waveform is pumped to the speaker , the speaker will move accordingly . So , for example , if the voltage waveform is a perfect sine wave , the speaker cone will move like a sign wave . Incidentally , this movement will cause the air surrounding the cone to move in a sine wave and produce a single pitch . In the whole process , the music waveform is converted to a voltage waveform , which electromagnetically moves the cone in the same waveform , reproducing the sound . So , by changing the frequency of the voltage waveform , you change how fast the speaker vibrates and change the pitch ( i.e the sound ) made by the speaker .', 'Your * [ eardrum ] ( URL_0 ) * is a thin membrane that translates the sound emanating from * any * source into the audible sensations you hear . A microphone is very similar : a delicate membrane that vibrates in response to the sound waves in the air , producing an electrical signal that can be recorded . A speaker does that in reverse : producing the frequencies that have been recorded . As an experiment , try the record + paper cup project : URL_1', 'Suprisingly enough ; * * * magnets * * * URL_0 The tone is dependent on the speed of the vibrations , slow = low fast = high . From there its a matter of how loud the speaker is . The further apart the oscillations are ( the space between the top movement and the bottom movement of the speaker part ) the louder the noise will be . Much like you vocal chords , the faster/(in this case ; more air = greater oscillations ) the difference in pitch and volume will be . Also the shape of your throat will make a differece too , much like the difference in speakers : URL_1']

id: How do animals hibernate for so long ? How do some animals manage to hibernate for so long without needing to poop or eat . Also , do they wake up in the middle of their hibernation sessions or not ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["I can answer the poop part of your question . Bears eat tons of grass prior to hibernation to form a butt plug . This keeps them from defecating . I 'm sure other animals have a similar mechanism .", "I do n't know about the pooping part , but I can explain the eating part . Essentially , what controls how fast your body utilizes food and stored fat is called metabolism , normally this is a fairly decent pace . However , bears eat loads before hibernating which is then turned into fat , then their internal metabolism slows waaay down . They 're living off of stored fat , more or less , as fat is just stored food and energy ( basically ) . The large amount of fat helps keep them warm , and is metabolized ( or turned into energy for the body ) at such a slow pace , they wake from hibernation almost as if they had never started the process . I do n't know if they ever wake up during Hibernation , but mother bears are known for giving birth while they hibernate and not waking up . The cub instinctively cuddles with the mom for warmth and nutrition through milk .", "How about water ? Surely they ca n't go months without taking a drink"]

id: How do neon colors work ? What makes them " pop " more than regular colors ? And why ca n't I imagine a neon brown ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Sometimes instead of being called neon colors they are called " fluorescent " colors . What makes them fluorescent is that they absorb light you normally ca n\'t see ( UV light ) and then release that energy as visible light . The result is that if you shine light that has UV in it ( like sunlight or a blacklight ) instead of just reflecting light like normal colors do , they actually glow as if they were a weak light bulb . The end result is that there is actually more light of those colors hitting your eyes so they seem brighter . As for why you ca n\'t think of " dark " neon colors , it \'s because what makes them distinct is that they add more light , while darkness is actually the absence of light .', 'Extra : most laundry detergents contain florescent additives , which is why your clothes are " whiter than white " in sunlight .', "Bonus fact : What we refer to collectively as Neon signs have all different kinds of gas ( usually one of the noble gasses I think ) in them to give them different colours . Lamps with specifically Neon gas glow red . If it 's a different colour it 's actually a different gas in there ( though everyone still calls them neon lamps anyway ) ."]

id: How do cemeteries work ? How do they stay in business ? At some point every single plot will be taken and last I checked you do n't rent the space or pay a monthly upkeep service - so how do cemeteries stay in business ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Because people are dying to get in ! ! ! BuDum - Tss ! ! ! Plus , they are usually affiliated with a church , who owns the land and pays the workers from donations', 'Many cemeteries do not give you your plot forever . You either have the spot on a year - by - year basis , or you buy it for 25 or 50 years . After this they give you the option to renew or they either cremate or put the body / casket in a mass grave type area . In others , such as churches , the land may be tax free and may have been deeded by benefactors . If permanent plot prices are sufficiently high , a fund could be established and the interest could probably more than cover the upkeep , but more likely the funds would help the church at first and later the church would help upkeep the cemetery as part of its general expenses .', "You do have to buy a cemetary plot , so that 's some income . But once the land is paid for , the only real expenses are a caretaker and tax on the land . And a lot of cemetaries are owned by churches , like MOS said , so they 're tax - free , as well ."]

id: How does a measurement device use significant figures to measure something ? It âs my first week in chemistry class for my next degree and my nursing - oriented brain is already struggling . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['The point of significant figures is for error purposes . If you âre using a ruler that is only marked along the inches and not half inches or lower for example , what do you do if the actual length of the object is 7.5436 inches ? The best you can do using the instrument is say that it âs 8 inches long , but that âs not quite right as you can clearly visualize that it âs somewhere between 7 - 8 inches long . Margin Of Error is the term we assign to how far off you can be , and this usually amounts to about halfway between the two values . In the above example , your margin of error is a half inch , because if the actual length of the object is in fact 7.5 inches , you have no choice but to say it âs 8 inches long with a margin of error of .5 inches . Meaning , your actual value can be anywhere between 7.5 to 8.5 inches long .', "Significant figures are n't used by instruments , they are part of a measurement . If I measure something at 1000.1 mm plus or minus 5 mm , then there are three significant digits ( the first 1 and two zeroes ) . The last zero is just there to fill out the number , and the 1 after the decimal point is pointless ( sorry , math pun ) . Similarly , a measurement of 0.000123 has , at most , three significant digits ( 1,2,and 3 ) . Leading zeroes , trailing zeroes and digits which are outside the accuracy of measurement are not significant . They can still be important to establish the amplitude of the significant digits .", 'Significant figures show how precise the measurement is . For example , I could say the nearest Starbucks is 2 miles away , when it was actually 1.812 miles away . Pretty close to what I said , but someone who listened to me might drive 2 miles and miss the Starbucks completely . Measurement devices which have more significant figures are more precise and thus more useful . However there is a limit to how many digits actually matter . Usually this is either 3 or 4 significant figures so that the maximum error is less than 0.1 % .']

id: How do cities remain modern looking as time passes ? Cities like Shanghai and Hong Kong come to mind . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Because things build up around the old portions of the city , so that the older , small parts are less noticible in a larger overview of the city . If you explore a city locally , you 'll find the older portions , but the sky line will be dominated by all the new things .", "Successful cities are always experiencing new construction . Major cities like New York , Boston , and London are constantly growing and improving with each generation ( yes , in spite of the hiccups we all hear about ) . Stagnant cities do n't see new construction and wind up looking the same or worse after several generations . New England is dotted with old mill cities that stopped growing when companies started outsourcing to Asia . These post - industrial places look the same now as they did 60 years ago .", 'Not only is there new construction , but whole existing buildings get facelifts . Take a look at the skyscraper on the [ 1900 block ] ( URL_0 ) of Smith St. , Houston , TX on Google Street View . You can see the building pre- and post - facelift . The new look is definitely a lot more modern .']

id: How do viruses like Measles and Flu begin ? What i 'm looking to understand is how that one unlucky person contracts these viruses in the first place . Not necessarily how it is spread from Person - to - Person . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Viruses are n't actually organisms by the strict definition . One of the current proposed theories is that they mutated from eubacteria several MYA . A lot of modern viruses are found in wild animals and ' jump ' to our species through improper handling ( like aids and herpes )", 'Measles and flu are interesting because they usually first appear in domesticated animal populations ( birds and pigs ) and then mutate enough to become transmissible to humans .', 'Normally a mutation in the genetic structure of a virus']

id: How do dogs fall into deep sleeps so quickly and with such ease ? Why can dogs fall asleep almost instantly and yet it takes people some time before they knock out ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Not gon na lie but my dog has got nothing going on in his life right now besides eating , shitting , and barking at trees and stuff . I do n't think his brain is wracking itself trying to write poetry or anything . Might be easier going to sleep when there 's nothing to really worry about in life .", 'Reminder : * * no blatant speculation ! * *', "My guess is that dogs do n't have the everyday responsibilities that we have , so when they feel sleepy they can just sleep . I do the same thing when I am on vacation and do n't have any obligations . I just fall asleep whenever I am sleepy so I am never in bed trying to sleep ."]

id: How do people just die of old age with no other causes ? What makes some people live 120 years and some die of old age at 70 ? Edit : My 92 year old great aunt just died last night unexpectedly , after I made this post . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['There \'s no such thing as " dying of old age with no other causes " ... there are always other causes . One common killer is pneumonia , but lots of diseases can step in and finish you off . The problem with old age is that your body just gets weaker and weaker at defending / healing itself . At some point diseases that a healthy adult body would laugh up become massively dangerous infections . Dying of " old age " is more of a euphemism for " they died because they were old and could n\'t fight off some disease , nothing unexpected or abnormal . "', 'You do n\'t literally die of being old . It \'s not your body saying " welp , you \'re 89 now , time to die " . It \'s often a specific thing or collection of things that kill you BECAUSE you \'re old . Think of a car : a car does n\'t just up and stop working simply because of its model year ; it stops working because parts have n\'t been replaced or maintained , and have gotten worn down over the years . It \'s the same with people : everything is slowing down and your body has less capacity to replace cells that die or get less efficient . This means that your organs do n\'t work as well , your bones get more brittle , and your immune system is n\'t as good as it used to be . Stuff that you would be able to shrug off when you were younger and could replace cells more easily or fight off infections more easily is a lot harder to shrug off when you \'re older . Most of the time , people who die of " old age " die of pneumonia and other infections , heart attacks , complications from dementia ( often pneumonia / other infections from reduced mobility / hygiene , or from aspirating food when you forget how to swallow ) , or complications from cancer . All of those are specific causes tied to the wear and tear of old age , but you do n\'t die just because you \'re old .', '> How do people just die of old age with no other causes ? They do n\'t . > What makes some people live 120 years and some die of old age at 70 ? The specific cause of death , which can be very wide ranging . No one dies " of old age , " people die of some specific complaint , such as heart failure or any number of other conditions , ultimately which lead to insufficiency in supplying the brain with what it needs to stay alive .']

id: How do worms know where they 're going ? I do n't think they have eyes , do they ? Do they have like light - sensitive orbs or do they go by touch ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["worms do n't have noses but can detect odors with chemoreceptors expressed on their bodies . they can also orient in response to touch and temperature information . source : am neuroscientist", "Worms do n't have the neural capacity to care where they are going . They do n't have the neural capacity to understand the concept of location . Worms have no idea where they are , where they are going , or even that they 're moving at all . They sense and respond by reflex . They bend in response to higher concentrations of chemicals .", 'Just yesterday saw an article saying that worms have wee little receptors in their front end that detects the magnetic field . So maybe their instinct is tied to that in some way .']

id: How do taxes work ? I 've just graduated from high schools and I still have no fucking clue how taxes work . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Income tax works like this : Your first X dollars are taxed at a specific rate . That 's a plain percentage -- possibly 0 % . Your next Y dollars are taxed at a slightly higher rate . Your next Z dollars likewise . If you do certain things the government wants to promote , you can pretend your income was lower . As an example , let 's say the tax brackets are 0 % up to $ 10k , 10 % on the next $ 15k , and 30 % after that . You made $ 50k . You bought an electric car for $ 5k , and that 's tax deductible . So in your taxes , you write down your gross income : $ 50k . Then you subtract the $ 5k deduction for the electric car : $ 45k . Now you look at the first tax bracket . It 's 0 % up to $ 10k , so you take off up to $ 10k from your income , multiply that by 0 % , and add it to the tax you owe . That bracket gave you $ 0 in taxes and accounted for $ 10k of your income . You still have $ 35k left , so you look at the next bracket . It takes up to $ 15k of your income , and that portion of the income is taxed at 10 % , so it adds $ 1,500 to your taxes . You still have $ 20k left , so you look at the next bracket . That takes all your remaining income and taxes it at 30 % , giving you another $ 6,000 in taxes . That handles all your income , so you just sum up the amount of tax from each bracket -- $ 0 + $ 1,500 + $ 6,000 â $ 7,500 total . There are other types of tax , but that 's probably the one you 're talking about .", 'For the US : 1 . You estimate how much tax you will owe when starting a job . This will mainly be based on whether you have any dependents ( such as children ) . Your job will give you a form to fill out that does this for you . 2 . That estimated tax gets deducted from each paycheck and sent to the federal , state , and local governments . Once per year , you file a tax return : 1 . Your job will mail you your tax information , called W-2 forms . 2 . Figure out your total tax liability ( how much you owe the government ) 2 . Figure out how much tax credit you get ( how much the government owes you ) 3 . Subtract the credit from the liability to find out how much tax you should actually be paying . 4 . Compare the tax you actually owe to the estimated tax that was withheld in Step 2 . 5 . Figure out whether you underpaid or overpaid over the course of the year . If you underpaid , you owe the government more money . If you overpaid , you get a refund . 6 . Repeat for both state and local . Protip : [ Just use software to do it for you . ] ( URL_0 ) It \'ll ask you stuff like , " Are you married ? " or " Did you buy a house this year ? " or " What does your W-2 say in box 3 ? " and you just fill in the answers and hit " submit . "', 'I \'m going to assume you mean taxes as in income tax / the frenzy people get into about " tax day " ( normally on / around April 15th ) and " tax return / refund " that you hear people talking about . So here \'s the deal , baring some exceptions , every dollar you earn at a job is taxed . When you started working you might have been asked to fill out several forms , one of which might have asked you things like " how many dependents do you have . " Then it gives you a very rough ( and usually very bad , more on this later ) estimate of how much federal income tax you \'ll owe for the working year . So let \'s say it says " we estimate you should withhold 15 % of your wages for taxes " and you say fine . Now , your paycheck is 15 % less , but the important thing is you have n\'t lost any money . That 15 % that they take -- it \'s still there , it \'s still yours , you just do n\'t have it * now * . ( In a real paycheck there would be other deductions taken off too : social security , local taxes , etc . ) Now around February - April , most people will * * file * * their federal taxes . This is nothing more than filling out a few pages of documentation to let the government know how much money you earned , so they can figure out how much money you need to pay . So you \'ll typically get some forms from your job around this time called the W2 that lists how much money you \'ve earned , how much you \'ve paid in taxes , and how much you \'ve withheld for taxes . Let \'s say that the gross salary is 50k over the course of the year . Gross means absolute total , before any taxes etc were taken out . This is the theoretical amount you \'d have earned if you did n\'t pay taxes , pay social security , etc . The US federal income tax system is one called a " progressive tax " system . Another tax system you might have heard in the news is called a " flat tax " system , which is also known as a " regressive tax " system . The flat / regressive tax system is simple to understand : you pay the same percentage of taxes no matter your income . So if the flat tax was say 10 % , then your 50k income means you pay $ 5000 , and someone \'s 500k income means they would theoretically pay 50k . This is n\'t actually a good thing because imagine a person earning 20k / year gross : for him paying $ 2000 in taxes is a huge amount of money leaving him with less to spend for necessities . For that rich guy making 200k , he \'d pay 20k , which is the entire income of the poor guy , but he still has 180k left to spend on things like " food " and " housing . " Sales tax is a form of a regressive tax because poor people pay the same in taxes for that chicken that needs to feed his family for the entire week , whereas for a rich person the measly dollar or two in sales tax for the chicken is literally pocket change . Back to the income tax / progressive tax . The system is split into several brackets . I do n\'t recall them off the top of my head , but let \'s say the following are the brackets : * From $ 0 to $ 30000 you pay 0 % taxes * From $ 30001 to $ 50000 you pay 20 % taxes * From $ 50001 to $ 100k you pay 30 % taxes * Etc So back to your 50k gross income : this means that the money you earn up to 30k will * * always * * be taxed at 0 % . It does n\'t matter if you make 50k , 25k , 500k . The first 30k will always be 0 % . The money you earned between 30k and 50k are now taxed at 20 % , always and forever . So you do some math : you have $ 20000 left untaxed , and on that 20k ( and * * only * * on that 20k ) you will pay 20 % on taxes . The total amount you owe is just added up from all the brackets . This is important to understand because every now and then you \'ll hear conservative talking points like " I was given a raise which pushed me into the next tax bracket and now I take home less money because I pay more in taxes ! " which is 100 % factually incorrect . Even if you were " pushed into the next tax bracket " , the only additional taxes you would pay is the amount in only that next tax bracket , so unless that next tax bracket had a tax percent over 100 % then it is impossible to pay so much more in taxes that you take home less money , due to income tax . Now when you do your taxes you might also hear people talking about " deductions " . What are these ? These are ways to make your income look " less " so that you pay less taxes overall . Remember that your gross income was 50k . If you support yourself ( ie , your parents do n\'t claim to support you ) then you are allowed to take a personal deduction . Let \'s say this deduction is worth $ 5000 . You subtract it from your gross income to get your " adjusted taxable wage " , which would be 45k in this example . This would now lower your tax burden : the first 30k is still taxed at 0 % , but now you only need to pay 20 % on 15k for the next bracket , instead of 20 % on the original 20k . There are quite a few ways to lower your tax burden . Donating to charity for example would lower it . I think you get a tax credit if you bought an electric car , so that lowers your taxable wage as well . I think first time home buyers get a credit as well . If you deposit money directly from your salary into a retirement plan ( IRA , 401k , etc ) then it lowers your taxable wages as well . Ok , so you now have figured out how much money you owe the federal government in income taxes . How do you pay it ? Well actually , you \'ve already essentially been paying it . Remember that federal withholding we talked about ? That \'s money that has been set aside ( withheld ) from your paycheck to be used to pay federal income taxes . So after one year of working , let \'s say they have withheld a total amount of 10k from your wages , and now you figure out you only need to pay 5k in taxes . You fill out your forms and give the IRS a bank account for them to deposit the remaining 5k into . A couple weeks later you get a huge 5k " bonus " and you \'re happy and go out and buy a brand new car with this " free money . " Only that \'s not free money . That \'s money that you actually earned . That \'s money that you told the government to withhold for you to pay taxes with , but that extra amount you get back means that he government has withheld too much money and are just giving it back to you . This money was just sitting there this entire time , earning no interest for you , not letting you access it to buy things , etc . The best way is to actually sit down and do the math to figure out how much you \'ll need to pay , and tell them to withhold as close to that amount as possible , but this is a much harder subject to talk about .']

id: How do dollar stores manage to sell brand named products for such a low price ? 2 liter bottle of Coke for a $ 1 vs. the same drink for $ 2.50 a grocery store . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Dollar stores generally operate on a high volume , low margin basis . What this means is the store attempts to sell many more items per day than a large grocery store but receive less profit per item . They rely heavily on buying from wholesalers at low cost and having very little operating costs . You may also notice that many dollar stores carry very few or no perishable goods . A large grocery store may require extra profits on items like Coke because they may have to discard the $ 200 of turkey meat that is now expired and no longer salable . There are many other factors that can contribute to the sales price , however . Some Dollar stores are large chain franchises that heavily utilize economies of scale to obtain large price cuts from wholesales . Small Dollar stores generally rely on low financing costs .', "Because at a grocery store all those high prices you 're seeing are ' impulse ' buys . They 're stationed at the front where people will quickly buy anything . For Cub Foods there 's a section where you can buy this hugeeee can for pop for less than a buck . Yet Upfront there are smaller bottles for more than twice the price . Once again , because they know people will be making impulse buys upfront", "It could also be the store buying overflow of stock from other companies . Here in Sweden we have one that buys from all around Europe . So a product that 's expensive in let 's say Germany is dirt cheap here because we do n't know the brand ( and the brand wo n't get damaged by low prices ) a little OT but yeah some companies might get to much of an item that they ca n't turn fast enough so selling it of cheaper is more cost effective ."]

id: How do you test something for randomness ? I read this : URL_0 and I 'm still a little baffled I guess . For instance , if I mix up a Rubik 's Cube , how could someone test if it was truly random or not ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Randomness usually means unpredictability . It 's hard to prove that something is random . But , it 's easy to show something is NOT truly random . Let 's say someone shuffles a deck of cards and then shows you the top card . More specifically , let 's say they do this a trillion times in a row . After each shuffle and display , you write down which card they showed . You would expect that after each shuffle , every card would have the same chance of ending up on the top of the deck . So , after the trillion retries , you look over your notes and see whether this is the case . If each card shows up in your list about 1/52 of the time then you can say the shuffling was pretty well randomized . If the King of Hearts shows up 95 % of the time , then you would assume that something is funny with the shuffling technique . Likewise , if you can begin to predict which card will appear , then that definitely indicates it is not truly random . If you see from your list that the same pattern of cards ALWAYS repeats then that is a sign that the shuffle is not truly random . If you handed someone a Rubik 's Cube then they could n't really say whether your mix up was random or not . But , if you did it a bunch of times and no pattern emerged then they could say you were mixing it randomly .", 'Reminds me of a joke : a brilliant computer scientist claims to have invented a computer that can generate truly random numbers ( not psuedorandom , but truly random ) . He assembles a room full of mathematicians and scientists to demonstrate it . He asks the machine to give him a truly random number . The machine responds " 1 " . Someone else in the room asks for another truly random number . The machine responds " 1 " . A third person in the room asks for another truly random number , and the machine responds " 1 " . At this point , everyone turns a cynical eye on the inventor and someone asks , " are you * sure * these numbers are truly random ? " The inventor replies , " well , that \'s the problem with truly random numbers , it \'s impossible to tell . " On a more serious note , in your Rubik \'s Cube example , there are only a finite number of positions that it \'s possible for a Rubik \'s Cube to be turned to , so the " randomness " of any given starting position is just one divided by the total number of possibilities .', 'gndn \'s joke is very on point to your question . Testing for randomness is very difficult in general . Testing a single sample for randomness is completely impossible . For example , you ask me to guess an integer between one and a million , and I say " 4 " . It * seems * to you that I did n\'t really select the number at random . After all , if you inspected a lot of random numbers in that interval , most of them would have six digits , so a small number like " 4 " seems rather unlikely . But mathematically , every number in the interval is equally likely , since that \'s what randomness implies . So the number certainly could have been " 4 " . Or even " 1 " . Or " 999,999 " . You simply have n\'t seen enough examples to have any way to gauge whether or not my method of randomly selecting numbers seems to be a good one . And even if you have a large number of samples , there \'s always the possibility that pure dumb chance has resulted in a " funny looking " set of numbers coming out of a good , random number generator . With a large sample it will be * improbable * for this to happen , but it wo n\'t be * impossible * . So your tests of randomness can only provide * chances * that the set of results was not random , not certainty .']

id: How do skyscrapers get demolished ? Let 's say that in a very densely populated area with high rise skyscrapers all around , you had to demolish one . How would you do it without damaging the surrounding buildings ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Controlled demolition after you gut it . Basically : - Strip out all the useful bits that you can sell off or reuse ( cabling , ducting , carpet , light fixtures etc . ) so that it 's just an empty shell . - Place explosive charges on the main structural members , which are shaped and placed so that the force of the explosion is inwards ( so it does n't blow outwards into other buildings or far away ) . - Sequence the explosives so that they go off in controlled order . Basically , you want to blow the bottom out at several points so that the upper levels collapse straight downwards under the weight of gravity ( pancaking ) . - Once the building is down , dispose and salvage of the material , e.g. structural steel ( rebar ) in concrete can be salvaged and sold for scrap recycling . The rest goes in landfill .", "Assuming that everything else around it is so tightly packed that any of the more rapid methods like explosives are out ... you do the opposite of what the builders did . Start at the top , and dismantle it in a slow , controlled manner . If you 've got a bit more space , such as with a suburban tower block surrounded by housing a bit of a distance then explosives might be an option , but that 's not going to be possible in a city centre .", "You take it apart in the opposite way it was built essentially . In places where using explosives to bring down a building is not permitted such as Toronto , this is how it 's done . Though it is a very expensive way to demolish a large building . A lot of the times the building is gutted and refurbished / renovated to suit the new needs such as a condo tower ."]

id: How do people decipher ancient writing systems ? For example , how did people decipher the Sumerian number system ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Specifically , the Sumerian number system was used in astronomy a lot . Slightly newer civilizations made use of these same astronomical charts . For example , the Ancient Greeks used Babylonian star charts , but they translated them to Greek . This sort of thing could be applied to all kinds of writing . New civilizations were interested in reading what was written by slightly older civilizations that were n't so old everyone forgot how to read them . Things got translated over and over again to newer languages . A lot of Ancient Greek texts actually came to us through the Arabic translation movement . Later on those Arabic translations were translated into Latin . Of course there are probably exceptions . Some things may have been lost for a while , like how we needed the Rosetta Stone to understand Ancient Egyptian . I 'm taking a class on the History of Science right now ( from the Babylonians and Ancient Egyptians up to the 17th century ) , so we learned a lot about how knowledge got passed along .", "There 's the obvious example of the Rosetta Stone , where the same text is basically given in three different languages . Linguists usually use frequency analysis , where they try to figure out the frequency of each word appearing . The underlying assumption is that across different languages , certain words that serve grammatical purpose would have similar frequencies , which gives clues as to what they are . Languages are also usually interconnected with each other . For example , even though they 're quite far apart geographically , English and Sanskrit actually belong in the same family group and share some roots . By studying other languages you can trace the development and etymology of the language .", "First : English is not my first language . You have been warned . Second : I know that this is already marked as answered , but I wanted to share my knowledge from this [ book ] ( URL_0 ) which is awesome btw :) > Rosetta Stone This example is also great to elaborate the difficulties with deciphering ancient languages : Just because you know the translation , you can not read the unknown text . Scientists thought for a century that hieroglyphics are [ ideograms ] ( URL_5 ) though later research showed that they are mainly [ phonograms ] ( URL_4 ) mixed with few ideograms . Deciphering ancient languages can be seen as a type of [ cryptoanalysis ] ( URL_2 ) as in ' I have a bunch of symbols and I want to know their meaning ' . As /u / Neo63 stated frequency analysis is a major part of decryption . Since ancient languages are luckily most of the time not encrypted scientists can use symbols or chains of symbols which occur frequently in many texts to try to decipher its meaning . This was a major part in the deciphering of [ Linear B ] ( URL_1 ) , which was Greek in another alphabet , where [ Micheal Ventris ] ( URL_3 ) translated often ocurring symbol chains as the names of cities . Of course this was only possible because he could assume that the stone plates held trading information ( there were numerous columns with an easy to decipher number system on them ) . This leads to another important part of deciphering ancient languages : Knowing the * context * . Trade information on a stone plate ? There are certainly names of cities somewhere in the text . Of course you can not just search for symbol chains with the same length as ' Knossos ' because you do not know if the symbols represent letters or syllables or words . In case of Linear B on part of its deciphering was the detection of cases which lead to the deciphering of the syllables ( there were about 60 symbols , which points to a language of syllables , whereas phonetic languages contain 10 - 40 symbols and ideographic languages contain up to multiple thousand ) ."]

id: How do âheldâ amounts appear on statements and affect balances of traditional credit cards?
text: ['The "hold" is just placeholder that prevents you from overspending until the transaction is settled. The merchant isn\'t "holding" your money, your bank or card provider is protecting itself from you overdrawing. In general, it takes 1-3 days for a credit transaction to settle. With a credit card, this usually isn\'t an issue, unless you have a very low credit line or other unusual things going on. With pre-paid and debit cards, it is an issue, since your spending power is contingent upon you having an available balance. I\'m a contrarian on this topic, but I don\'t see any compelling reason to use debit or stored value cards, other than preventing yourself from overspending. I\'ve answered a few other questions in detail in this area, if you\'re interested.']

id: How do film / tv productions handle deaths of actors ? Examples ? I know that multiple actors replaced Heath Ledger in The Imaginarium of Dr. Parnassus but I 've never seen it . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Usually it leaves them scrambling . I know when John Ritter died they actually had to write that death into " 8 Simple Rules " .', "It depends on the situation , how much the actor has already shot , if it 's an ongoing series etc . Ledger had n't shot many scenes of Dr. Parnassus if I remember right so they put in what he had done then got other actors to do the other bits as a tribute . When John Ritter died he had already taped 3 episodes of the next season of the show he was on , * 8 Simple Rules * . They were shown , then on the 4th the writers had his character die and the show became about the remaining characters dealing with his death .", "Every one I can think if they wrote it into the script . Only Fools and Horses ( British sitcom ) had a whole scene at grandad 's funeral . It was funny but sad . He was replaced by an Uncle character . Did n't Finn in Glee have his death written into the scrip ? . I actually have n't seen it but I think that is the case ."]

id: How do surveys account for the inherit bias and lying in the answers it receives ? I always feel like I am bias in certain questions and wonder how it affects my outcome . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Surveys are inevitably biased to some degree , but bias can be minimised using a number of strategies : Survey design - trying to get the wording and ordering of questions in such a way that respondents are not influenced to answer in certain ways . Size of sample - a large sample with more respondents could potentially minimise bias , because even if a couple of participants deliberately lie , their impact on the overall findings is minimal . Control groups - testing the same survey with different target groups or slightly different formats ( for example changes to the order and wording of questions ) to see what difference this makes . Careful reporting - the reporting of survey results need to explicitly acknowledge potential biases , the gaps in the sample and the limits of the methodology . The findings must not be treated as \' facts \' but as evidence that is limited by the nature of the research . For example , rather than report that " our survey found that 15 % of people cheat on their wives " , a good researcher will report that " 15 % of survey respondents - mostly white males in their 40s - reported cheating on their wives " .', 'They can check the internal consistency of your responses . One method it to as the same question in different ways . Someone lying on the survey may not remember their previous responses , and not answer all of those questions the same way .', '> inherit Hi ! It seems the word you \'re looking for is " inherent " , thought you might like to know . Have a great day !']
