id: How do college campuses have the same WiFi network across entire campuses ? How do all the routers connect to the same network ? Also in some places on campus my internet works way better than others , so does each router have its own bandwidth ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["It 's called a [ wifi mesh ] ( URL_0 ) . There are multiple ways to set up a wifi mesh . From having one wifi access point connect over wifi to a neighbor , to having all access points connect to a central switch over Ethernet . As for why some on - campus locations appear ( or are ) to be faster or slower than others , that 's something you 'd have to ask your campus network staff .", "Large - scale WiFi deployments tend to work quite differently to simple home or small business networks . There are so many Access Points ( APs ) that they wo n't fit on a single Ethernet network , they interfere with each other , and users are constantly being passed from one AP to another , sometimes on different networks , as they move around . Also , you ca n't just have a single password and tell everyone , so you need to implement enterprise - scale authentication allowing users to connect using their username and password . Without going into too many details , enterprise WiFi typically has a central controller box ( or boxes for redundancy ) . The APs are really dumb radios that send and receive all their packets to and from the central controller to be dealt with . The WiFi packets are sent via a TCP / IP protocol so the APs can all be on different Ethernet segments themselves , even though the WiFi environment they present to the users looks like a single network . The central server device is configured to have access to the corporate authentication service ( e.g. , via Radius ) so it can use the same username / password authentication as other IT services on campus . The problem with bandwidth tends to be on the WiFi side rather than the Ethernet network side . Campuses tend to have hundreds of WiFi users , some with multiple devices . In a small space all these devices will be talking with just a few APs with only a small number of non - overlapping WiFi channels available . At 2.4GHz , for example , there are 11 channels ( varies by country ) but you have to space by 5 channels to avoid overlap , so using only channels 1 , 6 , and 11 is common . There are more channels ( 8 ? ) at 5GHz but still not that many . In common areas they will pack in many APs and turn down their WiFi power to try to limit how much they interfere with each other , but this is really a work - around . Also , devices using old WiFi standards tend to slow down the network for everyone . So there 's no point stealing enterprise APs ; they 're totally useless devices without tons of expensive hardware to make them work , hardware that requires expertise to configure and run .", "The network is deployed out in segments . Think of it like this - each floor of each building gets its own network , and then the buildings have routers that connect all of those networks together , and then those routers connect to the campus ' data center where there are bigger routers that handle connecting not only the buildings to each other but the entire campus to the Internet at large . As far as the WiFi goes - when you 're deploying a campus - wide network , there will be centralized management of the access points in order to handle things like channel assignments and client management . Every access point is given the same name and to a user looks like seamless coverage , but there will be dozens if not hundreds or thousands of access points blanketing the campus with the same SSID . However , those access points are all going to be working on different channels so as to not overlap signals with each other ( either in the general 1 - 6 - 11 configuration to eliminate channel overlap or in a 1 - 4 - 8 - 11 configuration to simply minimize it ) . As well , the central management of the access points will work to try and prevent a single access point from getting overloaded . Throw 200 people into a lecture hall with one access point and the amount of effective bandwidth for users is going to be quite minimal . But if you have ten access points in and around the lecture hall , the server can force clients to disconnect from one access point and reconnect to another access point with a decent signal strength so that you have people on the edges of the hall connecting to access points in other rooms so that each access point gets 20 users competing for the bandwidth instead of 200 . Access points can be connected in two ways - wired or mesh . If an access point is wired , as most access points in a campus - level network should be , it will have its own dedicated bandwidth that it can serve of either 100 Mbps or 1 Gbps . If the access point is connected in a mesh configuration , bandwidth management becomes more complex because the access point needs to use its radios for both serving clients and getting their traffic upstream . Why does it work better in some places rather than others ? There are a lot of reasons for that . It could be that other users are causing bandwidth congestion - a couple of people connected to the same access point are watching Netflix , so you go to download a file and find that the pool of bandwidth you 're sharing is mostly going to serve them instead of you because their usage is more constant than yours . It could be that there are too many users connected to the access point - wireless bandwidth is a shared pool among the users , so the more users there are the more contention there is to try and use the same bandwidth and the more overhead increases trying to separate everyone 's traffic . And it could be that you 're getting a bad signal - your radio might indicate that you 're getting a good signal power , but the wall between you and the access point might be scattering that signal to hell and back in a way that causes both your device and the access point to have to constantly resend data to ensure it 's being received properly ."]

id: How do people learn a language just by talking to people who are fluent ? If you do n't understand what is being said to begin with , how do you eventually start understanding ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Think of how kids learn what will be their native language . They do nt pop out understanding even the concept of words , they just live amongst people speaking the language and pick up on the fact that certain mouth sounds represent certain things . Gradually through context and repetition they build up enough of a collection of sounds with enough understanding of meaning to converse . Same thing with learning a new language later . I may have no idea what " cerveza " means , but if I hear a spanish speaker say it and then receive a beer I can have a pretty good idea .', 'One big piece of language learning is tied to our conceptual vocabulary . Conceptual vocabulary is our ability to apply meaning and context to an item , an action , an emotion , etc . in the world around us . For example , I could hold up a banana and depending on your knowledge and exposure to that banana or the banana industry or facts about banana , you \'d know that green bananas do n\'t normally taste that great , that most bananas we see are yellow and if a banana is black or mushy to the touch it \'s probably bad . Assuming your conceptual vocabulary veers towards normal , you \'d know you ca n\'t write with a banana and you ca n\'t drive a banana . This is based on an entire lifetime of seeing bananas , eating bananas and just in general , your brain \'s natural association with an abstract sound connecting to a piece of our reality that associates meaning back to our brain . When we learn language as a child , our brains are connecting the dots between the language around us and the world around us . That \'s why it \'s so important to expose kids to a variety of different experiences , as well as explaining those experiences and things to the child . Babies and kids need to hear and interact with language while growing up because it activates their brain for more language . The usual rule is that kids really need to be exposed to vast amounts of language and experiences by age 5 because our brains are hardwired to use those first five years to really absorb all those really complicated parts of a language , such as grammar and cultural factors and social cues . Research has been done on young children about their understanding of grammar and it \'s amazing how they understand really complicated abstract grammar simply based on them knowing what " sounds " right and what " sounds " wrong . That \'s based on exposure , parents and adults teaching them how to use it , correcting them when they use it wrong . If you want to read up more about this need for constant stimulus required for language development , you can look into the story of Genie . She was a kid who was locked in a crib since birth and who was basically neglected and alone until she was discovered at 13 . Even after she was rescued , she never developed language skills because she was so deprived for so long at so young that her brain never trigger first language . Her language skills improved while some researchers were working with her , but once the researched stopped and she was put in a home for the mentally ill , her skills rapidly regressed because she just was n\'t being exposed to language anymore . If you \'re talking about how we can move to a different country and slowly grow to learn the language , it \'s about how we \'re connecting the dots of the new language around us with our existing knowledge of conceptual vocabulary as well as our understanding of our first language . It \'s similar to how we learn language as a child , but since we already have our first language , learning a second language is more based on connecting the world , our existing language and our conceptual language together . That \'s why learning nouns and verbs are always easier when learning a second language , while grammar is probably a bit more difficult when it \'s not related to our first language . That \'s why we point and gesture and try to mine actions if we \'re in a country where we do n\'t speak the language . I can hold up a banana and I call it a banana while a person who only speaks Tagalog knows it as saging , but we both understand the banana , when green it \'s underripe , yellow is good , mushy or black spots is bad , etc . etc . It \'s when you start discussing abstract things that you need to begin factoring in cultural social elements and how it affects reality and how your first language / culture understanding of the world and its relation to the second language / culture \'s understanding of the world . The biggest obstacle on why a lot of people " ca n\'t " learn a second language is mostly psychological and contextual rather than sheer ability . We correct children all the time when they use improper grammar or use a vocabulary word incorrectly , we also go out of our way to explain things to children so their understanding of the world keeps on growing . A lot of adult language learners might have a hard time taking corrections or what they perceive as " criticisms " . We also have to immerse and surround the learner with an environment just filled with fluent speakers . When someone moves to another country , if they completely immerse themselves , meaning no exposure to their first language , then they will pick up the language so much faster compared to someone who frequents ex - pat areas or still uses their first language to write and read . Conversing with fluent speakers helps us test our language ability and for us to read and note when we say things right and when we say things wrong . We self - adjust and that just accumulates to the point where if we correct often enough , we \'ll get to a point where we do n\'t make many mistakes anymore . While bilingual children have an easier time learning a third or fourth language compared to monolingual children , if you have an ability to speak and understand a language , you can learn another language . It \'s just a factor of effort and placing yourself in the right context with the right frame of mind .', "I think the human brain is hardwired for it . There was a dude on I Almost Got Away With It who said he learned Spanish / Portugese this way ( ca n't remember which ) . Basically he showed up in South America and for a few months just asked random people what this and that word meant , and before long he was speaking the language fluently . Another couple months he had a job as a teacher which he kept for years until he got busted ."]

id: How does a fly survive a powerful swat from a human hand ? Flies are so small and fragile . Why are n't they really fucked up , and still able to fly , after you smack them away ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["When you swat a ... well , anything , your hand builds up a small layer of air in front of it . When you swat a small thing , for a brief moment , they accelerate as the air layer pushes them . By the time your hand reaches them , they are not hit as hard as you think they were hit . Now , if you take something larger than your hand , say , a friend 's face , then the air layer is not big enough to push them , and they will feel the full force of the blow . I am just trying to re - create this from memory . This was posted many months ago . EDIT : Yes , this is exactly why fly swatters have holes , to remove as much of the lair^^^^heh as possible .", 'Someone showed what happens when a fly gets swatted a while back . Even if they survive they are totally fucked up .', 'They probably weigh so little that the air around your hand actually pushes them away .']

id: How do doctors calculate percent / chance of survival for any particular surgery ? Is it simply the number of successfulâ procedures compared to number of procedures where people have died ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Pretty much . Often it 's more of just an educated guess based on how complicated the surgery will be and the number of things that could potentially go wrong .", 'That is the basic concept . However there are lots of factors involved . For example there may be complications after a procedure and even unidentified complications so you might want to compare the survival rate after a few years . But this may create a bias as the deaths might be unrelated and rather caused by other factors . For example colon cancer is more common in older people so the procedures for colon cancer have an artificially low survival rate as people die from unrelated causes shortly after the procedure . So if you are a young person getting colon cancer the statistics might not tell you much .', 'Yes . Suppose you are going in to a heart - bypass surgery . It has been performed many many times in people of different ages , races and underlying health conditions . Then you gather statistics about those surgeries and get probabilities based off real fatalities . You can get nit picky and start getting probabilities for : young male , not overwight , with no other underlying health conditions , and so on .']

id: How do planes / subs know when missiles have a ' lock ' ? Or have I been watching too many movies Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Missile systems generally consists of a radar to detect where the target is and send commands to the missile to tell it where to go . The radars have several modes which have their different use cases and a target can detect the signals from the radar to see what mode it is in . A radar might start out using low frequency and large sweeping scans to detect the rough placement of all planes in the sky . However this does not give accurate enough and frequent enough updates to be able to hit anything . So they change to a higher frequency radar with a more narrow sweep . This means they can only detect the airplane in the direction they aim the radar but they will be more accurate . This change of mode can be detected in the target airplane but still have to be interpreted correctly . A lot of radars had different modes of operation in peace and war so that the enemy would not be able to analyze their signals before the war .', 'I always use the flashlight analogy . Two planes trying to find each other in the sky with radar is like you and your buddy playing flashlight tag at night in pitch dark . Each plane \'s radar is normally in a " search " mode , where it just sweeps back and forth , searching a huge swath of sky in front of the aircraft . This is just like you , sweeping your flashlight back and forth in front of you , scanning in the dark for your friend . When your flashlight \'s beam passes over him , you can see him for a split second , before your flashlight sweeps past him and continues on . You keep sweeping your flashlight back and forth , so every few seconds , when your flashlight beam passes back over your buddy , you get another " update " on where he is . Now lets say you want to start chasing your friend so you can tag him ( in the context of a plane , you \'re launching a missile ) . You ca n\'t chase your friend very well when you can only see him once every few seconds as your flashlight passes over him . So you point your flashlight directly at your friend and track him with it . From your friend \'s point of view , every few seconds , he sees a flash of light from your flashlight as the beam passes over him . He knows you \'re searching for him , but he has no way of knowing if you have seen him yet . Then , your intermittent flashes of light change to a constant beam , as your turn your flashlight and point it right at him . Now , he knows you \'ve seen him , he knows that you know exactly where he is , and you are either getting ready to start chasing him , or already have . This is getting " locked on " . Now lets put this back into the aircraft context : A radar basically works like a giant , invisible flashlight . Each plane normally has it \'s radar in a " scan " or " search " mode , where it sweeps back and forth , scanning the whole sky for potential enemies . When it sees something ( i.e , when something bounces the light back at the radar ) the radar takes note of the position , [ puts it on a display in the cockpit for the pilot to see ] ( URL_0 ) , and continues scanning . If the pilot wants to track something ( or more importantly , try and shoot at it ) , he instructs the radar to point directly at the object it found earlier . Now , instead of sweeping around and only seeing the object intermittently , the radar points right at the target and delivers constant information on it \'s direction and speed . This is getting " locked on " or " tracking " . It \'s important to the other pilot , because like your friend playing flashlight tag , he knows when the light from your radar is hitting his aircraft . When the light switches from an intermittent ping to a constant stream , it means you are tracking him , know where he is , and either have already shot at him or are preparing to shoot . This is why getting " locked on " is a big deal . Edit : Now missiles . Going back to the flashlight tag analogy , let \'s say you \'re a big , heavy guy . You ca n\'t run too well or too fast , so if you tried to chase your friend yourself , he would easily run away . So , instead , you carry with you a lighter , smaller friend , who can run much faster and is much more agile than you are ( a missile ) . However , in order to run so fast , your little friend does n\'t carry his own heavy flashlight , he relies on the light from your flashlight so he can see the guy he \'s supposed to tag . So you have to keep your flashlight pointed at your target . This is Semi - Active Radar Homing ( SARH ) . In truth , I simplified the Radar system a bit in my first explanation . A radar system is not just a big , invisible flashlight , it also includes a special " camera " that allows you to see the light that bounces back from the target . So just like a flashlight just produces the light that allows your eyes to see your friend , the radar dish is just sending out light that the " camera " can then see reflected back from the target . The idea with semi - active radar homing is that in order to make our missiles as small , light , fast , and agile as possible , we do n\'t have to put a big radar dish in them , we can just put a little radar camera in them , and as long as * someone * is locked on with their radar ( the person that shot the missile , his friend in another plane , someone on the ground , etc . ) , the missile will use the light from their radar to see the target and guide itself in .', "Warplanes can detect when they get hit by a radar pulse . When a radar system is just looking around for stuff , it will ping pretty infrequently , because it 's looking around at the whole sky . As it gets interested in something , say a plane , it will focus the area it 's looking , and be able to send more pulses to that area , which will increase the resolution and give its operators a better idea of where the object they 're looking for is . Once a missile is fired the radar , either on the ground or in the missile , will narrow down , further and further , as it wants to increase the accuracy and the refresh rate of the target , because smaller movements of the target plane become much more important to determining whether the missile hits , and become more important the nearer a the missile gets . All this means that planes receive an increasing number of radar pings and can consequently tell when the missile is getting nearer . You see this portrayed in films as pilots sitting in cockpits with increasingly frantic beeping as the missile gets nearer ."]

id: How do people in India identify people from other castes ? Are there any ethnic signs or anything ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Think about your own society ( or mine , since I 'm American ) . Can I tell white trash from old money from new money ? With a little bit of generalizing , yes : it 's easy to tell , by their behavior patterns , by the way their family of origin interacts , by the way they celebrate holidays , by the way they dress , by their professions , by their accents , even by their names . Could an old money prepster from Connecticut pass as white trash if he dressed a certain way and maybe spoke a bit differently ? Sure . It 's not really an ethnic thing . This is intuitively similar to how caste works in India , although I 'm sure someone will downvote me for taking a complex subject and distilling it so simply .", 'The caste system is no longer so prevalent in India(as compared to older days ) and so there might not be a immediate discerning difference that you might be able to see . However , I \'m pointing out the fact that I live in an upper middle class area and so my answer will reflect my understanding and observations of this question , as compared to answering your entire question definitely . As all societies , class is relatively easily distinguished between . The area you live in , the way you speak , dress and behave all act as identifying factors . With caste , it \'s not so simple . There are thousands of castes in India , I \'m not sure of the exact number . Now , with the progression of society , many of the lower castes have risen up to make a decent living for themselves and can be indistinguishable from the general public . Of course , you could recognise the caste of people based on the general area and general physical features but you can never surely identify someone based on this . The last names of people usually can be an identifying factor of their caste , as people of the same caste share a set of last names . This is not true in all cases as the ancestors of certain lower caste members changed their surnames to something that was not associated with their caste in order to prevent discrimination from people from " upper castes " In today \'s day , I would say it \'s hard to identify someone \'s caste off hand but it \'s really not required day to day . Almost no one uses the old caste system , so it does n\'t really matter what caste you belong to . I doubt anyone apart from people living in extremely rural areas still maintain the practice of using a person \'s caste to judge their worth . Although one major fact that should be known is the governments current view on castes . Government institutions especially colleges and universities have reserved seats for SC / ST(Scheduled Castes / Scheduled Tribes ) so that they are not at a disadvantage in gaining seats for a course because of their background . While this does help people from less priveleged backgrounds get good education , it also causes a lot of people to take unfair advantage of the system . A lot of people who are well off and have a good education and living condition get to use the reserved quota system for their benefit even though they do n\'t need it . This reservation system also causes a whole lot of problem for the general category of people(which is a lot of people ) to get seats in university because barely any seats are left for them because of the reserved seats . Sorry if I expanded a bit too much , but I hope I answered your question . Here \'s a link if you want to read more about it . URL_0', "I am from India and you literally have NO idea just how much castes play an important role in the Indian politics . It is atrocious . Absolutely ATROCIOUS . I mean the caste system was invented at the time of Aryans . I am sure google can tell you more about Aryans than me . But they created this caste system so they can manage and/or administer the people in the society efficiently . And it would come as surprise that the caste system has NOT been completely abolished ' til this date & age and now the system is merely seen as a POLITICAL TOOL here . And I also think that it is the Aryans to blame for the current state of Indian politics , if you go down the rabbit hole deep enough , you 'll understand what I am saying . TL;DR - I just hope the caste system gets COMPLETELY ABOLISHED in the near future . Best wishes , Kushagra ."]

id: How do forensic psychologists create such specific criminal profiles ? Such as the make , model and color of the car the criminal drives , the hobbies he or she might have , etc . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["They do n't . Criminal profiling is a pretty controversial topic among professionals . For every criminal profile that is right there is usually one that is wrong . The efficacy of criminal profiling is hotly debated . It does n't help that shows misrepresent what it is and how well is works .", "In certain situations , it may be possible to infer some psychological traits or characteristics of the criminal through profiling with a reasonable degree of accuracy based on factors such as who the targeted victim(s ) were , where the crime took place , what evidence was left at the crime scene , whether the crime scene was left neat / clean or messy / dirty , etc . The degree to which these profiles are accurate tends to increase with the number of data - points ( e.g. crime scenes ) that the profiler has to work with ( i.e. that are believed to be linked to the same offender ) . Profiling specific details ( e.g. a particular car model ) can not be done with any sort of accuracy unless the profiler has additional information ( e.g. physical evidence or eye - witness accounts ) which leads him / her to make such a conclusion . It is possible , however , that certain evidence may lead the profiler to suspect the criminal drives a certain type of vehicle . For example , evidence may suggest that the crime was politically motivated and the offender is an environmental protection activist . It may therefore be predicted that the offender drives an environmentally friendly electric / hybrid car . If , on the other hand , the criminal is suspected of being a hunter and weapons enthusiast , it may be predicted that he drives a utility truck of some sort which has lots of storage space . Criminal Profiling is still a hotly debated topic in Forensic Psychology because - although many profiles do turn out to be quite accurate - there are many criminals who are eventually caught and do n't end - up matching the predicted profile . The forensic utility of profiling is still questioned and it 's important for people to realize that these profiles are merely educated guesses and law enforcement should not eliminate or ignore suspects who do n't fit the suspected profile . Source : Degree in Psychology & Criminology .", 'Most of the traditional " real - life " FBI profiles are more demographic - based than psychology - based . That is , they figured out that most rapists and other predatory sexual criminals started at around X age , grew more criminally sophisticated ( and often more violent ) as they committed more crimes , had certain types of experiences and behaviors in their background ( abuse , neglect , voyeuristic behavior , violence toward animals ) , etc . Based on that data they \'re able to predict certain things about an offender with a certain degree of accuracy : age ( or at least experience level ) , race -- since most sexual criminals tend to victimize those of their own race -- background / living situation , and so on . In addition , there are certain other things that are more specific . For instance , if a murder is carried out " military style " , then they might surmise that the killer has military or law enforcement experience . If the crime scene is haphazard or disorganized , they may surmise that the killer is less experienced and probably younger , while a " neater " crime scene indicates someone who \'s been at it for a while . The real misconception about profiling in terms of how it \'s portrayed in popular culture , I think , is that it \'s often shown as a more intuitive process , which only certain hyper - imaginative / hyper - empathetic individuals are able to carry out . This is where characters like Will Graham from the show " Hannibal " or Frank Black from " Millennium " come in , who are portrayed as having an almost quasi-(if not explicitly)psychic ability to " see through the killer \'s eyes " or what have you .']

id: How do we find the valuation of a company ? Does it have anything to with EPS , NPV or IRR ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['This is an incredibly complex topic . People have written 1000 page textbooks on this topic , but here \'s a simplification . * * Any * * investment is worth the sum of the present value of the future cash flows . Stock , bond , entire company , annuity , lottery ticket , does n\'t matter . It \'s calculated as the sum of the expected cash flows after they \'ve been discounted by a rate to count for the risk . [ Here \'s ] ( URL_0 ) a picture in case the visualization helps . So if we want to know how much a company is valued , we predict how much cash we \'d generate and adjust it for the risk of t phe company . This is basically an NPV . IRR is the discount rate that will make the NPV 0 ( including the price of the investment ) . So , you \'re probably asking , * It \'s almost impossible to accurately assess both the risk of the company and the cash it will produce . How does is this method reliable at all ? " Well , by in large , it \'s not , so you \'re predictions will be affected by what side of the deal you \'re on . If you \'re looking to invest , you \'re predictions will be conservative because you want to know how much you can make if the company does poorly . If you \'re looking to sell you \'re company , you want to show it in the best possible light , so your predictions will be better . But , to try and tether our predictions to earth , often times people will look at what other people are paying for similar companies . As one of my professors said , " Someday , someone will pay you a lot of money for advice . And your advice will be , \' do what everyone else is doing . \' " Basically you look at a multiple of trading price or purchase price to revenue or profit , and use that multiple to create a value for your own company . EPS : EPS is net income per share . Not necessarily directly related to value , but often times markets will value a company based on predicted EPS , so if it goes over or under , the value will shift .', "It 's really simple . You take the number of outstanding shares , which for publicly - traded companies is a matter of record , and multiply it by the current share price . This gives a statistic called * market capitalization , * which is what you 're looking for .", "There are many ways to value a company . Probably the best value you can get is when someone is willing to buy it . /u / cnash 's answer is one way , but you have to realize that the market capitalization is a MINIMUM valuation . Basically , at today 's closing stock price of $ X , everyone who thought the company was worth less than $ X / share sold their stock . The only people who still hold stock think the company is worth MORE than $ X / share . How much more than $ X / share the company is worth can be calculated in many ways , including gut feeling . There are firms out there that have a bunch of experts that do this for a living , and they all have their own twists and turns of how they calculate the value ."]

id: How do protests have an effect ? i.e. How does a bunch of people standing around for something actually get that thing to happen ? If I was a lawmaker , I would just ignore them . They ca n't stand around forever . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Protests bring awareness to others hoping they will join in to help the cause . Also it can cause disruption in the daily activities of a certain area bringing the need to fond a resolution to get these people out and return to normalcy .', 'They can interrupt the economic process in an area , and pressure will be put on the government to deal with them .', "> If I was a lawmaker , I would just ignore them . They ca n't stand around forever . 1 . Conspiracy aside , you would n't be a lawmaker for very long , because the same people protesting are probably the ones voting , or more accurately not voting for you anymore . 2 . The standing around is n't what actually makes the change . Protesting is a component in raising awareness on many levels . It interrupts a lot of things , which can lead to news outlets taking notice , which makes more citizens aware of the issue . It also makes lawmakers have to face if it is worth it to let the disruption continue . Lawmakers very often do ignore small protests for that reason , but big ones do more damage . But it 's important that people do n't JUST protest . They have to petition the government , or change their voting habits , or even impeach officials if necessary . And if things get really really serious they would need to have a revolution , but hopefully not . edit : forgot a thing ."]

id: How do rubbing ointments like Vicks work ? How does rubbing it on my throat make me cough less ? I 've wondered this for years Explain like I'm five.
text: ["It 's the vapors that actually contain the chemicals to reduce coughing ( thus the term , VapoRub for vapor rub ) . Rubbing it on your chest or neck simply puts it in close proximity to your mouth and nose where you can inhale it .", "It 's not an antitussive ( anti - cough ) as far as I know , it just uses natural airway assisting aromas like peppermint to open and soothe inflamed tissues .", 'Menthol clears the sinus passages or creates the sensation thereof . It is believed to work by stimulating the cold receptors and either constricting the blood vessels or making you more sensitive to the air flow . The studies on those two results are lacking , but it does make people feel like they can breathe better .']

id: How does a nuclear bomb explode before hitting the ground ? I always thought that a bomb was meant to explode when hitting the ground Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Bombs are made for different purposes , those which explode on impact are designed to destroy what they actually hit , whilst those that explode in the air cause damage to a wider area . Nuclear bombs are an area effect weapon so they work best when detonated at altitude this can be triggered in a number of different ways one of which is using the difference in pressure at different heights .', 'While some bombs are crude enough to rely on simple kinetic energy ( slamming into the ground ) to ignite , many â including nuclear bombs â are not set up that way and require a fuze . A fuze is just a little device that triggers the detonation . For a ground burst , a fuze might be a little button that gets pushed , which would set off a tiny explosion , that would set off the larger , main explosion . For an airburst , there are different kinds of fuzes that can be used either individually or together to make sure the bomb goes off at the right height . All of this applies to conventional as well as nuclear weapons , though with nuclear weapons it is especially important to have good fuzing because they will not typically explode in a nuclear fashion if they just slam into the ground without a fuze ( they are complicated devices that require precise timing to work ) Examples of aerial fuzing might include : * A timer that activates when the bomb leaves the plane or whatever . This is a very crude method but if you know it will take 45 seconds to fall to the right height , you can just time it . * A device that uses barometric pressure to detect how far up or down it is . The precision on this kind of thing can be tricky , but they have been used . * A device that serves essentially as a little radar antenna to detect where the ground is , by bouncing radio signals off of it . And so on . In the first atomic bombs , all three of these were used in a sequence to make sure that the bombs were more or less at the right altitude before they exploded ( the timer made such the bomb was outside of the plane , the barometric switch made sure it was below a certain altitude , and the radar antenna did the final check ) . You could even use GPS for this sort of thing , though there are errors that might be added . Depending on the nature of the target you are trying to hit , there are pros and cons for setting the bomb off in the air or on the ground . Generally speaking if you are trying to hit something relatively small and " hard " â like , say , an underground bunker or silo , or a single building , even a large one , like the Pentagon â you want your bomb to go off as close to the target as possible , because it concentrates the most pressure on it . If you are trying to hit something relatively large and " soft " â like , say , a city â you want your bomb to go off in the air , because it disperses medium and light pressures over a larger area ( for a variety of reasons ) . It is just a small note that for many years the nuclear weapons of the USA could _ only _ be used as airbursts because it is actually much harder to make a heavy , complex , delicate instrument that goes off at exactly the moment it hits the ground ( and before the collision breaks it ) than it is to make one that detonates several hundred feed above the ground .', 'i believe he is asking " how " in terms of how the process flows so the device always explodes before hitting the ground rather than " why " we let them explode above ground']

id: How do artificial flavourings work ? Do you mix a bunch of chemicals and end up with a strawberry tasting substance , is it just a process of concentrating the original food , or something else completely ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Nature produces some compounds that we find particularly tasty . We 're able to identify the structure of some of those compounds , and some of them are also pretty easy to synthesize , so we do .", '" flavour molecules " have a particular shape . For simplicity \'s sake , lets say that on a molecular level " strawberry flavour " is a hexagon . Our taste buds have proteins on their surface with a complementary shape to the flavour molecule , that allows them to stick together a bit like a notch and a dip in a jigsaw puzzle - but only if they \'re the same shape . When these two bind , the protein changes shape and releases a signal saying " Woo , strawberries ! " and your brain then receives the message " Woo , strawberries ! " Artificial flavourings work by having a similar shape to the flavour molecule , that allows it to bind to the flavour molecule \'s receptor . Let \'s say our artificial molecule is a hexagon with an extra stick coming off it . The receptor protein does n\'t notice this extra stick , because it \'s only looking for the hexagon . Whenever it binds to a hexagon , regardless of anything attached to the hexagon , it sends the " Woo , strawberries ! " message .', 'In some cases it was accidental that someone realized a certain chemical tasted like a certain food . In most cases , chemists determine what naturally - occurring chemicals are responsible for the flavours in foods , and then they either synthesize that chemical or an analogue to it .']

id: How does Google have a searchable version of the internet that is n't the same size as the internet ? I just what how can this machine even work what is this a school for ants ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['In the same way a book has a index which is much smaller then the size of the book but allows you to find which page something is on , Google has a index of Internet . First of all the Google Search Database does contain a large portion of the text of the internet but is less concerned with the video , and pictures which is where most of the actual size comes from . It then creates a index of the data allowing the search engine to quickly search the internet , and then compresses the crap out of the webpage making it small and manageable enough .', "It does n't actually store the entire internet . It merely stores the locations . It 's the difference between owning a house , and knowing where a house is .", "They also do n't they only index about 5 % of the web , or so i was told in my comp sci class ."]

id: How does Dry Cleaning work ? Is it truly dry ? The concept of " Dry Cleaning " seems like magic to me Explain like I'm five.
text: ['I \'ve been waiting my whole reddit life for this . I \'ve worked at my families dry cleaners for 12 years . u / firstworldanarchist is correct . The clothes do get " wet " from a chemical called PERCHLOROETHYLENE . There are many different chemicals that dry cleaners use , but this was the most common one in the 80 \'s and 90 \'s , but is being phased out due to possible environmental concerns . The newer " greener " chemicals just do n\'t work as well at removing stains on garments . PERCHLOROETHYLENE is a chemical that will absolutely destroy any oil based substance as well as any other stain ( for the most part ) that water can not dissolve . This means that your grease stain from that salad dressing you dripped on your shirt is removed through a washing cycle much like that of a normal home washer , but using a different cleaning solution , as well as much higher temperatures . Things such as gum and lipstick will also dissolve in the chemical , making your garment like new again . But things such as pop stains will come out looking like a white patch due to the left over sugars that the chemical can not dissolve , which then the stain would be treated with a steam gun to dissolve it .', 'It uses an ~~alcohol~~ ethylene based liquid , instead of water . So the clothes get " wet " to remove the dirt , they just never come in contact with h2o .', "No it 's not dry . It really should be called chemical cleaning . edit It actually is caled _ chemical cleaning _ in swedish"]

id: How do we know what Ancient Egyptian sounds like ? This question has always baffled me . We had no clue how to read their writing until the discovery of the Rosetta Stone , so how the heck do we attribute sounds to their hieroglyphics ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['It really depends on what language you \'re talking about . In the specific example you cite , we are fortunate enough to have use of the Rosetta stone which has the same passage in Hyrogliphics , Demotic Egyptian Script and Ancient Greek . Since we know what Demotic Egyptian sounds like , we can do pretty well with figuring out what Ancient Egyptian sounds like . Also , Languages do n\'t exist in a vacuum . They frequently have modern relatives that can be useful in guiding us when we try to decipher how phonemes sounded . For Ancient Egyptian , the modern derivative language would be Coptic , primarily used as the liturgical language of Egyptian & Sudanese Christians . Last , through our experience studying language , we have developed a number of linguistic shortcuts that help us map out how sounds change across language and time . For example , in Semitic languages , we find that the " sh " sound and the " \'s " sound are frequently interchangeable . This would explain why the Arabic Salaam is the Hebrew Shalom or why the Arabic " Quds " ( Jerusalem ) is cognate with the Hebrew " Kadosh " ( Holy ) . This gives us short hand rules for reconstructing the sounds of dead languages . The degree to which we are successful depends on a lot of the factors outlined above . We \'re a lot better if a language has lots of " progeny " - so to speak -and is less old . That being said , I think a serious scholar of ancient Egypt would do surprisingly well if you dropped him in a 3rd Century BC Heliopolis bazaar . * * Edit :* * One additional thought . The above not withstanding , some other ancient languages we are not so fortunate with . For example , if you can decipher [ this guy ] ( URL_0 ) you can look forward to a plump job in Oxford or Harvard or wherever the fuck you want . If you look at the wiki page , you \'ll notice that the progress that we * have * made is largely a result of our knowledge of other languages , namely Semitic .', "We do n't , really , any more than we know what Ancient Greek or Latin sounded like . All we can do is make a rough guess based on how modern language sounds , but that 's pretty inaccurate since language changes so much over the years . We have to use something to speak it though , so we just guess . If we had a time machine , though , chances are the average ancient Egyptian would barely understand what someone was saying .", 'While I agree with everyone else who says that we do n\'t know for sure , we can make very educated guesses , there are some surprising clues . For example , when we find poetry with rhyming words , that tells us a lot about sounds - it tells us that two words sound the same , which might not have been obvious from their spelling . Ever read Shakespeare and get annoyed that things do n\'t quite rhyme sometimes ? Back in Shakespeare \'s day , they did rhyme ! For example : > Shall I compare thee to a summer \'s day ? > Thou art more lovely and more temperate : > Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May , > And summer \'s lease hath all too short a date : > Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines , > And often is his gold complexion dimm\'d ; > And every fair from fair sometime declines , > By chance or nature \'s changing course untrimm\'d ; > But thy eternal summer shall not fade > Nor lose possession of that fair thou owest ; > Nor shall Death brag thou wander\'st in his shade , > When in eternal lines to time thou growest : > So long as men can breathe or eyes can see , > So long lives this and this gives life to thee . A few hundred years ago , " temperate " and " date " would have rhymed , and " owest " and " growest " would have rhymed . I do n\'t know much about ancient Egyptian but I know that there are many clues like this that we can use to make pretty good educated guesses about how it sounded .']

id: How do they make decaffeinated coffee ? I would really like to know . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["You know the gas , carbon dioxide ( CO2 ) ? If you squeeze it really tightly -- put it under very high pressure -- it actually behaves kind of like a liquid . Like a liquid , it can dissolve things , like water can dissolve salt . Imagine you have a toy that 's covered in salt that you want to get rid of . A simple way of getting rid of the salt would be to toss the toy in some water . The salt dissolves , but the toy is intact , and you end up with a salt - free toy . Coffee decaffeination works in a similar way , except instead of water , this liquid - like CO2 is used . This CO2 can dissolve caffeine , but not other things in a coffee bean . So if you run this special CO2 over a batch of coffee beans , you 'll take out all of the caffeine , leaving you with caffeine - free coffee beans . And , as a special bonus : you also get a bunch of pure caffeine dissolved in this special CO2 , which you can sell to companies that put caffeine in their products ! And getting the caffeine out is really easy . In the salty toy example , if you wanted to get your salt back , you would have to evaporate the water that the salt was dissolved in . That can take a long time . But with the special CO2 , you simply un - squeeze it , and then it becomes normal gaseous CO2 , leaving you with your caffeine .", 'The real question is * why * .', "I saw this on my front page , thinking that it was from /r / jokes . Upon reading the text I thought to myself , that 's a terrible punchline . And now I feel like an idiot ."]
