id: How do gas planets have any kind of objects orbiting them and/or gravity when they are just a big ball of gas , no rocks and stuff ? It seems to me if they have gravity stuff would just go right through them . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Gas is the same stuff as solid matter , just all spread out . Every particle of matter has its own gravity ; the gravity of a planet is the combined gravity of each of its particles . Also , gas giants are only mostly made of gas - they 're believed to have solid cores and oceans of liquid .", 'Even something that is as fluid as gas still contains mass . When you you have something as big as Jupiter , that is a lot of mass . The greater the mass of an object the greater the influence , that we call gravity , it exerts on other objects . Gas planets can exert enough gravity to cause other objects to remain in their orbit . Additionally there is ongoing debate on whether gas giants like Jupiter actually contains a solid core or not although it is generally accepted that there is a mass of heavy elements near the center . Edit : Added some stuff .', 'Stars are made of gas too . You just have toget enough of it in one place . Besides , gas giants do have molten rocky cores .']

id: How do satellites avoid running into each other ? If there are so many up there ... also , what would happen if 2 hit each other ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Mostly they do n't hit because earth is massive and there is still tons of space between them , making the chances of a collision very very low . So the main reason is that we 're just throwing them up there and hoping they do n't hit each other . There is an organization called [ NORAD ] ( URL_0 ) which tracks all known debris ( satellites are n't the only thing floating around up there ) and can warn people if two things are about to collide , and then if the satellite can , it moves out of its orbit slightly to avoid the collisions . If two satellites were to collide , they would probably be ruined , even if it was just a scrape .", "[ This is an image of all of the satellites around Earth . ] ( URL_0 ) Pretty scary , huh ? But really , they are all far apart enough ( and their orbit trajectories are n't all opposite ) so that they do n't collide . Also , as Master565 noted , NORAD can enable satellites to dodge debris .", 'Space is REALLY , REALLY , REALLY big .']

id: How do buffets make profit ? Every time I go to a buffet , I always eat the expensive shit . It just baffles me how they make profit , because I 'm always 98 % sure I just ate more than I paid them . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["If you buy in bulk , raw ingredients are * insanely * cheap . Buffets are profitable specifically because everyone is 98 % sure they ate more than you paid them ; unless it 's a very high quality buffet , there probably is n't anything you * could * eat enough of to manage that .", "There are a couple things working in favor of a buffet . First is that when I go to a buffet during the week , I go there because I can get my food fast and do n't have the time to glutton myself . Most people choose buffets for that reason . The next is that buffets save the restaurant a lot of money on things that you do n't get when you go to an all you can eat . The cost of food for the restaurant is n't the biggest cost . It is the cost of the person taking your order , the cost of the person cooking your food , and the cost of the person bringing the food to you . In a buffet , what do you get for service ? A hostess who seats you and takes your drink order then shows you where the plates are . She can seat more people than she could in a traditional restaurant . If she can seat and serve more people , that saves the cost of hiring another person who would have to take on the extra customers .", 'although you ate a lot , you probably only ate about $ 4 worth of food that you paid $ 8 for .']

id: How do you fit two GTX1080 into a laptop ? URL_0 Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Most of the physical structure you see in computer components away from the actual board is for cooling purposes . You can strip most of that away and the card still functions , assuming you can keep it cool . This is also part of the reason why " gaming laptops " are treated as a joke by many PC users ; they have serious firepower on paper , but throw them a mean look and they \'ll overheat .', 'The actual GPU chip is not that big . Graphics card tend to be big because of the heatsink and fans . With some careful placing and integration you could easily fit all the components of a big gaming computer on a PCB the size of a laptop . The problem is that it will still generate as much heat as a gaming computer . To start with laptops use all available space for heatsinks . The chassis is also close to the components which also help dissipating heat . Gaming laptops also tend to have very fast fans to get as much air through them as possible . That being said current gaming laptops is very hot and noisy and the next generation is likely not going to be any cooler or quieter .', "Because it 's barely a laptop ... The thing is almost the size of three macbooks put together ."]

id: How do people decipher ancient writing / symbols ? For example , hieroglyphics . How do you even begin to understand them ? Is there a standard procedure ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Well , every case is unique . In the case of hieroglyphics , as others here have already pointed out , linguists were very fortunate to have found the Rosetta Stone . But mostly , it \'s a case of using the same kind of techniques used to crack codes and ciphers , except it \'s much more difficult . What linguists are looking for is some kind of pattern , so you really need to find as many examples of the script as you can . It \'s then a laborious process of cataloguing every symbol that appears . How often does it appear ? What other symbols appear with it ? How is it distributed in the text ? For example , suppose a Martian found a few books in English and wanted to decipher it . One of the first things he might notice is that at one corner of each page is a sequence of signs that follow a very regular pattern . He might guess that this is a counting system , and that each page was carefully numbered . This is actually a huge help , because not only does he know that we use a decimal counting system , but he knows which order the pages are intended to be read in , which also allows him to deduce that we read from left to right . On looking at the text , he notices that there is a relatively small number of different symbols , but they are grouped into clusters . So perhaps he \'s looking at a writing system that uses an alphabet , with symbols representing sounds grouped into words . Some of these words appear quite often : " the " , " a " , " an " , " it " , " is " and so on are very common , so perhaps they have some kind of grammatical function . A lot of words seem to end in " ing " or " ed " , so maybe those are grammatical markers as well . He would probably notice that the sequence " the " never occurs at the beginning of a line or after a " . " symbol , but in those positions he often sees the sequence " The " . If he \'s really on the ball here , he \'d realize that " T " and " t " are two variants of the same letter . Looking back at all the statistics he \'s collected about the frequency of certain symbols and where they occur , he \'ll notice many more such pairs , and this would allow him to deduce that English uses an alphabet with two forms for each letter , and one of those forms ( which is usually bigger and more " blocky " looking than the other ) has some significance . It \'s through this kind of process that he gradually builds up a picture of the English language . If he has a way of knowing what kind of book he \'s holding in his tentacles ( " Wait , is that a representation of an atom ? Could this be a chemistry textbook ? " ) , he \'s well on his way to deciphering the text ( " If this represents a proton and an orbiting electron , then that must be the word for \' hydrogen \' " ) .', 'The story of the Rosetta Stone is great . I visit it at the British Museum a few times a year , and the story of it is just fantastic . In 1799 a soldier involved in Napoleon \'s Egyptian expedition finds this stone , and straight away it \'s obvious it could be useful because its context suggests that it \'s the same text in multiple languages . It has upon it a decree from King Ptolemy V in 196 BC in three languages : hieroglyphs , demotic script and ancient Greek . The decree is basically a " Yo , Ptolemy V and his wife are totally boss and all the priests are like super impressed and stuff , and you should be too , \' k ? " style of message . By 1801 they were still struggling with understanding the Greek . Basically , whilst scholars have a good handle on ancient Greek , it \'s full of weird administrative jargon and bits of it were missing , so it took a while to sort that out . Then there is the middle section in Demotic . Hardly anybody knew how to read this , but there was this Swedish guy who had a bit of a handle on it , and could confirm that it was indeed the same text as the Greek , so that meant the hieroglyphs were likely to be the same text too . In 1811 a man called Silvestre de Sacy is thinking about the problem and considering a suggestion that the foreign names in hieroglyphs are phonetic . He does nothing about it until another guy called Thomas Young , wrote to him about the stone in 1814 , when de Sacy suggests he finds the cartouches that might contain Greek names , and see if he can find phonetic characters in them . Thomas Young does so and decodes the name of Ptolemy and a bunch of other characters as a result . This is good result . Later that year he is exchanging letters with a teacher in Grenoble who has written scholarly works on Egypt called Jean - FranÃ§ois Champollion . Champollion takes another look at his lithograph of the stone and is able to find the cartouche for " kleopatra " and realises he can build a phonetic alphabet . It takes another 20 years for Champollion to fill in the gaps , but he and others do so and by 1832 there is a good understanding of what \'s going on . Those 20 years were spent trying to understand grammar and making all sorts of leaps of faith and trying to figure out how closely it resembled Demotic script and Greek . It \'s slow , methodical work . So in this case it \'s clear that the trick was a bunch of accidents and sharing of knowledge based on hunches and publication of pieces of the puzzle and a lot of hard work .', 'In 1799 , the [ Rosetta Stone ! ] ( URL_0 ) was found which provided a decree in three different languages : Greek , Demotic , and Hieroglyphic . Since we knew Greek , it gave us a translation guide to two other languages , which formed our modern understanding of the ancient Egyptians . I hope this helps .']

id: How do people die in wildfires ? It âs not like the area spontaneously combusts , do nât people have ample time to get to safety ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['> It âs not like the area spontaneously combusts , do nât people have ample time to get to safety ? It sort of does spontaneously combust . Imagine a wall of flame approaching at 50 + mph and winds carrying embers which are dropping around you . Each of those might start their own fires in any direction , blocking your movement and vision . Look around your house , how far can you see ? Probably not more than a mile or two at most . Once you can see fire you are probably out of time .', "In normal forest fires most of the time yes people can evacuate in time because they have an hour or two to get out of the way . If you 're talking about the fires in California right now like in the Napa Valley those are not regular forest fires , those are firestorms . A firestorm is a result of a fire that burns so hot that it actually changes the weather around it and causes air to be sucked into the base of the Flames causing them to burn even hotter which causes more air to be sucked in and the Flames to burn even hotter ... the result is a wall of flame several stories tall moving faster than what you can legally do on some freeways . The time difference from when you first see the Flames to when you are literally being burned by the Flames can be 2 to 3 minutes . Now you might say that it is possible to get away from a fire in 2 to 3 minutes but I 'll remind you that in most places of the world roads do not go directly away from disasters . Especially in places that are literally valleys or Canyons where there are only one or two roads out of an area meaning sometimes your last evacuation route is actually towards the flames and you need to just shelter in place . Sheltering in place can be an acceptable Last Resort but considering the raw power of a firestorm there 's really no hope , we 're even seeing melted engine blocks from the devastation areas so there 's really nothing you can do to hide from it . For those in the path if they did not evacuate when it was 25 miles away ( the next town over ) they may not have had a chance to leave at all . So stop and consider what is 25 miles away from you , and think that if that was a natural disaster , would you evacuate from your city just because of what 's happening 25 miles away ? Also the next time you 're on the freeway think about a wall of flame the height of a large building going that speed .", 'a wildfire breaks out 50 miles from you . do you evacuate ? probably not . with wind , fire can travel 10 mph . that fire that was 50 miles away from you when you went to bed is now on top of you when you wake up in the morning .']

id: How does NASA and other space agency âs manage to land a rover / probe on an moving asteroid ? Title . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["We 're really really good at intelligent computer and propulsion systems . There 's four steps to doing it . The first is launching . Got that down quite well with multi - stage rockets . The second is getting to the asteroid and matching its orbit . Got that down quite well with the ability to figure out where the asteroid 's orbit will take it . The third is selecting a spot to land . That can be performed by imaging the asteroid and determining a likely spot . The final one is programming the propulsion systems on the orbiter part to drop its lander on the asteroid . With all the data you 've collected so far , this is also achievable using sophisticated computer - driven propulsion systems with distance - detection measurement devices and self - correcting capability . All of that stuff , we have now . We just need to do a lot of tweaking and testing and solid engineering to make it all work together .", "Others have already given the explanation , I just want to address an underlying assumption you seem to be making : You might as well ask how people managed to land on a moving moon , i.e. our Moon . Nothing in space is standing still . Everything is moving in orbit around something else . Our sun orbits around the centre of the galaxy . Our galaxy and the local galaxy group orbit around their centre of gravity . What you want to do is make sure you orbit the centre of gravity ( the Sun , in this case ) at the same speed and with the same orbital parameters that the asteroid does . So it 's like the car analogy that u / Xalteox made : when you 're next to an asteroid at exactly the same speed , you would n't notice that the asteroid is moving . So how do we get to the asteroid ? Very basically ( and I 'll skip the launch part ) , you 're in Earth orbit , travelling a few hundred kilometres above the surface at around 7,700 m / s - that 's roughly 17,000 mph or 28,000 km / h. We need to change our orbit so it crosses that of the asteroid . Timing is important - crossing the asteroid 's orbit when it 's on the other side of the sun is useless . The time where you can burn to intercept is the transfer window . Theoretically , it would n't matter that much , only you would need very , * very * large amounts of fuel , a much larger engine to propel the much heavier spacecraft and maybe several billions of dollars . That 's not feasable , so we wait for the transfer window . Once it comes , we burn the engine for a while until we 're at such a speed that Earth 's gravity can no longer pull us back around . Think of a car on a racetrack that 's too fast to go around a curve and skids off the track - that 's what we 're trying to do here . Only our result will be that we 'll change from orbiting Earth to orbiting the Sun . Once we are at the intercept point ( and hopefully we got everything right and the asteroid is also there ) , we burn the engines again for a while , changing our speed until our orbit of the Sun matches that of the asteroid . And then we do what the other posters said : use thrusters to gently manoeuvre us down to the surface . As I said , this is the very basic version . If you want to try something like that , I 'll shamelessly advise you to download the free demo version of Kerbal Space Program from Steam . Once you 've become addicted to the game like most people ( including me ) , there are mods to make it as realistic ( i.e. very hard ) as home simulations can be , n - body physics and all .", 'Imagine jumping from one car to another while moving 60 miles per hour . The wind makes it a little difficult to do so in reality , but imagine that the air , therefore wind does not exist . It would be quite simple to jump across , no issues .']

id: How does a mirror of a video make it harder to takedown ? On places like putlocker and other streaming sites they have mirrors of videos where the video is reflected horizontally . How does that make it harder for copyright infringement ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["These horizontally mirrored videos that you speak of are effective at evading many automatic detection systems that are designed to fingerprint copyright source material and automatically detect similar ( potentially infringing ) content that is posted to the site . When the ( audio ) pitch is altered slightly and/or the video is mirrored horizontally , the ' fingerprint ' of the original source material is no longer sufficient to identify the altered mirror video that is posted , thus these videos can remain on the site longer and evade detection until they are manually reported or discovered by one of the site 's operators or content moderators .", "The creators basically send their video to a scanning script on a video sharing website . The ' scanner ' will check to see whether anyone else has uploaded any of the same bits of that video or audio . If it matches , it will then automatically take down the video due to copyright infringement . People are able to get around this by mirroring / flipping the video as you said as well as other techniques such as changing the audio 's pitch or cropping the video . ( this is my first post on this sub , so apologies if I 've done anything incorrectly ) .", '~~"mirroring " they meant here is hosting it on several different host / server . Since there are several party involved , to take down some infringing video , infringed party have to contact all involved server and notice them for take down . From here on , math doing the work , it is easier to notice 1 host and take 1 video down , than notice 5 different host and take 5 identical video down.~~ Did n\'t realize until i re - read the question a few times . I honestly never notice any pirated video that " flipped " around . Data in computer saved as number " 0 " and " 1 " called bit forming a long line of something like " 0100 1010 1001 " . Some server than handle bulk data may check for the " files signature " , if data were similar enough ( to their black list ) , they will be flagged to be further check . I know that is how it worked for picture ( more complex for color picture , after file compression , let alone video ) , the file signature for picture can still be the same if they \'re just flipped around , but for a video files , they \'re large enough so that their similar part became obscure . That \'s all i know about this topic , there are also another identifier for copyright infringement that i do n\'t understand how it work .']

id: How do waves transfer Energy I m talking about Tsunami waves . How much energy does it transfer ? Where does it come from , where does it go ? How fast do they move ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Tsunami waves like all ocean waves occur because two molecules ca n't be in the same place at the same time . This is a basic fact of fluid dynamics . So when waves ' move ' the water is mostly staying in the same place because it moves very little . But it bumps up against the water molecules around it giving up their energy and stopping as they 've given it up . But whatever molecules they just bumped into now have the energy and so they move a short distance , bump into something , give it up and stop etc . It 's like those desktop toys with the metal balls clanking back and forth . The balls themselves do n't move , or they move very little . They mostly act as a conductor of energy . So a tsunami originating in Japan travels as an energy wave ' through ' the water . The water itself does n't move so Japanese water stays in Japan even if the tsunami is moving towards Hawaii . This is also the reason why at sea a tsunami is not even really noticeable . The energy is spread out immensely from top to bottom , so you have a huge mass of water bouncing around but the wave is only centimeters high . It still has energy because of how much water is in play though . As the wave approaches shallower depths , the energy stops being spread out among large masses of water , and starts being concentrated , by the decreasing depth , and the wave starts growing taller and taller . This focusing of the energy also causes the waves to slow down in speed , and increase in height . In the open ocean a tsunami energy wave travels incredibly fast , like jet speed fast . As it comes up onto shore though it 's much slower , but much taller , and at that point water is moving not just acting as a conductor . The slow waves at the coast , with fast waves coming in behind it , causes a surge , pushing large amounts of water near the shore so not only do the waves get tall , but the local sea level also rises . This is why the water on land looks like it 's risen and flooded instead of just immediately washing back out to sea .", 'thermal energy in earths magma below crust > kinetic energy in tectonic plates ( earthquakes underwater ) > kinetic energy in water . the energy is then lost in a lot of ways , i m guessing , at a fundamental level , because work is done against gravity as it moves out of the sea , but also friction with everything the tsunami contacts according to this link URL_0 the 2011 tsunami in japan had an energy ~1.3x10 ^ 14 Joules ( as a low estimate )', 'So , think of it this way , little Tim - Tom - Mathis - Tong , our planet is n\'t exactly solid . We float on these big plates of rock . Think of them exactly like dinner plates , except much much bigger , so they could hold at least 10 times more of your Mom \'s disgusting meatloaf . So these plates are just floating on top of liquid magma , and every now and then the plates collide or separate . When this happens , those plates actually moving sends a huge shock wave out into the water . The thing about liquids is that they act like they \'re composed of a bunch of little bouncy balls . Now , what happens if you push one bouncy ball in a stack of bouncy balls ? The other balls move . So , when this plate releases this huge shock into the water , it creates a " wave " of movement that emits from wherever the center point of those plates touching was . As the balls keep moving away they dissipate that energy , or speed , to each other ball . But as the energy wave goes closer to land , it has less and less balls to push . So that energy becomes more concentrated , and it becomes so concentrated that it creates a massive wave of water ! AND BOOM ! IT KILLS GODZILLA ! Yeah , what a jerk wave , right ?']

id: How does a elevator algorithm work ? Considering there are multiple elevators going to the same floors . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['The elevator algorithm is simple : 1 . If there is a called floor in the direction the elevator is going , go there 2 . Otherwise , if there is a called floor in the opposite direction , change directions and go there 3 . Otherwise , go nowhere ( or sometimes go back to a specific floor ) Generally with multiple elevators there is no coordination beyond not servicing a floor that another elevator is already headed to . There * are * more advanced algorithms . The Marriot Marquis in NYC was known for having wait times of up to 30 minutes , and about a decade ago installed a [ destination dispatch ] ( URL_0 ) elevator system . Users punch in their desired floor in advance , and the system tells them which shaft to use . This allows a computer to optimize the elevator use more efficiently .', "The elevator algorithm is actually pretty important in computer science . It is pretty simple to understand though . When called , the elevator will prioritize the calls that are in his way , then it goes the other way . If the elevator is going up , it will continue to go up until there 's no one left calling it in the up direction or until it reaches maximum floor . Then it goes down with the same logic .", 'The real answer is : It is * very * complex . In the most simple approach you click a button and a software determines which elevator goes there and then blocks all others from answering that call . In reality ... it is vastly , vastly complex and engineers and computer scientists work on it . For example , modern algorithms try to base where which elevator does what based on the time of the day , for example : * in the morning a lot of people want to go from the " bottom " to all kinds of floors further up with a massive peak demand * during the day most people want to drive around in the house but the demand is spread more evenly , the algorithm might attempt to reserve elevators for certain parts of the house , one might jump a request if it already has many buttons pressed from the inside , and another is scheduled for that outside - request * unless it is around noon , when all kinds of people want to go down for lunch * and in the evening a lot of people might want to go down to the bottom again . * many , many , many more cases depening on time , the type of house ( only offices in there ? A mix of office and businesses ? Entertainment venues ( a club on the roof ? A gym in the middle ? Shopping center ? What if there is also residence in it ? ) . All that said : There are probably entire careers in CS / engineering for " elevator optimisation " and every manufacturer has his own , probably very well guarded algorithms with custom ones for special houses ( you can bet that the Burj Khalifa does not steer its elevators with Siemens - Standard - Algorithm#2 they might roll out for some 5 - story residence ) . * * tl;dr There is no general answer and the issue is vastly complex . * *']

id: How do photographers make the sun / moon look massive ? [ Like this ] ( URL_0 ) Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Simply by zooming in with powerful lenses on far away objects . Think about the size of the moon relative to other objects on the far horizon- a tree may appear to be the same size of the moon if it 's far enough away from you . Now , simply zoom in on that scene and the moon will appear gigantic .", "This is called [ perspective ] ( URL_3 ) The concept is very simple - objects closer to you appear larger relative to objects farther away from you . You can make a finger in front of your eye look big enough to hide an entire bus that is few hundred meters away . The real trick is not that the Moon looks massive in that picture - perspective is actually tricking you to see the Moon as much smaller than it really is . Compare the size of the tree and the Moon in the photo - they look similar in size , but in reality the Moon is hundred thousand times bigger , it 's 3474 kilometers ( 2158 miles ) in diameter . It only looks as small as the tree because it is much farther away from us than the tree is . Here is one of my favorite illustrations of perspective using the Moon - two pictures of the International Space Station and the Moon together : - [ From Earth ] ( URL_2 ) - [ From space ] ( URL_1 ) In the first case , the camera is very far away from both , so their size relative to each other is somewhat closer to reality ( they would show real relative size only in a photo taken from a point that is equal distance from both ) , while in the second case , the camera is much closer to the ISS , making it appear much larger compared to the Moon . See also [ forced perspective ] ( URL_0 ) for how perspective can be used to trick deliberately .", 'if you want to see the difference between moving closer to something to make it bigger , and zooming in on something to make it bigger , google " dolly zoom "']

id: How do student loans influence college tuition ? With the situation at UC Berkeley , I 'd really like to understand what student loans actually mean in terms of their relation to the government . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['If pencils cost $ 2 and most people only have $ 1 then in order to sell pencils to the public the cost needs to come down . If people started taking out $ 1 loans to buy $ 2 pencils then stores can still sell pencils at $ 2 and the price would not go down', 'What do you mean in the context of the government ? Broadly , the government raised how much students were allowed to borrow . Because students were allowed to borrow more money , they could give schools more in tuition . Because students could give more to schools in tuition , schools raised tuition .', "Student loans are a speculative investment that no rational lender would ever undertake without collateral and co - signers . In other words , your parents should have to mortgage their house to afford your college tuition . The government has decided that it wants more college graduates than there are people who can afford to attend , or who could borrow the money to attend . To close that gap , the government engages in lending to people who otherwise would never be able to qualify for those loans . In return the government is gambling that in fact those people will manage to pay off that debt . They are gambling that the value of the education received will enable those borrowers to increase their lifetime earnings by enough to make the necessary repayments . Because there 's so little scrutiny about how much is borrowed and for what purpose , the college system has been able to raise tuitions with the knowledge that the government will continue to make loans available to pay for the tuition . So the risk the government has to take on each individual student has increased over time . Today things appear to be approaching an equilibrium where the difference in lifetime earnings and the cost of the debt + interest is approaching zero . When we pass that threshold , and the cost of the debt + interest becomes demonstrably more than the increase in lifetime earnings , there will be a revolution . A whole lot of people are going to default on their student loans . Then we 'll see what happens next ."]

id: How does Nasa know the exact course to chart with their space probes to get them on different planets ? ELI5 : How does Nasa know the exact course to chart with their space probes to get them on different planets ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Well they 're literally rocket scientists ... No , seriously , NASA has some of the finest astronomers in the world , who have learned how to perform the complex trajectory calculations necessary to fire a space probe travelling thousands of miles per hour , off of one planet travelling sixty - five thousand miles per hour , towards another planet travelling fifty - four thousand miles per hour ( Mars , for the sake of argument ) . To use a sports analogy , a hockey player does n't pass the puck to where his teammate is , he passes it to the point his teammate will be by the time the puck arrives . NASA is doing pretty much the same thing , just on an exponentially larger scale and using rockets .", 'Astrophysics -- figuring out how things as big as planets , moons , and stars move -- is pretty much only based on gravity . So the basic problem is : if we have a bunch of big objects and they all have mass and so they all attract each other , and we know where they are and how fast they \'re moving ( and in what direction ) , how do we figure out where they are going to be at any point in the future ? This is called the " n - body problem " . For very simple problems we can solve this exactly . For example , if the sun was concentrated into one tiny point ( but still weighed the same ) and the earth was another tiny point and the earth was the only planet , the earth would go around the sun repeating a kind of lopsided circle called an ellipse . But of course it is not that simple . We have two possible options . First , we can pretend that things really are simple , because it turns out the motion is very close anyway . That \'s what we do most of the time , but it \'s not quite accurate enough for aiming space probes and stuff . So the second method is to plug in some numbers and try to calculate how things change over a very short time , and then do it again with the updated numbers , and so on . This is called the numerical method , and it can be as accurate as you want , as long as you are willing to use very short time periods ( the shorter the time periods you use , the more math you have to do : for example , if you did it every ten minutes , you \'d need six calculations an hour , but if you did it every minute , you \'d need sixty ) . So that is basically what we do . We figure out which direction and how fast a planet is going , then we move forward a bit in time and figure out which direction and how fast the planet is going * then * , then we do it again . And eventually we find out where the planet is going to be in three months when our probe is supposed to reach it , and we \'ll know where to aim . One other thing you should know is that there are two main ways of figuring these problems out . One was found by Isaac Newton about three hundred years ago , and the other by Albert Einstein about a hundred years ago . Newton \'s way is easier , but Einstein \'s is more correct , so we usually use Einstein \'s these days when we need to be very correct , like in space probes . Explaining the difference between the two methods is a topic for another ELI5 , though .', 'In addition to what others have said , you also have to realize that these are not " fire and forget " missions . Each craft has a set of small rockets on board and enough fuel to make minor course corrections as they fly through space . You do still have to get all of the calculations extremely close at the beginning , but there is some room for error .']

id: How do pilots who speak different languages communicate with each other / air traffic control ? Is there an interpreter or something , or is the language barrier not really an issue ? How does this work ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['All pilots are required to know how to speak English , as are the people in the control tower . That way , everybody has a language they can all communicate in .', "As others have said , English is the international language of aviation , and there are some specific phrases that pilots are required to know in order to be able to communicate in English . However , there are two important pieces of information missing : - Not all airports use English . Some smaller airports which are mostly used by private hobby pilots use the local language . Some airports use a mix of English and the local language . Each country publishes a list of all the airports within the country , with a load of information about each airport , and one piece of information that 's published is which language is spoken at each airport . For example , at many smaller French airports , air traffic control only work during normal working hours , but after air traffic control is closed , the airport still remains open but all communication is in French . This information is published to pilots by the French authorities . - Even when the language is English , some pilots and controllers insist on using the local language . There was an accident in France many years ago ( sorry , I do n't remember the details and do n't have time to find them right now ) where a factor in the accident was that the French pilot was speaking French to the French air traffic controller . The air traffic controller made a mistake and cleared a British aircraft to take off when the French aircraft was still on the runway . Had the British pilot been able to understand the communication between air traffic control and the French pilot , he probably would have realised the mistake and questioned the instruction to take off , but because he did n't understand what was going on with the other aircraft , he had no way of knowing the runway was occupied , and followed the air traffic controller 's incorrect instruction to take off .", 'There is a specific list of English phrases all pilots must know - called Aviation English . It is designed to cover almost any situation and even designed to minimise any issues accents can cause . Some pilots and air traffic controllers still speak their native language regularly but when required can use Aviation English .']

id: How do microphone " Pop Filters " work ? How does putting a piece of fabric over your mic stop wind noise and plosives ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["> How does putting a piece of fabric over your mic stop wind noise Wind does n't blow through fabric very well . Most people learn this from their experience wearing clothes .", "A well - built microphone is Very sensitive to sound waves , and the metal mesh around it is for physical protection more than sound filtration . The ' fabric ' is actually a foam ; like a sponge . It 's not necessary for microphones further than a foot away , but speaking into a naked microphone close to your mouth will yield loud pops with every P and pick up all the .. saliva slapping sounds you may make when you speak .", 'I want to add to the very good explanations with [ this short example . ] ( URL_0 ) for people who might not know what you mean . Essentially " pop " noises are very sharp spikes of wind in addition to the sound . The microphone acts picks up the wind as well and that creates spikes in the audio . A pop filter stops the wind and only lets the vibration of the air ( the actual sound ) through . Try pulling your T - shirt over your nose . You still sound fine but blowing through it is very hard .']

id: How do digital clocks get " off " over time ? I have to reset the clock in my car every few months because it 'll be 3 - 4 minutes behind . How does this happen ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Digital clocks have a small device that vibrates in order to keep time . The clock is manufactured to know how many vibrations are in 1 second . However its never exact . It could actually be 1.0000001 seconds or 1.01 seconds or .999 seconds . So over time . Those very tiny errors add up to a couple extra minutes .', 'The quality of the crystal used in clocks determines how accurate it is . This is why you \'ll see some clocks and watches with " Quartz Movement " , they are saying the crystal inside the watch is made of quartz and is more reliable than some other crystal types . Higher end watches use more expensive crystals or even precious gemstones to keep more accurate time . Even a digital clock / watch has a crystal in it , and the ones they put in a car are far cheaper than one in a halfway decent digital watch .', "Some cheaper digital clocks use the frequency of the wall current . Wall current ( AC ) pulses 60 times per second in North America , and clocks can use this pulsing to determine the length of a second . However , the pulsing is n't exact . Other digital clocks use transistors to keep the second . These are far from perfect . The best type of self - contained digital clock is one that is synced to quartz , which vibrates precicely . You can also get one that syncs itself to an atomic clock , which is only off by a second every few million years"]

id: How do doctors find out a persons allergy ? Do they take blood samples and can tell from that ? I 'm assuming that they just do n't shove a peanut in your face to see if you have nut allergy . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['They place a grid on your body . Usually your back . 16 or so common allergens are then applied to your back and they see what your body reacts to .', 'Answering from personal experience . They have a " kit " containing hundreds of different common allergens and use a special tool to " inject " the allergens into your skin , in my case they " injected " my back . Then they wait 10 - 15 minutes for a reaction to occur . The areas that turn red indicate you are allergic to whatever was injected there . For allergies like peanuts many people find out by accident usually when they are young and the allergy has not yet fully developed . They swell up and feel funny after eating whatever it is then go to the doctor who tells them they had an allergic reaction .', "Skin tests if someone has a reaction but it needs to be pinpointed . Sometimes allergies are discovered during treatment . As a paramedic I always ask for allergies in a patient 's history , I also ask ( even if they say they do not have allergies ) before I administer a medication . Every patient is monitored for a reaction after drug administration to ensure there is not a reaction . So for some there is a dedicated test , other times we 'll find out during treatment ."]

id: How do emergency responders get access to gated communities & other restricted areas . Do they have a list of all the codes or a master unlock of sorts ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["One of the most common ways is the use of a Knox Box . It 's a small metal lock box . The first responder has a key to the box , and the keys to the building are inside . Google Knox Box , and you 'll see what they look like , and you 'll start seeing them everywhere you go .", 'There is no one - catch all solution . It would depend on the community and jurisdiction : 1 . The access mechanism has a built - in bypass for emergency services ; 2 . The community or area has 24/7 staffing to let in emergency vehicles ; 3 . The emergency service contacts , directly or indirectly , the security service for the area they are trying to access to let them on ; 4 . They break in ;', 'Nah . They have something better . A pretty heavy truck with a large metal bar in the front . But , seriously speaking , this is something that is in may places well regulated with laws . When a building is deemed fit to live in , the fire marshal ( or , you know . some other official with similar responsibilities ) signs off and confirms that the building is accessible and thus suitable . Along with all the other stuff like the inspection on the buildings * passive * fire protection and the test protocol for the sprinkler system . If there is a motor gate or some other obstacle that makes it rough to get in , expect that there are terms surrounding how that gate is to be operated . Things like " we should have a working RFID tag and a PIN . if it \'s not working , we will breach it . " Some communities try to be a bit stiff about it and covertly change the code or replace the locks . And when the fire marshal finds out , he will probably ask nicely to have a new code . Once . The next step is to issue an order to vacate .']

id: How does a computer screen work ? How am I able to see everything that i 'm seeing on my screen ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Your monitor has a grid of tiny little boxes called pixels ( short for picture element ) . Each one of these can be controlled independently to display a certain color and brightness . Your computer figures out how to draw your screen by filling in each pixel and sending that information to the monitor . It does this usually around 60 times each second , so for instance , if you move your mouse , each time the screen gets re - painted , the mouse pointer is just the tiniest bit further along its path , creating an illusion of movement .', "Sub - question that I think is relevant . Is everything on the screen , in machine code , simply the rgb value of every single pixel in one long string followed by the next screen 's individual pixel values , ad infinitum , 60 times a second ?", 'this awesome video explains how lcd screens work : URL_0']

id: How do they film shooting scenes in movies ? Do they use bullets ? It alwayas amazed me and I ca n't find anything about it on the internet Explain like I'm five.
text: ['The short answer is " not often " The long answer is that the prop houses use a variety of different types of firearms in the making of their scenes . Some scenes do use live ammo , example would be this [ phenomenal clip from the movie Act of Valor ] ( URL_1 ) where they shoot up a car . Scenes like this require a lot of safety , coordination and remote shooting . Most often they use firearms that have been specially modified to fire blank ammunition . This requires the firearm to have a blank firing adaptor to be affixed to the firearm in some way , usually camouflaged at the end of the barrel , between the flash suppressor and the barrel itself , so that the action can cycle normally ( otherwise the firearm becomes single shot only and needs to be manually recharged ) . To create the bullet impact effects with these sorts of guns they will use a variety of techniques from CGI to practical effects such as squibs behind the surface being shot at , paintball guns with the balls loaded with dust and a sparking compound , or other practical features . Firearms safety is a big deal in the movie world as [ Brandon Lee was killed by improper firearm handling ] ( URL_0 ) on a set and an incompetent prop crew . Edit : with CGI becoming less and less expensive , you \'d be surprised by the number of rubber guns being used on productions and no blanks being used at all . Airsoft weapons are a lot cheaper to buy and easier to replace so you \'ll find them in use in many scenes where no actual firing is being done .', "they use special guns that can only shoot blanks . As seen on that gun maker show on discovery . Red Jacket is the company name n the show . If the scene does n't have people at risk of being hit , they probably could use real bullets . Shooting a a car or wall for instance .", 'They use blanks for the most part . Bullet impacts on people and objects are often created using [ squibs ] ( URL_0 ) .']

id: How do student loans contribute to the rising price of higher education ? ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["It 's less the fact that student loans exist , and more the fact that the government guarantees student loans . So , when students were able to get loans from the government , colleges raised tuition , to see how much money that they * could * get for it . Basically , since high prices did n't * deter * anyone ( or at least not * many * people , comparatively ) , since they could just get a loan to cover the costs , and college was being pushed on these kids as something that they * absolutely had to do * by high school teachers and counselors , as well as their parents ... they raised prices as high as the government would give loans , until the gov't put a cap on it at some point .", 'In the US the price of higher education is based on supply and demand . If more people can get student loans then more people are able to pay more expensive studies so the demand goes up and so does the price .', 'There are many interrelated reasons that /u / Qwerty_Resident has already touched on . 1 . There is a high demand for college degrees because they correlate significantly with lifetime earnings . 2 . Demand increased astronomically when student loans became much easier to get . Why did they become easier to get ? The government put in regulations that did n\'t allow lenders to use relevant criteria for their loans --- basically they were unable to effectively screen applicants based on who they thought would actually have the earnings to pay them back . At the same time , the government made it impossible for borrowers to discharge student loan debt via bankruptcy ... this satisfied the lenders that they would still be able to collect on these ( essentially ) bad loans , so they made them . ( You should see some parallels with the housing crisis here --- the " dream " that everyone should own a house is quite similar to the one that everyone should go to college . ) 3 . Universities have not kept pace with demand , that is , they have n\'t increased significantly the supply , therefore the price rises . Also , they have n\'t invested earning into more classrooms and teachers generally , but in student attracting activity centers and the like . ( Keep in mind that new construction is often very expensive for universities --- and a long - term investment . )']

id: How do whiskey companies deal with the fact that the product they make today gets sold to a market 15 years in the future ? How do you respond to shifts in demand with a latency of 15 + years for the maturation of your product ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['If the demand is higher than predicted : * Raise prices , of course * Offer more whisky that has n\'t been aged as long . If a distillery produces both a 12 and an 18year bottling , they may choose to release more of the 12 year right away . Of course that means 6 years later they \'ll have less available at 18 years . At that point they \'ll either make less money or try to raise prices on the 18 . * Right now , some distilleries that traditionally offered only 12 year and older are starting to release younger whisky , such as 10 or even 8 year old . If demand is lower than predicted : * Hold some to sell later . * Release something called a " bastard malt " . That \'s a whisky that does n\'t have the original distillery on the label , and is sold cheaper than the branded bottles . It \'s not necessarily true that these bottles will be as good as the ones that carry the true distillery name . The taste of the whisky in every cask is different , so the best casks can be retained for the distillery brand . One thing that gives the distilleries a little more flexibility is that the age on the bottle does n\'t mean all the whisky in the bottle is exactly that many years old . It \'s actually * minimum * age in the bottle . Everything in the bottle is at least that many years old , but may be older . \\ * Edit Fixed some typos that made me sound like I \'d had a dram or two before answering .', 'Mackmyra whiskey from Sweden solves this in a fun way . They let you buy casks with a group of friends , you get to follow the journey of that batch and taste it during the aging progress ( I believe once every year or so ) , the kicker is that you pay a hefty overprice for this in order to fund their future products ( the usual aged whiskey ) but you get a really unique experience and insight in return .', "There are some new distilleries starting up in Texas that are having to deal with the fact that they ca n't sell new whiskey as bourbon until it has aged a certain amount . To compensate and still bring in money for their investors they are either releasing blended whiskeys or distilling other spirits such as vodka . The plan is to eventually just sell aged bourbon , but they have to do something in the mean time to show profit to their investors . This strategy may not be relevant to the big established producers , but it works for the small specialty producers ."]

id: How do musicians make money ? How are they paid when their songs get played on the radio ? Besides concerts and endorsements , of course . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["> How are they paid when their songs get played on the radio ? This is a VERY basic answer . The laws are different to each country . Every song is assigned an ISRC code . ISRC codes are the international identification system for sound recordings and music video recordings . Each ISRC is a unique and permanent identifier for a specific recording which can be permanently encoded into a product as its digital fingerprint . The ISRC provides the means to automatically identify recordings for royalty payments , and increasingly becoming a tool in the fight against piracy . In many countries , there are agencies set up dedicated to gathering royalties for artists , and distributing them . In for example , Australia , ( generally speaking ) every time you hear music in a public place someone is paying royalties , and agency APRA / AMCOS collects and distributes licence fees . All clubs , bars , cafes , shopping malls , stores with ' in store ' radio playlists , music venues , or anywhere that has a DJ , are required to submit a playlist of the tracks they play , and are charged accordingly . If you do n't provide a list of tracks , you 'll receive a fine . I believe you can also purchase a licence for a year to play music in stores without providing a playlist , but offhand I 'm not 100 % sure of the details . This of course , also applies to radio stations and tv channels and shows .", "Musicians do n't make money . Source : My brother is a full time musician .", 'Some basic lists : URL_0 URL_1 Their source : URL_2']

id: How do large cities not run out of number and letters combinations to put on license plates ? What would happen if they did ? Title . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Because with a 7 digit license plate , there are over 78 billion unique combinations of letters and numbers . If any licensing agency somehow managed to exhaust that number , they would just add another digit .', 'California uses 7 characters for their license plates . With letters and numbers that means that each character has 36 options . This means there are 36 ^ 7 possible combinations of license plates . Which is more than there are currently people on earth . In reality they are more limited than this : The first character is always a number for example , but they do not have to be .', 'They do nt . For license plates with three letters followed by three digits there are 17,576,000 combinations there are not that many vehicles in most jurisdictions . Big places like california with over 30 million registered vehicles have 7 digit plates which increases the number of combinations .']

id: How do scientists give lab rats and other test subjects cancer to do their cancer studies ? I feel as though this should be obvious ... Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Most animal models of cancer use mice without an immune system , and they just inject some cancer cells from a flask into the mouse . Different cancer cells sometimes spread to different parts of the body ( e.g. Lung cancer cells spreading to the lungs ) and some just form a tumour at the site of injection . Other animal models can use a chemical that causes cancer to induce tumours . Source- PhD student in a cancer research lab Edit- because the mice do n't have an immune system , they do n't try to get rid of the cancer , because those cells will be foreign to the mouse , the same as bacterial cells that our immune system can attack", 'Tumor cells are grown in a dish and injected into the rodent . Different types of tumors grow in different injection sites ( and grow better in certain places or in specific strains of animals etc ) . For example , breast cancer cells can grow into a tumor in several places but tend to grow well in the mammary fat pad of female rodents . You can also model metastases by injecting your tumor cells intravenously- they will hit the lungs on their way around , and will settle / grow there .', 'One method is implanting tissue directly from a patient . Once a patient signs a consent form , a portion of the tumor is brought to the research lab . Immune - compromised mice / rats are knocked out using anesthetic , an incision is made , and a small piece of the tumor is implanted in the animal just under the skin . When it grows to a large enough size , the tumor is extracted , spilt into many pieces , and implanted in many more mice ( or frozen for later use , or collected for analysis , etc . ) . This is repeated to maintain stocks of mice with the desired tumor type , some of which are then used for studies . Source : do this for a living .']

id: How do they sync a voice to cartoon characters ? How do they sync up a characters voice in a cartoon ? I do n't me CGI stuff , I am asking about the hand drawn material . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Storyboard artist for a 2d kids show here , The dialogue is recorded first . We listen to it while working out the acting and staging and draw the important poses and expressions that feel natural to the performance of the voice actor . This is called " blocking " . From here the board artist might add some more detailed acting ( as you do in television cartoon production , to make for a faster animation process ) , or if you work in full length features , pass it off to the animator to figure out the really detailed expressions and mouth shapes .', 'Contrary to what would seem logical , the voice acting is done first . It all boils down to frames per second . Have the recorded dialogue mapped out via fps acts as a guideline for the animator to know at what frames / second the mouth animations should start / change .', "Whatever type of animation it may be , whether its hand drawn , CGI , stop motion , whatever , the voice actors always come first . The voice actors come in to record their lines , and then the animators have to work around those recordings , trying to translate the meaning and emotion of the voicework into the movements and expressions of the animation . After that , they just put the two together and they both sync up perfectly because the animation was tailored for the voice itself . In fact , in a lot of cases , some characters are practically born straight from the voice . Take Sherri Stoner for example , series writer and voice actress of Slappy the Squirrel from Animaniacs . The different people involved were pitching ideas for different characters to appear in the show . Sherri shared her idea of an aged retired cartoon actress which was a great idea on its own . But then she acted out the voice of the character as she saw it in her head and the rest is history with Slappy the Squirrel becoming a well known member on the Animaniacs cast . The voice acting came first before the animation , and the voice was used to help the animators sort of create a template from which they drew and animated her body and mannerisms . However , on the other hand , dubbing is a totally different scenario and is the situation most likely used in your question . Let 's say there is a foreign hand drawn animated film from Japan like Spirited Away for example . The animation and foreign voice work has already been done and there 's not much that can be done after that . Since a lot of regular people would prefer to listen to a movie rather than get subtitles , the studio rounds up a bunch of voice actors . The voice actors are given translated lines of the original script and stand in front of a huge screen that is projecting a silent version of the film . Then its up to the voice actors to try and say their lines while trying their best to either match the mouth work of what 's up on screen or just fit in as much of the line as one can in a scene ( Since in some instances , a ten word sentence in one language could be shortened to three in another language or needs four extra words in another language . ) While I know you do n't mean CGI either , CGI animated films are a lot easier to dub over . It 's the same regular schtick with voice actors dubbing over what 's happening in the film , but do n't really have to pay attention to the mouths ; they mostly have to pay attention to the timing to make sure they do n't go over or under the allotted time slot . Usually the original studio would give the dubbing studio access to the film 's files . Then the dubbing studio goes in and then edits the mouth movements so that they better match the dub 's voices while not interrupting the core animation ."]

id: How do anti - theft scanners at the entrance to stores work ? What causes them to go off ? Sometimes it does n't go off as intended , sometimes it does go off when someone shoplifts . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['My Daughter has worn hearing aids since birth . When she was very young ( 3 or 4 ) we were leaving a grocery store , and she asked me what that noise was . " What noise ? " I asked . " That \' Wubba Wubba Wubba Wubba \' sound . " I looked at her quizzically and asked her where she heard it , and eventually we figured out it was the grocery store security scanners . Now , she can tell me anytime a store has their scanners on , or off , because they case RF Feedback in her hearing aids .', 'You did n\'t really specify what kind of store so ill answer for grocery . My first job was a courtesy clerk at Safeway . The carts have sensors in them . When the carts go through the checkout the sensor is let \'s say " cleared " so that it can go out through the door . If you bring the cart in the store and then try to go back out with it without going through the checked then the sensor will activate and lock up the wheels .', 'Here where I live even big name stores the like of Walmart only put little strings of wire duck taped to valuable productos . So it is really easy to steal stuff .']

id: How do TSA body scanners work ? For example can they see just through your clothes or can they see Inside your body ? Can you smuggle stuff in your anus or vagina ? Like drugs etc .. Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["The scanners use radiation which penetrates your clothes but not your skin . It bounces off much the same way light bounces off regular objects , so all you need is a machine that can see these wavelengths , plus an operator who can look at the scans and see the outline of a gun or knife . One fairly discerning thing is that you do n't have to conceal things inside your body for the scanner to miss them , just hang it off the side . The scanners apparently have an outline of the body and objects which sit outside this range ( say in a pocket on your hip ) are outside this outline , so they do n't show up on the images the operators see . And keep in mind that these operators see thousands of scans per shift , so it 's not surprising that they miss stuff all the time . In other words this is primarily ' security theater ' , something meant to look like it works but is actually easy to fool . Plus it 's dosing you with radiation , not much to be sure , but radiation is n't good for you .", "They do n't . They were pitched to congress as extremely valuable by a former congressman who happened to own stock in the company . As a result they became the only mandated equipment for the TSA . Since then there have been multiple privacy complaints about them . There have also been multiple reports and studies that show they are easily beaten and unable to work as advertised .", 'The scanners can only see through your clothes . They would not see anything you put in your anus or vagina . They work kind of like an xray except they use less radiation so it shows a picture of the body shape and non organic solids are easy to detect .']

id: How does a painting like " When Will You Marry " sell for $ 300 million dollars when it does n't look like anything spectacular [ This Painting ] ( URL_0 ) Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['When it comes to a lot of art , context is more important than the actual material . Rarity , historical context etc . make a thing more valuable than its actual aesthetic properties . For example , some shitty buggy SNES or N64 games will sell for huge amounts if they are well preserved and in the original packaging etc , even when any high school student nowadays could write a better game in a week .', 'The rarity of Gaugin paintings coupled with very rich people willing to pay 9 - figures for a painting account for the sale price of that painting . Those factors ignore the inherent artistic beauty of the painting -- * which remember is in the eye of the beholder * -- which also contributes to the price . Artistic scholars also confirmed the artistic value of the painting . Lastly , historically , art has been seen as a relatively safe investment as paintings tend to hold their value over time .', "Another reason , believe it or not , is branding . Media whoring . Showing off . ePeen . The buyer is largely believed to be the government of Qatar ; a tiny country in the middle east ( about the size of New Jersey with less than 300,000 citizens ) that sits on one of the worlds largest natural gas and oil reserves . Hence they have a massive amount of wealth concentrated to relatively few people , most of whom belong to the Al - Thani family . And , they like to splash that wealth in ways to bring attention to the country and increase their international influence and reputation . They have made several record - breaking art purchases over the past decade , but without any consistency . It 's mostly haphazard without following any real theme . As some media have insinuated , they 'll buy whatever 's so expensive that it gets noticed . They also sponsor several museums around the world , art shows , prizes etc -- all while there are museums in Doha ( the capital city ) closing down due to the lack of funds . It 's not just art , Qatar is throwing money at anything that will bring media coverage to the country . The football World Cup in 2022 is being held there despite a lack of football history , venues or a suitable climate , and the bidding process is largely suspected to have involved bribery . The 2019 World Athletics Championships are being held there . They bid for the 2016 and 2020 Olympics . They spend ridiculous amounts of money on sports teams ( Paris St Germain ) and sponsorship ( Barcelona ) , media ( Al Jazeera ) , airlines ( Qatar Air ) -- anything to increase their presence on the international stage . So whether this artwork was really something that the Al - Thani family considered so beautiful they had to pay 300 m for , or whether they paid 300 m to have Qatar on everyone 's lips in the western media ... That 's anyone 's guess ."]

id: How do zits / pimples actually form on your face ? Why are they suddenly there ? Why are some bigger than others ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Zits form when facial pores become blocked or clogged , the body tries to clear the blockage by pumping the infected area with liquid ( that gross stuff that oozes out when its popped ) resulting in pressure that is painful and turns the skin red . So short answer : just wash your face .', "[ Here 's ] ( URL_0 ) a simple video that describes the pathophysiology .", 'A zit is an infection of the pore . It typically forms when the pore is clogged and infection ensures . Some are bigger because the infection - and your bodies response to it - are " larger " ( e.g. more stuff ) . Additionally , the size of the zit as you experience it is influenced by its proximity to the skin and the part of the body its on . This is the reasons prevention of zits involves cleansing - that can unclog the pore and decrease the amount of bacteria on the surface of your skin .']

id: How does 83b election work when paying fair market value at time of grant?
text: ['The tax cost at election should be zero.  The appreciation is all capital gain beyond your basis, which will be the value at election. IRC Â§83 applies to property received as compensation for services, where the property is still subject to a substantial risk of forfeiture.  It will catch unvested equity given to employees. Â§83(a) stops taxation until the substantial risk of forfeiture abates (i.e. no tax until stock vests) since the item is revocable and not yet truly income.  Â§83(b) allows the taxpayer to make a quick election (up to 30 days after transfer - firm deadline!) to waive the substantial risk of forfeiture (e.g. treat shares as vested today). The normal operation of Â§83 takes over after election and the taxable income is generally the value of the vested property minus the price paid for it.  If you paid fair market value today, then the difference is zero and your income from the shares is zero. The shares are now yours for tax purposes, though not for legal purposes.  That means they are most likely a capital asset in your hands, like other stocks you own or trade.  The shares will not be treated as compensation income on vesting, and vesting is not a tax matter for elected shares. If you sell them, you get capital gain (with tax dependent on your holding period) over a basis equal to FMV at the election.  The appreciation past election-FMV will be capital gain, rather than ordinary income.  This is why the Â§83(b) election is so valuable.  It does not matter at this point whether you bought the restricted shares at FMV or at discount (or received them free) - that only affects the taxes upon Â§83(b) election.']

id: How does a brain anus rhythm instantly kill you I know it has something to do with blood clots maybe ? But how do you just die instantly ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Okay ... once I 've managed to stop chuckling I 'll answer this . ..... .... .. . Okay . First off , its aneurysm . It refers to a structural weakening of a vessel wall , resulting in prominent bulging as blood pressure pushes against it . Typically , these aneurysms arise in major vessels , such as the aorta , basilar arteries , carotids , or any of the vessels composing the brain artery complex known as the ' Circle of Willis ' . If these aneurysms get severe enough , they can rupture , causing you to bleed out into your brain . Because these ruptures occur in the major vessels , it results in a rapid , dramatic loss of blood flow to your brain . It does n't ' kill instantly ' but depending on the size and location , it can cause rapid loss of consciousness and subsequent death as your brain becomes starved of blood and oxygen .", 'As you may have noticed , this entire thread is now locked . This is something of a " nuclear option " for us moderators , so a bit of explanation is in order . We \'re not going to speculate as to whether or not " anus rhythm " was a carefully - crafted title to get upvotes or a simple victim of autocorrect , but for the purposes of this submission , we \'re giving the OP the benefit of the doubt , and erring on the side of " autocorrect mishap " . So the title itself is not the direct issue . The issue is how others are responding to that title . If you read the rules in the sidebar , they say : > Direct replies to the original post ( aka " top - level comments " ) are for serious responses only . Jokes , anecdotes , and low effort explanations are not permitted and subject to removal . The only valid responses to the question posed by the OP are ones that take the typo in stride ( maybe even joke about it , that \'s fine ) , and then * explain how aneurysms work * . That \'s it . That \'s the only type of top - level comment that we allow ( that , or a related , * serious * followup question ) . Instead , over 95 % of the comments have been jokes or snide remarks about " anus rhythms " ( including made - up disease descriptions ) , variations of " lol " , and against - the - rules ( if well - intentioned ) anecdotes that lack any explanation . Per our subreddit rules , we \'ve been removing these comments . However keeping this thread pruned is taking a serious amount of effort . As of this writing , there are eight serious responses , and * * hundreds * * of removed joke responses . And the joke responses are pouring in faster than we can reasonably keep up with . At this point , we feel that there have been enough serious responses to explain aneurysms to the OP , and the effort of keeping up with the flood of rule - breaking responses is detracting from our ability to moderate the rest of the subreddit , hence the " nuclear option " .', 'First off .... That Title ! ! :) A Brain Aneurysm wo nt necessarily kill you , my mother had one while she was sleeping in her bed and recalls waking up to a " Popping " sound followed by the feeling of blood running all the way down the right side of her face under the skin ( This is what she can remember after months of regaining her memory ) all of her short term memory was gone for a good 6 months at least , It was quite hard to watch her try and do the simplest tasks , and repeatedly do other tasks , because she could n\'t remember if she had done them or not . Example : Finding her car keys ( she once even had all her neighbors inside thrashing her house helping her find them ) she literally skipped back a few years in memory for a while , so everything current was new to her , over time she got better despite doctors saying it could be permanent and now she has fully regained her short term memory :)']

id: How do you play Magic : The Gathering ? I 'm referring to the card game , it all looks so technical but I still wanna learn how to play . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Well , I used to play in tournaments . I \'ll give this a whirl . Two ( or more ) players face off against each other with their decks . A standard deck is 60 cards ( can be more but not less ) and the various types of cards are : Sorcery , Creatures , Instant , Enchantment and Land cards . There are a few more types then that , but we \'re keeping it simple . You draw seven cards to start and one card at the start of your turn . At the end of your turn , if you ever have more than seven cards you have to discard cards until you have seven . Lands are the most basic card . It usually makes up about 1/3 of your deck and its used to power your spells . You can only put one land card into play each turn . Lands are " tapped " to draw the power from them and each color of magic has its own kind of land . Forrest , Mountain , Swamp , Plains and Island . Respectively that \'s Green , Red , Black , White and Blue . Sorcery cards are big spells , they can only be played during your turn and they have big effects like player takes XZY amount of damage . Instants are small but fast spells , you can cast these whenever you want * * IF * * you have enough power to do it , even interrupting your opponent . Counter - spell is a famous instant card . Creatures are straight - forward . Summon a creature to fight for you . Enchantments offer lingering effects . They effectively add a new rule to the game , like any creature weaker than XZY dies . Players , or Planeswalkers as they are known in the lore , each start with 20 health . Through a combination of attacking with creatures and flinging spells you wear each other down to 0 and the last man standing wins . Each of the colors of magic is also famous for its theme . White magic has lots of healing and holy stuff . Black magic is really fucking cool and has lots of evil stuff . Red magic has lots of direct damage abilities . Green magic is famous for massively powerful creatures . Blue magic is famous for * * MASSIVE AMOUNTS OF DICKERY . * * That is an extremely abbreviated version of the game . I may be back later today to expand upon it further . * * EDIT : I \'m back ! * * Lets go over the basics of creatures cards . Let \'s use this creature [ Prodigal Sorcerer ] ( URL_0 ) as an example . If you look in the top right we see its cost to play . One blue mana and two of any color mana . So that \'s one island you need to tap and two of any other kind of land . Look at the bottom right hand corner and you see its strength and defense as x / y. X is the strength , Y is the defense . If a creature takes damage equal to its defense it dies . The creature comes into play but it ca n\'t do much yet . It \'s still woozy from being yanked into existence so all it can do is defend . This is known as summoner sickness and it goes away at the start of your next turn . In this case , our creature does have an ability , it can shoot another creature or player for one damage . To use an ability you must fulfill its conditions , which is tapping the card in this case . Be careful though , a tapped creature ca n\'t defend from attacking creatures so using this ability leaves you open as you can only untap things at the start of your turn .', 'I will just mention there is a Magic subreddit here - /r / magicTCG Also for learning , the Duels of the Planeswalkers game(s ) that are available on Steam / PS Store / Xbox Marketplace are awesome for learning some of the basics .', "It 's great and not as hard as you 'd think . The trick is to start simple get a friend and the two player starter set . Follow the instructions to play your first game and then try again without the instruction and a good shuffle . The key is to have a bit of patience with one another and mostly to have a friend willing to play and learn . Wizards website has loads of advice and any forbidden planet or similar comic book shop will have people who can talk you through and advise on things ."]

id: How do the military check the medical history of people who only recently came to a country ? a Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['The military does not necessarily need someones medical history from old records . The military does its own thorough medical evaluation of recruits before they enter the service . Additionally , people are required to disclose any medical conditions prior to entering the service . If someone was found out to have lied they could face criminal prosecution . So with the military doing their own evaluation , and people being required to disclose their past medical conditions , why would they need old records ?', "They do n't go check medical histories much . They will run you through their own batteries of tests and medical and physical tests to determine any problems . They also ask you to disclose any known medical issues . Even if accepted however , if medical issues are found in the future , military people are routinely discharged / released for medical issues , even prior issues that were unknown but found later .", "The military does n't check your medical history , but they do perform a quite thorough physical at MEPS before allowing you to enlist / commission . They 'll ask you about your medical condition and if they found out you lied they will discharge you under fraudulent enlistment ( this frequently happens with asthma ) ."]
