text: ["The catch is that you have to pay for each bid , whether or not you win the auction . If they get lots of people to bid , the fees add up to much more than the cost of the item , even if an individual person does n't pay much .", 'Because Beezid charges you money to buy bids unlike ebay where you can bid for free .', "There 's been a ton if these web sites in the past 10 years , not many of them are still around . Seems like it 's not a profitable operation ."]

id: How do so many different languages have the same basic phonetic for " mom " ? Was curious and browsed through translate and almost all the languages I found had the same sound for mom . Mom Ma mama etc Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["If you think about all the muscles / parts involved in generating speech ( lips , tongue , glottis , vocal chords , etc . ) , the consonant ' m ' and the vowel ' a ' are far less complex to produce relative to other sounds . The ' ah ' sound is close to the default resting position of the speech - producing muscles / parts in the mouth , and the ' m ' sound is just the closing of the mouth . source : was a baby .", "Plato argued that all language is onomatopoeia-- which does n't explain why there are so many languages , I take it he just thought Greek got it right . Mama is one word that sort of makes sense with this-- that it 's a ' mmmm ' sound of a contented baby nursing . And , like so many said , it 's easy to say-- if it were , ' verkelmpt ' or something equally hard , it would n't take long for proud mommies to claim ' he said ve - ve-- that 's short for verkelmpt-- see my baby is a genius ! ;", 'M is a basic shape , so when a baby says " mama " , it is repeating the " ma " sound . Then " o " sound is also basic , so a lot of languages , such as Farsi , have the term " momon " , or in English , " momma " .']

id: How do videogames cost money to make ? Aside from paying employees . I always hear things about how companies can save money by not debugging or stepping down graphically but how does stuff like this cost money ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['* Equipment to develop the game on . * Employee salaries ( artists , programmers , writers , etc . ) . * Constant costs ( office space , rent , power , etc . ) * Licensing fees ( many games use already - created game engines ) ; Ogre3D , Source Engine , etc * Bandwidth / Distribution / Marketing costs Just a few .', "Salaries are the biggest expense for a software development company . These are rough estimates for Southern California yearly salaries . * Project manager : $ 130,000 * Senior Software Engineer : $ 120,000 * Software Engineer : $ 50,000 - $ 100,000 * Art Director : $ 130,000 * 2d Artist : $ 40,000 - $ 100,000 * 3d Artist : $ 50,000 - $ 100,000 Throw a half decent team together and you have over $ 100,000 in salaries per month . If they 're employees add approx 25 % to that for taxes , workman 's comp . etc ... Freelancers pay their own taxes . Throw a medium size team together and you can see $ 300k monthly expenses without trying . If you add on the other components that others have mentioned you can see how it becomes extremely expensive to spend 2 years developing something . Not that I condone it but one can understand why companies often try to take shortcuts . In the long run it 's a hindrance but in the short term it pleases the entities that write the checks .", 'You answered your own question . It takes a /lot/ of man hours to debug a piece of software as large as a console video game .']

id: How do Young Earth Creationists rationalize radiocarbon dating ? Not trying to stir the pot , just genuinely curious about how they do it . Since it is based on relatively simple math , and relatively simple science , on what basis do they reject it ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['I grew up in a moderately fundamentalist community , so I \'ll speak from personal experience . From the point of view of a fundamentalist , you are approaching the problem backwards . When you and I look at a problem such as " how old is this item , " we look for a method or data point to work from . When a fundamentalist looks at the same problem , they start with their interpretation of the bible . The earth is X,000 years old . Therefore , the item must be less than X,000 years old . Any information that supports this is correct . Any info that contradicts this must be either divine interference , a mistake , or a lie told by someone attempting to disprove God \'s existence . A perfect example of this . I went to a private school growing up . In our " science " textbook , was a section on radiocarbon dating . Our book included a graph showing us how reliable RC dating was . According to the text , after 5000 years , RC dating is unreliable . I will qualify all of this by saying that I know very few young earthers . Most practicing Christians that I know only believe that its been roughly 6 - 10 thousand years since Adam and Eve . They feel that any amount of time from Genesis 1:1 to the end of the garden of Eden could have been any amount of time .', "[ Here is Ken Ham 's explanation ] ( URL_0 ) for why radiocarbon dating is not a proof that young - earth creationism is wrong . Notice that the fact that it is nonsense is camouflaged in scientific - sounding language . Many young earth creationists will actively avoid reading science books that are n't written by young earth creationists , and so they will trust that this is real science ( after all , it sounds very science - y ) , and not double - check its logic against other science .", 'They believe one of two things , depending on the denomination of their churches : 1 . God manipulated it to test our faith . Or ... 2 . Satan manipulated it to fool us .']

id: How do contactless cards generate their RFiD signal ? Surely there needs to be a source of energy to generate this signal but how come I do n't need to charge my card Explain like I'm five.
text: ['The reader hits it with a pulse which gives it enough energy to send a response with , this makes the bases big and lets the tags be tiny . Its a combination of wireless communication and wireless charging', "Hej , The thing about RFID is that the signal is n't generated by the chip that is in the card , but by the chip reading device ( if it is a passive RFID tag ) . The device emits radio waves . Its a bit like a barcode but you can scan it trough clothing without having to ' see ' it .", "Yer not alone in askin ' , and kind strangers have explained : 1 . [ ELI5 : How is it that RFID stickers work without any batteries ? ] ( URL_1 ) ^(_10 comments _ ) 1 . [ what powers the RFID tags in passport etc ] ( URL_0 ) ^(_9 comments _ )"]

id: How do animals in eggs know when to hatch ? The egg does n't just dissolve , they actively break out . But why ? Is it just their size in relation to the egg ? Hormones ? Something external to the egg ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Genetic programming . Remember how you latched onto your mom 's boob for your first meal ? OF COURSE NOT . But you did , because it was genetically programmed that you had an instinctual latching - on process to get that milk into you ( or , alternately , from a bottle if you were n't breast fed ) . Animals are the same . They bust out of the egg when their genetics tells them it 's time to based on their level of development , whether or not they have a yolk sac still attached ( like many fish do ) or they 're pretty much 100 % complete and ready to go .", 'It is determined based on when the animal is finally hungry because it has no more nutrition left in the egg . The egg provides nutrition for the animal to grow within the egg ( specifically the white part ) , and once all of that is gone , the animal is left hungry and wanting more food / protein to keep growing . It is at this time that the animal breaks out of its shell in search of more nutrition :) .', "I think you might have better luck finding the sort of answers you 're looking for on /r / askscience :)"]

id: How do monarchies begin ? How does a family become ' the Royal family ' in the first place and convince everyone to accept that ? Real - world examples if possible Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Conquest . Kings started out as warlords , or leaders of a warrior family who conquered a large area of land , put their friends and relatives in charge of parts of it , and passed it on to their heirs . To make alliances , they often also married ( or had their sons marry ) the daughters of other nearby warlords . If one son inherited from two warlords , then the kingdom could get bigger without conquering .', 'Strange women lying in ponds distributing swords ...', 'This happens in every conflict ever , warlords fashion themselves as the true rulers of the land , even if they only control a couple villages . They expand until they clash with another warlord who also thinks he should be the king . Whoever wins keeps on doing this until they establish a government , taxes and a regular army .']

id: How does Cancer actually kill people ? Sorry if I seem insensitive , however I wonder how does a cancer actually kill someone ? Edit : Thank you for your answers ; Very helpful ! Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Cancer is abnormal growth of cells of any kind , and it may kill you in a few ways . They may squeeze on veins and arteries , causing blockage . They may produce hormones which may kill you by throwing your internal chemistry off balance . They may eat too many nutrients , weakening the body . They may grow in place you do n't want them to grow ( having a bone growing inside your head is not fun ) . The worst thing that may happen is that some of the cells break off , find their way into bloodstream and start growing in multiple places at once ( only one cell is needed to make a tumour ) .", 'So a cancer cell is a cell that no longer goes under apoptosis , or cell death . It also stops functioning as a normal cell . It continues to perform mitosis and spawn new daughter cells , which do n\'t die . The cancerous area heavily performs angiogenesis , which is the creation of new blood vessels . This will start to " crowd out " healthy cells as well as deprive them of a normal blood flow . Death is usually caused by organ failure , it depends on what type of cancer . Edit : Some spelling .', 'In addition to what other people have said , it can also leave you weak enough for a secondary illness to kill you , like a bacterial or viral infection . Sort of like HIV .']

id: How do US exactly pay their nation debt ? We are in debt of trillions dollars , but how does we pay it back ? especially if it 's in different currency . ca n't we just make money to pay off debt without involving our economy system ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Most of the US Debt is owned by entities within the US , either private citizens , or other parts of the US government . It is not a single debt but rather numerous different debts owed by different entities to different entities . Payments are made by the revenue the US government raises , such as through taxes . While the government can ' make money ' that leads to inflation . Among the other things this would do , it would reduce the value of US bonds , which would make people less interested in taking bonds and thus reduce a form of revenue . So it leads to further potential problems . At present , the government is not defaulting however , so they may not take such a route .", 'Most US debt is in the form of US treasury bonds . These are essentially a fancy IOU the government has issued that say , " If you gives us $ X now , in Y years , we \'ll give you $ X+interest . " These have been sold for a long time , and the money is only due from the government when that amount of time has passed . Once the term of the IOU has run out , the government pays you , and a tiny portion of the US federal debt has been replaced . All US government debt is held and dealt with in US dollars . If you \'re a foreign citizen , it \'s on you to then exchange those dollars for your local currency , or whatever you want . Since we pay our debt in US dollars , and also control the printing of US dollars , the US * could * theoretically , just start running the printing presses and give everyone what they \'re owed . After all , they \'re owed a certain amount of dollars , not a certain value those dollars represent . However , the problem with this is inflation . Contrary to not involving our economic system , this would severely undermine it . Printing money would raise the inflation rate , making individual US dollars less valuable , and while a little inflation can be good , too much is a bad thing . Furthermore , it \'d undermine trust in the US government . Would you loan money to someone who then turns around and games the system to repay you with worthless junk ? No , and that \'d mean that debt for the US government would become more expensive , and that \'s bad . It \'s the same problem with just printing enough money to give a million dollars to anyone . When you do that , you make it so a million dollars just is n\'t worth as much . Does it matter if you \'re a millionaire when a Big Mac costs a thousand bucks ?', "There 's a schedule just like someone pays their mortgage or credit card bill in installments rather than paying off the whole thing at once . The USA creates debt by selling bonds . It says that if you pay us 10 $ now we 'll pay you 11 $ back in ten years . People are willing to do that because the USA is a stable nation that pays its creditors on time . If you live outside the USA and buy those bonds you 'll be paying in USA dollars rather than in your own currency anyway ."]

id: How do nuclear weapon yield selectors work ? How do you " dial - up " or " dial - down " the power of a nuclear bomb ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['The yield of a thermonuclear bomb can be " easily " adjusted by changing the amount of deuterium and/or tritium fuel that \'s fed into the fission stage to ignite fusion . Dialing back or removing the tritium " booster " fuel or choking off the deuterium would decrease yield . These bombs could even theoretically remove the fusion stage entirely and detonate as a low yield fission bomb . Adjusting the fission stage is a little more difficult , since those bomb desins are relatively crude and would probably need a redesigned fissile mass to reliably change the yield .', "From what I understand from reading information available to the public , it works like this : You start with a standard fission warhead with a dense radiation case , which is generally made of depleted uranium . This type of warhead is generally fairly small--10 kilotons , in the case of the US W40 . Then , you add a system to inject tritium gas into the core immediately prior to detonation . The system must be calibrated to deliver a very specific mass of tritium , which differs depending on the desired yield . The remainder of the tritium is vented to the atmosphere . Upon detonation , the heat and shockwave generated by the fission primary heat and compress the tritium to the point where a runaway fusion reaction ignites -- each fusion event further heats and compresses the tritium plasma , driving further fusion reactions , until the expanding plasma destroys the bomb casing . Now ... I'm sure it 's actually quite a bit more complicated than that -- nothing about nuclear weapons is simple or easy -- but Ghats the principle behind how it works .", 'You do n\'t " dial up " the yield â you have a maximum possible yield and then you can " dial down " in several ways from that : * Detonate only the fission stage of a two - stage bomb â drops the yield by a LOT * Change the deuterium - tritium gas used as a " booster " of the fission stage â changing the amount allows somewhat precise control over the yield of the fission primary , which will affect the fusion secondary \'s yield as well * Change the timing of the external neutron initiator to the fission stage â if it comes too early or too late ( or not at all ) , this will lower the yield * Some early US weapons had their cores inserted only at use time , and you could put in different core geometries for different yields ; this was not possible by the mid-1950s when sealed - pit weapons became the standard The trick , of course , is not sabotaging your whole bomb ( producing a fizzle ) while trying to dial it down .']

id: How do nerve cells in very muscular / fat people accommodate for the increased surface area of skin ? Are more nerve cells created ? What happens ? Does touch sensitivity decrease due to reduced density ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['The same way nerves cover increased surface area as we grow from babies to adults , the axons grow . The tension being pulled on the axons as they are stretched to accommodate larger areas actually promotes growth of the axons Edit : more eli5 explanation . Nerves are composed of multiple fibers called axons . An axon is basically like a usb cable communicating between the computer ( neuron ) and another device ( communicating neuron ) . Neurons do not usually multiply in number after early development , however the axon coming off of the neuron has the ability to grow if stimulated to do so . When you get fatter and your skin begins to stretch this also pulls on the axons which will then be simulated to grow .', "If the axons grow than why are women 's nipples with large breasts less sensitive ?", 'One millimetre on your skin has thousands of nerve endings , even if you put on a lot of weight and your skins surface area increased you will still have lots of nerve cells under the skin .']

id: How do doctors / paramedics know what 's wrong with a person if they 're unconscious ? For example , if a person is knocked unconscious by an accident , and is injured , how do doctors or paramedics diagnose the patient ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["C - CATASTROPHIC hemorrhage A - Airway ( is their airway clear ? have they chocked on something . is there vomit in the airway ? ) B - Breathing ( the air can get in but it ca n't get in due to the pt not breathing C - Circulation ( Blood going round and round ? ) Observations - HR , Respiratory rate , SP02 ( oxygen % ) , Blood pressure , Blood glucose , Pupil size + reactivity , 12 lead ECG . With some one in cardiac arrest . you 've got the 5 H 's and 4 T 's H 's Hypoxia : low oxygen levels in the blood Hypovolemia : low amount of circulating blood Hyperkalemia or hypokalemia : disturbances in the level of potassium in the blood , and related disturbances of calcium or magnesium levels Hypothermia / Hyperthermia : body temperature not maintained ( no - one is dead until they are warm and dead ) Hypoglycemia : Low blood glucose levels - once went to a pt in a GP surgery with ? CVA ( stroke ) so GP called for an Amb to pick them up . Patient was unconscious on a bed in the surgery . A quick check of this persons blood glucose showed a level of 1.2 ( normally 4 - 7 ) . after getting some IV glucose in they were up and about and back to normal . T 's Tension pneumothorax : increased pressure in the thoracic cavity , leading to decreased venous return to the heart Tamponade : fluid or blood in the pericardium Toxic and/or therapeutic : chemicals , whether medication or poisoning Thromboembolism - A blockage in the blood vessel . Like those that happen in the coronary arteries which causes heart tissue to die from lack of oxygen .", 'Paramedics would usually assess the patient first with a tip to toe survey , this would find anything like lumps bumps and cuts . They also will have basic test equipment for things like blood pressure and sugar . So assuming there are no witnesses they could still reach a reasonable conclusion until they got to the hospital where the doctors have more sensitive test equipment .', "By examining the patient for the more common causes of being unconscious . Typically when in an accident it 's not going to be totally unexpected that they took a bump to the head if they 're unconscious and in most cases unconsciousness does n't last very long ."]

id: How do we self - induce sleep ? What happens in the body / brain when I lie down and essentially make a voluntary decision to go to sleep ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Contrary to popular belief-- needing it . You have a human , sleep cycle used to be 4hrs at a time , twice per diurnal cycle , now a whole 8 hours . If you google ' human sleep cycle ' , you will see for the first 4 hours or so of the sleep cycle dedicated to some rem , the normal alpha and beta , and the delta deep sleep . After that is a long period of cyclic rem sleep until you launch out of it . No delta sleep is ' normal ' , after the delta sleep cycle , is a period of recouping a lot of REM sleep . This is because obviously as mammals for quite sometime we were nt necessarily safe sleeping 8 whole hours in a deep enough sleep to heal up and rest up our gigantic brains . The extra rem at the end is just your brain recouping since you are nt having another 4 hr sleep cycle with REM and delta wave deep sleep . Fast forward to modern life and the physical strain is not much of an issue , its the mental and social strain that works through our day . Remember rest itself is /rest/ , recovery . The brain is efficient at logical tasks , social tasks , but the body and its stress from physical expendeture is an entirely different thermodynamic expendeture , and homo sapian biology , when it comes to rest , is very dependent on the body 's hormonal cycling after physical work to garner enough chemicals to turn your brain off . Sleep is the time you also produce Human Growth Hormone . This hormone is used everywhere , not just the brain . The biofeedback to get these mechanisms in action that correspond overall to quicker and deeper sleep requires your body to ultimately be expended through a days work . This is the endocrinological equivalent of tiring out , so you can imagine without much physical expendeture , the brain does nt have enough ' push ' to the endocrine system to initiate sleep so much . You can do your own sleep experiment like this . Notice after a day of intense brain activity but not much body activity you sleep in a restful night . Chances are its less than 8 hours on average . Physical labor but not much mental flexing will favor the other end of the sleep spectrum , deep delta wave sleep , so maybe 6.5 - 8 hrs . But an intense day on both fronts will knock you out for quite some time . If you want good sleep , go for quite a fucking jog , make those muscles hurt , do a lot of activity with your brain , then lay in bed at sundown ( if you do nt have a chronic sleep disorder ) you will go out like a light .", 'I try not to think about this question too much because then I just ca n\'t get to sleep . " What \'s happening now ? ? ? ? "', 'I would love the answer to this question , as I have chronic insomnia my guess is that most answers will say that it is involuntarily']

id: How do you text in Chinese ? To my understanding , the Chinese language is composed of complex characters that usually represent words . So how do you text with a language on a limited keyboard ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Pinyin and knowing the tones . Chinese has a writing script based on roman alphabet which is what kids and beginners use when first learning the language . This is called pinyin . This is basically the phonetic transcription of the language . There are then 4 corresponding tones in Chinese . Flat ( 1 ) , Rising ( 2 ) , Falling - Rising ( 3 ) and Falling ( 4 ) . The word ' train - station ' in Mandarin is huÇchÄzhÃ n . So you type it out like that but add the tones by adding a number after the corresponding character . ( But not every character has a tone . ) So huÇchÄzhÃ n would be huo3che1zhan4 and this would type out as ç«è½¦ç«", 'There are many many ways to type in Chinese , but I \'ll list the common ones only : 1 . Pinyin : This is the standard romanization for the PRC where characters are written in the Latin alphabet . Like /u / kabajingai said , you can type the entire romanization out to get your desired word . However , this is pretty time - consuming , so most people usually remove the tone numbers when typing . You can go even further and shorten a word like æå , peng2you5 ( friend ) to just " py " because " py " is not a valid syllable so the system recognizes it as an abbreviation . 2 . Zhuyin / Bopomofo : This system was used in China before the standard Latin phonetic transcription came about in the 1950s , but now it is only used in Taiwan . It functions in the same as pinyin , but instead of Latin letters , you have distorted Chinese characters that almost resemble Japanese katakana . Each symbol represents a specific morpheme , and tonal marks similar to those in pinyin are used to represent the tones . 3 . Wubihua : The first two systems were phonetically - based , but this one is handwriting - based . All Chinese characters have a standard stroke order ( order of the lines you have to draw to make the character ) , and there are only five buttons in this system you can press to get your desired character . There are ~34 types of strokes in Chinese , but some of them are very similar to each other , so Wubihua classifies the 34 strokes into either a horizontal , vertical , falling to the left , falling to the right / dots , and turning strokes ( which are a combination of any of the previously four as long as you do n\'t lift the pencil when writing ) . 4 . Wubi and Cangjie : These are also writing - based , but instead use the radicals that make up the characters . These are more complicated to learn as a beginner because the rules and algorithms might seem a bit strange at first . Cangjie is based on geometrical distribution , and I am not familiar with the typing at all , so do n\'t ask me about it . Wubi is simpler imo because it is purely based on radicals and strokes . It \'s like a faster Wubihua where common stroke orders that might take six keyboard presses are transformed into one keyboard press . 5 . Drawing : And of course , you can actually draw the character on the screen if your phone supports it . I like this way better because my handwriting is faster than typing , and it \'s neat enough that my phone can register what the hell I \'m typing . Usually when you draw , the character will be distorted from what your computer - written fonts look like , cause messy handwriting and stuff .', 'There is way to read and spell Chinese characters . Called pinyin . So you basically use the alphabet to spell out the word or character . Then you choose the right one from the words that appear on the screen like auto - correct or T9 . There is also a way to choose radicals , basically the building blocks of the Chinese characters .']

id: How do you make a company ? I 'm trying to start up a company that is a general contractor which deals with all aspects of home remodeling and construction , including electric work , flooring , painting , etc . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["If it 's a sole proprietorship ( a one - man business ) , you have to do almost nothing . Go read this : URL_0", 'If you sold mittens it would be very easy . id: How do you convince a solider to shoot at the civilians of his own country ? Is n't that what 's going on in Syria for the past few months ? Do n't the soliders realize that they are fighting against their own interests ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Syria is really really complicated right now . But for a simplified answer : The Syrian military is more scared of what the government will do to them * * and their families * * if they do n't shoot , than what will happen if they do fire on their own people .", "A soldier is trained to engage the enemy and view with trust only those within his group . When a soldier is used in policing operations , the civilians become the enemy . When you 're in a situation which is rapidly deteriorating , you do not have time to think . Think about falling off your bike - do you consciously put your hands forward to break your fall , or do your muscles react automatically ? The soldier reacts in a similar way . When a high stress environment presents itself , his training kicks in , and his thoughts disappear . He will not realize what he is doing until afterwards - this often triggers PTSD as the realization of his crime sets in .", "Just like you convince a soldier to shoot at anyone else - you tell them the people they 're shooting at are their enemies , and the enemies of their homeland , and that it 's their patriotic duty to protect their homeland against its enemies . If that does n't work , you remind them they 're in the army , and if they refuse an order they can be jailed or executed ."]

id: How do our bodies " read " DNA ? I know that DNA is the order of chemicals telling the body / cells what to do , but how do the cells know what the DNA means ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Well , the cells do n\'t exactly " know " what the DNA means , per se . The process of converting genes ( DNA ) into their functional output , typically proteins , begins with a process called transcription . During this process , an enzyme ( a type of protein ) scans the DNA and makes a copy of a gene . But , instead of copying it in the form of DNA , it makes a copy of it in the form of RNA . A good analogy to this would be if your mother emailed you a recipe and you did n\'t have a printer handy , so you wrote instead , you write it down . The message still says the same thing , but it is in printed handwriting instead of electronic data . The next step in the process is converting that RNA information into something that is functional , a protein . This happens in a cell structure called the ribosome . The newly created RNA enters the ribosome , and through a process called translation . Essentially , the ribosome " decodes " the RNA and translates it into the language or proteins . A cells in every living organism convert the RNA information into proteins using the same genetic code by reading it in three letter ( A , C , G , T ) chunks called codons . The codons tell the ribosome how to build the protein and when to stop adding pieces . These pieces are called amino acids . Going back to the analogy , this is like you reading the recipe , combining the ingredients , and cooking it in the correct way . Protein translation is essentially the same thing , turning 1 - dimensional information into a 3 - dimensional product . Now , if you are asking how the cell knows which genes to activate or not to activate , that is another discussion . I would be more than willing to discuss that as well if you are interested .', "At the most basic level , DNA is a code that contains genes , which are instructions for making proteins . Proteins are the main functional molecules in cells . DNA is transcribed into mRNA , which is then translated into a chain of amino acids that fold up to form a protein . Three - base sequences of DNA / RNA called ' codons ' code for different amino acids . DNA contains more information than just the recipes for different proteins , however . There are regulatory regions of DNA that help control when different genes are being made into proteins .", "All of the responses so far are very lengthy so if you want a tldr : some of the molecules in your body are able to attach to your dna and change shape slightly depending on which part of a dna they attach to . It 's literally molecular machinery , just a lot of very rapid little chemical interactions ."]

id: How does a company provide faster internet ? Is there an internet speed knob they turn ? When a company decides to provide faster internet , what are they actually doing ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Two different reason , either the medium changes or the process changes . To make that more concrete : * Medium : the physical connection changes . Copper , coaxial , fiber . Fatter wires , more wires . You now have more physical capacity through which to send a signal . * Process : The equipment at each end of the physical connection changes . For copper ( regular telephone lines ) , this went from ADSL- > VDSL- > bonding . For cable / coaxial , it 's DOCSIS1,2,3 . For fiber there 's still lots of room for room for growth in this area . An analogy : USB1- > USB2- > USB3 , generally there 's no change in the medium . It 's still a regular old USB cable . The controller and software for the end devices changes . This is what I called a process change . For VGA to HDMI , the physical connection type changes ( which also entails a different process ) , as can be seen by the different type of wire that 's needed . In general , changing the physical medium is a lot more costly than changing the process ( which for a telco / cableco usually means changing some of the equipment / nodes in the field and not actually laying new wire connections going to the home )", 'They change a bunch of scheduler policies and bandwidth configurations in various devices on their network , then they coordinate with third party transport providers like Verizon or TWC who provide fiber or ethernet to your house , they make those same changes in their network , resulting in faster network speed .', 'Source : I \'m an intern at a major ISP in the US . You are correct in saying that they " turn a knob " to an extent . For this particular ISP , each customer has a " profile " ( for lack of a better term ) for all the services they have . For example : I might have standard internet , phone and tv . Then I might have an HBO or Showtime package with the tv , etc , etc . Behind the scenes , when you call to upgrade , all someone is doing is changing that little profile . So if you wanted 50MBPS , all I have to do is go in and flip the switch that says " Enable 50MBPS " , or whatever it may be called . Now , as for how that is possible : 1 ) It depends on the connections to your modem . 2 ) It depends on the modem itself . If all the infrastructure in the area can support 1GBPS , and your modem can , then I just need to flip the switch and give you that speed . This is where things tend to get hairy . This is the fundamental part of it . ISP \'s need to know how much they can provide without having to tear up old infrastructure . If you call and ask for 100MBPS service , and you only get 50MBPS ( assuming the 100 is turned on ) , then something with the infrastructure is wrong . It could be that you have an old modem that is not able to allow more than 50MBPS . It could also be that the connection to your house is outdated . So : Yes , they do " flip a switch " to give you service . That being said , the infrastructure needs to be in place in order for them to actually provide you with that service .']

id: How do finance professionals procounce âCECLâ?
text: ['According to the following links, it is commonly pronounced "Cecil".   https://kaufmanrossin.com/blog/bank-ready-meet-cecil/ The proposed model introduces the concept of shifting from an incurred   loss model to the current expected credit loss model commonly referred   to as CECL (pronounced âCecilâ). http://www.gonzobanker.com/2016/02/cecl-the-blind-leading-the-blurry/ [...] and its name is CECL (Current Estimated Credit Losses, pronounced like   the name âCecilâ). The name Cecil means âblind,â which is ironic, because FASBâs upcoming   guidance will push FIs to clarify the future performance of their loan   portfolios by using models to predict CECL of all loan portfolios. https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/operational-financial-impact-cecl-banks-nikhil-deshmukh Termed as Current Expected Credit Loss (CECL, or Cecil, as some call   it), [...]']

id: How does " fracking " cause earthquakes ? I keep seeing in the news of earthquakes blames on fracking , especially in Oklahoma . Is this cause / effect proven , is it a theory , and how does it happen ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["It does n't , I 'm a petroleum engineer and I can assure you that fracking wo n't cause any earthquakes . It can cause other things , like when you do it on a gas reservoir some gas may leak if not done right , but no eartquakes .", "According to the best recent study on the subject , it [ does n't ] ( URL_0 ) . > So we have concluded that hydraulic fracturing is not a significant mechanism for inducing felt earthquakes . It is extremely unlikely that any of us will ever be able to feel an earthquake caused by fracking .", "It 's not fracking that is generally thought to be causing the earthquakes in Oklahoma , but wastewater injection wells . They are two very different things , but a lot of people are blaming the earthquakes on fracking because it 's already got a bad rap ."]

id: How does U - Haul get away with having all vehicles licensed in 1 state ? All U - Haul vehicles I 've seen are licensed in Arizona . How can they operate in so many jurisdictions but only pay for licensing in 1 state ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["There are laws pertaining to fleet vehicles - in other words , a fleet of vehicles all owned and operated by one company - that allow the company to title and license all their vehicles in the place where the company 's main center of operations is located . Companies use this because it allows them to set up a single account under which all the fleet vehicles ' tags are renewed at once , rather than being sprinkled on different due dates throughout the year . In U - Haul 's case , their HQ is in Phoenix , AZ , so AZ fleet licensing laws allow them to title and license all their vehicles in that county . Every state has slightly different requirements for how many vehicles constitute a fleet and how fleet licensing is handled . AZ and IL are two of the more common states you 'll see on big trucking fleets because they have the business - friendliest fleet licensing laws .", 'Does the plate have the word " apportioned " on it ? If it does then the fees from that plate are divided among all the states . This is common for vehicles that are engaged in interstate commerce . By federal law a vehicle can only be licensed in one state . I have seen U - Haul \'s with various state plates , and not all of them are apportioned . It \'s likely that U - Haul has a majority of Arizona plates , but does register some of it \'s vehicles in other states so as not to draw the ire of said states .', 'The proliferation of Arizona plates has much to do with their registration laws . If a vehicle is taken off the road for being poorly maintained / unsafe there is no requirement to get a vehicle inspection performed before it can be put back on the road . Dear Arizona , Fuck you . Regards , MostlyHarmlessEmu']

id: How do smartphones know how to rotate correctly when " Auto - Rotate " is enabled ? It always interested me since I got my first smartphone years ago . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["There 's a tiny weight suspended in springs inside your phone , it can measure where the weight is . This weight and measuring thingy is called an accelerometer , because it can only measure acceleration , gravity for example .", '[ This ] ( URL_0 ) is what they typically look like', 'They have an accelerometer in them . Basically , it measures acceleration . Your phone uses it to tell which way the ground is ( it detects the acceleration caused by gravity ) and your phone rotates the screen appropriately .']

id: How do people decipher ancient writing systems ? For example , how did people decipher the Sumerian number system ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Specifically , the Sumerian number system was used in astronomy a lot . Slightly newer civilizations made use of these same astronomical charts . For example , the Ancient Greeks used Babylonian star charts , but they translated them to Greek . This sort of thing could be applied to all kinds of writing . New civilizations were interested in reading what was written by slightly older civilizations that were n't so old everyone forgot how to read them . Things got translated over and over again to newer languages . A lot of Ancient Greek texts actually came to us through the Arabic translation movement . Later on those Arabic translations were translated into Latin . Of course there are probably exceptions . Some things may have been lost for a while , like how we needed the Rosetta Stone to understand Ancient Egyptian . I 'm taking a class on the History of Science right now ( from the Babylonians and Ancient Egyptians up to the 17th century ) , so we learned a lot about how knowledge got passed along .", "There 's the obvious example of the Rosetta Stone , where the same text is basically given in three different languages . Linguists usually use frequency analysis , where they try to figure out the frequency of each word appearing . The underlying assumption is that across different languages , certain words that serve grammatical purpose would have similar frequencies , which gives clues as to what they are . Languages are also usually interconnected with each other . For example , even though they 're quite far apart geographically , English and Sanskrit actually belong in the same family group and share some roots . By studying other languages you can trace the development and etymology of the language .", "First : English is not my first language . You have been warned . Second : I know that this is already marked as answered , but I wanted to share my knowledge from this [ book ] ( URL_0 ) which is awesome btw :) > Rosetta Stone This example is also great to elaborate the difficulties with deciphering ancient languages : Just because you know the translation , you can not read the unknown text . Scientists thought for a century that hieroglyphics are [ ideograms ] ( URL_5 ) though later research showed that they are mainly [ phonograms ] ( URL_4 ) mixed with few ideograms . Deciphering ancient languages can be seen as a type of [ cryptoanalysis ] ( URL_2 ) as in ' I have a bunch of symbols and I want to know their meaning ' . As /u / Neo63 stated frequency analysis is a major part of decryption . Since ancient languages are luckily most of the time not encrypted scientists can use symbols or chains of symbols which occur frequently in many texts to try to decipher its meaning . This was a major part in the deciphering of [ Linear B ] ( URL_1 ) , which was Greek in another alphabet , where [ Micheal Ventris ] ( URL_3 ) translated often ocurring symbol chains as the names of cities . Of course this was only possible because he could assume that the stone plates held trading information ( there were numerous columns with an easy to decipher number system on them ) . This leads to another important part of deciphering ancient languages : Knowing the * context * . Trade information on a stone plate ? There are certainly names of cities somewhere in the text . Of course you can not just search for symbol chains with the same length as ' Knossos ' because you do not know if the symbols represent letters or syllables or words . In case of Linear B on part of its deciphering was the detection of cases which lead to the deciphering of the syllables ( there were about 60 symbols , which points to a language of syllables , whereas phonetic languages contain 10 - 40 symbols and ideographic languages contain up to multiple thousand ) ."]

id: How do nighttime rainbows function ? p.s . did n't know it was a thing till today . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['A moonbow ( also known as a lunar rainbow or white rainbow ) , is a rainbow produced by moonlight rather than sunlight . Other than the difference in light source , its formation is exactly the same as for a solar rainbow : It is caused by the refraction of light in many water droplets , such as a rain shower or a waterfall , and is always positioned in the opposite part of the sky from the moon relative to the observer . Moonbows are much fainter than solar rainbows , due to the smaller amount of light reflected from the surface of the moon . Because the light is usually too faint to excite the cone color receptors in human eyes , it is difficult for the human eye to discern colors in a moonbow . As a result , a moonbow often appears to be white . [ Wikipedia ] ( URL_0 )', "The sunlight reflecting off the moon can also produce a rainbow if similar conditions are met . You 'll need a bright near - full moon to do it and it will be very faint , but it 's possible .", 'Same way as rainbows , just light is being reflected off of the moon . Look up night rainbows .']

id: How do Siamese twins work ? How do Siamese twins decide who does what with their body ? For example ; if one twin has to go to the bathroom and the other does nât . Who controls the twins bodily functions ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['As far as I know , there is only one set of conjoined twins this applies to : Abby and Brittany Hensel . Their entire bodies , except for their heads , are conjoined . They each control one half of their conjoined parts , so they have to work in tandem for everything . For example , each controls one leg so it was thought at first that they âd never be able to walk because coordinating is too difficult . But they managed to do it , establishing a rhythm and intuitively sensing the walking rhythm . They have nât spoken about toilet issues as far as I know , though I would imagine the same principle would apply . When they were little , one of them tended to be the one to do most of the eating , with the other saying she was nât hungry . Since they share one digestive system , they could do this without harm . The reason I say it only applies to them is that the degree to which they are conjoined is more extensive than with most other conjoined twins . There could be others but they âre not in the public eye . And there was a set that was conjoined in a similar fashion in the UK . The parents decided to separate them , and one died . That case is one of the reasons why the Hensels decided not to separate their girls . There âs another set of conjoined twins in Canada , Tatiana and Krista Hogan , whose brains are conjoined but their bodies are separate . They âre 11 . They can see out of each others â eyes , control limbs that are part of their twin , and feel what the other feels , because of the degree to which their brains are attached .', "Great question . Could use a better example . I 'm completely curious about movement and mental coordination . Is it a shared thought ? Is there any internal discussion between the two minds before the movement occurs ? Does one ever get tired , while the other is wide awake ? How does that work with any other feelings like hunger , pain , laughter or elation ?", "It entirely depends on how they 're joined . First thing to understand is that there are different types of twins . For example , with non\\-identical twins that 's where two different sperm fertilize two different eggs and even though the twins share a womb and are born at the same time , genetically they 're no different than any other siblings . Identical twins are where a single sperm fertilizes a single egg and somewhere along the line , the embryo splits in two , so you get two individuals that are genetically identical . You get ' Siamese ' twins when the embryo only partly splits . It splits enough to form two separate individuals , but does n't completely physically split apart . So , you can have ' extreme ' conjoined twins like Abby and Brittany Hensel . They look like a single person with two heads , but the truth is they have separate hearts , stomachs , lungs and Spinal cords . In their case this essentially means that each of them has half a body under their control . Abby has no control over and ca n't feel the arm and leg on Brittany 's side and vice versa and they each only have control over their half of the body . Then , you have less ' extreme ' conjoined twins like Daisy and Violet Hilton . They were joined at the hip , but each had their own bodies and the only thing ' shared ' was blood circulation and their pelvises were fused together . So , the answer to your question is it really depends on the twins . The bodily functions might not be shared at all , or if they are shared , it depends which twin ' owns ' the particular biology ."]

id: How do scientists know that the moon was formed from two planets colliding ? and how do they know how long ago it happened ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["The reasoning goes like this : The Moon missions brought back Moon rocks , which when studied , revealed that the Moon is primarily compromised of a kind of rock also found on Earth . Hence , scientists believe that the Moon 's material came from Earth at some point . They also know that when Earth was formed , the material comprising it was mostly homogeneous . It was n't until millions of years later that the different types of rocks and materials began to stratify , or organize themselves by density ( dense things sank to the core , while lighter things were displaced ) . Since the Moon 's material is not only identical to the rocks on Earth , they are also mixed . This tells scientists that the event which created the Moon happened * before * the layers had a chance to properly layer themselves , as we see now . So essentially we know that there is a timeline of de - homogenation that began shortly after the Earth was done , and careful analysis of the Moon rocks can show us where about on that timeline the material came from .", "Calculus , geology , mineral study , carbon dating , and very good instruments . We know that the moon is made of the same stuff as the Earth . We know that it 's orbit is getting farther and farther away as time goes on , and the Earths rate of rotation is getting slower . We know that some of the minerals in the rocks on the moon form only in molten conditions meaning the entire moon was molten at one point , and finally we know give or take how old the moon and the Earth are . So if you have an ever increasing distance , and an ever slowing rate of rotation , and you play that scenario backwards towards the distant past , then you see the moon getting ever closer to the Earth , and the Earth spinning faster and faster . The most plausible explanation for this behavior , for the mineral makeup of the moon compared to the Earth , as well as the Earth 's own geology in the oldest rocks ever found , we can plausibly say that the moon is made of material that was ejected from the Earth in a massive impact some 4.5 billion years ago in a massive collision . The object that struck the much smaller proto - Earth was the size of Mars and it hit at tens of thousands of miles per hour , obliterating both bodies and ejecting material out into space where it formed a ring system as the new Earth 's gravity pulled it back . Over time this ring system became lumpy and began collecting in larger and larger chunks as gravity drew small to large . The heat of this gravitational pull rendered the moon molten and the surface a kind of basaltic lava flow . The impact also had the Earth spinning incredibly fast with a day lasting about 6 hours long . It took billions of years for it to slow to a 24 hour day and for the moon to move as far away as it has .", 'When astronauts brought back " moon rocks " , and scientists did their sciency things to those rocks , they quickly realized those " moon rocks " were almost 99.9 % similar to earth rocks']

id: How does a Turing machine work and what does it do All I know is it 's in a CPU and it manipulates binary data Explain like I'm five.
text: ['A Turing machine is * not * in a CPU and it does * not * manipulate binary data . It is important to not start with false assumptions , I think . :-) A Turing machine is more like a rule - based game than a physical toy . Think of it like the game Solitaire . You start with a deck of shuffled cards and lay them out according to the rules of the game . This is one part of the Turing machine , which we call the input . The next part of the Turing machine is the end state --- this describes the conditions when the game has ended . In Solitaire you win by getting all your cards into numerical ordered columns ; and you lose by getting through all your cards without managing to do this , so you have no further options . The third important part of the Turing machine is the rules of the game : at each stage it tells you which moves you can make . In some types of game there are several moves you can make at each step , and it \'s a matter of the player to choose . Others there is no choice and the fun of the game comes from having it unfold in front of you even though you ca n\'t affect the outcome . The Turing machine was invented to make formal the notion of rules and processes . The question that Alan Turing wanted to answer was about the " end game " . Is it possible to know whether you will win a game of Solitaire without playing the game of Solitaire ? Could you be stuck in an endless loop if there was no way to lose , only to win ? In the process of answering this question he realised that he could write down each of his Turing machines as a grouping of symbols , like { input , rules , end conditions } and that would be a complete definition of that Turing machine . This would be the ultimate formal definition of Solitaire , or whatever . But once you \'ve got a definition of a Turing machine as a series of symbols , you can feed that to a Turing machines whose rules tell it how to recognise symbols . So let \'s say I have a Turing machine called SolTM = { input deck , Solitaire rules , end conditions } . And I have a new one called UTM = { input TM , rules , end conditions } . If I manipulate SolTM using the rules defined in UTM then I am making the UTM _ act like SolTM _ . This is the essence of Alan Turing \'s _ Universal Turing Machine _ , a device that can pretend to be other devices if given a description of how they work . I appreciate this may be some pretty hairy stuff , and over the heads of most 25 year - olds :-) but it \'s also the foundations of our understanding of computation , ie the question of " mechanically " producing an output from input+rules .', "Wikipedia does a decent job , so I 'll try to simplify that a bit more ( at the expense of exactness ) . A turing machine is * not * a physical machine ( though people have made them ) . It is a theoretical object which is used to model , in a sense , the simplest possible computer . It is fed an input , and can return ' yes ' or ' no ' ( or continue forever ) . An example ( and a good exercise ) is to ' build ' a machine to test if an integer is divisible by 9 . The input would then be the integer , and the machine would return ' yes ' or ' no ' at the end . Say you have an infinite tape of symbols , and a ' head ' , which the tape is fed to , and which can be in different ' states ' or ' modes ' . At each symbol , the head takes some action . An action could be ' if the head is in state 1 and if the symbol is an A , erase the A and write B , change to state 2 , and move three spaces to the right ' , or ' if the head is in state 2 and the symbol is a C , return yes and quit ' . To test for divisibility by nine , the machine might be as follows : the input tape contains the number written in decimal notation , with one digit per space . We would have ten states , 0 , 1 , 2 , ... 9 . The rules would be : ' start in state 0 and move to the first symbol ' , and ' at each symbol , add the symbol to the current state and add the digits until we have a number less than 10 , then move right one space ' , and ' if we hit a blank space and we are in state 9 or 0 , return yes . otherwise return no ' . This uses the idea that if the sum of digits is divisible by 9 , then the number is divisible by 9 . Try this out with , say , 574281 as an input to see how the machine works . A turing machine is not a model of a real computer . It is , however , theoretically capable of doing anything a real computer can do . The simplicity of turing machines compared to real computers makes them very useful for proving things , because if something can not be done with a turing machine , it can not be done with any equivalent computing machine . They are also used extensively for algorithm analysis . The number of ' actions ' taken by the machine is a useful measurement of how fast an algorithm is .", 'The general idea is that you have a machine that reads an infinite tape and keeps track of what state it \'s in . The tape tells you what to do next ( read the next instruction , read the last one , etc ) . A Turing machine is totally abstract so the tape can be infinite in length , but you can only have a finite number of states . The important thing to keep in mind here is that there \'s no difference between data and instructions . CPUs work in more or less the same fashion , except that the " tape " ( memory ) is finite , thus a language is said to be " Turing complete " if it supports all the possible operations that a Turing machine can process . Another important point : Turing machines are where theory hits the pavement -- you can prove things about Turing machines based only on math , but the same can not be said about real world computers . This is one of the main reasons why people study them . Edit : many typos fixed !']

id: How do they digitally remaster old movies , and make them higher quality/ resolution ? Can someone please explain this to me ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['The resolution of film is something between 2k and 4k - much higher than VHS and TV . Original masters are scanned into a computer at high resolution where they are often cleaned up / retouched by visual effects artists ( think clone tool in Photoshop for removing dust and scratches ) .', "The old school film reels that movies were shot on have a resolution ( that 's the dots that make up the picture ) several magnitudes higher then what we currently consider to be HD . This was necessary to display it on such a large movie screen and still have a good picture . With remastering they can capture a larger resolution so they can create a HD release for home use . They also scan the film digitally into computers so they can remove bad frames and other things that may have appeared on the film as it degraded over time .", 'Digital restoration artist here . Been restoring film for almost 20 years . Film is transferred to a digital media . It can be transferred at rez up to 6k . However , the file size is so massive , that it \'s usually at 4 or 2 k rez . I \'m not an expert , but I \'ve been told that the human eye can really only process to 3k . After its transferred , the files are painstakingly " fixed . " ( scratches , warps , stretches and dirt are removed digitally . ) Then the colorization process is done . The original scans are stored separately than the colored color graded scans . Each frame in 2k is about 12,500 kb . Each reel has about 20,000 frames . Each film can range from 5 - 8 reels of film . With the restoration software being so easy to use now , and film management is easy to do also , the bulk of the work is done in India or China . I get the stuff they ca n\'t or wo n\'t do , but it \'s a matter of time before they do it all ...']

id: How does a mirror help to fix phantom limb syndrome ? Ca n't remember where I saw this . If a nerve is sending pain signals , surely just looking at it in a mirror wo nt stop the pain ? Thanks Explain like I'm five.
text: ["You do n't just look in a mirror . You arrange the mirror in such a way the reflection of your intact limb appears where your missing limb is . This visualization makes it easier you to find and relax the neurons that are trying to send signals to the missing limb .", 'You saw it on a Ted talk . The mirror is positioned so the person with the missing limb sees the reflection of the remaining limb , which tells the brain the missing limb is still there . It does not stop nerves from firing , it tells the brain the missing limb is in tact and unharmed which works for some patients .', "There was an episode of House where he did this . I 'm too lazy to google it but if you want to watch with a good explanation google away"]

id: How do bytes take up " space " ? You know , like how my hard drive only holds 1 TB . I must assume that they do n't take up physical space , but if that 's the case , then what do bytes actually occupy ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Your hard drive is a round plate , kind of like an old record . It \'s divided into thousands and thousands of " sectors " , tiny little spots . Each one of those tiny spots is a byte ... When you save a byte on your hard drive , the drive head makes a change in the magnetic charge in that spot . The computer turns these positive and negative magnetic charges into ones and zeroes .', 'Think of it this way . You have a large plate with the whole surface area covered in small 1 cm^3 cubes ( think , > 10 ^ 1000 cubes ) , each side having either a 0 or 1 on it . It already takes up space , but when your hard drive pin drives its magnet over these cubes , it changes it from 0 to 1 or vice versa . The containers that hold bytes take up space , but writing bytes to them simply changes the orientation of these bytes . OR you have a box full of air . You pump in different air , while venting out the old . Space occupied is the same , but composition is different .', 'It \'s more like resolution . You can " see " some pretty tiny pixels on your computer screen . - or some pretty small ink dots on paper . Beyond some point in \' smallness \' , your eyes have a hard time making anything meaningful out of those small marks . The way data is stored on magnetic media ( spinning hard disk plates ) is related to how small we can make a reliable reading of what each bit means . The capacity of your drive is how many reliable - separate - bits can be read with the current , consumer - level tech . EDIT - to your follow up on /u / mobyhead1 ; bits are a magnet that can be flipped .. on or off , 0 or 1 , N or S. bytes are a grouping of 8 bits that mean something together .']
