id: How do people sell a house when the mortgage is n't fully paid off ? Does the loan transfer to the next buyer ? I wish this was something that was taught in school ... Please explain like I'm five.
text:
['When a person sells a house and the mortgage is not fully paid off, the process is called a "short sale." In a short sale, the lender agrees to allow the homeowner to sell the house for less than the amount that is still owed on the mortgage. 
Here's how it works: 
1. The homeowner contacts their lender and explains that they need to sell their house but owe more on the mortgage than the house is worth. 
2. The lender reviews the homeowner's financial situation and determines whether they are eligible for a short sale. The lender will look at factors such as the homeowner's income, the amount of equity in the house, and the homeowner's ability to make the mortgage payments. 
3. If the lender agrees to the short sale, the homeowner can then try to sell the house. The lender will review any offers that the homeowner receives and decide whether to accept or reject them. 
4. If the lender accepts an offer, the buyer will need to pay the amount agreed upon in the offer to the lender. The lender will then use this money to pay off the remaining balance on the mortgage. 
5. Once the mortgage has been paid off, the lender will release the lien on the house and transfer the title to the new owner. 
In a short sale, the homeowner is responsible for paying any difference between the amount they owe on the mortgage and the amount that the house sells for. This is called a "deficiency balance." The lender may ask the homeowner to pay the deficiency balance, or they may agree to forgive it.']

id: How do phone networks work ? Phone networks keep getting better and faster , with faster internet access on phones . Is there a limit to this ? How can we transfer so much information in a second through the air ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
["Phone networks work by using a series of towers and antennas to transmit and receive signals from phones. When you make a call or send a text message, your phone sends a signal to the nearest tower, which then sends the signal to the recipient's phone through another tower. The towers are connected to each other and to the phone network through a series of cables and other equipment.

As for the internet, phone networks use a similar process to transmit and receive data. When you access the internet on your phone, your phone sends a request for data to the nearest tower, which then sends the request to a computer server that stores the data you requested. The server then sends the data back to the tower, which sends it to your phone.

There is a limit to how much information can be transmitted in a second through the air, but technology is constantly improving, which means that phone networks are able to transmit more and more information in a shorter amount of time. This is why phone networks keep getting faster and faster.

To explain it simply: phone networks use towers to send and receive signals from phones, and these towers are connected to each other and to the phone network through a series of cables and other equipment. This allows us to communicate with each other and access the internet on our phones. As technology improves, phone networks are able to transmit more and more information in a shorter amount of time, which makes them faster and more efficient."]

id: How does a pool stay cool when it is in direct 95 + degree sun all day ? Could it have something to do with a thermocline maybe ? Please explain like I'm five.

This can help reduce the amount of heat absorbed by the water, which can help keep the water temperature lower. Another way to keep a pool cool is to use a pool pump and filter system to circulate the water. This helps to mix the cooler water from the bottom of the pool with the warmer water at the top, which can help even out the temperature of the water. A thermocline is a layer of water in a pool or lake that has a significant change in temperature. It is usually caused by the sun heating the top layer of water, which can create a temperature gradient between the top and bottom layers of water. In a pool, the thermocline is typically found near the middle of the pool and can create a distinct line where the water temperature changes. So, while a thermocline can help keep a pool cool by separating the warmer water at the top from the cooler water at the bottom, it is not the only factor that can help a pool stay cool in hot weather. Using a pool cover and circulating the water can also help keep the water temperature lower."]

id: How does a Tesla car engine work , and in which areas does it differ from the standard petrol motor ? I 've just never seen it broken down before . Even an insightful link would be appreciated . Explain like I'm five.

["A Tesla car has an electric motor instead of a traditional gasoline engine. Instead of burning gasoline to create motion, the electric motor in a Tesla uses electricity from a set of batteries to power itself.

One of the main differences between a traditional gasoline engine and an electric motor is that the electric motor is much simpler and has fewer moving parts. Gasoline engines have many parts that move and work together, such as the pistons, crankshaft, and valves, which can wear out over time and require maintenance. Electric motors, on the other hand, have only one moving part (the rotor) and are generally more reliable and require less maintenance.

Another difference is that electric motors are much more efficient than gasoline engines. When a gasoline engine burns fuel, only a small percentage of the energy created is used to power the car. The rest is lost as heat and noise. Electric motors, on the other hand, can convert almost all of the electricity they receive into motion, making them much more efficient.

Overall, electric motors are a cleaner and more efficient way to power a car compared to gasoline engines. They don't produce any emissions and require less maintenance, which makes them a good choice for people who want to reduce their impact on the environment and save money on fuel and maintenance costs."]

id: How do you put someone in a medically induced coma ? I always hear about this happening but how can we do this ? Do they continously inject drugs into them , and how long / safe is it ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["A medically induced coma is a deep state of unconsciousness that is typically caused by a medical procedure or medication. It is used to protect the brain from further damage or allow it to rest and heal. It is also used to control certain medical conditions, such as seizures.To induce a coma, a healthcare provider will give the person a medication that causes them to become unconscious. The medication is usually given through a vein (IV) in the arm, but it can also be given as a shot or inhaled.The person will be closely monitored while they are in a coma. They will be checked regularly for signs of brain activity and other vital signs, such as heart rate and breathing. Healthcare providers will also check for any potential side effects or complications from the coma.A coma can last for a few days or several weeks, depending on the person's condition and the treatment they are receiving. When the person is stable and their condition has improved, the healthcare provider may slowly start to reduce the medication and bring them out of the coma.It is generally safe to be in a medically induced coma, but it can have some risks, such as infection or blood clots. Healthcare providers will take steps to prevent these complications and monitor the person closely to ensure their safety."]

id: How does a deadly cancer like melanoma actually kill you ? What 's going on in your body that actually causes your death ? Why are some tumors benign and others malignant ? What about a tumor makes it malignant ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Melanoma is a type of skin cancer that can be deadly if it is not caught and treated early. It happens when the cells that produce pigment in your skin (called melanocytes) grow out of control and form a tumor.

Sometimes, these tumors are benign, which means they are not cancerous and are not likely to spread to other parts of the body. Benign tumors can usually be removed and do not usually come back.

Other times, these tumors are malignant, which means they are cancerous and can spread to other parts of the body. This is called metastasis. When melanoma spreads, it can be very difficult to treat and can be life-threatening.

So, how does melanoma kill you? When melanoma spreads to other parts of the body, it can damage or destroy the tissues and organs it invades. For example, if melanoma spreads to the brain, it can cause headaches, seizures, and other problems with brain function. If it spreads to the lungs, it can cause trouble breathing. If it spreads to the liver, it can cause liver damage. When these organs are damaged or not working properly, it can make it hard for the body to function and can lead to death.

As for why some tumors are benign and others are malignant, it is not fully understood. It is thought that certain changes in the DNA of cells can cause them to become cancerous, but more research is needed to understand exactly what causes these changes and how to prevent them.']

id: How do they filmmakers take shots in front of mirrors without having the camera being in the reflection ? Is it just CGI ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Filmmakers can take shots in front of mirrors without having the camera being in the reflection by using a technique called "keyhole blocking." This involves carefully positioning the camera and the actors in the scene so that the camera is hidden behind a small gap, such as a gap between two objects or a door that is slightly open. This allows the camera to capture the action in the scene without being reflected in the mirror.

Another way to avoid having the camera reflected in the mirror is to use a special type of mirror called a one-way mirror. A one-way mirror is a mirror that is partially transparent, meaning that it is possible to see through it from one side but not from the other. If the camera is positioned on the side of the one-way mirror where it is possible to see through it, the camera will not be reflected in the mirror.

Sometimes, filmmakers will also use computer-generated imagery (CGI) to remove the camera or other crew members from the reflection in the mirror. This can be done by digitally replacing the reflection in the mirror with the desired image.

Overall, there are several different ways that filmmakers can take shots in front of mirrors without having the camera reflected in the mirror, including keyhole blocking, using one-way mirrors, and using CGI.']

Alternatively, an individual can qualify based on net worth, which must be at least $1 million, either individually or jointly with a spouse, excluding the value of the individual's primary residence.It is important to note that the SEC's accredited investor definition applies only to individuals, and does not extend to entities such as corporations or partnerships. id: How does a elevator algorithm work ? Considering there are multiple elevators going to the same floors . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["\\nAn elevator algorithm is a set of rules that determines how elevators move and pick up passengers. When multiple elevators are working in the same building, the algorithm helps to coordinate their movements and make sure they are efficient and effective at getting people to their destinations.\\n\\nHere's how it might work:\\n\\nWhen someone presses the button to call an elevator, the algorithm receives a request for a pickup on a certain floor.\\n\\nThe algorithm looks at all the elevators in the building and determines which one is closest to the pickup floor. This is usually the one that will be sent to the floor to pick up the passenger.\\n\\nThe algorithm also considers the direction that each elevator is moving in. For example, if there is an elevator on the same floor as the pickup request and it is going in the same direction as the passenger's desired destination, it might be a better choice to send that elevator instead of one that is farther away but going in the opposite direction.\\n\\nOnce the algorithm has chosen the best elevator for the job, it sends a signal to that elevator telling it to stop at the pickup floor and open its doors.\\n\\nThe passenger gets on the elevator and presses the button for their desired floor.\\n\\nThe algorithm receives the destination request and determines the most efficient route for the elevator to take to get to that floor. This might involve stopping at other floors to pick up or drop off passengers along the way.\\n\\nThe algorithm sends a signal to the elevator to close its doors and start moving towards the destination floor.\\n\\nWhen the elevator reaches the destination floor, it stops and opens its doors, allowing the passenger to exit.\\n\\nThat's a very basic overview of how an elevator algorithm works. There are many different ways to design an algorithm, and the specifics can vary depending on the needs of the building and the number of elevators being used."]

id: How do microphone " Pop Filters " work ? How does putting a piece of fabric over your mic stop wind noise and plosives ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['\\nA pop filter is a device that goes over a microphone to help reduce the amount of wind noise and plosives (explosive sounds made when saying certain consonants) that get picked up by the microphone. It does this by using a thin piece of fabric, such as nylon or mesh, that is placed in front of the microphone.\\n\\nWhen you speak or sing into a microphone, the sound waves from your voice travel through the air and hit the microphone diaphragm, which vibrates and creates an electrical signal. This electrical signal is then amplified and sent to a speaker or recording device.\\n\\nPlosives are sounds that are made when you say certain consonants, like "p" or "b." These sounds produce a burst of air that can hit the microphone diaphragm with a lot of force, which can create a loud, distorted sound. Wind noise is created when wind blows against the microphone, which can also create a loud, distorted sound.\\n\\nThe pop filter helps to reduce these types of noise by blocking some of the air and wind that hits the microphone. The fabric is thin enough to allow sound waves to pass through, but it catches and absorbs some of the air and wind that would otherwise hit the microphone diaphragm. This helps to reduce the amount of noise and distortion that gets picked up by the microphone, which can improve the overall sound quality of your recording.']

For example, they might believe that the similarities between parents and their children are simply due to genetics, and that genetics works in a way that is unrelated to evolution. \nIn any case, it is important to note that the scientific theory of evolution explains these phenomena through the process of natural selection, in which certain traits are passed down from one generation to the next because they help the organisms that have them to survive and reproduce. It will swing back and forth in a regular pattern.\\n\\nAs the Earth rotates underneath the pendulum, the pendulum appears to change direction. This is because the direction of the pendulum's swing is relative to the surface of the Earth, and the Earth is moving underneath it.\\n\\nThe pendulum will continue to swing in the same direction, but the Earth's rotation causes the pendulum to appear to change direction.\\n\\nBy observing the pendulum's movement over time, we can see the Earth's rotation and calculate the Earth's rotational speed.\\n\\nSo, the Foucault pendulum is a way to demonstrate the Earth's rotation using the regular swinging motion of a pendulum. id: How do âheldâ amounts appear on statements and affect balances of traditional credit cards?
text: ["When you use a traditional credit card to make a purchase, the merchant may place a hold on your account for the amount of the transaction. This means that the funds will be temporarily set aside in your account and will not be available for you to use until the transaction is completed. The hold will appear on your credit card statement as a pending transaction.The purpose of the hold is to ensure that the merchant has the funds available to complete the transaction. For example, if you use your credit card to pay for a hotel room, the hotel may place a hold on your account for the full amount of your stay, even if you only use the card to pay for one night. This is to protect the hotel in case you decide to stay longer or incur additional charges.The hold will typically be released a few days after the transaction is completed, at which point the funds will be made available for you to use again. The hold will also be released if the transaction is cancelled or if it is not completed for any reason.It's important to note that the hold will affect your available credit and may cause your balance to go over your credit limit. However, the hold will not be reflected in your balance until the transaction is completed and the funds are actually transferred from your account."]

id: How do checks work and why are they still being used ? They just seem really inconvenient . Explain like I'm five.
text:
['A check is a piece of paper that you can use to pay for things instead of using cash or a credit or debit card. When you write a check, you are telling your bank to give a certain amount of money to someone else.

To use a check, you first need to have an account at a bank. When you open an account, the bank gives you some checks that you can use to pay for things. You can also get more checks from the bank if you need them.

To write a check, you need to fill out certain information on the check. This includes the date, the name of the person or company you are paying, and the amount of money you are giving them. You also need to sign the check to show that it is really from you.

To use a check, you give it to the person or company you are paying. They can then take the check to their bank and get the money from your account. This process can take a few days, so it is not as fast as using a credit or debit card.

Checks are still used today because they can be a convenient and safe way to pay for things. For example, if you do not have a credit or debit card, or if you do not want to use your card for a particular purchase, you can use a check instead. Checks are also useful if you need to send money to someone who does not have a bank account or who is far away.']

id: How do banks make money when they are paying me interest for the money I give to them for safe keeping ? Do they lend people so much money that they are able to cover the interest they have to pay for savings account holders ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['\\nBanks make money by using the money that people deposit in their accounts (like a savings account) to lend to other people. They charge the people who borrow money (called "borrowers") a higher interest rate than the rate they pay to people who deposit money (called "depositors"). The difference between the interest rate they charge borrowers and the interest rate they pay depositors is called the "spread," and it is how banks make most of their money.\\n\\nFor example, let\'s say a bank pays you 2% interest on your savings account and charges borrowers an interest rate of 5%. If you deposit $100 in your savings account, the bank will pay you $2 in interest. If the bank then lends that $100 to a borrower and charges them 5% interest, the borrower will have to pay the bank $5 in interest. The bank gets to keep the difference, which is $3, as profit.\\n\\nSo, when you deposit money in a bank, you are helping the bank make money by lending your money to other people. The bank pays you a small amount of interest as a thank you for letting them use your money to make more money.']

id: How do they shoot space movies to look like zero gravity ? I 'm talking older movies , too , like 2001 a Space Odyssey when superior editing technology was still a ways off . Please explain like I'm five.
text:
['There are several techniques that filmmakers use to create the illusion of zero gravity in movies. One technique is called "forced perspective." This involves shooting a scene with the camera at an angle that makes objects in the foreground look larger than they are, while objects in the background appear smaller. This creates the illusion that the objects in the foreground are closer to the camera and are therefore subject to less gravity. 
Another technique is called "high-speed photography." This involves shooting a scene at a very high frame rate, typically hundreds or thousands of frames per second. When the footage is played back at a normal frame rate, it appears as though the objects in the scene are moving much more slowly than they actually are. This can be used to make it look like objects are floating or moving slowly in a weightless environment. 
In some cases, filmmakers will also use special effects and computer-generated imagery (CGI) to create the illusion of zero gravity. This can involve digitally altering the movement of objects in a scene or creating entirely digital environments that look like they are in space. 
In the past, filmmakers have also used practical effects to create the illusion of zero gravity. For example, in the movie "2001: A Space Odyssey," the filmmakers used a special rig called a "zero gravity plane" to simulate weightlessness. The plane would fly in a parabolic pattern, allowing the actors to experience brief periods of weightlessness. The filmmakers then shot the scenes during these periods and used editing techniques to make it look like the actors were in a weightless environment.']

id: How do credit union loans and dividends vs interest work?
text: ["A credit union is a non-profit financial institution that is owned and controlled by its members. Credit unions offer many of the same products and services as banks, including loans and savings accounts. However, because credit unions are non-profit, they generally offer better rates on loans and higher dividends on savings accounts.When you borrow money from a credit union, you are essentially borrowing from other members of the credit union. The credit union uses the money you and other members have deposited in savings accounts and other types of accounts to fund loans. When you make a loan payment, the credit union uses that money to pay back the other members who have deposited money in the credit union. This is why credit unions are able to offer lower rates on loans.A dividend is a distribution of a portion of a credit union's profits to its members. Credit unions are non-profit organizations, so any profits they make are returned to their members in the form of dividends on savings accounts and other types of accounts. Credit unions typically pay higher dividends on savings accounts than banks because they do not have to worry about making a profit for shareholders.", "A credit union is a type of financial institution that is owned and controlled by its members, rather than by shareholders. Credit unions offer many of the same financial products as banks, including loans and savings accounts.When you take out a loan from a credit union, you will typically be required to pay interest on the loan. The interest is a fee that you pay to the credit union for borrowing money. The rate of interest will depend on the terms of the loan and your creditworthiness.In addition to offering loans, credit unions also often offer savings accounts to their members. These accounts pay dividends, which are essentially a share of the credit union's profits. Dividends are typically paid out to members on a regular basis, such as monthly or quarterly. The rate of dividends that you earn on your savings account will depend on the credit union's policies and the amount of money that you have saved.In general, credit unions tend to offer more favorable terms and lower fees than traditional banks. They may also be more willing to work with you if you have credit challenges or are in a financially difficult situation."]

id: How does a lender compute equity requirement for PMI?
text: ["Private mortgage insurance (PMI) is typically required by lenders when a borrower puts down less than 20% as a down payment on a home loan. PMI is meant to protect the lender in the event that the borrower defaults on their mortgage.To determine the equity requirement for PMI, lenders typically consider the loan-to-value (LTV) ratio of the mortgage. The LTV ratio is calculated by dividing the loan amount by the value of the property. For example, if a borrower is seeking a mortgage of $200,000 to purchase a home with a value of $250,000, the LTV ratio would be 80% ($200,000 / $250,000).Lenders generally require PMI when the LTV ratio exceeds 80%. In this case, the borrower would be required to pay PMI until they have built up enough equity in the property to bring the LTV ratio down to 80% or lower. This can be achieved by making mortgage payments, which reduce the outstanding balance on the loan, or by the value of the property appreciating, which increases the value of the collateral for the loan.It's worth noting that some lenders may have different requirements for PMI, so it's always a good idea to check with the lender to confirm their specific policies."]

id: How do search engines like Google search through so much data so quickly ? Honestly , this is n't from a completely ignorant perspective when it comes to programming , so feel free to go into great detail ( If you 'd like ! ) with your explanation . Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Search engines like Google use a combination of techniques to search through so much data quickly. Here are a few ways they do this:

Indexing: Google creates an index of all the words on the internet, along with the pages that contain those words. This way, when you search for something, Google can quickly look up the pages that contain the words you searched for, rather than having to search through every single page on the internet.

Caching: Google saves a copy of each page it indexes in a cache. This way, if someone else searches for the same thing you did, Google can show them the page from its cache, which is faster than loading the page from the original website.

Ranking: Google uses algorithms to determine which pages are most relevant to your search and should be shown first. This helps Google quickly narrow down the search results and show you the most relevant pages.

Distributed computing: Google has thousands of servers that work together to search the internet. When you do a search, your request is sent to many different servers, and the results are combined to give you the best results as quickly as possible.

Overall, search engines use a combination of these techniques to quickly search through vast amounts of data and provide you with the best results.']

id: How do markets âfactor inâ a future event?
text: ['Markets "factor in" a future event by incorporating expectations about the event into asset prices. This can happen through a variety of channels, such as changes in demand for a particular asset, changes in the supply of an asset, or changes in the risk associated with holding an asset.For example, if investors expect that a company will announce strong earnings in the future, they may be more likely to buy the company\'s stock, which would drive up the price. On the other hand, if investors expect that a company will announce weak earnings, they may be more likely to sell the company\'s stock, which would drive down the price.In general, financial markets are constantly incorporating new information about the future, and this information is reflected in the prices of assets. When a major event occurs, such as a change in interest rates or the release of economic data, it can have a significant impact on asset prices, as investors and traders adjust their expectations about the future in light of the new information.']

id: How do car engines work ? I have small background in thermodynamics so i think i can understand some terms . Please explain like I'm five.

Inside the engine, there is a cylinder with a piston inside it. The explosion pushes the piston down, causing the crankshaft to rotate. This rotation turns the wheels of the car, making it move. The process of burning fuel and turning the crankshaft is called the "combustion cycle." It starts when a spark plug sends a spark of electricity into the cylinder, which ignites the fuel and causes it to burn. As the fuel burns, it creates hot gases that push against the piston. The piston pushes back against the crankshaft, causing it to turn. When the crankshaft has turned a full 360 degrees, the combustion cycle is complete and it starts all over again. That\'s a very simplified explanation, but I hope it helps! Let me know if you have any questions.']

id: How do they find out the information that goes on Nutrition Facts labels ? Like number of calories , fat content , vitamin content , etc . etc . Please explain like I'm five.
text:
['Nutrition facts labels are required by law to be on most packaged foods in the United States. The information on these labels is based on scientific research and testing. 
To find out the number of calories in a food, researchers use a special machine called a bomb calorimeter. They put a small amount of the food in the machine and burn it. The heat that is given off is measured, and from this, the number of calories in the food can be calculated. 
To find out the amount of fat, protein, and other nutrients in a food, researchers use a process called proximate analysis. This involves using special chemicals to break down the food into its different parts, such as fat, protein, and carbohydrates. The amounts of these nutrients can then be measured. 
Vitamin and mineral content can also be determined through laboratory testing. Researchers can use special equipment to measure the amounts of different vitamins and minerals in a food. 
Overall, finding out the information that goes on nutrition facts labels requires careful scientific research and testing.']

id: How do people solve rubix cubes in < 10 seconds ? Edit : Rubik 's , my bad . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Solving a Rubik\'s Cube quickly involves using a series of specific algorithms and techniques. Here\'s a simplified explanation of how it works:First, the solver looks for any "solved" faces on the cube (faces that are all one color). They might start by looking for a white face, for example.Next, the solver tries to get the edge pieces (pieces that have two colors) in the correct position. They might do this by matching up the edge pieces with the center pieces (pieces that only have one color) on the white face.Once the edge pieces are in the correct position, the solver works on getting the corner pieces (pieces that have three colors) in the correct position. They might do this by matching up the corner pieces with the center and edge pieces on the white face.Finally, the solver uses algorithms (a set of steps to follow) to rearrange the remaining pieces so that the whole cube is solved.There are many different algorithms and techniques that people use to solve Rubik\'s Cubes quickly. Some people use a method called the Fridrich method, which involves using a series of specific algorithms to solve the cube in a particular order. Others use a method called the CFOP method, which stands for Cross, F2L (First 2 Layers), OLL (Orient Last Layer), and PLL (Permute Last Layer).To solve a Rubik\'s Cube in less than 10 seconds, a person would need to be very skilled at using these algorithms and techniques, and would also need to be able to execute them quickly and accurately. It takes a lot of practice and dedication to become a fast Rubik\'s Cube solver.']

id: How does Google Maps account for size distortion due to the Mercator projection ? So most online maps seem to use the Mercator projection , but say I 'm planning a trip from say , Niger to Germany , would n't the scales of length be really distorted ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['The Mercator projection is a way of showing the entire surface of the Earth on a flat map. It is widely used because it is a convenient and simple way to show the Earth on a flat surface. However, because the Earth is not a perfect sphere but rather an oblate spheroid (a sphere that is slightly flattened at the poles and bulging at the equator), the Mercator projection distorts the size of land masses as you move away from the equator. This means that countries near the poles (such as Canada and Russia) appear larger on a Mercator map than they really are, while countries near the equator (such as Brazil and Indonesia) appear smaller than they really are.To account for this distortion, Google Maps provides an option to switch to a different map projection called the "Gall-Peters projection," which shows the size of land masses more accurately. However, this projection has its own distortions and is not as widely used as the Mercator projection.So if you are planning a trip from Niger to Germany using Google Maps, the map will show the correct distance between the two countries, but the size of the countries themselves may not be shown accurately. It\'s important to keep this in mind when looking at maps, and to remember that they are just representations of the real world and may not show everything perfectly.']

id: How do contact lenses work ? How do they correct vision ? With monthly , bi - weekly , and dailies , what makes them last that amount of time ? What does toric do ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Contact lenses are thin, clear disks that you put on your eyes. They help you see better by bending light in a way that helps your eyes focus on things more clearly.\\n\\nThere are different types of contact lenses, and they last for different amounts of time. Monthly contact lenses are meant to be worn for about a month, and then you throw them away and get a new pair. Bi-weekly contact lenses are meant to be worn for about two weeks, and then you throw them away and get a new pair. Daily contact lenses are meant to be worn for one day, and then you throw them away and get a new pair the next day.\\n\\nToric contact lenses are a special type of contact lens that are shaped differently than regular contact lenses. They are made to correct vision problems that are caused by a condition called astigmatism. Astigmatism is when your eye is shaped more like a football than a sphere, which can make it hard for you to see clearly. Toric contact lenses are designed to correct this problem by bending light in a special way that helps your eye focus better.\\n\\nI hope that helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.']

id: How does HEX color code works ? Basically what the question is . At a machine level , how is it that this code reflects a color in monitors ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['\\nHEX color codes are a way to represent colors on a computer or other digital device. They are used to specify the colors of images, text, and other elements on a computer screen or other display.\\n\\nHEX color codes consist of a series of six characters, usually letters or numbers, that represent the different colors that make up a particular color. The first two characters represent the amount of red in the color, the next two characters represent the amount of green, and the final two characters represent the amount of blue.\\n\\nFor example, the HEX color code #FF0000 represents the color red, because it has a high amount of red (FF) and no green or blue (00). The HEX color code #00FF00 represents the color green, because it has a high amount of green (FF) and no red or blue (00). The HEX color code #0000FF represents the color blue, because it has a high amount of blue (FF) and no red or green (00).\\n\\nWhen these codes are used to display colors on a computer screen or other digital device, the device uses the codes to mix different amounts of red, green, and blue light to create the desired color. This process is known as RGB color mixing, and it allows computers and other digital devices to display a wide range of colors using just three primary colors: red, green, and blue.\\n\\nOverall, HEX color codes are a way to represent colors on a computer or other digital device by specifying the amounts of red, green, and blue that make up a particular color. When these codes are used to display colors on a digital device, the device uses RGB color mixing to create the desired color using different amounts of red, green, and blue light.\\n']

id: How do batteries work ? And why do they " last for 10 years " when they clearly do n't ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Sure! Batteries are like tiny power plants that can be used to store electricity for later use. They have two parts: a positive terminal (also called the cathode) and a negative terminal (also called the anode). Inside the battery, there is a chemical reaction that creates electricity, which flows from the negative terminal to the positive terminal through a wire. When you use a device that is powered by a battery, the device pulls the electricity from the battery, which makes the chemical reaction inside the battery stop. When the reaction stops, the battery is "dead" and needs to be replaced. Batteries are rated to last for a certain number of hours, but that doesn\'t mean they will last exactly that long. The "10 years" that you mentioned is probably the amount of time that a battery is expected to last under normal use before it needs to be replaced. However, there are many factors that can affect how long a battery lasts, such as how often it is used, how well it is taken care of, and the environment it is in. So a battery might last longer or shorter than the rated time depending on these factors.']

id: How do they clean up the lead at gun ranges ? How do they get rid of all the lead at outdoor ( or indoor ) gun ranges ? Or do they at all ? It must be an EPA nightmare . Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Gun ranges typically have systems in place to contain and clean up lead from bullets that are fired. This can involve using barriers such as walls and backstops to catch bullets and prevent them from leaving the range. At outdoor ranges, the soil and vegetation around the range may also be contaminated with lead from bullets, in which case it may be necessary to remove and properly dispose of the contaminated soil.

Indoor ranges may have ventilation systems in place to help control lead exposure and filter out lead particles from the air. These systems can help to reduce the amount of lead that accumulates on surfaces in the range.

To clean up lead at a gun range, workers may use special equipment and techniques to sweep, vacuum, or otherwise remove lead particles from surfaces. They may also use chemicals to dissolve or neutralize the lead, or they may use high-pressure water to wash it away.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has regulations in place to help protect the environment and public health from lead contamination at gun ranges. These regulations include standards for the construction and operation of gun ranges, as well as requirements for the proper disposal of lead-contaminated materials.']

id: How does 50 % sodium salt exist ? As sodium is a fundamental ingredient to the molecular structure of salt with a 1:1 relationship , how does Morton or other salt companies create the same amount of salt but with something like 50 % less sodium ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Salt is made up of two elements: sodium and chlorine. Sodium is a metal and chlorine is a gas. When they are combined, they form a compound called sodium chloride, which is what we commonly call salt. The chemical formula for salt is NaCl, which stands for sodium chloride.\\n\\nSalt companies, like Morton, can make salt with less sodium by using a process called "dilution." This means that they add other ingredients to the salt to reduce the amount of sodium in the final product. For example, they might add a substance called potassium chloride, which is a compound that is similar to salt but has less sodium and more potassium. Potassium is a mineral that is important for our bodies to function properly.\\n\\nBy adding potassium chloride to the salt, Morton is able to create a product that has less sodium but still has the same salty taste. This is helpful for people who need to watch their sodium intake because they have high blood pressure or other health conditions.\\n\\nI hope this helps to explain how 50% sodium salt can exist! Let me know if you have any more questions.\\n']

id: How do gears - like on a bicycle work ? I understand this is pretty basic .. I am a grad student and i even did decently well on a couple physics courses I took in undergrad .. I just still ca n't grasp it .. Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Gears are used to change the speed or torque (turning force) of a device. On a bicycle, the pedals are connected to a chain, which is connected to gears. When you pedal the bike, you are turning the chain, which in turn turns the gears. The gears are connected to the wheels of the bike, so when the gears turn, they make the wheels turn.\\n\\nIf the gears are bigger (have more teeth), they will be able to turn the wheels more slowly but with more force. This is useful for going up steep hills, because it allows you to pedal more easily.\\n\\nIf the gears are smaller, they will be able to turn the wheels more quickly, but with less force. This is useful for going faster, because it allows you to pedal faster without having to put in as much effort.\\n\\nBy shifting the gears on a bike, you can change the size of the gears that the chain is connected to, which changes the speed and torque of the bike. This allows you to pedal more easily or go faster, depending on what you need.']

id: How do different points on a vinyl record travel at different speeds ? Inspired by this Calvin and Hobbes comic : URL_0 How do two different points on a vinyl record travel at different speeds ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['When a needle (also called a stylus) is placed on a vinyl record and the record is played on a turntable, the needle follows the grooves in the record as it spins. The grooves on a vinyl record are spiral-shaped, which means that the distance between the center of the record and the groove is different at different points on the record.Because the distance from the center of the record to the groove is greater at the outer edges of the record, the needle must travel a greater distance to follow the groove. This means that the needle must move faster at the outer edges of the record in order to keep up with the groove. On the other hand, the needle must move slower at the inner part of the record, since the distance from the center to the groove is shorter.So, to summarize, the needle travels at different speeds on a vinyl record because the distance between the center of the record and the groove is different at different points on the record. The needle must travel faster at the outer edges of the record and slower at the inner part of the record in order to keep up with the groove.']

id: How do TV companies record viewing figures ? Surely it must be impossible to gauge an accurate figure with the amount of online viewing services available today . Explain like I'm five.
text:
['TV companies use a combination of methods to record viewing figures. One way they do this is by using a small device called a "viewership meter" that is installed in a representative sample of homes. These devices track which channels are being watched and for how long. This information is then used to estimate the total number of people watching a particular show.

Another way TV companies can track viewing figures is by looking at data from online streaming services, such as Netflix or Hulu. These services keep track of which shows and movies are being watched and how long they are being watched for.

It is important to note that it is difficult to get a completely accurate count of how many people are watching a particular show, especially with the increasing number of options for viewing content online. However, TV companies use statistical techniques to try to get as close to an accurate count as possible.']

id: How do serial entrepreneurs work ? How do serial entrepreneurs , especially when they start young , create companies in a matter of a few years , sell them , then repeat the process in a different space ? How are they so effective ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Serial entrepreneurs are people who start and run multiple businesses over the course of their career. They often have a lot of experience starting and running businesses, so they know what works and what doesn't. They are able to identify opportunities and act on them quickly, which can help them grow their businesses rapidly.\\n\\nOne way that serial entrepreneurs are able to create and sell companies quickly is by identifying a problem or need that they can solve with their product or service. They may then work to develop a solution and bring it to market as quickly as possible. They may also use their experience and connections to build relationships with potential customers and partners, which can help them grow their businesses faster.\\n\\nOnce a business has grown to a certain point, a serial entrepreneur may decide to sell it to another company or individual. This can allow them to take the profits they have made and invest them in a new venture. This process can be repeated multiple times, allowing the entrepreneur to build and sell multiple businesses over the course of their career.\\n\\nOverall, serial entrepreneurs are effective because they have a lot of experience starting and running businesses, they are able to identify and act on opportunities quickly, and they are able to build and maintain relationships that can help them grow their businesses."]

id: How does Google Finance calculate the Institution Owned metric for a stock
text: ["The Institution Owned metric on Google Finance reflects the percentage of a company's outstanding shares that are owned by institutional investors. Institutional investors include investment firms, pension funds, insurance companies, and mutual funds, among others.To calculate this metric, Google Finance gathers data on the ownership of a company's shares from regulatory filings and other publicly available sources. It then divides the number of shares owned by institutional investors by the total number of outstanding shares for the company. This percentage is then displayed as the Institution Owned metric on the company's profile page on Google Finance.It's important to note that the Institution Owned metric on Google Finance is only an estimate and may not be completely accurate. It's always a good idea to do your own research and consult with a financial advisor before making any investment decisions."]

id: How do black holes work ? Mainly - Where does what ever it sucks up go ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Black holes are extremely dense objects that are so heavy that they create a huge gravitational force around them. This force is so strong that it can even suck in light, which is why black holes are often referred to as "light eaters."

When something gets sucked into a black hole, it doesn't just disappear. Instead, it gets trapped inside the black hole's "event horizon," which is the point of no return. Once something passes the event horizon, it can't escape the black hole's gravity.

So what happens to the stuff that gets trapped inside a black hole? Scientists aren't exactly sure, but they have some ideas. One theory is that the matter gets crushed into an extremely dense point called a "singularity." Another theory is that the matter gets sucked into a different universe or dimension.

Either way, it's important to note that black holes aren't just vacuum cleaners sucking up everything in their path. They are extremely complex and mysterious objects that are still being studied and understood by scientists.']

id: How do internet speed tests work ? When using an internet speed test , am I just downloading as much data from their servers as possible ? Will this use a lot of data on my mobile plan ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Internet speed tests work by measuring how fast data can be transferred between your device and a server on the internet. To do this, the speed test sends a small amount of data to your device and measures how long it takes to receive it back.\\n\\nWhen you run an internet speed test, you are not downloading a large amount of data from the server. Instead, the test only sends and receives a small amount of data, which should not use a lot of data on your mobile plan.\\n\\nThink of it like filling up a bucket with water from a hose. The speed test measures how fast the hose can fill up the bucket by sending a small amount of water (data) through the hose and measuring how long it takes to fill the bucket. The test does not send a huge amount of water (data) through the hose, so it should not use a lot of water (data) from your mobile plan.']

id: How do wire transfers get settled?
text: ["When a wire transfer is initiated, the funds are transferred electronically from the sender's bank account to the recipient's bank account through the network of banks that handle the transaction. This process typically involves three steps:Authorization: The sender's bank verifies that the sender has sufficient funds in their account to complete the transfer and authorizes the transaction.Settlement: The banks involved in the transfer transfer the funds from the sender's account to the recipient's account. This typically happens in real-time or within a few hours, depending on the type of wire transfer and the banks involved.Reconciliation: The banks reconcile their records to ensure that the correct amount of funds has been transferred and that both the sender's and recipient's accounts are accurately reflected.Wire transfers can be settled through a variety of systems, including the Federal Reserve's Fedwire system in the United States, the SWIFT network for international transfers, and other proprietary systems operated by individual banks."]

id: How does ROUND - UP work and why is it bad ? I know it 's an herbicide , but I 'd like to know how it works to kill plants . Also , what does it do to humans ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Roundup is a herbicide that is used to kill weeds and other unwanted plants. It works by interfering with a plant's ability to produce certain proteins that are necessary for its growth and survival. When a plant is sprayed with Roundup, the active ingredient in the herbicide, glyphosate, is absorbed by the plant and disrupts the production of these proteins. This causes the plant to stop growing and eventually die.Roundup is considered bad for several reasons. One reason is that it can be harmful to humans if it is ingested or comes into contact with the skin. Glyphosate, the active ingredient in Roundup, has been classified as a probable human carcinogen by the World Health Organization. This means that it may cause cancer in humans, although more research is needed to confirm this.Another reason why Roundup is considered bad is that it can be harmful to the environment. When Roundup is sprayed on plants, it can drift through the air and come into contact with other plants or animals. This can have negative effects on non-target plants and animals that are not intended to be killed by the herbicide. Additionally, Roundup can persist in the environment for a long time and can accumulate in soil, water, and other places, which can have negative impacts on the ecosystems around it.In summary, Roundup is a herbicide that is used to kill weeds and other unwanted plants. It works by disrupting the production of proteins that are necessary for the plant's growth and survival. However, it can be harmful to humans and the environment, and has been classified as a probable human carcinogen."]

id: How do racoons and other creatures carry rabies without dying / going extinct ? Whoops ! * raccoons Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Raccoons and other animals can carry rabies without dying or going extinct because not all animals that have rabies will die from the disease. While rabies is a serious and often fatal disease, not all animals that are infected with the virus will become sick or die from it. This is because some animals are able to develop immunity to the virus and are able to survive the infection.Rabies is a virus that affects the central nervous system of animals. It is most commonly transmitted through the bite of an infected animal, but it can also be transmitted through scratches or abrasions. When an animal is bitten by another animal that has rabies, the virus can be transmitted through the saliva of the infected animal and enter the body of the animal that was bitten.Once the virus enters the body, it begins to multiply and spread to other parts of the body, including the brain and spinal cord. This can cause symptoms such as fever, weakness, and difficulty swallowing. If left untreated, rabies can be fatal.However, not all animals that are infected with rabies will develop symptoms or die from the disease. Some animals are able to develop immunity to the virus and are able to survive the infection. This is why it is possible for raccoons and other animals to carry rabies without dying or going extinct.']

id: How do air conditioners produce cold air ? I sound dumb when I ask this , but how do they produce cold air ? I understand how they produce heat as that seems fairly obvious , but I 'm clueless on them producing cold air . Thanks ! Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Air conditioners produce cold air by using a chemical called refrigerant. The refrigerant is a special type of gas that can easily change from a gas to a liquid and back again.\\n\\nInside the air conditioner, there is a long coil of metal tubing called an evaporator. The refrigerant is pumped into the evaporator and it changes from a liquid to a gas as it absorbs heat from the air inside the room. As the refrigerant absorbs heat, it begins to boil and produce cold air.\\n\\nThe cold air is then blown out of the air conditioner by a fan and into the room, making the room feel cooler. At the same time, the refrigerant gas is pumped out of the evaporator and into a separate coil of metal tubing called a condenser.\\n\\nIn the condenser, the refrigerant gas is squeezed under high pressure, causing it to change back into a liquid. As it changes back into a liquid, it releases the heat it had absorbed from the air inside the room. The heat is released into the air outside the air conditioner, which is why you might feel hot air coming out of the back of the air conditioner when it's running.\\n\\nSo, to sum it up, air conditioners use the refrigerant to absorb heat from the air inside the room and release it outside, producing cold air in the process."]

id: How do new parents who experience sleep deprivation for a few months / years stay alive ? I do n't imagine they get that great quality sleep by a 30 min nap during the day , either . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["New parents often experience sleep deprivation because they are caring for a newborn baby, who needs frequent feedings and diaper changes throughout the night. This can be very tiring for new parents, but there are a few things that can help them get through it:\\n\\nTaking turns: If both parents are present, it can be helpful for them to take turns caring for the baby at night so that one person can get some rest while the other one takes care of the baby.\\n\\nAsking for help: It's okay to ask for help from friends, family, or even hiring a babysitter to give the parents a break.\\n\\nNapping during the day: While a 30-minute nap may not be enough to fully catch up on sleep, taking a short nap during the day can help new parents feel more rested and better able to handle the demands of caring for a newborn.\\n\\nStaying healthy: Eating well, exercising, and getting some fresh air can help new parents feel more energetic and better able to cope with sleep deprivation.\\n\\nSeeking support: It can be helpful for new parents to talk to each other, a therapist, or other parents who have gone through the same experience. This can help them feel less alone and more able to cope with the challenges of caring for a newborn."]

id: How does Shazam actually work ? I gained a decent understanding from this article : URL_0 But i 'm still not sure how it chooses where to begin in its search considering the vast size of their database . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Shazam is an app that helps you identify songs by their audio. When you use Shazam, you hold your phone close to the music source and the app "listens" to the song for a few seconds. Shazam then compares the audio it heard to its database of songs, which is very large and contains information about many different songs. To choose where to begin its search, Shazam uses something called a "fingerprint" of the song. A fingerprint is like a set of instructions that tells Shazam what to look for in the database. It\'s a bit like a recipe that tells you how to make a cake. The recipe tells you what ingredients you need and what steps to follow to make the cake. In the same way, the fingerprint tells Shazam what parts of the song to look for and how to match it to a song in the database. Once Shazam has found a match, it shows you the name of the song and the artist. If the song is available on a streaming service like Spotify or Apple Music, you can tap a button to start listening to it right away. I hope that helps! Do you have any other questions about Shazam?']

id: How do you " hear yourself " mentally ? When you 're thinking , singing , talking in your mind what actually is happening to make this work ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['When you "hear yourself" mentally, it is because your brain is processing information and creating a mental representation of sound. This mental representation is not an actual sound that you can hear with your ears, but it feels like you are hearing it in your head.Here\'s how it works: when you think, sing, or talk to yourself in your mind, your brain is recalling memories of sounds that you have heard before and using those memories to recreate the sounds internally. For example, if you think of a song in your head, your brain will retrieve the memories of the sounds of the lyrics and the melody and play them back to you in your mind.It\'s a bit like when you close your eyes and imagine a picture in your head - your brain is creating a mental image for you to see, even though there is no actual image in front of your eyes. id: How do schools justify limiting free speech ? I know there have been tons of supreme court cases with students suing their schools because they violate free speech , but the schools always win . How do they keep winning ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['There are several reasons why schools may limit free speech, and these limits are generally considered to be acceptable under the law. First, it\'s important to understand that the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution protects the right to free speech, but this protection is not absolute. The Supreme Court has recognized that there are certain circumstances where the government (including schools, which are a part of the government) can regulate or limit speech without violating the First Amendment. One of these circumstances is when the speech in question causes a "substantial disruption" to the operation of the school. For example, if a student makes a speech during class that is so disruptive that it interferes with other students\' ability to learn, the school may be justified in limiting that speech. Another reason why schools may limit free speech is to ensure that all students have an equal opportunity to learn. For example, if a student is making racist or sexist comments that are disrupting the classroom environment and making it difficult for other students to focus, the school may be justified in limiting that speech. Finally, schools also have a responsibility to maintain a safe and orderly environment. If a student\'s speech is threatening or violent, the school may be justified in limiting that speech in order to protect the safety of other students. So, to summarize, schools can limit free speech if the speech causes a substantial disruption to the operation of the school, if it interferes with other students\' ability to learn, or if it threatens the safety of the school community.']

id: How does $ 200 worth of virtual currency turn into $ 2.4 million in 4 years ? URL_0 This redditor explained that he bought $ 200 worth of bitcoins and in 4 years it turned into $ 2.4 million . How does that happen ? Please explain like I'm five.
text:
["Sure! Let's pretend that you have a cookie jar that represents your virtual currency, and each cookie in the jar represents one unit of your virtual currency. When you bought $200 worth of virtual currency, you were essentially buying a certain number of cookies from someone else. 
Now, imagine that the value of each cookie can change over time, just like the value of a real-world currency like the US dollar can change. If the value of each cookie goes up, then the total value of all the cookies in your jar will also go up. 
For example, let's say that when you bought your cookies, each one was worth $1. But over the next four years, the value of each cookie goes up to $10. If you have 200 cookies in your jar, then the total value of your cookies would be 200 cookies * $10 per cookie = $2,000. 
Now, let's say that the value of each cookie goes up even more, to $12. If you have 200 cookies in your jar, then the total value of your cookies would be 200 cookies * $12 per cookie = $2,400. 
So, if the value of each unit of your virtual currency goes up over time, then the total value of your virtual currency can also go up. That's how $200 worth of virtual currency can turn into $2.4 million in four years."]

id: How do lesbians have safe sex ? Sex ed taught us what we need to do to prevent STD but they seem to only be applicable to heterosexual and gay partners . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Lesbians can have safe sex by using condoms, dental dams, and other barriers to prevent the exchange of bodily fluids that can transmit sexually transmitted infections (STIs) during sexual activity. It's important for all people who are sexually active to practice safe sex, regardless of their sexual orientation or the gender of their partner. Here are some tips for practicing safe sex as a lesbian: 1. Use condoms: Condoms can be used on sex toys or fingers to reduce the risk of STI transmission. They can also be used during oral sex to protect against STIs that are transmitted through saliva, such as gonorrhea and HIV. 2. Use dental dams: Dental dams are thin, square pieces of latex or polyurethane that can be placed over the vulva or anus during oral sex to prevent the exchange of bodily fluids. 3. Avoid sharing sex toys: If you do share sex toys, make sure to clean them thoroughly before and after use. You can also use a condom on the toy to reduce the risk of STI transmission. 4. Get tested regularly: It's important to get tested for STIs regularly, even if you're not experiencing any symptoms. This will help you and your partner(s) stay healthy and take steps to protect yourselves and each other. Remember, safe sex is about more than just preventing pregnancy. It's also about protecting yourself and your partner from STIs. By using barriers and getting tested regularly, you can help reduce the risk of transmission and enjoy a healthy and enjoyable sexual experience."]

id: How do soldiers who do n't participate in combat get PTSD ? I 've read about soldiers in non - combat roles or who are just lucky enough to avoid combat during their tour get PTSD . How does this happen ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["PTSD, or post-traumatic stress disorder, is a mental health condition that can develop after a person experiences or witnesses a traumatic event. This can include a wide range of events, such as combat, natural disasters, car accidents, sexual assault, or other violent incidents. \nSoldiers who do not participate in combat can still be exposed to traumatic events while serving in the military. For example, they might witness other soldiers being injured or killed, or they might be involved in dangerous situations that could threaten their own lives. They might also experience other types of stress, such as being away from home, being in a high-pressure environment, or seeing or hearing about disturbing events. \nAll of these experiences can be traumatic, and they can lead to the development of PTSD in some people. It's important to remember that everyone responds differently to traumatic events, and not everyone who experiences trauma will develop PTSD. However, if someone is experiencing symptoms of PTSD, it's important to seek help from a mental health professional to get the support and treatment they need."]

id: How does GPS work ? How does it know where you are ? Edit : Thanks for the replies now I understand how it works . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["GPS, or Global Positioning System, is a satellite-based navigation system that helps determine the location, speed, and direction of objects on Earth. It works by using a network of satellites orbiting the Earth to send signals to GPS receivers on the ground. These receivers pick up the signals and use them to calculate the receiver's location, speed, and direction. Here's how it works: GPS satellites orbit the Earth and constantly send signals down to the ground. A GPS receiver, like the one in your phone or car, picks up these signals. The receiver uses the signals to determine how far away it is from each satellite. It does this by measuring the time it takes for the signal to reach the receiver. Once the receiver knows how far away it is from at least four satellites, it can use this information to calculate its exact location on Earth. It does this by using a process called trilateration, which is a fancy way of saying that it measures the distance from the receiver to each satellite and uses this information to figure out where the receiver is. The receiver can also use the signals from the satellites to determine its speed and direction. It does this by measuring how fast the signals are changing and using this information to calculate how fast the receiver is moving. So, to sum it up, GPS works by using a network of satellites orbiting the Earth to send signals to GPS receivers on the ground. These receivers pick up the signals and use them to calculate the receiver's location, speed, and direction."]

For example, "Francois" is a French name, so it is pronounced differently in English than it would be in French. Changes in pronunciation over time: The way words are pronounced can change over time, especially if the word is borrowed from another language. For example, the word "colonel" was borrowed from French, and it used to be pronounced with a "k" sound at the beginning, like it is spelled. However, over time, the pronunciation changed to a "k" sound at the beginning. Differences in regional accents: People in different parts of the world or even different parts of a country may pronounce words differently due to their regional accents. For example, someone from the southern United States might pronounce "lieutenant" with a long "i" sound at the beginning, while someone from the northern United States might pronounce it with a short "i" sound. Unusual spelling: Some words are spelled in a way that doesn\'t follow the usual rules for pronunciation in English. For example, the word "envelope" is spelled with an "en" at the beginning, which usually indicates that the word should be pronounced with an "en" sound. However, the word "envelope" is actually pronounced with an "on" sound at the beginning. I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any more questions.']

id: How do Women 's menstrual cycles synchronise ? Is it actually proven to happen ? And what is actually physically happening for the synchronisation to occur ? There are other posts on the subject but no one explains how or shows any real proof . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['It is not uncommon for women who live or work closely together to report that their menstrual cycles become synchronized, meaning that their periods start around the same time. This is known as the "McClintock effect," after Martha McClintock, who first published research on this phenomenon in 1971. However, it is still not fully understood how or why this occurs. One theory is that pheromones, which are chemical signals produced by the body, may play a role in synchronizing menstrual cycles. Pheromones can be detected by the sense of smell and may affect the behavior or physiology of other people. For example, the smell of a woman\'s pheromones may affect the menstrual cycles of other women who are exposed to them. However, more research is needed to confirm this theory. It\'s important to note that not all women\'s menstrual cycles will become synchronized, and it\'s not uncommon for cycles to vary in length from one woman to another. Also, it\'s not necessary for menstrual cycles to be synchronized in order for women to live and work together effectively.']

id: How do people manage to " not let their emotions get to them " ? What does it mean ? Because it 's not as if there is an off / on switch for emotions ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
["Emotions are a natural and normal part of being human. It's okay to have emotions and it's okay to show them. However, sometimes our emotions can get the better of us and make us act in ways that we don't want to or that might not be helpful.

One way to manage your emotions is to recognize when you are feeling a strong emotion. This can help you take a step back and think about how you want to react. You might take some deep breaths, count to ten, or remind yourself that it's okay to feel this way.

Another way to manage your emotions is to find healthy ways to express them. You might talk to a trusted friend or family member, write in a journal, or do something physical like going for a walk or hitting a punching bag.

It's also helpful to practice self-care, which means taking care of your physical and emotional needs. This might include getting enough sleep, eating well, exercising, and finding activities that bring you joy.

Remember, it's okay to feel emotions, but it's important to find ways to manage them so that they don't get in the way of your daily life."]

id: How does a pitcher plant remove the contents it can not digest ? Say I had a pitcher plant , and I dropped a small marble inside the plant . Would it die or would it have a way to remove it ? Explain like I'm five.

These plants have special enzymes in their pitchers that help to break down and digest the insects and other small animals that they trap. However, if a non-living object like a small marble were to fall into a pitcher plant, the plant would not be able to digest it. Instead, the plant would simply keep the object in its pitcher until it decays or is otherwise removed.\\n\\nTo remove the object, the plant would have to rely on natural processes such as wind, rain, or the movement of animals to help knock the object out of the pitcher. Alternatively, a person could manually remove the object from the pitcher if they wanted to.\\n\\nOverall, a small marble would not harm a pitcher plant, but it also would not be able to be digested by the plant.']

id: How does Shazam work ? I know it listens to the music , but how can it tell the song by any part of the song with ( i 'm pretty sure ) no human interaction ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Shazam is a music recognition app that uses your phone's microphone to listen to a song that is playing and then tries to identify the song by matching the audio to a database of songs. When you open the Shazam app and tap the "Listen" button, it starts listening to the music around you. As the app listens, it breaks the audio down into tiny pieces called "features," which are like small pieces of the puzzle that make up the song.

These features are then compared to a database of songs to see if there is a match. The database contains information about lots of different songs, including the length of the song, the artist, the lyrics, and most importantly, the audio itself. When Shazam finds a match, it displays the song's title and artist on your phone's screen.

Shazam can identify a song by any part of the song because it has a large database of songs and it can match the features it extracts from the audio to the features of a particular song in the database. This is why it is able to identify a song even if you only sing a few words or play a short clip of the song.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.']

id: How do you make a pipe ( for instance copper pipe , used in domestic plumbing ) , from a solid piece of metal ? Fairly straightforward but somehow baffling - to me at least ... Explain like I'm five.
text:
['To make a copper pipe from a solid piece of metal, you can follow these steps:

First, you will need a large piece of copper metal. This can be in the form of a block, a sheet, or a rod.

Next, you will need a machine called a "pipe bender" to shape the copper into a pipe. The pipe bender has a long handle and a die (a shape that the metal fits into).

To start bending the copper, you will need to heat it up using a torch. Copper becomes softer and easier to bend when it is hot.

Once the copper is hot enough, you can place it into the die of the pipe bender. You will need to use the handle of the pipe bender to apply pressure and bend the copper into the desired shape.

As you bend the copper, it will start to take on the shape of a pipe. You can continue bending it until it is the size and shape that you want.

When you are finished bending the copper, you can let it cool down. As it cools, it will become hard and strong again.

Finally, you can cut the copper pipe to the desired length using a pipe cutter. The pipe cutter has a blade that you can rotate around the pipe to cut it to the right size.

I hope that helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.']

id: How do oil rigs work ? Especially the ones you see in empty fields , moving up and down Explain like I'm five.
text: ['\\nOil rigs are used to drill for oil and natural gas, which are substances that can be used to heat homes and power cars and other machines. There are different types of oil rigs, but the ones you see in empty fields are usually called "land rigs." These rigs have a tall metal structure that sits on the ground, with a big drill bit at the bottom that can dig deep into the earth.\\n\\nTo start drilling, workers first have to find a place where they think there might be oil or natural gas. They use special tools and equipment to test the ground and see if there are any deposits of these substances. If they think there is oil or natural gas in a certain area, they will set up a land rig on that spot.\\n\\nThe land rig has a long pipe called a "drill string" that is attached to the drill bit at the bottom. The drill string is made up of many smaller pipes that fit inside each other. To start drilling, the workers use a big engine to turn the drill bit at the bottom of the drill string. The drill bit is made of very hard material, like diamonds or tungsten, and it can cut through the rock and soil as it turns.\\n\\nAs the drill bit digs deeper into the ground, the workers use the engine to raise and lower the rig. This helps them control how deep they are drilling, and it also helps them bring the drill bit back up to the surface when they need to change it or fix it.\\n\\nOnce the drill bit has dug deep enough, the workers will start pumping a special mixture of water, sand, and chemicals down the drill string. This mixture is called "drilling mud," and it helps to cool the drill bit and keep it clean. It also helps to keep the walls of the hole from collapsing.\\n\\nIf the workers find oil or natural gas while they are drilling, they will use a special pipe called a "casing" to line the walls of the hole. This helps to keep the oil or natural gas from leaking out of the ground. Once the casing is in place, the workers will install a pump at the bottom of the hole to bring the oil or natural gas up to the surface.\\n\\nI hope that helps to explain how oil rigs work! Let me know if you have any more questions.']

id: How do power plants know how much electricity to generate ? Are power plants constantly overproducing electricity to be safe ? What happens to the excess energy ? What happens if there is n't enough energy to supply the grid ? Explain like I'm five.

id: How do sim cards work and why do we need them ? Of course I know WHY we need them , but I 'm wondering why it 's not possible to somehow link a contract to a phone without an exernal card Please explain like I'm five.
