id: How do dividend reinvestment purchases work?
text: ["Dividend reinvestment is a way for investors to automatically use their dividends to purchase additional shares of the same stock, rather than receiving the dividends as cash. When a company declares a dividend, investors who have chosen dividend reinvestment will see their dividends used to buy additional shares of the stock, rather than being paid out in cash. This can be a useful way for investors to gradually accumulate more shares of a particular stock, without having to make additional cash purchases.Here's how dividend reinvestment works:An investor owns shares of a company that declares a dividend.The investor has chosen to participate in the company's dividend reinvestment plan (DRIP).When the dividend is paid out, the investor's account will be credited with the value of the dividend in cash.Instead of receiving the cash, the investor's account will be used to purchase additional shares of the same stock at the current market price.The investor's account will be updated to reflect the additional shares purchased, and the investor will now own more shares of the stock.It's important to note that dividend reinvestment plans may come with fees and restrictions, so it's a good idea to carefully review the terms and conditions before signing up for a DRIP. Some companies may also offer partial dividend reinvestment, where investors can choose to receive a portion of their dividends in cash and use the remainder to purchase additional shares.", "Dividend reinvestment is a way for investors to automatically use their dividends to purchase additional shares of the company's stock, rather than receiving the dividends in cash. This can be a convenient way for investors to steadily build their ownership stake in a company without having to constantly make additional purchases on their own.Here's how dividend reinvestment typically works:The company declares a dividend and specifies the amount and the date it will be paid.On the dividend payment date, the company distributes the dividends to its shareholders. If you have elected to participate in the company's dividend reinvestment plan, the dividends will be automatically used to purchase additional shares of the company's stock, rather than being paid to you in cash.The additional shares are added to your account and appear on your statement. The price at which the additional shares are purchased is typically based on the market price of the stock at the time of the dividend payment.It's important to note that dividend reinvestment plans may have fees associated with them, so it's a good idea to carefully review the terms of the plan before electing to participate. In addition, reinvesting dividends may not always be the best strategy for every investor, as it may not be tax-efficient in all cases. It's a good idea to consult with a financial professional before making any decisions about how to handle your dividends."]

id: How do auto-loan payments factor into taxes for cars that are solely used by dependent(s)?
text: ["If you are paying off an auto loan for a car that is used solely by your dependent(s), the payments you make on the loan will not be tax deductible. Only business-related vehicle expenses, such as those incurred by self-employed individuals or employees who use their personal vehicles for work, may be deductible on your tax return.However, if you are providing financial support to your dependent(s) and you are claiming them as dependents on your tax return, you may be able to claim a dependency exemption for them. This exemption reduces your taxable income by a certain amount, which can lower your tax bill. To claim a dependency exemption, you must meet certain criteria, such as providing more than half of the dependent's support and being eligible to claim the dependent on your tax return.It's important to note that the rules for claiming dependency exemptions and deducting business-related vehicle expenses can be complex, and you should consult a tax professional or refer to IRS guidelines for more information."]

id: How do planets stay in orbit ? If they are attracted to a star , should n't they just zoom towards it ? Edit : ALREADY EXPLAINED , KTHANXBAI . Explain like I'm five.
text:
["Sure! Imagine you are playing with a soccer ball. If you throw the ball straight up in the air, it will eventually come back down to the ground because of the force of gravity. But if you throw the ball hard enough, it will keep going and going until it eventually comes back down to the ground. The same thing happens with planets and stars.

Planets stay in orbit around a star because they are constantly falling towards the star, but they never actually reach it. This is because they are moving so fast that they are constantly missing the star. The force of gravity is what keeps pulling them towards the star, but the speed at which they are moving is what keeps them from crashing into the star.

It's kind of like when you are on a swing and you start swinging really high. You feel like you are going to fly off the swing, but you never do. That's because you are constantly falling towards the ground, but your speed and the shape of the swing keep you from hitting the ground.

So to answer your question, planets stay in orbit around a star because they are constantly falling towards the star, but they are moving so fast that they never actually reach it."]

id: How does a Turing machine work and what does it do All I know is it 's in a CPU and it manipulates binary data Explain like I'm five.
text:
['A Turing machine is a theoretical computer that is used to understand how computers can be built and how they work. It is named after Alan Turing, a famous computer scientist who helped to develop the concept of the Turing machine.

A Turing machine has a few different parts:

An input tape: This is where the data that the Turing machine will be working on is stored. It is divided into a series of small squares, called "cells," and each cell can contain a "1" or a "0" (which are called "binary digits," or "bits" for short).

A read-write head: This is a little device that sits above the input tape and can move from one cell to another. It is used to read the data from the cells on the tape and to write new data onto the tape.

A set of rules: These are the instructions that tell the Turing machine what to do with the data on the tape. For example, the rules might tell the machine to move the read-write head one cell to the right if it reads a "0," or to move it one cell to the left if it reads a "1." The rules also tell the machine what to do when it reaches the end of the tape.

A state register: This is a little memory inside the Turing machine that can store a number. The state register is used to keep track of where the Turing machine is in its process of working on the data.

To use a Turing machine, you would start by putting some data on the input tape. Then you would turn on the machine and it would start reading the data, following the rules to manipulate the data and move the read-write head. The Turing machine would keep working until it reaches the end of the tape or until it is told to stop.

Turing machines are not used to build real computers, but they are a useful way to understand how computers work. They help us to understand how data can be stored and manipulated, and how a computer can be programmed to solve problems.']

id: How does a gravity boost work ? I have heard that many missions which take satellites beyond earth have used a gravity boost from Jupiter to speed up . But how would that work ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['A gravity boost is a way to use the gravity of a planet to change the speed and direction of a spacecraft. Imagine you are on a playground swing and someone gives you a push to make you go higher. The same thing can happen with a spacecraft and a planet.\\n\\nWhen a spacecraft is close to a planet, the planet\'s gravity pulls on the spacecraft and makes it want to fall towards the planet. If the spacecraft is going fast enough, it will fall into orbit around the planet instead of crashing into it.\\n\\nBut if the spacecraft is going just the right speed and at just the right angle, it can use the planet\'s gravity to "slingshot" around the planet and change its speed and direction. This is called a gravity assist, or sometimes a gravity boost.\\n\\nFor example, if a spacecraft is heading towards Jupiter and wants to go faster, it can fly close to Jupiter and use the planet\'s gravity to give it a boost. As the spacecraft approaches Jupiter, the planet\'s gravity will pull on it and make it speed up. Then, as the spacecraft swings around the back side of the planet, it will be moving much faster than it was before.\\n\\nUsing gravity assists, spacecraft can travel to other parts of the solar system much faster and cheaper than they could by using their own engines alone.']

id: How do bookies make money from taking bets ? Maybe I 'm just an idiot , but none of my friends knew why either . Edit : Thanks , that cleared it up ! Good luck in March Madness . Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Bookies make money by charging a small fee (called a "vigorish" or "juice") on bets. Let's say you bet $100 on a game and the bookie charges a 10% vigorish. If you win, the bookie will pay you $110 ($100 bet + $10 vigorish). If you lose, the bookie keeps your $100 bet. This way, the bookie makes a profit no matter what the outcome of the game is.

Now, let's say you and your friends all bet on different games and some of you win and some of you lose. The bookie will make money from the people who lost their bets, but will also have to pay out the people who won their bets. As long as the bookie charges a high enough vigorish, they will make a profit overall.

It's a bit like a casino, where the house (in this case, the bookie) always has an advantage and makes a profit in the long run. Hope that helps!']

id: How does a home scale tell you your body fat % , body composition , etc . Really curious how just standing on the scale can tell you those things and how accurate they really are . Explain like I'm five.
text: ["\\nSome home scales use a technology called bioelectrical impedance analysis (BIA) to estimate body composition, including body fat percentage and muscle mass. When you stand on the scale, a small electrical current passes through your body. This current flows more easily through water and electrolytes (which are found in high concentrations in muscle tissue) than it does through fat tissue.\\n\\nBy measuring how quickly the current flows through your body, the scale can estimate how much muscle and fat you have. The scale then uses this information to calculate your body fat percentage and other body composition measurements.\\n\\nIt's important to note that these estimates are not always completely accurate, and they can be affected by factors such as hydration level and the time of day. In general, BIA is considered to be a relatively reliable method for measuring body composition, but it may not be as accurate as more specialized techniques like dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA) or hydrostatic weighing.\\n"]

id: How does a " one - way " encryption become one way ? I know that encryption such as MD5 / MD6 are supposed to be irreversible , but since they are calculated by some equations , why ca n't they be reversed ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Encryption is a way of encoding information so that it can't be read by people who don't have the right key to unlock it. A one-way encryption is designed to be irreversible, which means that once the information has been encrypted, it can't be turned back into its original form. The reason that one-way encryption is irreversible is because of the way it works. When you encrypt something, you use a special algorithm (a set of steps) and a key to turn the information into a scrambled, unreadable form. The key is like a secret code that only someone with the right password can use to unlock the information. One-way encryption algorithms are designed to be very complex and hard to reverse. This means that even if someone knows how the algorithm works, it would be very difficult for them to figure out how to turn the encrypted information back into its original form. This makes it much harder for someone to steal or misuse the information. So, to sum it up, one-way encryption is irreversible because it uses complex algorithms and keys to turn information into a scrambled, unreadable form that can't easily be turned back into its original form."]

id: How do trees create oxygen when they 've lost all their leaves in winter ? How do they do it ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Trees create oxygen through a process called photosynthesis, which occurs in their leaves. During photosynthesis, trees take in carbon dioxide from the air and use energy from sunlight to convert it into glucose (a type of sugar). Oxygen is a byproduct of this process, and it is released into the air as a waste product.In the winter, when trees have lost their leaves, they are not able to photosynthesize and produce oxygen in the same way as they do during the growing season. However, trees are still able to produce a small amount of oxygen through a process called respiration, which occurs in all living cells. During respiration, trees and other plants take in oxygen and release carbon dioxide, just like animals do.So even though trees don't produce as much oxygen in the winter as they do during the growing season, they are still able to produce some oxygen through respiration. This is one of the reasons why it's important to plant trees and other plants in our communities â they help to clean the air and produce oxygen for us to breathe."]

id: How do fridges work ? How can energy be used to make something colder than it 's surroundings ? It 's been bothering me for a solid five minutes . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Fridges work by using a cooling system to make the inside of the fridge colder than the outside air. Inside the fridge, there is a gas called a refrigerant that flows through a system of tubes. When the refrigerant is pumped through the tubes, it absorbs heat from the air inside the fridge. This process cools down the air inside the fridge. The refrigerant then travels to a compressor, which is a kind of pump. The compressor squeezes the refrigerant, which makes it hot. The hot refrigerant is then sent to a set of coils on the back of the fridge. These coils are called the condenser coils. When the hot refrigerant passes through the condenser coils, it releases the heat it absorbed from inside the fridge into the air outside the fridge. This process cools down the refrigerant, so it can be pumped back into the fridge to absorb more heat and keep the inside of the fridge cold. So, in short, the fridge uses energy (usually from electricity) to run the compressor and pump the refrigerant through the cooling system. This helps to remove heat from the inside of the fridge and keep it cold.']

id: How does / do welfare , unemployment and social services negatively effect the US economy ? And ... How does / do welfare , unemployment and social services positively effect the US economy ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Welfare, unemployment, and social services can have both positive and negative effects on the economy.

Positive effects:

Welfare, unemployment, and social services help to reduce poverty by providing financial assistance to people who are struggling to make ends meet. This can help to stimulate the economy by increasing consumer spending and supporting local businesses.

These programs also provide a safety net for people who are experiencing a temporary hardship, such as a job loss or medical emergency. This can help to prevent people from falling into extreme poverty, which can have long-term negative consequences for both individuals and the economy as a whole.

Social services, such as education and healthcare, can also improve the overall well-being of the population, which can lead to increased productivity and economic growth.

Negative effects:

One potential negative effect of welfare, unemployment, and social services is that they can create a disincentive for people to work. Some people may choose to rely on these programs instead of seeking employment, which can reduce the overall labor force and economic productivity.

These programs can also be expensive to maintain, especially if the number of people receiving assistance increases significantly. This can put a strain on government budgets and lead to higher taxes or deficits.

There is also the risk that some people may abuse the system, either by fraudulently obtaining benefits or by taking advantage of the assistance provided. This can be a drain on resources and can undermine the effectiveness of the programs.']

id: How do small towns in the US sustain themselves ? It seems like their net imports ( food , gas , tech , etc . ) would greatly outweigh their exports . How does a small town economy function ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
["Small towns in the US often rely on a mix of local businesses, tourism, and agricultural production to sustain themselves.

Local businesses, such as restaurants, grocery stores, and shops, provide goods and services to the people who live in the town. These businesses may also sell their products or services to people who live in nearby towns or cities.

Tourism can also be an important source of income for small towns. Many small towns have natural beauty, historical sites, or other attractions that draw visitors. These visitors often spend money on food, lodging, and other local goods and services, which helps to support the town's economy.

Agricultural production, such as farming or ranching, can also be an important part of the economy in small towns. These activities can provide food for the local community and also generate income through the sale of crops or livestock.

Overall, small towns rely on a combination of local businesses, tourism, and agriculture to sustain themselves. These activities provide jobs and income for the people who live in the town and also help to support the local economy."]

id: How does a radio frequency become " secure " ? Or a telephone line for that matter . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Radio frequencies and telephone lines can be made secure by using encryption. Encryption is a way of scrambling the data that is transmitted over the radio frequency or telephone line so that it can\'t be understood by anyone who might intercept it. To make the data secure, a special "key" is used to encrypt the data before it is transmitted. The key is a secret code that is known only to the sender and the receiver of the data. When the data is received, it is decrypted using the key to turn it back into its original, unencrypted form. There are many different types of encryption that can be used, and they can be very complex. But the basic idea is that the data is transformed into a secret code that can only be understood by someone who has the key to unlock it. This helps to keep the data private and secure, even if it is transmitted over a radio frequency or telephone line that is not completely secure.']

id: How do we find the valuation of a company ? Does it have anything to with EPS , NPV or IRR ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["There are many ways to determine the value of a company, and different methods can produce different results. Some common methods include using earnings per share (EPS), net present value (NPV), and internal rate of return (IRR).\\n\\nEPS is a measure of a company's profitability. It tells you how much money the company makes per share of its stock. You can use EPS to compare the profitability of different companies or to see how well a company is doing over time.\\n\\nNPV is a way to determine the value of an investment. It takes into account the expected future cash flows from the investment and the time value of money. The time value of money means that a dollar today is worth more than a dollar in the future because you can use the dollar today to make more money.\\n\\nIRR is a measure of the profitability of an investment. It tells you the percentage return you can expect to receive on an investment based on the expected cash flows.\\n\\nTo find the valuation of a company, you can use any of these methods or a combination of them. It's important to consider the strengths and limitations of each method and to use the one that makes the most sense for the specific company you're evaluating."]

id: How do teeth turn yellow ? Is it possible to simply brush your teeth for an hour to turn then ( very ) white ? Damn auto - correct , ( obviously ) then = them Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Teeth can turn yellow for a variety of reasons. One common cause is the accumulation of plaque and tartar on the surface of the teeth. Plaque is a sticky film of bacteria that forms on the teeth, and if it is not removed through brushing and flossing, it can harden into tartar. Tartar is difficult to remove and can cause the teeth to become yellow. Other reasons for yellow teeth include:

Drinking beverages that can stain teeth, such as coffee, tea, and red wine
Using tobacco products, which can stain the teeth
Aging, which can cause the enamel on the teeth to thin and the dentin (the layer underneath the enamel) to become more visible
Taking certain medications that can cause the teeth to become discolored
No, it is not possible to simply brush your teeth for an hour to turn them very white. While brushing and flossing can help to remove plaque and prevent the buildup of tartar, it is not a substitute for professional teeth whitening. Professional teeth whitening is a process that uses special products and procedures to remove stains and discoloration from the teeth, making them brighter and whiter. This can be done at a dental office or at home using a whitening kit. If you are interested in whitening your teeth, it is best to talk to a dental professional to determine the best course of action for your specific needs.']

The technical term for this is "stress-induced cardiomyopathy," also known as "broken heart syndrome."\\n\\nIn broken heart syndrome, the heart becomes weak and doesn\'t pump blood as well as it should. This can cause symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, and fainting. In some cases, broken heart syndrome can be serious and even lead to death.\\n\\nIt\'s important to note that while emotional stress can contribute to broken heart syndrome, it is not the only cause. Other factors, such as physical stress (such as a surgery or severe illness) and certain medications, can also increase the risk of developing the condition.\\n\\nSo to sum it up, broken heart syndrome is a medical condition that can be caused by emotional or physical stress. id: How do vaccines work ? How are they made , and how do they work in our bodies ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Sure! Vaccines are special medicines that help our bodies protect us from diseases. When we get a disease, it's because a germ (like a virus or bacteria) has entered our bodies and is making us sick. Our bodies have a special system called the immune system that helps fight off germs and keep us healthy. To make a vaccine, scientists first find a germ that causes a certain disease. Then they make a special version of that germ that is either very weak or has been killed entirely. This special version of the germ is what goes into the vaccine. When we get a vaccine, our bodies think that the special germ in the vaccine is the real thing, so our immune system starts to fight it off. While it's fighting off the fake germ, our immune system also learns how to fight off the real germ. That way, if we ever come into contact with the real germ, our immune system will be ready to fight it off and we won't get sick. So, vaccines help our bodies learn how to protect us from diseases by giving our immune system a chance to practice fighting off germs. They can help keep us healthy and prevent us from getting sick."]

id: How does a preferred share âAnnual Concurrent Retraction Privilegeâ work?
text: ["Preferred shares are a type of ownership interest in a corporation that have certain privileges over common shares. One of these privileges is the annual concurrent retraction privilege, which allows the holder of the preferred shares to sell their shares back to the company on an annual basis.Here's how it works:The holder of the preferred shares must exercise their annual concurrent retraction privilege by giving written notice to the company during a specified time period, usually within a few months of the anniversary of the issue date of the shares.The company must then purchase the shares from the holder at the price specified in the terms of the preferred shares. This price is usually equal to the original issue price of the shares, plus any dividends that have accrued but have not been paid.The company has the right to pay for the purchased shares in cash or by issuing new preferred shares to the holder.Once the holder has exercised their annual concurrent retraction privilege, they are no longer entitled to do so again until the next annual period.I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions."]

id: How do all the clocks in the world stay synchronized ? With different time zones and so many clocks , how do we keep our time straight ? Also what kind of accuracy should I expect from a regular clock ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
["Great question! Clocks in different time zones stay synchronized by using something called Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). This is a time standard that is used all around the world and it is based on the Earth's rotation.

When it is noon in UTC, it is also noon in all of the other time zones around the world. However, since the Earth is round, different parts of the Earth are facing the Sun at different times. That's why we have different time zones. For example, when it is noon in UTC, it might be 7:00 AM in New York (which is in the Eastern Time Zone) because the Sun is just starting to rise there.

To keep all of the clocks in the world synchronized, we use something called a time signal. This is a special radio signal that is sent out from a very accurate clock, called a time standard. The time standard is a very accurate clock that is kept in a special place where the temperature and other conditions are kept very stable. This helps the clock stay accurate.

Most regular clocks, like the one on your phone or the one on your wall, are accurate to within a few seconds. Some clocks are even more accurate and can keep time to within a fraction of a second. However, no clock is perfect and they all lose or gain a little bit of time over time. That's why it's important to set your clock once in a while to make sure it is showing the correct time."]

id: How do scientists develop complex equations ? How do scientists develop complex equations for things like gravity , etc ? I âve never understood how you can take an observation / theory and make it into some sort of equation . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Developing complex equations is a process that involves several steps.\\n\\nFirst, scientists make observations about the natural world. These observations might be made through experiments, or by simply observing the world around us. For example, scientists observed that objects fall towards the ground when dropped, and that the speed at which they fall increases as they get closer to the ground.\\n\\nNext, scientists try to come up with a theory to explain the observations they have made. A theory is a set of ideas that helps to explain how something works or why it happens. For example, scientists might develop a theory that explains why objects fall towards the ground when they are dropped.\\n\\nOnce a theory has been developed, scientists can use it to make predictions about how things will behave in the future. For example, a theory of gravity might be used to predict the path of a satellite orbiting the Earth.\\n\\nFinally, scientists can use mathematics to turn their theories into equations. Equations are a way of expressing a relationship between different quantities using numbers and symbols. For example, the theory of gravity can be expressed as an equation called the "gravitational force equation," which describes how the gravitational force between two objects depends on their mass and the distance between them.\\n\\nDeveloping complex equations is a challenging process that often involves many different scientists working together and using a variety of different tools and techniques. However, by using careful observations, creative thinking, and careful use of math, scientists are able to develop equations that help us to understand and explain the world around us.']

id: How does a public company turn shares into cash?

The company will receive cash in exchange for the shares.Buyback the shares: A company can also buy back its own shares from investors on the open market. This is known as a "share buyback." The company will pay cash for the shares it buys back, which can then be retired or held as treasury stock.Issue dividends: Another way for a company to turn its shares into cash is by issuing dividends. Dividends are payments made by the company to shareholders, typically in the form of cash or additional shares.Raise capital through new equity: Finally, a company can raise capital by issuing new shares of stock and selling them to investors. This can be done through a public offering or a private placement. The company will receive cash in exchange for the new shares it issues.']

id: How do optical computer mice work ? Is it actually " watching " bumps in the surface of the mousepad move across the field of view ? How can it be reliable across different types of surfaces without some sort of calibration ? Please explain like I'm five.

As you move the mouse, the camera takes pictures of the surface and sends them to the computer. The computer looks at these pictures and compares them to the previous ones to figure out how far the mouse has moved. This is how the mouse knows where to move the cursor on the screen. Optical mice do not rely on bumps or grooves in the surface to work. They can work on most surfaces as long as there is enough contrast for the camera to see. This means that they can work on a smooth mousepad, a desk, or even a piece of paper. Optical mice do not need to be calibrated because they use the camera to see the surface they are being used on. This allows them to work on a variety of different surfaces without any special adjustments.']

id: How do developers make " better " compression algorithms ? What do we know or do now that we did n't when we first started file compression ? What makes new image and video codecs better than their predecessors ? Please explain like I'm five.
text:
['Developers make "better" compression algorithms by finding ways to compress data more efficiently. This means that they are able to reduce the size of the data while still maintaining the same quality. There are a few different ways that they can do this. 
One way is by finding more efficient ways to represent the data. For example, instead of representing each pixel in an image as a separate piece of information, they might use patterns or colors to represent groups of pixels. This can help to reduce the amount of data that needs to be stored. 
Another way is by finding more efficient ways to compress the data. This might involve using algorithms that are more efficient at finding patterns in the data, or using techniques like predictive coding to better estimate what data is most important to keep. 
Finally, developers can also make new codecs (compression algorithms for audio and video) better by improving the way that they handle different types of data. For example, they might create codecs that are better at compressing video with a lot of fast-moving action, or codecs that are better at compressing audio with a wide range of frequencies. 
Overall, the goal of compression algorithms is to reduce the amount of data that needs to be stored or transmitted, while still maintaining the quality of the original data. As technology and our understanding of data compression improve, we are able to create more efficient algorithms that can compress data even more effectively.']

id: How does Closed Captioning work on live TV ? Is someone typing out the words or is it a software that detects speech ? Settling a bet with a friend . Please explain like I'm five.
text:
['Closed captioning is a way to display the spoken words and sound effects in a television program as text on the screen. It is used to help people who are deaf or hard of hearing understand what is being said on the TV. 
There are two main ways that closed captioning can be done for live TV: 
1. Manual closed captioning: This is done by a person who listens to the audio of the TV program and types out the words as they are being spoken. This person is called a stenographer or a captioner. The text is then transmitted along with the TV program and displayed on the screen for viewers to read. 
2. Automatic closed captioning: This is done using speech recognition software. The software listens to the audio of the TV program and tries to transcribe the words into text. The text is then transmitted along with the TV program and displayed on the screen for viewers to read. Automatic closed captioning is not always as accurate as manual closed captioning, but it can be done more quickly and is often used for live events where it is not possible to have a stenographer present. 
Either way, closed captioning is a useful tool for people who are deaf or hard of hearing to understand what is being said on TV. It can also be helpful for people who are learning a new language or for anyone who wants to follow along with a program more closely.']

id: How do we know how ' old ' light is ? How can we know that there is light that is 13 billion + years old ? If we are still receiving it and sensing it , how can we date something that does n't have tangible mass ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Light is a type of electromagnetic radiation, which means it travels through the air as waves of energy. We can't see light itself, but we can see the things that light bounces off of or passes through.Scientists have developed several ways to determine the age of light. One way is by studying the properties of the light itself, such as its wavelength and intensity. For example, light from a star that is very far away will be stretched out and made weaker by the expansion of the universe, so scientists can use this information to estimate how long it took the light to reach us.Another way to determine the age of light is by studying the objects it comes from. For example, scientists can use telescopes to study distant galaxies and estimate their ages based on their size, shape, and other characteristics. They can also use radio telescopes to study the remnants of supernovae, which are giant explosions that occur when massive stars die. By studying these remnants, scientists can estimate how long ago the supernovae occurred, which can help them determine the age of the light that we see from these events.So while light itself doesn't have tangible mass, we can still use what we know about the way it travels and the objects it comes from to learn more about its age and the history of the universe."]

id: How do memory devices erase data ? I could n't fall asleep last night because this was bugging me . How is it removed from the device , and where does it go ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['There are several ways that data can be erased from a memory device.

One way is through a process called "overwriting," where new data is written on top of the old data. This can be done by simply saving new files to the memory device, or by using a special program that writes a series of 1's and 0's over the old data.

Another way to erase data is to use a process called "deletion," where the memory device is instructed to mark the space where the data was stored as available for new data. The data is not actually removed from the device, but it becomes hidden and cannot be accessed without special software.

A third way to erase data is to physically destroy the memory device, such as by smashing a hard drive or breaking a memory card. This is a permanent way to erase data, but it also destroys the memory device itself.

When data is erased from a memory device, it is not actually removed or destroyed. Instead, it is simply made unavailable for use, either by being overwritten with new data or by being marked as deleted. The data still exists on the device, but it is no longer accessible.']

id: How do automatic windshield wipers know when the windshield is wet ? Not to mention how wet it is . Edit : flaired as ' technology ' because there 's no ' black voodoo magic ' option . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Automatic windshield wipers use sensors to detect when the windshield is wet. There are different types of sensors that can be used for this purpose, but one common type is a moisture sensor. This sensor consists of two electrodes that are separated by a small gap. When the windshield is dry, there is very little resistance between the electrodes, but when the windshield is wet, the water acts as a conductor and the resistance between the electrodes decreases. This change in resistance is used to determine when the wipers should be activated.\\n\\nTo determine how wet the windshield is, some wipers use a combination of sensors to measure both the amount of moisture on the windshield and the speed at which the wipers should move. For example, the wipers might move more quickly when the windshield is very wet, and more slowly when it is only slightly damp.\\n\\nOverall, automatic windshield wipers use a combination of sensors and algorithms to determine when and how fast to move, helping to keep the windshield clear and your visibility good while driving.']

id: How do scientists delete or manipulate genes ? So researcher X maps or sequences a genome . Great . How do scientists identify and " knockout " genes for future study ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Scientists use a variety of techniques to delete or manipulate genes in order to study their function. One common technique is called "gene knockdown," which involves using small pieces of RNA to block the expression of a specific gene. Another technique is called "gene knockout," which involves using genetic engineering techniques to permanently delete a gene from an organism's genome.

One way to do this is through a process called CRISPR/Cas9 gene editing. CRISPR stands for "Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats," and Cas9 stands for "CRISPR-associated protein 9." Essentially, CRISPR/Cas9 is a tool that scientists can use to make very precise cuts in DNA at specific locations. By using this tool, scientists can delete, replace, or add new DNA sequences to an organism's genome.

To use CRISPR/Cas9, scientists first need to identify the specific gene they want to manipulate. They can do this by looking at the genome sequence of the organism they are studying and searching for the specific sequence of DNA that corresponds to the gene they are interested in. Once they have identified the gene, they can use CRISPR/Cas9 to make precise cuts in the DNA at the locations where the gene is found. These cuts can then be used to delete or manipulate the gene as desired.

Overall, scientists use a variety of techniques to delete or manipulate genes in order to study their function and understand how they contribute to the development and function of an organism.']

id: How does ATP give our cells energy ? Does that third bond contain a lot of energy ? On a molecular level how does it give us energy , for example in the Na K pump . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['ATP (adenosine triphosphate) is a molecule that stores energy in its bonds. When our cells need energy, they use ATP to power various processes. The energy in ATP comes from the third bond between the second and third phosphate groups. When this bond is broken, energy is released and can be used by the cell. One way that ATP gives energy to our cells is through the sodium-potassium pump. This is a protein that moves sodium ions out of cells and potassium ions into cells. It uses energy from ATP to do this. When the sodium-potassium pump is active, it uses up ATP molecules and releases the energy stored in them to power the movement of the ions. So, to summarize, ATP stores energy in its bonds and releases it when those bonds are broken. This energy can be used by our cells to power various processes, such as the sodium-potassium pump.']

The stage of the illness: The further along an illness is, the more advanced it is and the more difficult it may be to treat. 3. The patient's response to treatment: Some patients may respond well to treatment and live longer than expected, while others may not respond as well and have a shorter prognosis. To determine how long a terminally ill patient has to live, doctors will consider all of these factors and use their medical knowledge and experience to make an educated estimate. It's important to remember that this is just an estimate and that every patient is different, so the actual length of time a patient has left can vary."]

id: How do animals that live underwater heal from cuts ? Does the water prevent their blood from clotting ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Great question! Just like humans, animals that live in the water have blood that is able to clot when they get a cut. Clotting is the process that helps stop bleeding and starts the healing process.However, the water itself does not prevent an animal\'s blood from clotting. Instead, the animal\'s body has special cells called platelets that are responsible for helping the blood to clot. When an animal gets a cut, these platelets will rush to the wound and start to clump together, forming a "plug" that helps stop the bleeding. At the same time, the animal\'s body will also release a protein called fibrin, which helps to strengthen the clot and keep it in place.So, even though animals that live in the water are surrounded by water all the time, their bodies are still able to heal from cuts and wounds just like any other animal.']

id: How do we know what the Earth 's core is made of ? To say that a book from that science guy says so does not qualify . Explain like I'm five.

["There are a few ways that scientists have learned about what the Earth's core is made of. One way is by studying the way that earthquakes travel through the Earth. When an earthquake happens, the energy from the earthquake travels through the Earth in the form of waves. By studying these waves and how they travel through the Earth, scientists can learn about the different layers of the Earth and what they are made of.

Another way that scientists have learned about the Earth's core is by studying the way that the Earth's magnetic field works. The Earth has a magnetic field because it has a core made mostly of iron and nickel. The movement of this molten metal creates an electric current, which in turn creates a magnetic field. By studying the Earth's magnetic field, scientists can learn more about the composition of the Earth's core.

Finally, scientists have also used satellites to study the Earth's gravity field. By measuring the gravitational pull of different parts of the Earth, scientists can learn more about what is underneath the surface and what the core is made of.

Overall, scientists have used a combination of these techniques and others to learn about the composition of the Earth's core. While we don't have a direct sample of the core to study, we have been able to learn a lot about it through these indirect methods."]

id: How do muscles get " stronger " ? I heard daily exercise is bad for the muscles , because they have to get time to " regenerate " . Is that true ? I was wondering how do muscles get stronger ? Explain like I'm five.

["Muscles get stronger when they are asked to work harder than they are used to. This is why it's important to give your muscles time to rest and recover after a workout.

For example, if you always lift the same weight during your workouts, your muscles will get used to that weight and it won't be as difficult for them to lift it. But if you gradually increase the weight, your muscles will have to work harder to lift it, and they will get stronger as a result.

It's also important to eat a healthy diet that includes enough protein, because protein helps your muscles repair and grow.

So to sum up, muscles get stronger when they are asked to do more than they are used to and when they have enough time to rest and repair themselves."]

id: How do ships navigate ? Do they use radio Navaids like aircraft ? Also , is traffic controlled like aircraft , or is it just " see and avoid " ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Ships use a variety of tools to navigate. One of these tools is a device called a GPS, which stands for Global Positioning System. GPS uses satellites orbiting the Earth to determine the ship\'s location. Ships also use other tools such as radar, which is a device that sends out radio waves and can detect other objects, such as other ships, and compasses, which help the ship\'s crew determine which direction they are going. Ships also use radio navigation aids, similar to the ones used by aircraft, to help them navigate. These include devices such as lighthouses, which are tall structures that have a light on top that flashes in a specific pattern to help ships know where they are. Ships can also use radio beacons, which are stations that transmit a radio signal that can be picked up by the ship\'s radio. Traffic is not generally controlled for ships in the same way that it is for aircraft. Instead, ships rely on "see and avoid" methods, where the crew of the ship uses their eyes and other tools, such as radar, to watch for other ships and try to avoid them. Ships also use rules called "colregs," which are a set of guidelines that help ships avoid collisions with each other.']

id: How does a change in market cap affect a company's operational decisions?
text: ["Market capitalization, or market cap, is a measure of the value of a company's outstanding shares of stock. It is calculated by multiplying the company's stock price by the number of shares outstanding. A company's market cap can be affected by a variety of factors, including changes in the company's financial performance, changes in industry conditions, and changes in investor sentiment.A change in a company's market cap can have some impact on its operational decisions, but it is just one factor among many that the company may consider when making business decisions. For example, if a company's market cap increases significantly, it may have more resources available to invest in new projects or expand its operations. On the other hand, if a company's market cap decreases, it may need to be more cautious about spending and may need to focus on cost-cutting measures.However, it's important to note that market cap is just one measure of a company's value, and it does not necessarily reflect the company's underlying financial performance or its ability to generate profits. As such, it is just one factor that a company may consider when making operational decisions, and it is not the only factor."]

id: How do planets get their perfect circular formation ? I understand ( for the most part ) how they are formed . But if the rocks are smashing into each other all the time , how do planets get so perfectly rounded ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Planets are formed from a disk of gas and dust that surrounds a newborn star. As the material in this disk cools, it begins to clump together, forming small particles that eventually grow into larger objects. These objects collide and merge with each other, eventually forming planets.

The reason that planets are round is because they are made up of many small particles that are attracted to each other by gravity. When a planet is forming, the particles are constantly smashing into each other, but they are also being pulled together by the force of gravity. This causes the particles to become more and more compact, eventually forming a sphere.

The force of gravity also helps to smooth out any bumps or unevenness on the surface of the planet, which is why planets are generally very smooth and rounded. In fact, most planets in our solar system are almost perfectly spherical! So, the force of gravity is responsible for the perfect circular formation of planets.']

id: How does a phone touchscreen work through a screen protector but not through a glove ? I do n't get capacitive screens . How is a stylus different to a metal conductor like a key or paper clip ? Is conductive thread the same as copper wire ? Please explain like I'm five.
text:
["A touchscreen works by using an electric current to detect when and where you touch the screen. The screen itself is made of a material that conducts electricity, and your finger is also a conductor of electricity. When you touch the screen with your finger, you interrupt the flow of electricity, and the phone's touchscreen can detect this interruption and figure out where on the screen you touched. 
A screen protector is made of a material that does not conduct electricity, so it does not interrupt the flow of electricity when you touch the screen. This is why you can still use a touchscreen with a screen protector on it. 
Gloves, on the other hand, are made of insulating materials that do not conduct electricity. This means that when you touch the screen with a gloved finger, the flow of electricity is not interrupted, and the touchscreen cannot detect your touch. 
A stylus is a special pen-like tool that you can use to write or draw on a touchscreen. It has a small, conductive tip that can interrupt the flow of electricity when you touch the screen with it. This allows the touchscreen to detect your touch even if you are using a stylus instead of your finger. 
Conductive thread is a special type of thread that is made of a material that conducts electricity. It is often used in clothing or other fabric items to create touch-sensitive surfaces or to connect electronic components to each other. Copper wire is also a conductor of electricity, and it is often used in electronics and electrical systems for this reason."]

id: How do protests have an effect ? i.e. How does a bunch of people standing around for something actually get that thing to happen ? If I was a lawmaker , I would just ignore them . They ca n't stand around forever . Please explain like I'm five.
text:
['Protests can have an effect on lawmakers and decision-makers in a variety of ways. Here are a few possibilities: 
1. Attention: When a large group of people come together to protest, it can draw the attention of the media, lawmakers, and the general public. This attention can help to raise awareness of the issue being protested and put pressure on decision-makers to address it. 
2. Public opinion: Protests can also influence public opinion on an issue. When people see others expressing strong feelings about an issue, it can make them more likely to support the cause as well. This can create a groundswell of public support that lawmakers may feel compelled to respond to. 
3. Voter pressure: If a protest movement is successful in rallying a large number of people to its cause, it can put pressure on lawmakers to address the issue in order to win the support of those voters. 
4. Direct action: In some cases, protests may involve more than just standing around. They may involve sit-ins, strikes, boycotts, or other forms of direct action that disrupt business as usual and make it more difficult for decision-makers to ignore the issue. 
5. Negotiations: Finally, protests can sometimes lead to negotiations between the protesters and decision-makers. This can provide an opportunity for both sides to come to an agreement and find a solution to the issue at hand. 
Overall, the effectiveness of a protest depends on a variety of factors, including the size of the protest, the level of public support for the cause, the strategies used by the protesters, and the willingness of decision-makers to engage with them.']

id: How does a car measure it 's speed to show up in the speedometer ? What happens if the car is replaced with wheels of different diameters ? Does it matter ? Title . Explain like I'm five.
text:
["Cars measure their speed by using a device called a speedometer. The speedometer is typically located on the dashboard of the car and shows the driver how fast the car is going.

To measure the speed of the car, the speedometer uses a small device called a speedometer cable. The speedometer cable is connected to the car's transmission, which is the part of the car that sends power from the engine to the wheels. As the car moves, the transmission turns a small gear called a drive gear, which is connected to the speedometer cable.

The speedometer cable sends the rotational speed of the drive gear to the speedometer, which then converts that information into a speed reading that is displayed on the dashboard.

If you replace the wheels on a car with wheels of different diameters, it can affect the accuracy of the speedometer. This is because the speedometer is calibrated based on the diameter of the original wheels. If you put on wheels with a larger diameter, the speedometer may show that the car is going slower than it actually is. Similarly, if you put on wheels with a smaller diameter, the speedometer may show that the car is going faster than it actually is.

In general, it's important to make sure that your car's wheels are the correct size and that the speedometer is calibrated correctly, so you can accurately gauge how fast you are driving and ensure that you are following the speed limits."]

id: How do muscular knots form and how do we prevent them I had suspected that this may be a blood circulation issue too ? Are knots just lumps of blood ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Muscular knots, also known as muscle spasms or muscle trigger points, are small, tight areas of muscle that can be painful when touched. They often feel like lumps or knots in the muscle.\\n\\nMuscular knots can form for a variety of reasons, including overuse, injury, or tension. For example, if you use a muscle too much or in an awkward position, it can become sore and develop knots. Similarly, if you have an injury or strain a muscle, knots can form as a result of the muscle healing. Stress and tension can also cause knots to form in the muscles.\\n\\nTo prevent muscular knots, it's important to take care of your muscles by stretching regularly, getting enough rest, and using good posture when you're sitting or standing. You can also try massaging the knots to help them relax, or using heat or cold to reduce inflammation and soreness.\\n\\nIt's not accurate to say that knots are made of blood, but good blood circulation can help to prevent knots from forming. When blood flows smoothly through the body, it brings oxygen and nutrients to the muscles, which can help them stay healthy and strong. If you have poor circulation, your muscles may be more prone to knots and other problems.\\n\\nIn summary, muscular knots are small, tight areas of muscle that can be painful when touched. They can be caused by overuse, injury, tension, and other factors. To prevent knots, it's important to take care of your muscles and maintain good blood circulation."]

Instead, the optic nerve is connected to the back of the eye, where it receives visual information from the retina.The muscles that control the movement of the eyeball are located around the eye, and they are connected to the outside of the eyeball by a thin layer of tissue called the extraocular muscles. When these muscles contract, they cause the eyeball to move in different directions.The optic nerve has some slack to allow for the movement of the eyeball, but it is not coiled up like a spring or rope. Instead, the optic nerve is flexible and is able to move slightly as the eye moves. This allows the eye to look in different directions without tugging on the optic nerve.']

id: How do physiologists differentiate between mental disorders and personality ? Obviously , in cases such as schizophrenia it 's pretty obvious that there is a disorder , but I was wondering if there are criteria for the most controversial ones like afluenza or even ADD . Please explain like I'm five.
text:
["Mental disorders and personality are two different things that can sometimes be difficult to differentiate. Mental disorders are conditions that can affect a person's thinking, mood, and behavior. They can be caused by a variety of factors, including genetics, environment, and life experiences. Some common mental disorders include depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia. Personality, on the other hand, refers to an individual's unique pattern of thoughts, emotions, and behaviors that make up their character. Personality is generally considered to be stable over time, but it can change somewhat as a person grows and develops. There are several ways that doctors and other healthcare professionals can differentiate between mental disorders and personality when trying to diagnose a person. Some of the criteria they may use include: Severity: Mental disorders can cause significant distress or impairment in a person's ability to function in their daily life. Personality traits, on the other hand, may not cause significant problems for the person or those around them.
Duration: Mental disorders tend to be ongoing and may last for months or years, while personality traits are typically more stable over time.
Causes: Mental disorders can be caused by a variety of factors, including genetics, brain chemistry, and life experiences. Personality traits, on the other hand, are thought to be influenced by a combination of genetics and environment.
Symptoms: Mental disorders can cause a wide range of symptoms, including changes in mood, behavior, and thinking. Personality traits do not typically cause these kinds of changes. It is important to note that there is no one-size-fits-all approach to diagnosing mental disorders and personality traits. Healthcare professionals use a variety of tools, including interviews, assessments, and medical tests, to determine the best course of treatment for a person."]

id: How do scientists split atoms ? I still do n't get it . How does one actually get something that can cut an atom ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Splitting atoms is a process called nuclear fission. It happens when a neutron hits the nucleus of an atom and causes it to break apart into two smaller atoms. This releases a lot of energy, which is why nuclear fission is used to generate electricity in power plants.\\n\\nTo split atoms, scientists use special machines called reactors. These reactors use uranium or plutonium as fuel. When the atoms in the fuel are hit with neutrons, they split and release energy. This energy is used to heat water, which makes steam. The steam turns a turbine, which generates electricity.\\n\\nScientists can also split atoms using another process called nuclear fusion. In this process, two lighter atoms are combined to make a heavier atom, releasing a lot of energy in the process. However, nuclear fusion is much harder to do than nuclear fission, and scientists are still working on finding a way to use it as a practical source of energy.']

id: How do amortization schedules work and when are they used?
text: ['An amortization schedule is a table or schedule showing the periodic payments on a loan, including the amount of principal and the amount of interest that make up each payment until the loan is fully paid off. The schedule typically shows the balance of the loan after each payment, so you can see how the balance decreases over time as the loan is paid off.Amortization schedules are commonly used for loans such as mortgages, car loans, and student loans. These types of loans typically have a fixed term, with fixed periodic payments that are made over the course of the loan. Each payment consists of a portion of the principal (the original amount of the loan) and a portion of the interest (the cost of borrowing the money). As the loan is paid off, the amount of each payment that goes toward the principal increases and the amount that goes toward interest decreases.To create an amortization schedule, you need to know the following information:The total amount of the loan (the principal)The interest rate on the loanThe term of the loan (how long the loan will be in effect)The frequency of the payments (monthly, biweekly, etc.)Using this information, you can create an amortization schedule that shows the breakdown of each payment into principal and interest, as well as the remaining balance of the loan after each payment. You can use an online amortization calculator or spreadsheet to create an amortization schedule, or you can create one manually using a pen and paper.Amortization schedules can be useful for helping you understand how your loan will be paid off and how much you will pay in total over the life of the loan. They can also be helpful for budgeting and planning, as you can see how much of each payment is going toward the principal and how much is going toward interest.']

id: How does a sacrificial metal work ? I heard that Zinc ( ? ) is used on ships to prevent rusting , I do nt understand how it would rust first Explain like I'm five.
text:
['A sacrificial metal is a type of metal that is used to protect other metals from corrosion. When a sacrificial metal is placed in contact with another metal, it will corrode before the other metal does, thereby protecting the other metal from corrosion.

For example, zinc is often used as a sacrificial metal on ships. When zinc is placed in contact with steel (which is a common material used in ship construction), it will corrode before the steel does. This is because zinc is more reactive than steel, meaning it is more prone to corrosion.

Here's an example of how this works:

Imagine you have two pieces of metal - one is made of zinc and the other is made of steel. If you put them both in a solution that can cause them to corrode (such as saltwater), the zinc will start to corrode before the steel does. This is because the zinc is more reactive and will therefore be more affected by the solution.

As the zinc corrodes, it forms a layer of zinc oxide on its surface. This layer of zinc oxide acts as a barrier, protecting the steel from the corrosive solution. In other words, the zinc "sacrifices" itself by corroding first, thereby protecting the steel from corrosion.

I hope this helps to explain how a sacrificial metal works. Do you have any other questions?']

This signal is picked up by the tag or label, which then sends back a response. If the response is not received by the sensor or antenna, it may set off an alarm to alert store staff.\\n\\nThere are a few reasons why the alarm may not always go off as intended:\\n\\nThe tag or label may be damaged or not functioning properly, which can prevent it from responding to the radio frequency signal.\\n\\nThe sensor or antenna may be malfunctioning or not positioned properly, which can also prevent it from detecting the response from the tag or label.\\n\\nThe item being brought into the store may not have a tag or label attached to it, in which case the sensor or antenna will not detect it and the alarm will not go off.\\n\\nOn the other hand, the alarm may sometimes go off when someone shoplifts. This could happen if the person tries to remove the tag or label from an item before bringing it into the store, or if they try to block the sensor or antenna from detecting the item. id: How do exchanges match limit orders?
text: ["When a limit order is placed on an exchange, it is entered into the order book for a particular trading pair. The limit order will remain in the order book until it is either filled or canceled.When another user places a market order, the exchange will attempt to match the order with the best available limit order(s) in the order book. If the market order can be fully filled by a single limit order, then the trade will be executed and the limit order will be removed from the order book. If the market order cannot be fully filled by a single limit order, then it will be partially filled and the limit order will be updated to reflect the remaining amount.If the market order cannot be filled by any of the limit orders in the order book, it will be added to the order book as a new limit order. The exchange will then continue to try to match the order with any incoming market orders or other limit orders.It's worth noting that the specific details of how exchanges match orders can vary. Some exchanges use a price-time priority system, which means that orders with the best price are given priority and orders that were placed earlier are given priority over orders placed later. Other exchanges may use different systems for matching orders.", "When a user places a limit order on a cryptocurrency exchange, it is added to the order book for the relevant trading pair. The order book is a list of all outstanding orders that have been placed on the exchange, and it is organized by price level.When another user places a market order, the exchange's matching engine will look for the best available price in the order book to fill the order. If there are multiple orders at the same price, the exchange will typically use a first-in, first-out (FIFO) approach to determine which orders to fill first.If the market order can be fully filled by a single limit order, then the trade is executed and the limit order is removed from the order book. If the market order is larger than the available volume at a single price level, then the exchange will continue to fill the order at the next best price level until the entire order is filled or until there are no more orders left in the order book.It's important to note that the way exchanges match orders can vary, and different exchanges may have their own unique methods for matching orders. Some exchanges also offer additional features, such as time-in-force options and iceberg orders, which can affect the way that orders are matched and executed."]

There are a few different mechanisms in place to help make sure that countries are reporting their emissions accurately.\\n\\nOne mechanism is that countries have to use a specific set of guidelines when they report their emissions. These guidelines, called the "UNFCCC reporting guidelines," outline how countries should measure and report their emissions, and they are designed to make sure that all countries are using the same methods and standards.\\n\\nAnother mechanism is that countries are required to have their emissions reports reviewed by other countries or international organizations. This is called "international consultation and analysis," and it helps to ensure that the emissions reports are accurate and complete.\\n\\nFinally, the Paris Agreement also includes a system called the "Transparency Framework," which is designed to help countries track and report their emissions over time. This helps to make sure that countries are meeting their commitments to reduce their emissions, and it also helps other countries and organizations to understand what is happening with emissions around the world.\\n\\nOverall, while it is always possible that some countries might try to lie about their emissions, the mechanisms in place under the Paris Agreement help to make sure that emissions are reported accurately and that countries are held accountable for their actions.\\n']

id: How do scientists seperate particles from the rest of their groupings ? Basically like how do they shoot off one particle at a time in experiments like the " Gold Foil Experiment " Explain like I'm five.
text: ['There are many ways that scientists can separate particles from their groupings, depending on the specific type of particles and the properties they have. Here are a few examples:\\n\\nFiltering: This method involves using a filter or sieve to separate particles based on size. For example, if you wanted to separate sand from pebbles, you could use a filter with small holes that only allow the sand to pass through, while the pebbles are too big to fit through the holes and stay on the other side.\\n\\nCentrifuging: This method involves using a machine called a centrifuge to spin a sample at high speeds. The particles in the sample will be separated based on their weight and density, with the heavier particles settling to the bottom and the lighter particles remaining at the top.\\n\\nMagnetic separation: This method involves using a magnet to attract and separate particles that are magnetic from those that are not. For example, if you had a mixture of iron filings and sand, you could use a magnet to pull out the iron filings and leave the sand behind.\\n\\nChromatography: This method involves separating particles based on their chemical properties. Scientists can use different techniques, such as paper chromatography or column chromatography, to separate different substances from a mixture.\\n\\nIn the "Gold Foil Experiment," scientists used a method called alpha particle scattering to separate particles. They shot alpha particles (which are made up of two protons and two neutrons) at a thin sheet of gold foil and measured how the particles were deflected or absorbed. By analyzing the data, they were able to learn more about the structure of atoms.']

id: How do developed nations change their voting systems , short of revolution ? I 've been learning about the STV ( Single Transferable Vote ) , and I ca n't understand how the current system in the USA could possibly be preferable to this : URL_0 Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Developed nations often change their voting systems through a process called electoral reform. This can involve changes to the way elections are conducted, such as switching to a different voting system like the Single Transferable Vote (STV). In the United States, electoral reform is typically initiated by lawmakers at the state or federal level. If a bill proposing a change to the voting system is passed by the legislature and signed into law by the executive, the new system will be implemented in future elections.The process of changing a voting system can be difficult, as it often requires the support of a majority of lawmakers and can be controversial. Some people may oppose electoral reform because they believe that the current system works well, or because they are concerned about the potential impact on their political party.The Single Transferable Vote (STV) is a voting system that is used in some elections, including some elections in the United States. In STV, voters rank candidates in order of preference. If a candidate receives a majority of the first preference votes, they are elected. If no candidate receives a majority, the candidate with the fewest votes is eliminated, and their votes are transferred to the next preferred candidate on the voter\'s ballot. This process continues until a candidate receives a majority of the votes. STV is designed to ensure that the winner of an election represents the majority of voters and to allow voters to express their preferences more accurately. Some people believe that STV is a more fair and democratic voting system than the current system used in the United States, which is called the "first past the post" system. In the first past the post system, the candidate who receives the most votes wins, regardless of whether they have a majority of the votes.']

id: How does a country pay off its debt to other countries ? A cursory google search and ELI5 query did n't have the answer I was looking for . Is it a cash transfer ? Electronically done ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['There are a few different ways that a country can pay off its debt to other countries. Here are a few options:

Transferring cash: One way to pay off debt is to simply transfer the money from one country to another. This can be done through various methods such as wire transfer or through the use of checks.

Selling assets: A country may choose to sell assets, such as government-owned buildings or land, in order to raise the money needed to pay off its debt.

Negotiating with creditors: If a country is unable to pay its debt in full, it may negotiate with its creditors to come up with a plan for paying off the debt over time. This could involve making smaller payments over a longer period of time or restructuring the terms of the debt in some other way.

Using foreign exchange markets: A country may also be able to pay off its debt by using the foreign exchange markets to buy back its own currency. For example, if a country has borrowed money in U.S. dollars and its own currency appreciates against the dollar, it may be able to use its own currency to buy back the dollars it needs to pay off its debt.

Seeking assistance from international organizations: In some cases, a country may seek assistance from international organizations such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in order to pay off its debt. The IMF can provide loans to countries experiencing financial difficulties, which can be used to pay off debt.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.']

id: How do we know how far away a given star is ? I understand how we figure the real distance of closer bodies , but how do we know a quasar is 30 million light years away , or that Andromeda is 2.5 million light years away ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['There are a few ways that we can determine the distance to stars and other objects in the universe. One way is by using something called parallax. Parallax is the apparent shift in the position of an object against the background when viewed from different angles. For example, if you hold your finger up in front of you and close one eye, then open that eye and close the other eye, your finger will appear to move against the background. This is because you are looking at it from two different angles. We can use this same principle to determine the distance to nearby stars. By measuring the apparent shift in the position of a star against the background of more distant stars (as viewed from opposite sides of Earth\'s orbit around the sun), we can calculate how far away the star is. This method is most accurate for stars that are relatively close to us (within a few hundred light-years). For more distant objects, such as quasars and galaxies, we use other methods to determine their distance. One such method is called the cosmic distance ladder, which involves using a series of "rungs" or steps to measure the distance to increasingly distant objects. Each rung of the ladder relies on a different type of "standard candle," which is an object that is known to have a certain intrinsic brightness. By measuring the brightness of the object as seen from Earth, we can determine its distance. For example, one type of standard candle that we use is a type of star called a Cepheid variable. These stars have a very regular pulse, and the time between pulses is directly related to the star\'s intrinsic brightness. By measuring the time between pulses, we can determine the star\'s brightness, and therefore its distance. Once we have determined the distance to a Cepheid variable, we can use it as a "rung" on the cosmic distance ladder to measure the distance to other objects that are farther away. For example, we can use Cepheid variables to measure the distance to nearby galaxies, and then use those galaxies as "rungs" to measure the distance to even more distant galaxies. This way, we can build up a "ladder" of distances that reaches all the way out to the most distant objects in the universe.']

id: How do speakers virtually produce any sound ? From my understanding speakers are made up of some vibrating cone of a fixed shape . It just seems to me that such a thing could only produce one sound like a drum . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Speakers work by converting an electrical signal into sound waves that we can hear. Inside a speaker, there is a coil of wire called the voice coil, which is attached to a cone-shaped diaphragm. When an electrical current is passed through the voice coil, it creates a magnetic field. This magnetic field causes the voice coil and the attached diaphragm to move back and forth very quickly, creating vibrations. These vibrations cause the air around the speaker to vibrate as well, creating sound waves that we can hear. The shape of the cone-shaped diaphragm and the size of the speaker determine what kinds of sound waves it can produce. Different shapes and sizes of speakers are designed to produce different frequencies (or pitches) of sound. For example, a small speaker with a thin, lightweight diaphragm might be good at producing high-pitched sounds, like a tweet or a chirp, while a larger speaker with a heavier diaphragm might be better at producing lower-pitched sounds, like a bass drum or a bass guitar. By using different combinations of speakers, an audio system can produce a wide range of sounds, from deep bass to sparkling highs.']

id: How does Yahoo finance adjust stock data for splits and dividends?
text: ["When a company declares a stock split, it increases the number of shares outstanding by issuing more shares to existing shareholders. For example, if a company declares a 2-for-1 stock split, an investor who owns 100 shares before the split would own 200 shares after the split. The value of the investor's holdings in the company would remain the same, but the value of each individual share would be halved.To adjust stock data for a stock split, Yahoo Finance divides the historical price of the stock by the split ratio. For example, if a stock traded at $100 per share before a 2-for-1 split, the adjusted price would be $50 per share after the split.Dividends are payments made by a company to its shareholders, typically in the form of cash or additional shares of stock. When a company declares a dividend, it reduces the value of its stock by an amount equal to the dividend per share.To adjust stock data for dividends, Yahoo Finance subtracts the value of the dividend from the historical price of the stock. For example, if a stock traded at $100 per share and the company declared a $1 per share dividend, the adjusted price would be $99 per share.It's important to note that stock splits and dividends can have a significant impact on the historical price data of a stock. Adjusting for these events can make it easier to compare the performance of a stock over time and to analyze trends in the stock market."]
