id: How do zits / pimples actually form on your face ? Why are they suddenly there ? Why are some bigger than others ? Please explain like I'm five.
text:
["Acne is a common skin condition that occurs when the hair follicles on your skin become clogged with oil and dead skin cells. The clogged pores can become infected with bacteria, and this can cause a pimple or zit to form. Pimples are also called zits, spots, or blemishes. 
Pimples can form on any part of your body, but they are most common on the face, neck, chest, and back. They can range in size from very small to large and can be red, white, or black in color. Some pimples are painful, while others are not. 
There are many different things that can cause pimples to form. Some common triggers include: 
Hormonal changes: Pimples are common during puberty when the body's hormones are changing. Hormonal changes can also cause pimples to form in adults.
Genetics: If your parents had acne, you are more likely to develop acne as well.
Diet: Some people find that certain foods, such as chocolate or fried foods, can trigger pimples.
Skin care products: Some skincare products can irritate the skin and cause pimples to form.
Stress: Stress can affect the body's hormone levels and can cause pimples to form. 
Pimples can be treated with over-the-counter or prescription medications, such as creams or gels that contain benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid. It is important to keep the skin clean and to avoid picking or squeezing pimples, as this can cause them to become infected or leave scars."]

id: How does a DVD work ? How is data stored on a DVD , and how is it read by DVD players and computers and stuff ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['A DVD (short for Digital Versatile Disc or Digital Video Disc) is a type of disc that is used to store and play back video, audio, and other types of data. DVDs are made of a special type of plastic that is coated with a thin layer of metal. This metal layer is where the data is stored.

When you insert a DVD into a DVD player or a computer with a DVD drive, a laser is used to read the data on the metal layer. The laser is very precise and can pick up tiny bumps and scratches on the surface of the DVD. These bumps and scratches are actually a code that represents the data that is stored on the DVD.

The DVD player or computer then converts this code into the video, audio, or other types of data that you can watch or listen to. The DVD player or computer sends this data to your TV or speakers, so you can see or hear it.

So, in short, a DVD works by using a laser to read the data that is stored on the metal layer of the DVD, and then converting that data into something you can watch or listen to.']

id: How do shows like south park and family guy get away with openly making fun of famous people While often using their names and likenesses . Please explain like I'm five.

In the United States, there is a law called the "fair use" doctrine that allows people to use someone else\'s work, like a person\'s name or likeness, for certain purposes, like parody, without getting permission from the person or paying them. This is because the law recognizes that parody can be a form of free speech and can be an important way for people to express their opinions or make social commentary. So, when South Park or Family Guy make fun of famous people, they are using their names and likenesses in a way that is meant to be humorous and is protected by the fair use doctrine. It\'s important to note, however, that the fair use doctrine is a complex legal concept and there are limits to what it allows. id: How do speedometers work ? How do they know a car is there ? How do they know exactly how fast it 's going ? Edit : I mean the speedometer the police use . Explain like I'm five.

The speed sensor sends a signal to the speedometer, which then displays the speed of the car on the dashboard.\\n\\nThe speed sensor works by detecting the rotation of the car's wheels. As the wheels turn, the sensor sends a signal to the speedometer, which calculates the speed of the car based on the number of rotations per minute (RPMs) of the wheels.\\n\\nThe speedometer in a police car works in the same way, but it may use a different type of speed sensor or a more advanced speed measurement system.\\n\\nSo, to sum up: a speedometer is a device that measures the speed of a car by using a speed sensor to detect the rotation of the car's wheels. id: How does a turbocharger in a car work ? I know a bit about cars and how they work , but turbos are very foreign to me . Could someone explain how it is they work , in basic terms ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
["A turbocharger is a device that is used to boost the power of an internal combustion engine. It does this by forcing more air into the engine, which allows it to burn more fuel and produce more power.

Here's how it works:

The turbocharger has a small turbine that is attached to a shaft. This turbine is powered by the exhaust gases that are produced by the engine.

The turbine is connected to a compressor, which is a device that takes in air and compresses it, making it denser.

The compressed air is then sent through a pipe and into the engine's combustion chamber, where it is mixed with fuel and burned to create power.

The more air that is forced into the engine, the more fuel it can burn, and the more power it can produce. This is why a turbocharged engine can produce more power than a similar engine without a turbo.

Overall, a turbocharger helps an engine produce more power by forcing more air into it, which allows it to burn more fuel and create more power."]

id: How do share buybacks work?
text: ['A share buyback, also known as a stock buyback, is when a company repurchases its own outstanding shares from the market. This reduces the number of shares that are available for trading, and can increase the value of the remaining shares. There are several reasons why a company might choose to buy back its own shares.One reason is to increase the value of the remaining shares. When a company buys back its own shares, it is effectively saying that it believes the shares are undervalued. This can lead to an increase in the price of the remaining shares, as investors may see the buyback as a sign of confidence in the company.Another reason is to return value to shareholders. If a company has a large amount of cash on hand and no good investment opportunities, it may choose to buy back its own shares as a way to return some of that cash to shareholders. This can be an attractive option for shareholders, as they can receive a cash payout without having to sell their shares.There are several ways that a company can buy back its own shares. The most common method is to conduct a tender offer, in which the company offers to buy a certain number of shares at a fixed price. Shareholders can choose to sell their shares back to the company or hold onto them. Alternatively, the company can buy shares on the open market through a process known as open market repurchases.It is important to note that share buybacks can be controversial, as some people believe that they can be used by companies to manipulate their stock price or to avoid paying dividends. However, if done for the right reasons, share buybacks can be a legitimate way for companies to return value to shareholders and to address imbalances in their capital structure.', "A share buyback, also known as a stock buyback, is a way for a company to repurchase its own outstanding shares from the open market. The company typically does this to reduce the number of shares outstanding, which can increase the value of the remaining shares by lowering the supply. Share buybacks can also be used to return capital to shareholders, or to make strategic acquisitions.There are several ways that a company can execute a share buyback. One method is through an open market purchase, where the company buys back its shares on the open market through a broker. Another method is through a tender offer, where the company offers to buy back a specific number of shares at a predetermined price.Share buybacks can be funded through the company's cash reserves, or through the issuance of debt or additional shares. The specific details of a share buyback, including the number of shares to be repurchased, the price, and the funding source, are usually announced in a press release or Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) filing.It's important to note that share buybacks are not the same as dividend payments, which are a distribution of the company's profits to shareholders. Share buybacks can have a similar effect of returning capital to shareholders, but they do not involve the distribution of the company's profits."]

For example, the charge controller in a phone battery may be designed to work with the specific charging and power needs of a phone, while the charge controller in an AA battery may be designed to work with a wider range of devices.']

id: How do animals who are moved miles away find their way back ? Pigeons would be be obvious example but there are stories of several other animals doing it . How does it work ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
["Animals use a variety of methods to navigate and find their way back home, even if they are moved far away.

One way they do this is by using their senses, such as sight, smell, and hearing, to gather information about their surroundings. For example, a pigeon might use its sense of smell to identify familiar landmarks, or use its keen eyesight to recognize distinctive features of the landscape.

Another way animals navigate is by using the Earth's magnetic field. Many animals, including birds, fish, and some insects, have special cells in their bodies that can detect changes in the magnetic field, which helps them orient themselves and navigate in a particular direction.

Finally, some animals use celestial cues, such as the sun or the stars, to help them navigate. For example, birds might use the position of the sun in the sky to determine which direction is north, and then use this information to fly back home.

Overall, animals use a combination of their senses and natural navigation skills to find their way back home, even if they are moved far away."]

id: How does Netflix load so fast ? I 'm on a 2 Mbps connection , and even gifs on reddit take forever to load . How is it that I can watch full HD episodes of Archer with only 10 seconds or so of load time ? Please explain like I'm five.

This means that when you start to watch a video, Netflix will first send a lower quality version of the video to your device. As the video plays, Netflix will continuously check your internet connection speed and send a higher or lower quality version of the video as needed to make sure the video plays smoothly without buffering.In addition to using adaptive bitrate streaming, Netflix also stores copies of its videos on servers located all around the world. When you start to watch a video on Netflix, it will automatically connect to the server that is closest to you, which can help to reduce the amount of time it takes for the video to start playing.Finally, Netflix also uses a variety of other techniques to optimize the delivery of its videos, such as using specialized servers and networking equipment, and carefully managing the way that its videos are encoded and stored. All of these factors contribute to the fast loading times that you experience when watching Netflix.']

id: How do you go about buying a house directly from an owner? I.e. no broker involved?

This includes researching the property's history, checking for any liens or other legal issues, and having a professional inspection to ensure the property is in good condition.Negotiate the price: Once you have a good understanding of the property's value, you can start negotiating the price with the owner. You can shop around for the best rates and terms, and be sure to compare offers from multiple lenders.Review and sign the contract: Once you've agreed on the price and financing, you'll need to review and sign a purchase agreement with the seller. This document should outline the terms of the sale, including the purchase price, closing date, and any contingencies.Close the sale: Once all the details are finalized, you'll need to complete the closing process. This includes paying the purchase price and any closing costs, as well as transferring ownership of the property to you."]

id: How do video game " engines " work and why are some better than others ? For example , why does Dice 's Frostbite engine make Battlefield and other games beautiful compared to Activisions Call of duty engine ? Please explain like I'm five.
text:
['A video game engine is the software that powers a video game. It provides the tools and technology for developers to build and create the game, including features like graphics, physics, sound, and artificial intelligence. 
There are many different video game engines available, and each one has its own set of features and capabilities. Some engines are better at creating certain types of games, while others may be better suited for different kinds of games. 
For example, the Frostbite engine, developed by Dice, is known for its high-quality graphics and realistic physics. This makes it a good choice for games that require a lot of detail and realism, such as the Battlefield series. 
On the other hand, the Call of Duty engine may not be as advanced as the Frostbite engine in terms of graphics and physics, but it might be optimized for fast-paced, action-oriented gameplay, which is important for the Call of Duty series. 
So, the reason some game engines are better than others is because they are tailored to the specific needs of the game they are being used to create. Different games have different requirements, and the best engine for a particular game will depend on those requirements.']

id: How does a program make things " random " ? Like how do machines guarantee randomness in some functions ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['One way that a program can generate random numbers is by using a technique called "pseudorandom number generation." This means that the program uses a mathematical formula or algorithm to generate a sequence of numbers that appear random, but are actually determined by the algorithm.For example, a program might use the current time, the temperature, or other unpredictable data as a starting point, and then apply a formula to that data to generate a random number. While the resulting number is not truly random (since it is determined by the formula), it is still difficult to predict, and so it can be used in many situations where true randomness is not strictly necessary.There are also other ways to generate truly random numbers, such as using hardware devices called "random number generators" that measure physical phenomena (like noise or radioactive decay) and use that data to generate random numbers. These methods are more expensive and complex, but they can be used in cases where it is important to have truly random numbers.']

id: How do Young Earth Creationists rationalize radiocarbon dating ? Not trying to stir the pot , just genuinely curious about how they do it . Since it is based on relatively simple math , and relatively simple science , on what basis do they reject it ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Radiocarbon dating is a technique that uses the decay of carbon-14 to determine the age of organic materials, such as wood or bones. It is based on the fact that carbon-14 is constantly being created in the Earth's atmosphere through the interaction of cosmic rays with nitrogen atoms. When an organism dies, it stops taking in carbon-14, and the carbon-14 in its body begins to decay at a predictable rate. By measuring the amount of carbon-14 in a sample and comparing it to the known decay rate of carbon-14, scientists can determine how old the sample is. Young Earth creationists, who believe that the Earth is only a few thousand years old, may reject radiocarbon dating because it produces ages that are much older than this. They may argue that the decay rate of carbon-14 has changed over time, or that the sample has been contaminated with older carbon. However, these arguments are not supported by scientific evidence and are not widely accepted by the scientific community. It is important to note that radiocarbon dating is just one of many methods that scientists use to determine the age of materials. Other methods, such as potassium-argon dating and uranium-lead dating, have been developed to provide additional information about the age of materials and help scientists confirm the results of radiocarbon dating."]

id: How do we know that gravity curves spacetime and is not a force ? As I understand it , electromagnetism is a force but gravity changes the shape of spacetime . How do physicists understand this difference ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Gravity is a force that causes objects with mass to be attracted to each other. The way that gravity affects the motion of objects is through the curvature of spacetime.Imagine that spacetime is like a stretchy fabric, like a rubber sheet. If you put a heavy object, like a bowling ball, on the fabric, it will cause the fabric to stretch and bend. If you roll a smaller object, like a marble, towards the bowling ball, the marble will be attracted to the bowling ball and will roll towards it, following the curve of the fabric.This is a simple way to understand how gravity can be thought of as a curvature of spacetime, rather than a force. In reality, the concept of spacetime is a bit more complicated, but the basic idea is the same.On the other hand, forces like electromagnetism do not cause objects to curve through spacetime. Instead, they act directly on the objects themselves, causing them to accelerate or change direction. For example, when you rub a balloon against your hair, the electrons in your hair are attracted to the balloon, causing an electrostatic force that makes your hair stand up. This force is acting directly on the electrons in your hair, rather than causing the fabric of spacetime to curve.I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any more questions.']

id: How does a no-limit charge card affect your credit score?

id: How do nukes work ? I know that inside the missile / shell there is radioactive material but how does it create the massive explosion when the missile hits the ground ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Nuclear weapons work by using the energy stored in the nucleus of an atom to create a powerful explosion. Atoms are made up of tiny particles called protons and neutrons, which are held together by a force called the "strong nuclear force." Inside a nuclear weapon, there is a special type of radioactive material called nuclear fuel, which is made up of atoms with a lot of protons and neutrons packed closely together in the nucleus. When the right conditions are met, the strong nuclear force that holds the protons and neutrons together can be overcome, and the nucleus will split into two smaller nuclei. This process is called nuclear fission. During fission, a lot of energy is released in the form of heat and light. This energy can be used to create an explosion. In a nuclear weapon, the energy from the fission process is used to create a chain reaction, where the energy from one fission event is used to cause another fission event, and so on. This chain reaction releases a massive amount of energy all at once, creating a powerful explosion. So, when a nuclear missile hits the ground, the energy from the fission process is released, creating a huge explosion that can cause widespread damage and destruction.']

id: How do the numbers after the decimal in pi just " go on forever " Why does it go on forever when virtually no other number does ? And how do we know ? And why is it random ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Pi, denoted by the Greek letter Ï, is the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter. The value of pi is approximately 3.14, but it goes on infinitely without repeating in a predictable pattern. This means that if you tried to write out all of the numbers after the decimal point, you would never run out of digits. In other words, the digits of pi are "random" in the sense that they do not follow a pattern that we can predict.

One way to understand why pi is an infinite, non-repeating decimal is to think about trying to measure the circumference and diameter of a circle using a ruler. No matter how carefully you measure, there will always be some small amount of error in your measurement. This error will be especially noticeable when you try to measure a very large circle, because the ruler will be a very small part of the circle's circumference. As a result, the value of pi will always be an approximation, and the digits after the decimal point will never end.

It is also possible to prove mathematically that pi is an infinite, non-repeating decimal. One way to do this is to use a concept called "transcendental numbers," which are numbers that cannot be expressed as the solution to any algebraic equation with a finite number of steps. It has been proven that pi is a transcendental number, which means that it cannot be expressed as the solution to any equation and therefore must be an infinite, non-repeating decimal.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.']

id: How does Nasa know the exact course to chart with their space probes to get them on different planets ? ELI5 : How does Nasa know the exact course to chart with their space probes to get them on different planets ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ['To get a space probe to a specific planet, NASA uses a combination of math and physics. They use math to calculate the path that the probe should take, taking into account things like the distance between the probe and the planet and the speed at which the probe is traveling. They also use physics to understand how the probe will be affected by things like the gravity of other planets and the sun, which can affect its course. One way that NASA figures out the best path for a space probe is by using a technique called "orbital mechanics." This involves using math and physics to predict how a probe will move in space based on the forces acting on it, such as gravity and the push of its engines. Once they have a good understanding of the probe\'s path, NASA can then use this information to plan the course of the probe and make any necessary adjustments along the way to ensure that it stays on track. This might involve using the probe\'s engines to change its speed or direction, or using the gravity of other objects in space to "slingshot" the probe towards its destination. Overall, it takes a lot of careful planning and precise calculations to get a space probe to a specific planet, but by using math and physics, NASA is able to chart a course that will get the probe where it needs to go.']

id: How does a ranked voting system work ? I keep hearing that it is better the USA 's current system of voting but how so ? And how would it help eliminate the 2 party system ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["A ranked voting system is a way of casting and counting votes in an election where voters are able to rank the candidates in order of preference. Instead of just choosing one candidate, voters can indicate their top choice, second choice, third choice, and so on.In a ranked voting system, if a candidate wins a majority of first-choice votes, they are declared the winner just like in a normal election. If no candidate wins a majority of first-choice votes, then the candidate with the fewest votes is eliminated and their votes are redistributed to the voters' next choice. This process is repeated until one candidate has a majority of votes and is declared the winner.One advantage of ranked voting is that it can help ensure that the winner of an election has the support of a majority of voters, rather than just a plurality of voters. In a normal election, it is possible for a candidate to win with less than 50% of the vote if there are more than two candidates running. In a ranked voting system, this is less likely to happen because the votes of the least popular candidate can be redistributed to the voters' next choice.As for how a ranked voting system could help eliminate the two-party system, it's important to note that ranked voting is just one of many potential reforms that could help encourage more political diversity. However, ranked voting could potentially help by making it easier for third-party candidates or independent candidates to win elections. Since voters are able to rank multiple candidates in order of preference, they can choose to support a third-party candidate as their first choice while still expressing a preference for one of the major party candidates as their second choice. This could make it more likely that a third-party candidate could win an election, or at least have a stronger influence on the outcome."]

id: How do water / other liquids ruin electronics ? When you spill water or any other liquid on a piece of technology or an electronic , it ruins it . What exactly happens here ? Explain like I'm five.

However, when the insulation gets wet, it can lose its effectiveness, causing the metal components to come into contact with each other and create a short circuit.

A short circuit is when electricity flows through a path that it is not supposed to, usually causing a lot of heat to be generated and sometimes even a fire. When this happens inside an electronic device, it can cause the device to stop working or even to be permanently damaged.

So, to summarize, when you spill water or any other liquid on an electronic device, it can cause a short circuit, which can damage the device and cause it to stop working.']

id: How do they determine television rating statistics ? Can they actually tell how many people have their televisions on a specific channel at specific times ? If so , how ? Are n't some television services one - way ? ( Satellite ) Explain like I'm five.
text:
["Television ratings statistics are determined by measuring the number of people watching a specific television channel at a specific time. There are several different ways to measure television ratings, and each method has its own strengths and limitations.

One way to measure television ratings is through the use of Nielsen ratings, which are collected by a company called Nielsen Media Research. Nielsen uses a panel of households across the United States that agree to have their television viewing habits tracked. The panel is representative of the U.S. population as a whole, so Nielsen can use the data collected from the panel to estimate the number of people watching a particular television show or channel at a specific time.

Another way to measure television ratings is through the use of set-top boxes, which are devices that are connected to a television set and track what the television is being used to watch. Set-top boxes are often used by cable and satellite television providers to track their customers' viewing habits.

It is also possible to measure television ratings through the use of online streaming services, such as Hulu or Netflix. These services track the number of people who watch a particular show or movie on their platforms and can use this data to estimate the number of people who are watching at a specific time.

Overall, there are many different ways to measure television ratings, and each method has its own benefits and drawbacks. It is important to keep in mind that no single method is perfect and that different methods may produce slightly different results."]

id: How do contactless cards generate their RFiD signal ? Surely there needs to be a source of energy to generate this signal but how come I do n't need to charge my card Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Contactless cards use a technology called radio-frequency identification, or RFID, to communicate with the payment terminal. RFID uses radio waves to transmit information wirelessly between the card and the terminal.\\n\\nThe RFID chip in the card contains a small antenna that is used to send and receive the radio signals. When the card is placed near a payment terminal, the terminal sends a radio signal to the card, which activates the RFID chip. The chip then sends a unique code back to the terminal to identify the card and initiate the payment process.\\n\\nThe RFID chip in the card does not require a power source or battery because it is able to generate its own electricity using the radio waves it receives from the terminal. This is known as "passive" RFID technology, as the card is not actively sending or receiving signals, but rather responding to signals from the terminal.\\n\\nI hope this helps to explain how contactless cards work! Let me know if you have any more questions.']

id: How do you test something for randomness ? I read this : URL_0 and I 'm still a little baffled I guess . For instance , if I mix up a Rubik 's Cube , how could someone test if it was truly random or not ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
["To test if something is truly random, you can use statistical tests. These are methods that involve collecting data and analyzing it to see if it follows certain patterns that are expected if the data is truly random.

For example, if you wanted to test the randomness of a Rubik's Cube, you could mix it up a bunch of times and record the colors on each face of the cube after each shuffle. Then you could analyze the data to see if the colors are distributed evenly across the faces of the cube. If the colors are distributed evenly, that would be an indication that the shuffling of the cube is random.

There are many different statistical tests that can be used to test for randomness, and they can be quite complex. But the basic idea is that you collect data and analyze it to see if it follows the patterns that you would expect if the data was truly random."]

id: How does a HSA ( Health Savings Account ) work and compare to traditional insurance ? The other answers were n't great and are possibly outdated . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["A Health Savings Account (HSA) is a type of account that you can use to pay for medical expenses. It is often paired with a high-deductible health plan (HDHP), which is a type of health insurance that has a higher deductible than traditional health insurance plans. The deductible is the amount of money you have to pay for your medical expenses before your insurance starts to cover them. With an HSA, you can contribute money to the account on a tax-free basis. You can use this money to pay for qualifying medical expenses, such as doctor's visits, prescription drugs, and certain types of medical equipment. You can also use the money to pay for your deductible and other out-of-pocket costs associated with your HDHP. One of the main advantages of an HSA is that the money in the account can be used to pay for medical expenses tax-free. This means that you can use the money in your HSA to pay for medical expenses without having to pay taxes on it. This can help you save money on your medical expenses. Another advantage of an HSA is that the money in the account belongs to you. This means that you can keep the money in your HSA even if you change jobs or insurance plans. Overall, an HSA can be a good option for people who want to have more control over their healthcare expenses and save money on taxes. However, it is important to keep in mind that an HSA is paired with an HDHP, which may have a higher deductible than traditional insurance plans. This means that you may have to pay more out of pocket for your medical expenses before your insurance starts to cover them."]

id: How do animals with independent eyes like a chameleon experience vision ? Animals whose eyes move independently from one another , do they have two separate " vision areas " for lack of a better term ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Animals with independent eyes, like chameleons, do indeed have two separate "vision areas," so to speak. Each eye is able to move independently of the other, which allows the animal to have a wider range of vision and to see in different directions at the same time. Here\'s how it works: each eye has a lens that focuses light onto the retina, which is a layer of special cells at the back of the eye. The retina contains light-sensitive cells called rods and cones, which send signals to the brain when they are stimulated by light. The brain then processes these signals and creates an image of what the animal is seeing. In animals with independent eyes, each eye has its own lens, retina, and set of rods and cones. This means that each eye is able to send separate signals to the brain, which allows the animal to see two different things at the same time. For example, a chameleon might use one eye to look at a predator while using the other eye to keep an eye on its surroundings. I hope that helps to explain how animals with independent eyes experience vision! Let me know if you have any other questions.']

id: How do boxers train not to be knocked out ? I have a few theories 1 . A natural physical / physiological resistance 2 . Come back from the brink of being knocked out 3 . Being KO'd frequently builds up resistance Please explain like I'm five.
text:
["Boxers train not to be knocked out by doing a variety of things: 
1. Physical training: Boxers work on building strength and endurance in their muscles through weight training, cardio exercises, and sparring (practicing fighting with another boxer). This helps them physically handle the impact of punches and stay on their feet longer during a fight. 
2. Mental training: Boxers also work on their mental toughness by training themselves to stay focused and calm under pressure. They practice techniques like visualization and deep breathing to stay composed and clear-headed, even when they're in the middle of a tough fight. 
3. Techniques to avoid getting hit: Boxers also work on techniques to avoid getting hit, such as dodging, weaving, and footwork. By learning how to move their body effectively and stay out of their opponent's range, they can reduce their chances of getting hit and being knocked out. 
4. Knowing how to take a punch: Finally, boxers learn how to take a punch and minimize the damage it causes. They practice techniques like rolling with the punch and tucking their chin to help absorb the impact and reduce the chances of being knocked out. 
Overall, being a successful boxer requires a combination of physical, mental, and technical skills. By working on all of these areas, boxers can improve their chances of not getting knocked out and having a successful fight."]

3. In-app purchases: Some browsers offer extra features or tools that users can purchase within the app. For example, users might be able to purchase a "pro" version of a browser that has more features than the free version. 
4. Data collection: Some browsers collect data about the sites and content that users visit and sell this data to advertisers or other companies. This can help the browser company make money. 
Overall, the main way that browsers make money is by showing ads to users and collecting data about their browsing habits. This allows the browser company to target ads to users and make money when users click on these ads.']

id: How do cartoon artists manage to draw their characters exactly the same way every time ? There 's got ta be teams working at them , but how do they manage to draw the characters the same way as the guy next to them . Thousands of times . Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Great question! Cartoon artists, or animators, use a process called "character modeling" to ensure that their characters are drawn consistently. This means that they create a set of guidelines, or a model sheet, that shows how each character should look from different angles and in different poses.

For example, a model sheet might show a character's face from the front, side, and back, as well as the character's body from different angles. It might also show the character in different poses, such as standing, walking, or jumping.

By following these guidelines, animators can draw the character consistently, no matter who is drawing it. They might also use reference images, or pictures, to help them get the character's proportions and details just right.

It takes a lot of practice and attention to detail to be able to draw characters consistently, but it's an important part of creating high-quality cartoons.']

id: How do people become morbidly obese ? I 've always been in good shape by keeping active and not overeating . I simply can not comprehend how one becomes incredibly fat . I mean no disrespect . Explain like I'm five.
text:
["There are many different factors that can contribute to morbid obesity, which is defined as having a body mass index (BMI) of 40 or higher. Some people may become morbidly obese due to medical conditions such as hormonal imbalances, metabolic disorders, or certain medications that cause weight gain. Other people may become morbidly obese due to unhealthy eating habits and a lack of physical activity. It's also possible for people to have a combination of these and other factors that contribute to their weight gain.

One way to think about it is that when we eat more calories than we burn through physical activity and everyday life, our bodies store the excess calories as fat. Over time, this can lead to weight gain. On the other hand, when we eat fewer calories than we burn, our bodies use stored fat for energy, which can lead to weight loss.

It's important to note that everyone's bodies are different, and what works for one person in terms of diet and exercise may not work for another. It's important to speak with a healthcare professional to determine the best approach for managing weight and overall health."]

id: How do bookies make money from taking bets ? Maybe I 'm just an idiot , but none of my friends knew why either . Edit : Thanks , that cleared it up ! Good luck in March Madness . Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Bookies make money by taking bets from people on the outcome of sporting events and other events. They set odds on each event, and the odds reflect the probability of each outcome occurring. The bookie will take bets from people on each outcome, and they will pay out to the people who bet on the correct outcome. For example, let\'s say there is a football game and the bookie sets the odds at 50/50 for each team to win. This means that the bookie thinks both teams have an equal chance of winning. If 100 people bet on the game, and 50 people bet on one team and 50 people bet on the other team, the bookie will make a profit no matter which team wins. This is because the bookie will keep the money from the losing bets, and pay out the winnings to the people who bet on the winning team. So, the bookie makes money by taking a small percentage of the bets placed on each event as their profit. This is called the "vigorish," or "vig" for short. As long as the bookie sets the odds correctly and takes bets on both sides of the event, they will make a profit.']

id: How do bitcoins work ? I do n't understand bitcoins . How can people just generate money ? How can people give out bitcoins in exchange for dollars ? What are they losing ? Are they just printing free money ? It all seems very arcane to me . Explain like I'm five.
text: ['Bitcoins are a type of digital currency that is created and managed using advanced computer technology. They are not physical objects like paper money or coins, but rather they are stored in a digital wallet on a computer or smartphone. Bitcoins are created through a process called "mining," in which computers solve complex math problems. When a problem is solved, a new bitcoin is created and added to the network. This process helps to verify transactions and prevent fraud, and it is the reason why bitcoins are sometimes referred to as a decentralized currency. People can exchange bitcoins for other currencies, such as dollars, or they can use them to buy goods and services from businesses that accept bitcoins. When someone gives out bitcoins in exchange for dollars, they are not "losing" anything. They are simply exchanging one type of currency for another. It is important to note that the value of bitcoins can fluctuate greatly. The value of a bitcoin is determined by supply and demand, just like the value of any other commodity. If more people want to buy bitcoins, the price will go up, and if more people want to sell bitcoins, the price will go down. This means that the value of a bitcoin can change significantly over time, which can make it a risky investment. Overall, bitcoins are a complex and sophisticated form of digital currency that is created and managed using advanced computer technology. While they can be used to buy goods and services and exchanged for other currencies, their value can also fluctuate greatly, which can make them a risky investment.']

id: How do ants survive enormous falls that would kill us ? Whenever I brush an ant off of a shelf , they fall what would be the equivalent of a pretty tall 10 story building but they survive totally unharmed . How ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Ants are able to survive falls that would be very dangerous for humans because they have a number of adaptations that help them to protect themselves. First of all, ants are very small, which means that they have a smaller surface area and less mass, so they experience less force when they fall. This means that they don't hit the ground as hard as a larger animal like a human would. Secondly, ants have a hard exoskeleton, which is a hard outer shell that covers their body. This exoskeleton helps to protect them from injury when they fall, because it absorbs some of the force of the impact. Finally, ants are able to move their legs and antennae very quickly when they fall, which helps them to orient themselves in mid-air and land on their feet. This helps them to absorb the impact of the fall and reduce the chance of injury. So, when an ant falls from a high place, it is able to survive because it is small, has a hard exoskeleton, and can move its legs and antennae quickly to help it land safely."]

Instead, we have to rely on other clues to figure out how the Ancient Egyptians might have pronounced their words. One way we can do this is by looking at other languages that are related to Ancient Egyptian, and seeing how they pronounce their words. For example, the modern language of Coptic, which is spoken in Egypt today, is descended from Ancient Egyptian and can give us some clues about how Ancient Egyptian might have been pronounced. Another way we can learn about the pronunciation of Ancient Egyptian is by looking at how the hieroglyphics were written. Some hieroglyphics represent the sounds of words, and by looking at how these symbols are used, we can make educated guesses about how the words might have been pronounced. Overall, while we can't be completely sure about how Ancient Egyptian sounded, we can use these different methods to get a good idea of what it might have been like."]

id: How do we know humans are monogamous ? I have been wondering what actual scientific evidence we have for humans being monogamous . I keep thinking that it is just what we have always been told but is there any evidence that it is so ? Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Monogamy is a relationship pattern in which two people have a romantic and sexual relationship with only each other. There is some evidence that suggests that humans have a natural inclination towards monogamy, but it is important to note that not all humans practice monogamy and there is a wide range of relationship patterns that humans engage in.

One piece of evidence for humans being naturally monogamous is that in many cultures around the world, monogamy is the most common form of relationship. Additionally, many human societies have social and cultural norms that support monogamy as the ideal relationship pattern.

Another piece of evidence is that humans have evolved certain physical and behavioral traits that are thought to be related to monogamy. For example, humans have a long period of parental care and investment in their offspring, which may have led to the development of monogamy as a way to ensure that both parents are involved in caring for their children.

Overall, while there is some evidence to suggest that humans may have a natural inclination towards monogamy, it is important to recognize that there is a wide range of relationship patterns that humans engage in and that monogamy is not the only option.']

id: How does ADD / ADHD medicine work ? And what would happen if I ( a non - ADD person ) took some ? On a side note : what 's the difference between ADD and ADHD ? Please explain like I'm five.

id: How does Powerline networking work ? Like the Powerline Adapter Starter Kit from Amazon , it claims to gain network connectivity through your house 's power grid . How does this work and/or is this possible ? Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Powerline networking is a way to use your home's electrical wiring as a network. It allows you to connect devices to the internet or to each other by plugging them into outlets, rather than using cables or wireless signals.\\n\\nHere's how it works:\\n\\nYou plug a special adapter into an electrical outlet near your internet router. This adapter is connected to the router with a cable, and it sends data through your home's electrical wiring.\\n\\nYou plug a second adapter into an outlet in another room, where you want to connect a device like a computer or TV.\\n\\nThe two adapters communicate with each other using the electrical wiring in your home. They send data back and forth, just like how two computers can communicate over a network.\\n\\nThe device you plugged into the second adapter can now access the internet or connect to other devices on the network.\\n\\nPowerline networking is a convenient way to get internet or network access in rooms that are far from your router or don't have a good wireless signal. It's also a good option if you don't want to run cables through your walls or floors."]

id: How does a bird start a nest ? Would nât the first stick just blow away in the wind ? ELI5 : never understood how they start a nest Explain like I'm five.
text: ["Birds build their nests in a variety of different ways, depending on the species and the materials that are available to them. Some birds build their nests by collecting materials and arranging them into a structure, while others use their beaks and feet to construct a nest from scratch.\\n\\nTo start a nest, a bird will often begin by finding a suitable location. This might be a branch of a tree, a cliff face, or even a human-made structure like a roof or a window ledge. Once the bird has found a suitable location, it will begin to gather materials to use in the construction of the nest.\\n\\nThese materials might include twigs, grasses, feathers, and other materials that the bird can find in its environment. The bird will use its beak and feet to collect the materials and then arrange them into a structure that provides support and protection for the eggs and chicks.\\n\\nIt's true that the first stick or twig that a bird places in its nest might blow away in the wind, but birds are skilled at finding and using materials that are sturdy enough to withstand the elements. They may also use mud or other sticky substances to help hold the nest together and keep it from blowing away.\\n\\nSo, to answer your question, birds start a nest by finding a suitable location and then gathering and arranging materials to create a structure that provides support and protection for their eggs and chicks."]

It is important to note that downloading copyrighted material from The Pirate Bay may be illegal in some countries. Additionally, downloading files from The Pirate Bay can be risky, as the site is often used to distribute malicious software or files that are not what they claim to be. id: How does " fracking " cause earthquakes ? I keep seeing in the news of earthquakes blames on fracking , especially in Oklahoma . Is this cause / effect proven , is it a theory , and how does it happen ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ['Fracking, or hydraulic fracturing, is a process used to extract oil and natural gas from shale rock formations. It involves injecting a mixture of water, sand, and chemicals into the ground at high pressure to create small fractures, or cracks, in the rock. This allows oil and gas to flow more easily out of the rock and into the well. While fracking has been successful in increasing the supply of oil and natural gas, it has also been linked to an increase in earthquakes in some areas. These earthquakes are usually small and do not pose a significant risk to people, but they can be felt by people living nearby. The cause of these earthquakes is not fully understood, but it is thought that the injection of water and other fluids into the ground during fracking can cause the ground to shift and move, leading to earthquakes. Some scientists believe that these earthquakes may also be related to the disposal of waste water from the fracking process, which is often injected back into the ground. Overall, the relationship between fracking and earthquakes is still being studied, and more research is needed to understand the full extent of this connection.']

id: How does Shazam actually work ? I gained a decent understanding from this article : URL_0 But i 'm still not sure how it chooses where to begin in its search considering the vast size of their database . Explain like I'm five.
text:
['Shazam is an app that helps you identify songs by listening to a short clip of the song. It does this by comparing the clip to a database of songs and finding the best match. When you open the app and hold your phone near the source of the music, Shazam will listen to the song and try to identify it.

To search its database, Shazam breaks the song down into a series of "fingerprints," which are small snippets of the song that are unique to that particular song. It then compares these fingerprints to the ones in its database to find the best match.

Because the database is so large, it's able to find a match for almost any song you can think of. It's a bit like looking for a needle in a haystack, but Shazam is very good at finding the needle!']

id: How do geosynchronous orbits occur without falling to earth ? My knowledge of an orbit is an object continually falling toward earth but going fast enough to cancel out earth 's curvature . So , how can geosynchronous orbits exist without the satellite falling to earth ? Please explain like I'm five.
text: ["Geosynchronous orbits are special types of orbits that allow a satellite to stay in the same position above the Earth's surface. This is possible because the satellite is orbiting the Earth at the same speed that the Earth is spinning. Imagine you are standing on a playground merry-go-round. If you walk around the edge of the merry-go-round at the same speed that it is spinning, you will stay in the same place and not fall off. Similarly, a satellite in a geosynchronous orbit stays in the same place above the Earth because it is moving at the same speed as the Earth's rotation. Even though the satellite is not falling towards the Earth, it is still being pulled towards the Earth by the Earth's gravity. This is what keeps the satellite in orbit around the Earth. The satellite is constantly falling towards the Earth, but it is also constantly moving forward in its orbit, so it never actually hits the ground."]
